HEADLINE: The Cities And Their New Elite 

BYLINE:  By EMILY EAKIN 

 BODY:
Should Pittsburgh recruit gay people to jump-start its economy? Should Buffalo -- another fiscally flat-lining city -- give tax breaks to bohemians? As policy prescriptions go, these sound absurd. But according to a new theory devised by Richard Florida, a professor of regional economic development at Carnegie Mellon University, towns that have lots of gays and bohemians (by which he means authors, painters, musicians and other "artistically creative people") are likely to thrive.
 To understand why gays and bohemians are linked to prosperity, Mr. Florida explains, you must first understand something else: the role of an emerging economic force that he dubs the "creative class" and that civic leaders in dozens of communities regularly fork over $10,000 to hear him discuss. 
 Comprising doctors, lawyers, scientists, engineers, entrepreneurs and computer programmers -- almost everyone, in short, who is paid to think for a living -- the creative class now accounts for nearly 30 percent of the workforce, Mr. Florida writes in his new book, "The Rise of the Creative Class: And How It's Transforming Work, Leisure, Community and Everyday Life" (Basic Books). That's double what it was 20 years ago and 10 times what it was at the turn of the last century. Already the dominant economic group, he argues, the creative class is likely only to grow as what it produces -- ideas, information and technology -- becomes an ever larger part of the national economy. "Creativity has come to be valued," Mr. Florida writes, "because new technologies, new industries, new wealth and all other good economic things flow from it." 
Mr. Florida, 44, is hardly the first person to stress the importance of this new group of creative types. The sociologist Daniel Bell predicted its rise 30 years ago, and social scientists have been writing about it ever since under labels ranging from "knowledge" and "information" workers to "symbolic analysts." Two years ago, the journalist David Brooks documented the creative class's bloated bank accounts and weakness for Starbucks and S.U.V.'s in his witty best seller, "Bobos in Paradise" (Bobos being affectionate shorthand for "bourgeois bohemians").
In short, as Paul Romer, a professor of economics at Stanford University put it, there is growing recognition that when it comes to economic growth, "the relatively well educated and relatively creative are disproportionately important." 
Where Mr. Florida adds a new twist, however, is to argue that while the creative class is unquestionably a blessing to the economy as a whole, at the regional level the picture is hardly so rosy. Heralding a "pattern of geographic and class segmentation far worse than any we've ever had," he says, the creative class may mean boom times for one city and obsolescence for another. The reason, he contends, is that this tattooed and espresso-sipping set is unusually finicky. According to conventional economic theory, workers settle in those cities that offer them the highest-paying jobs in their fields. But creative-class workers, Mr. Florida says, are more particular: they choose cities for their tolerant environments and diverse populations as well as good jobs. 
This is where gays and bohemians come in. Towns that have lots of them, Mr. Florida argues, are more likely to have creative-class workers, high-tech industry and, as a result, strong economic growth. Not because there are disproportionate numbers of gays and bohemians in high-tech jobs, he explains, but because their presence signals an open-minded and varied community of the sort that appeals to software engineers and entrepreneurs. (Race, he says, turns out to be less useful as a marker of tolerance because cities with great racial diversity overall are often highly segregated.) 
This, in essence, is Mr. Florida's "creative capital theory." As he put it during a recent interview in Manhattan, "You cannot get a technologically innovative place unless it's open to weirdness, eccentricity and difference."
To make his case, Mr. Florida draws on data from the United States Census Bureau and the Bureau of Labor Statistics as well as a dizzying array of evocatively titled lists. His book includes a creative class index (ranking cities by the percentage of creative workers in their labor force); a high-tech index (ranking cities by the size of their software, electronics and engineering sectors); an innovation index (ranking cities by the number of patents per capita); a talent index (ranking cities by the percentage of college-educated people in their populations); a gay index (ranking cities by the concentration of gay couples in the population) and a bohemian index (a similar ranking of "artistically creative people"). Like Olympic decathletes, some cities tend to perform well by nearly every measure.Mr. Florida says the "most successful places" are the ones that combine all "three T's" -- tolerance, talent and technology.
Take San Francisco. Not surprisingly, perhaps, it ranks first on the high-tech index and the gay index, comes in fifth on the bohemian index and the innovation index and 12th on the creative class index. It was no accident, Mr. Florida contends, that Silicon Valley took root just a few miles away: "Silicon Valley was near San Francisco, where the geeky engineer with hair down to his waist and no shoes walks into a bar and no one blinks."
And given these scores, it's no wonder that San Francisco takes the top spot on the most important list of all: the creativity index, which ranks cities according to their overall performance and which Mr. Florida calls "a barometer of a region's longer run economic potential." 
Other cities on the creativity index are more surprising. Texas is not a state generally thought of as a bastion of tolerance or technological innovation. But three Texas cities -- Austin, Dallas and Houston -- rank among the list's top 10. (New York City placed a respectable ninth.)
Mr. Florida said even he was shocked by Texas's robust showing. "It's very impressive," he said. "My indicators are very strongly associated with employment growth, technological growth and population growth. Each of these cities has grown substantially. Austin is a growth miracle. It has a great university and has long been a lifestyle mecca for gays and bohemians. But 10 to 20 years ago, if anyone said 'Austin,' you would have said, 'Huh?' "
Most economists would agree, but that doesn't mean they buy Mr. Florida's creative capital theory as the explanation. "My view is that the best thing in terms of economic development is to invest in your centers of higher education," said Mark Zandi, chief economist at Economy.com, a company in West Chester, Pa., that tracks regional growth. "It's no surprise that Austin came up in the last 10 to 15 years. The University of Texas got all that oil money and invested it in technology." 
Moreover, he points out, Mr. Florida's theory fails to account for the extraordinary success of some non-high-tech centers like Las Vegas. More popular with gamblers and tourists than computer geeks, Las Vegas ranks a dismal 47th out of the 49 cities on the creativity index. Yet it had the fastest job and population growth of any major American city in the 1990's. 
Edward L. Glaeser, a professor of economics at Harvard, said that high numbers of skilled, creative people are clearly good for urban economies. But he was skeptical about tolerance. "I don't know that anyone has shown that tolerance is or isn't deterimental to city growth," he said. "If you wanted to predict growth in the 90's, you would look at warmth, skills and sprawl -- low-density car-driven culture." 
Despite such caveats, however, civic groups in several cities -- including Providence, R.I.; Memphis; Indianapolis; Phoenix; and Bellevue, Wash. -- have found Mr. Florida's ideas compelling enough to hire him as a consultant. 
And this spring, The Austin American-Statesman gave his theory an informal boost. Determined to find the best explanation for why the city's population doubled in the last 10 years, the newspaper asked Robert Cushing, a retired sociologist at the University of Texas in Austin, to test several academic theories: the "social capital theory" developed by the Harvard political scientist Robert D. Putnam, which says economic growth is tied to the amount of civic participation and social cohesion in a community; the "human capital theory" associated with Mr. Glaeser and the University of Chicago economist Robert E. Lucas, which says economic growth is driven by concentrations of educated people; and Mr. Florida's creative-capital theory. 
Mr. Cushing began with the social-capital theory. But using Mr. Putnam's own surveys, supplemented by census data, Mr. Cushing could find no positive connection between rates of civic participation and economic growth. "We came away with nothing," he said. "That doesn't mean there's nothing to the social-capital theory, but in terms of linking it to economic prosperity or urban growth, it was not the least bit helpful." 
Mr. Cushing went on to test the human-capital theory. But though he found an impressive correlation between a city's percentage of college-educated people and growth, he was not completely satisfied. "There are more than 100 university communities, and only 20 cities stand out as places in which it would appear that high-tech development is quite outstanding," Mr. Cushing said. "How do we explain Austin?" 
Finally, and with a good deal of doubt, he turned to Mr. Florida's theory. "When you hear about these cities that have gays or bohos, it doesn't sound scientific," he said. "It sounds gimmicky." To his surprise, the creative-capital theory turned out -- at least after preliminary testing -- to provide the best explanation for Austin's high-tech transformation. "I started the exercise very skeptical of the creative-class notion," said Mr. Cushing, whose findings are discussed in a continuing series of articles in the American-Statesman. "And was astonished by the results."

HEADLINE: An Escalating Blame Game Ensues Over the High Price of Auto Insurance 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
With costs soaring for auto insurance companies, New York is moving toward becoming the most expensive state in the country for coverage. But legislation intended to cut one of the biggest expenses -- fraudulent claims -- has stalled in Albany; adjournment of the state's Assembly is just weeks away, and the odds are rising against a compromise even as the problem worsens.
 Gov. George E. Pataki and other Republicans, Democrats, the top insurance regulator and the insurance companies themselves agree that new laws are needed to plug holes in the state's no-fault auto insurance system, which requires insurers to pay the first $50,000 in medical bills from injuries in an accident, no matter who is at fault. But the different players accuse one another of blocking a solution. 
 Some Democrats and consumer advocates say the insurers have not done enough themselves to address fraud, and have merely tried to pass on rising expenses to drivers while bolstering profits. 
The Democrats say they see no sign of compromise on the part of either Mr. Pataki or the Republicans in the Legislature. "There's been no effort by the administration whatsoever to bring the parties together on a legislative reform package," said Alexander B. Pete Grannis, the Manhattan Democrat and chairman of the Assembly Insurance Committee.
Some insurers and Republicans suggest that Democrats are blocking legislation to address the problem in hopes that the rising cost of auto insurance will become an issue they can use against Mr. Pataki, who is running for re-election this fall.
"It boils down to politics," said Robert P. Hartwig, the chief economist at the Insurance Information Institute, a trade group in Manhattan. "The Democrats control the Assembly and there's not a lot of incentive for them to make Pataki's life easier."
What most divides the sides is the Democrats' desire to have a consumer advocate in the State Insurance Department and to freeze rates and commit to a rate-reduction target. 
In the last year, several insurers, including Allstate, the leading company in New York, have raised rates an average of 10 to 15 percent. The insurers are also refusing to insure drivers they regard as likely to cost them money by filing an accident claim, a policy that forces tens of thousands of drivers to get mandatory coverage from the much more expensive state-run pool of last resort.
Black and Hispanic legislators charge that a preponderance of those rejected for standard coverage are minorities. The insurers concede that most drivers in the pool come from the most densely populated parts of the state, but they say their decisions on coverage are color blind. 
Political surveys suggest the issue has not become a major concern for most New Yorkers. Indeed, some drivers, like Dr. Jonathan Epstein, an emergency medical specialist in Manhattan, seem to be taking the price increases with a shrug. "If it goes up," he said, "there's very little I can do about it. I have to have a car and I have to have insurance."
But Abby Scala, an account executive at Kay Insurance Associates, one of the biggest brokers for auto and home insurance in metropolitan New York, said lots of other customers are beginning to rebel.
"My phone hasn't been this busy in 25 years," she said. "Almost everyone is calling when they get their renewal notices, asking us to shop around for better prices."
Most customers, she said, do not see auto insurance as a political problem, however. "They blame the insurance companies," she said. "They don't even think about the Legislature or the governor." 
Just across the Hudson River, prices in New Jersey have been the highest in the country for several years and have been a big factor in recent gubernatorial elections. The latest data from the National Association of Insurance Commissioners, an umbrella group of state regulators, put the average annual cost of insuring a car in New Jersey at $1,034 in 1999, $91 more than in New York and $351 more than the national average.
But Mr. Hartwig said that with prices declining in New Jersey as they are rising in New York, New York is likely soon to take the title of most expensive state. It may already have done so, he said; the statistics run two years behind the calendar, with the next report, for calendar year 2000, expected in mid- to late June.
Those figures will probably show New Jersey still in the lead because fraud costs were not significantly reflected in coverage prices in New York until 2001, Mr. Hartwig said. He estimated the average cost of insuring a car in New York in 2001 was $1,080, or $100 more than in New Jersey. But that is not official. And the headlines that come with becoming No. 1 may make a big difference politically.
There is nearly universal agreement on a need for stiffer criminal penalties for cheating on auto insurance claims and on giving insurers more time to investigate suspicions of fraud before paying claims. Such measures, officials and insurers say, could cut losses by up to $1 billion a year in New York. 
But the Republicans strongly oppose a proposal by Mr. Grannis to freeze rate increases for 18 months and then cut prices by up to 17 percent. They also say his proposal to establish a consumer advocate for insurance would merely create another layer of bureaucracy.
Gregory V. Serio, Mr. Pataki's top insurance regulator, and Republican legislators are against enacting rate-cutting provisions until there is evidence of savings. Mr. Serio faulted Mr. Grannis' proposed laws for not being as tough as those advocated by the governor and the Senate.
Even with the recent increases, Mr. Serio said, rates, in many cases, are not high enough to offset the insurers' losses. "A lot of companies are already in a position of rate inadequacy," he said. He said he worried that if companies were not making money, they would leave the state, as some have done in New Jersey. "We want to make sure we can keep the insurance companies in the market," he said, "but also bring some real rate relief to the public."
Mr. Grannis stressed that his rate cut would not be automatic. But he said the burden would be on the insurers to show why they should not reduce their rates.
"If we take $1 billion out of the cost," he said, "there clearly has to be a reduction for drivers, unless the company decides to pocket the difference, which is my worry."
Arguing for a consumer advocate, Mr. Grannis said New York regulators have tended to favor insurers over insurance customers.
Mr. Serio insisted that the Insurance Department, which is widely respected for its technical expertise, had never pulled its punches with the insurers. "Ask any insurance company," he said, "and they will tell you we don't rubber-stamp rates." 
But critics say Mr. Serio's office faces conflicting interests. "The Insurance Department has to wear two hats," said Russ Haven, legislative counsel for the New York Public Interest Research Group. "And that's always difficult. On one hand they have to look after the safety and solvency of the New York insurance industry. On the other hand they're supposed to protect New York drivers."

HEADLINE: Many Relatives, Wary and Anguished, Shun Sept. 11 Fund 

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
Nearly six months after the federal government opened its checkbook to the relatives of the 3,200 people killed or seriously injured on Sept. 11, fewer than 10 families have filed completed applications, illustrating the complex nature of the process, the anguish or wariness some families still have about settling a victim's financial affairs and lingering concerns about the government fund's fairness.
 In all, about 500 families have filed partial claims with the government's Victim Compensation Fund, many of which need to be verified or lack crucial information from employers and other sources. But even that figure has been smaller than expected, disappointing some supporters of the fund and surprising detractors, too. 
 Of those who have not filed, some say that they are not emotionally ready to translate personal devastation into actuarial calculations. Many say that the application form for death benefits, more than 30 pages long, is so complicated that it requires an armada of outside experts to complete. And some are waiting, anxiously, for other families to wade first into a multibillion dollar fund that has no precedent. 
"It's been slow because it's a new process, it's unfamiliar territory, and people are perplexed," said Kenneth R. Feinberg, the special master overseeing the fund. "But I'm using every device I know to ease the concern of people in grief. I tell them, 'You should file now, because you'll get your money sooner.' "
But the slow pace of applications is also heightening concerns that many families may reject the plan and choose to file lawsuits instead.
When Congress hastily passed legislation in September to create the fund as part of an airline bailout package, officials hailed the plan as a fast and straightforward alternative that would ease the trauma of thousands of families. In exchange for waiving their right to sue -- which some lawyers believe could be a protracted and even risky option -- families have been promised an average payment of about $1.5 million, within four months of their filing.
Now, however, as families grapple with the financial and legal minutiae associated with death, many are finding the fund to be opaque and overwhelming, confusing on one day and comforting the next. They also sense that the fund is a malleable work in progress, responsive to public pressure and subject to frequent clarifications.
Indeed, the House passed legislation last week that would make the American victims of the United States Embassies bombings in Africa in 1998 eligible for payments from the fund. Some senators are also seeking to include the victims of the 1993 World Trade Center bombing and the 1995 Oklahoma City bombing, prompting speculation that the fund may become an entitlement program for all terrorism victims.
For the Sept. 11 cases, the deadline for filing a claim is still far off: December 2003. And despite the slow start, Mr. Feinberg predicts that 90 percent of the families will eventually sign up. Even so, he has redoubled his efforts in recent weeks to promote the fund by establishing more outreach offices and traveling to Los Angeles and San Francisco to meet with victims' families there.
"It's all part of an effort to ease the access of the claimant to a very unique program, which is unprecedented in history," Mr. Feinberg said. "We'll try to make it efficient and reasonable."
In December, Mr. Feinberg issued draft regulations detailing the mechanics of the fund. But after many families and officials criticized the regulations as stingy, Mr. Feinberg made significant changes in the final regulations, which were issued in March, to increase the payments.
Families of deceased victims can expect a minimum of $250,000 for anguish and loss, and thousands, if not millions, more for economic losses. The fund is expected to award $1.85 million to each family, though deductions from that amount for insurance payments, pensions and other government benefits should leave a net average, Mr. Feinberg predicted, of $1.5 million.
Over all, the fund is expected to cost taxpayers about $4 billion. But given the subjective nature of the fund, and the enormous discretion Mr. Feinberg has to evaluate claims case by case, many families want to see how he handles the first few cases -- and whether he amends the rules along the way.
"I knew from the beginning it would be a waiting game," said Stephen Push, whose wife, Lisa J. Raines, was aboard the plane that flew into the Pentagon. "I suspect that because Feinberg is worried that not a lot of people are signing up for the fund, he's going to make an effort to finesse some issues through his discretion."
When Mr. Feinberg announced his final rules on March 7, 366 claims had been recorded. Since then, there have only been about 130 more, or less than two a day, at a pace that essentially has not changed.
Of the 500 claims to date, about a third are from people who were injured. About 37 percent of the claimants, both survivors and injured victims, have signed up to receive advances of up to $50,000.
Fewer than 10 people have filed completed applications. They will probably be notified next week that the clock has started on their claims: a tentative award to be decided within 45 days, then the option of appealing that award at a hearing.
What may be more significant, though, is what Mr. Feinberg does with a dozen or so test cases that are expected to be filed in two or three weeks. The cases range from low-income families with extenuating personal circumstances to middle-class relatives of rescue workers whose awards would be slashed by generous pension plans to high-income earners whose pay far exceeded the $231,000-a-year cap that Mr. Feinberg has said he will use when calculating economic losses.
"The reason that people are not running to the fund," said Michel F. Baumeister, a Manhattan lawyer who represents more than 50 families, "is that they don't trust it will be fair."
Those who have filed claims have done so primarily because they want to end the process quickly, for intensely personal reasons.
Gwyn Adams, of Houston, lost her oldest son, Shannon, who worked at Cantor Fitzgerald. He was 25, and single, with no dependents. He was renting an apartment with two friends in Astoria, Queens, and was earning $52,000 a year. According to Mr. Feinberg's computations, his survivors would receive $1 million.
To Ms. Adams, the idea of haggling with the fund over the worth of her son's life was unsettling. She found a lawyer in New York, Roberta G. Gordon, who handled her claim without charge. Three weeks ago, she traveled to New York to complete the application in what turned out to be a marathon 11-hour meeting capped by a sobering trip to ground zero.
"I was dealing with all the paperwork, and I couldn't emotionally bury him until I had this done," she said. "That was my way to say goodbye."
Those who haven't filed are still weighing everything from which family member should file the claim to whether to sue the airlines whose plans were hijacked -- as a handful have done, so far.
One victim who has filed a lawsuit, Ellen Mariani, of Derry, N.H., said she found the concept of the fund offensive.
"I think it's a shut-up fund," said Ms. Mariani, whose husband, Neil, was aboard United Airlines Flight 175, which was flown into the World Trade Center. "As far as I'm concerned, they want to get this over with and done and under the rug, but that is not justice."
At the very least, many relatives say that they have been overwhelmed by the level of detail regarding taxes, insurance benefits, workers' compensation and more. For assistance, some families are turning to Trial Lawyers Care, a program established by the Association of Trial Lawyers of America to provide free legal representation to victims, or to aviation-disaster specialists like Kreindler & Kreindler, a law firm that is charging a 10 percent commission for representing claimants.
Some families are also recruiting economists, forensic psychologists and other experts.
"It's very complicated, and I couldn't figure it out," said Cella Woo, an accountant, whose husband, Elkin Yuen, was a broker at Carr Futures.
Indeed, many families, still overcome by raw emotion, say it is much more prudent to watch the fund evolve than to make a claim now. Last week, in fact, Gov. George E. Pataki signed legislation related to the fund that would, among other provisions, prevent insurance companies from cutting off workers' compensation benefits and exempt the awards from state and local taxes.
But until families feel confident that the fund is worth their toil, few see any incentive for acting anytime soon.
"The fund is like a big rhinoceros," said James P. Kreindler, whose law firm represents more than 170 families. "It's very hard to get moving, and the reason why is fear and confusion. But once it gets moving, it'll have a full head of steam."

HEADLINE: Top Democrat For Governor Of Hawaii Withdraws 

BYLINE:  By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

DATELINE: HONOLULU, May 31 

 BODY:
Democratic hopes for extending a 40-year grip on the Hawaii governor's office have been dealt a major setback.
 The party's leading candidate in this year's contest, Mayor Jeremy Harris of Honolulu, unexpectedly pulled out late on Thursday, saying that "a year of bad publicity," including unsubstantiated accusations of corruption, had cost him at least 30 points in the polls. 
 "I simply don't believe the race is winnable," he added. "But I do believe this is one of the most important races in the history of the state." 
His departure left stunned Democrats scrambling to find another candidate, and it gave a boost to the leading Republican contender, Linda Lingle, a former mayor of Maui. Four years ago, she came within 5,000 votes of denying a second term to Gov. Benjamin J. Cayetano, who cannot run again because of term limits.
"I'm still the underdog because I'm a Republican," Ms. Lingle said upon learning of Mr. Harris's withdrawal.
For the short term at least, it appeared that the state's lieutenant governor, Mazie Hirono, would be anointed the top Democratic candidate, based on name recognition if nothing else. Ms. Hirono was briefly a candidate last year, but when polls indicated she could not win she dropped out to run for mayor of Honolulu. On Thursday, 30 minutes after Mr. Harris pulled out, she jumped back in. 
Hawaii is perhaps the most Democratic state. Not only has the governor's office been in Democratic hands for 40 years, but both houses of the Legislature are controlled by Democrats and all four members of the Congressional delegation are Democrats, as are all members of the governor's cabinet.
Now, as Mr. Harris's sudden departure demonstrates, Democrats are in disarray. They face accusations that they have mismanaged the state's economy, ignored the needs of its schools, padded the bureaucracy and turned a blind eye to corruption. In recent years, as more and more independents have moved into the state and island customs have begun to break down, fractures have begun to show in the Democratic base, a once-solid bloc of Japanese-Americans, government employees and unionized workers.
Mr. Harris was struggling to hold onto the labor vote, having squabbled with unions over budget cuts and salaries. But his most serious problem was what he referred to as "bad publicity."
Accusations of corruption are an old story in Hawaii politics. But it was Mr. Harris's lot to have the headlines, mainly involving the jailing of Honolulu employees and officials, appear just as he was beginning his campaign for governor.
His name came up directly only once, when an investigation was begun to determine whether workers in his 1996 and 2000 campaigns for mayor had mishandled funds. He denied any wrongdoing and contended that the investigation was politically motivated. 
Mr. Harris said on Thursday that he had been hurt by a politically motivated lawsuit that caused him to suspend campaigning for two months early this year while it was being tried. The suit contended that under Hawaii law, a mayor must resign from office to run for another elective job in the state. The State Supreme Court held that since Mr. Harris was not officially a candidate at the time the suit was filed, the law did not apply. 
Corruption was an issue in the 1998 governor's race. Ms. Lingle said Mr. Cayetano had done nothing to rid government of dishonest officials. In the next breath she would accuse him of allowing the economic boom of the 1990's to bypass Hawaii. Four years later she is hammering the same themes, arguing that corruption and government inefficiency are worse than ever.
"Change is in the air, and this time around I'm going to win," she declared on Wednesday shortly after filing papers to run, a formality since she has been campaigning almost since the results of the last race were posted.
She has also spent much of the past four years serving as the state's Republican chairwoman, working hard to increase the party's numbers in the Legislature. There are now 20 Republicans in the 51-seat House, a gain of 8 during that period, and 3 Republicans in the 25-seat Senate, a gain of 1.
"I'm almost willing to bet that as the next governor I'll have at least one house of our Legislature to work with that's under Republican control," she said.
Dan Boylan, a University of Hawaii professor who analyzes the state's politics, said he believed that this year's election represented the "absolute best" opportunity Republicans have had to capture the governor's office since 1958, the year they last won it. "But keep in mind," he said, "that the demise of the Democrats, at last and finally, has been predicted many times before."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Procter Is Suing Coca-Cola On Calcium Drinks Patent
Procter & Gamble, the consumer products giant, filed a lawsuit against the Coca-Cola Company, asserting that Coke's Minute Maid division had violated Procter's patent for adding calcium to fruit drinks. Procter is seeking an injunction and unspecified damages.
 Relations between Procter and Coca-Cola have deteriorated of late, analysts said. The two companies broke off a planned joint venture last fall. Page C2. 

Wall St. Ends Week on Downside
A rally died on Wall Street. The Nasdaq composite index fell 16.19 points, or 1 percent, to 1,615.73. The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 13.56 points, to 9,925.25. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index advanced 2.48 points, to 1,067.14. For the holiday-shortened week, the Nasdaq fell 2.8 percent, the Dow dropped 1.8 percent and the S.& P. lost 1.5 percent. C4.

Study Used by Pharmacia Criticized
An editorial in the June 1 issue of the British Medical Journal harshly criticizes a scientific study that Pharmacia used to promote Celebrex, its best-selling arthritis drug. A12.

Sulzer Medica agreed to pay $1 billion to settle lawsuits by American patients over faulty hip and knee implants. C3.

Court Overturns Internet Filter Law
A federal appeals court struck down a law yesterday requiring libraries to filter the Internet for material harmful to minors, saying that the technology blocks so much unobjectionable material that it would violate the First Amendment rights of library patrons. A1.

Adelphia Deal to Shed Units Unlikely
It seems increasingly unlikely that Adelphia Communications and the entrepreneur Paul Allen will cement a deal for some of Adelphia's cable systems. Negotiations continue, however, despite objections of one of Adelphia's largest shareholders. C2.

Terror Threat Leads to Loan Review
A leading bond-rating agency said it was reviewing its ratings on $5 billion in loans on about a dozen big commercial buildings and groups of buildings, another indication of financial concerns about the threat of terrorist attacks in New York and other cities. C2.

Reports Point to Sound Recovery
Four reports demonstrated the start of a sound recovery. Manufacturing in the Midwest jumped to a three-year high in May, an industry group said. The government said that orders for manufactured items in April gained 1.2 percent, their biggest rise since October 2001, and that productivity rose 8.4 percent in the first quarter. A report from the University of Michigan showed consumer sentiment rose in May to its highest level in a year and a half. C4.

Power Concerns Deny 'Wash Trades'
Many of the biggest power traders, including Dynegy, Mirant and PPL, filed documents with the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission denying use of so-called wash trades to inflate electricity volumes and revenue during the California energy crisis. C2.

AT&T to Sell Shares to Meet Debts
AT&T plans to meet a looming cash obligation by selling new equity worth $2.25 billion. The equity offering, expected to be priced next week, will be used to satisfy a 1999 agreement to acquire 69 percent of AT&T Canada, the part of the company AT&T does not already own, by June 2003, AT&T said. C4.

Chicago Teamster Leader Expelled
The longtime leader of the Teamsters in Chicago, William T. Hogan Jr., has been expelled from the union by an independent oversight board, which found that he had betrayed the union's interests. A11.

HEADLINE: A Changed Debate on Smoking Restrictions 

BYLINE:  By SHAILA K. DEWAN

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 31 

 BODY:
The State Senate plans to vote for the first time on a law that would ban smoking in restaurants statewide, except in bar areas and separately ventilated smoking rooms, said John McArdle, a spokesman for the Senate Republican majority.
 The bill that reaches the Senate floor, however, may be less strict than a measure the Assembly passed this week. Some Republicans have raised concerns about how much business owners would have to spend to comply with new regulations. 
 Tobacco lobbyists have been working behind the scenes to kill the bill, and the Empire State Restaurant and Tavern Association is seeking amendments that would weaken the bill considerably. 
Yet at a time when smoking restrictions have become commonplace throughout the country, even tobacco lobbyists say that the new bill, called the Clean Indoor Air Act, is far short of radical. Already, more than 70 percent of New Yorkers live and dine under more restrictive local laws than the current state law, which requires nonsmoking sections in dining rooms and applies only to restaurants with more than 50 seats. 
The bill is intended to protect the state's thousands of restaurant workers from prolonged exposure to secondhand smoke, which the Environmental Protection Agency considers a Class A carcinogen, said the bill's Democratic champion, Assemblyman Alexander B. Grannis.
The nature of the debate over smoking rules has changed significantly since the last big fight, when New York City passed its law in 1994. Philip Morris threatened to move its headquarters out of Manhattan. Scott Wexler, the head of the Empire State Restaurant and Tavern Association, predicted that restaurant business in New York City would drop by 25 percent. It did not, and many of the economic arguments against such laws have melted away, Mr. Grannis said. "Clearly the validity of the doom-and-gloom, anti-business stuff -- no one makes that argument any more," he said.
"The big difference has been the fact that the public now knows about the way the industry operates," said Blair Horner, the legislative director of the New York Public Interest Research Group, which supports the bill. "They're reduced to being able to block things through sheer political power now, because they don't even have any arguments."
But to a degree, tobacco companies have succeeded at framing the debate as one of hardship to small businesses. A senior aide to Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader, pointed to a provision that would require, for example, a partition or six feet of space separating the bar from the dining room. 
The bill's supporters, including the American Cancer Society, the American Lung Association and the Medical Society of the State of New York, are scrambling to keep attention on public health. They are quick to point out that a restaurant owner could avoid the expense of installing partitions or ventilation systems by simply banning smoking altogether. "Our attitude is that this bill is already a significant compromise from what the standard should be," said Russell Sciandra, director of the Center for a Tobacco Free New York.
The bill's lead sponsor, Senator Charles J. Fuschillo Jr., said, "I feel very confident and satisfied with the bill in its current form," adding that restaurants could seek hardship waivers. 
But if the tobacco industry has lost the battle to convince the public that secondhand smoke is not a big concern, it has not abandoned its quest for influence. Since a lobbying scandal in Albany weakened the tobacco industry's power, some Democratic committees have refused to take money from tobacco companies. But the Republican Party and Republican committees received $50,000 from Philip Morris alone from May to September 2001, according to an analysis by Common Cause/New York, a citizens' lobbying group. 
Gov. George E. Pataki has not taken a position on the bill. Dr. Antonia C. Novello, the state health commissioner, has said regulating smoking is best left to local governments.
But there are other signs that the bill is gathering support. The fact that Senator Kemp Hannon, chairman of the Health Committee, allowed the bill to pass his committee was taken as a sign that he had gotten a green light from Mr. Bruno. 
At a hearing last week held by Senators Fuschillo and Hannon, the bill's co-sponsors, no tobacco company representatives took the microphone. Mr. Wexler, who says the restaurant and tavern association no longer receives money from tobacco companies, testified that he would simply suggest ways "to make the new law more workable for restaurant owners," including allowing a ventilated smoking area in the same room as nonsmokers. The bill's supporters termed his proposals "poison pills" that would weaken the bill to the point of ineffectiveness.

HEADLINE: Zimbabwe Acts to Obtain AIDS Drugs At Low Prices 

BYLINE:  By HENRI E. CAUVIN 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, May 31 

 BODY:
Desperate for cheaper AIDS treatments, Zimbabwe has declared its H.I.V. epidemic a national emergency, a move that allows it to sidestep patents on essential drugs and import generic substitutes.
 Advocates and experts say they believe that Zimbabwe is the first country to use international trade regulations devised to cut the costs of antiretroviral drugs for AIDS. 
 Zimbabwe has one of the highest rates of infection with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. The government's action may encourage other poor countries to follow suit, particularly in Africa, where most H.I.V.-positive people live, the advocates say. 
 Wary of antagonizing pharmaceutical companies and confusing international investors, many African countries have been reluctant to take advantage of the trade rules.
 The World Trade Organization's meeting last November in Qatar emboldened developing countries, demystifying the organization's Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights. Countries were told that they could decide for themselves what constituted a national emergency.
 At least 25 percent of Zimbabwe's adults are infected with the virus, so its need is acute. And with its international image sullied by two years of political turmoil, it had little to lose in declaring an emergency.
 Dr. David Parirenyatwa, the deputy health minister, said in a telephone interview that the country was committed to complying with its international trade obligations and wanted to work within the intellectual property agreement.
 The prices of patented drugs have moved them further and further out of reach of the public health system, Dr. Parirenyatwa said, even as the effects of the epidemic have made treatment an imperative. 
 "What we've found," he said, "is if we don't treat, we create more orphans, because the parents die and those who are working are less efficient because they are sick."
Last month Zimbabwe was awarded almost $23 million over the next two years from the new Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria, and Dr. Parirenyatwa said
 antiretroviral drugs like AZT and Combivir would be among the needs the money would be spent on.
 GlaxoSmithKline, the British pharmaceutical giant, manufactures AZT, Combivir and at least three of the eight other AIDS drugs under patent in Zimbabwe, according to the Consumer Project on Technology, a Washington advocacy group.
 A spokeswoman said that Zimbabwe had been offered the company's lowest price for its AIDS drugs, but that she could not say whether any drugs had been sold at that price.
 But even the marked-down price can still be far out of reach for poor countries. Ellen 't Hoen, of Doctors Without Borders, said that the world was starting to realize the stark limitations faced by many such countries -- and that the countries were starting to realize that though poor, they are not powerless.

HEADLINE: Despite Protest, Moody's Cuts Japan Rating 

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON 

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 31 

 BODY:
Alarmed by Japan's climbing debt load, Moody's Investors Service lowered the nation's credit rating by two notches today.
 The move affected the rating on government and government-guaranteed bonds issued in local currency. At the new rating of A2, down from Aa3, bonds from Japan, the world's second-largest national economy after the United States, are now considered as risky as those of Cyprus, Latvia, Poland or Mauritius. 
 The Finance Ministry has been publicly battling with the main credit-rating agencies -- Moody's, Standard & Poor's and Fitch -- since late April, when Moody's said it was considering a two-notch downgrade. The vice minister of finance, Haruhiko Kuroda, responded by assailing the three as ignoring Japanese financial strengths, including the world's largest pools of savings and foreign-exchange reserves.
The government's tone has sometimes been shrill enough to suggest that lawmakers are more concerned with national prestige than with finances. Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi, for example, has wondered aloud why Japan should be rated the same as some countries that it provides with aid.
But Moody's and many private economists say Japan's leaders are not doing enough to address the country's mounting problems. Moody's cited government indebtedness that is rising to "levels unprecedented in the postwar era in the developed world."
The national debt is expected to reach 139 percent of the gross domestic product this year, which would be more than twice the level in the United States. The country's banks have their own crippling debt problems, the pension system is grossly underfinanced, and the population is aging faster than any other.
Experts say the government's responses to these phenomena -- a cap on new bond issues; some spending cuts; talk of tax, pension and health care changes -- are too timid. But the finance minister, Masajuro Shiokawa, told reporters that "we won't be changing policy because of the downgrade."
Moody's acknowledged that the chances of a major bond crisis were remote, because domestic investors hold nearly 95 percent of the nation's debt. The cost of servicing all that debt is falling because the Bank of Japan has set short-term interest rates effectively at zero, and new low-rate bonds are gradually replacing older ones at higher rates. The central bank has also agreed to buy many new bonds itself.
Still, Japan's economy is not growing fast enough to generate the tax revenue needed to pay down the debt significantly. And the banking system's problems are being aggravated by deflation. 
"The banking problem is too complex for the government to think about," said Kazuhiko Ogata of HSBC Securities in Tokyo. "If the government is forced to pump more taxpayer money into the banks, politicians will have to take responsibility for their actions -- something they are unwilling to do."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares End Week Mixed on Worries Over World Events

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Pleased by encouraging economic reports but wary about world events going into a weekend, Wall Street backed away from a solid rally yesterday, leaving stocks mixed.
 Blue chips closed higher although they retreated from an earlier triple-digit advance. Technology gave back all its gains, turning negative. 
 The market's earlier gain was the first sign of life after a weeklong decline caused by a string of discouraging corporate earning reports. But analysts were not surprised by the pullback, with investors worried about the possibility of terror attacks and the conflict between India and Pakistan.
"It's end-of-the-week jitters," said Arthur Hogan, chief market analyst at Jefferies & Company. "There are enough things to worry about in the world that could go wrong." 
The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 13.56 points, or 0.1 percent, to 9,925.25, having gained as much as 130.36 points earlier. The advance broke the Dow's four-session 304-point losing streak.
The broader market was mixed. The Nasdaq composite index fell 16.19 points, or almost 1 percent, to 1,615.73, having climbed as much as 19.55 points earlier. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index advanced 2.48 points, or 0.2 percent, to 1,067.14.
The market was encouraged by positive economic news -- healthy business activity in the Chicago area, a jump in worker productivity and an uptick in consumer sentiment -- but caution crept back into trading as the session wore on.
Among the gainers, Home Depot rose $1.54, to $41.69; Procter & Gamble climbed 80 cents, to $89.55; and UPS advanced $1.38, to $60.38, after Bear, Stearns raised its rating on the stock to buy from neutral.
But technology pulled back, with Microsoft falling $1.73, to $50.91, and Oracle declining 50 cents, to $7.92.
Analysts have been skeptical about the sustainability of any gains, especially as companies start issuing earnings warnings during the next month and also make predictions for the second half of 2002.
"There is a lot of news to come," said Barry Berman, head trader for Robert Baird & Company in Milwaukee. "The market is going to be very volatile to economic data for a while." 
Losers included companies that issued weaker-than-expected outlooks or earnings. Lowe's stumbled 73 cents, to $47.16, after projecting 2002 earnings below analysts' expectations.
Palm fell 62 cents, to $1.59, after announcing that revenue for the fourth quarter will miss expectations and keep it from posting a profit.
Advancing issues outnumbered decliners 5 to 3 on the New York Stock Exchange. Volume was light at 1.23 billion shares, up marginally from 1.22 billion Thursday. --------------------

Treasury Prices Drop
By Bloomberg News
Treasuries posted their biggest decline in two weeks yesterday after an index of Chicago-area manufacturing rose more than expected in May, adding to evidence an economic recovery is under way.
By late in the day, the 10-year note lost 5/32 , to a price of 98 23/32 . The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.04 percent from 5.02 percent on Thursday.
The 30-year bond dropped as well, off 10/32 , to 9619/32 . Its yield increased to 5.62 percent from 5.59 percent.

HEADLINE: Moody's Sees Risks in Threats to Landmarks 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
In another indication of financial concerns about the threat of terrorist attacks in New York and other cities, a leading bond-rating agency said yesterday that it was reviewing its ratings on $5 billion in loans on about a dozen big commercial buildings and groups of buildings, including the Rockefeller Center complex.
 Most of the buildings are in Manhattan, like the Conde Nast building at 4 Times Square. But also among them are the Columbia Center, the tallest building in Seattle, and the Sun America tower in Los Angeles. 
 The agency, Moody's Investors Service, said it regarded the buildings as potential targets and wanted to make sure they were sufficiently insured to protect lenders.
"There are a lot of people running around saying they have terrorism insurance," said Tad Philipp, a managing director at Moody's. "In some cases it is adequate; in other cases it's not."
Moody's did not provide details of coverage on individual buildings. But it said that in the reviews over the next few weeks those with inadequate coverage would have to either buy more insurance or face the likelihood of a downgrade in their loan ratings.
A downgrade would have immediate financial consequences. A lower rating, reflecting greater risk, would reduce the price of bonds. It would also require some pension funds and other institutional investors to sell their bonds, regardless of market conditions, if the ratings dipped below the minimum grade required by their investment standards.
Moody's said it was not suggesting that the buildings on its list were in imminent danger. "They are riskier than they were at the time they were originally rated," Mr. Philipp said. "Basically, they have a small chance of an event. But there would be fairly drastic consequences if an event occurs."
Before the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, coverage against terrorism was included at no extra charge in most commercial insurance policies. After the attacks, the insurance companies withdrew the coverage. Some have gradually agreed to provide the coverage, but at much higher costs than for standard coverage. Brokers say up to $1 billion in coverage for a single building is now available. But many property owners have decided to save money and not buy the coverage. The decision by Moody's is expected to force them to reconsider.
Bankers, real estate companies, insurers and others in the financial services business have been urging Congress to provide for federal payment of most losses in the event of another terrorist attack. Though the House adopted a terrorism insurance bill late last year, the Senate has been unable to agree on the issue.
"If Congress were to come up with a backstop to make insurance more available, that would have a major positive effect," said Daniel B. Rubock, a vice president at Moody's.
Members of Congress have hesitated to act because economic disruptions have generally not been as severe as predicted. Steve Bartlett, the chief executive of the Financial Roundtable in Washington, an association of big banks, insurers and securities companies, said Moody's action was "a huge vote in favor" of federal assistance.
"This is further evidence that there is a huge problem," Mr. Bartlett said.

HEADLINE: Signs of Vigor For Recovery In 4 Reports On Economy 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 31 

 BODY:
Manufacturing, which suffered the most in last year's recession, is on a firmer footing, reports showed today, and combined with sharp productivity gains and soaring consumer confidence, demonstrate the start of a sound recovery.
 "Overall, the numbers suggest that the recovery really is taking hold in the second quarter," said Lou Crandall, chief economist at Wrightson Associates. 
 Four reports helped to reinforce views, flagging in recent days, that the Federal Reserve might raise rates in August. The Fed is next due to discuss interest rates on June 25. 
Manufacturing in the Midwest jumped to a three-year high in May, according to the National Association of Purchasing Management-Chicago. Its index surged to 60.8, the highest since April 1999. Last month the index came in at 54.7.
May was the fourth consecutive month with a reading above 50, which points to an expanding regional manufacturing economy.
"The recovery in the manufacturing sector means that the weakest part of the U.S. economy is now on the mend," said Mark Vitner, senior economist at Wachovia Securities.
The Commerce Department said orders for manufactured items in April posted their biggest rise since October 2001, gaining a larger-than-expected 1.2 percent, to $323.87 billion. Orders for machinery rose 4.5 percent, the most since March 2000, while orders for electrical equipment and appliances were up 9.6 percent. Demand for computer and electronic products was up 3 percent.
"The third cylinder of the economic engine -- capital spending -- has really begun to fire, and this is a signal of improving business confidence," said Sung Won Sohn, chief economist at Wells Fargo.
There was other good news for the economy. A Labor Department report showed that productivity rocketed ahead in the first quarter, rising 8.4 percent as profit-seeking American businesses squeezed more out of their workers. This met expectations even though it was slightly below the previously reported 8.6 percent rise.
Consumers, too, are doing their bit for the recovery. Sentiment rose in May to its highest level in a year and a half. The University of Michigan's final May consumer-sentiment index rose to 96.9 from 93 in April, market subscribers said, beating expectations and slightly above the preliminary reading of 96 released two weeks ago.
"The fundamentals for consumer spending are pretty healthy," Mr. Sohn said, "so consumer spending will be another economic stabilizer."

HEADLINE: Pollyanna Meets Cassandra 

BYLINE:  By BILL KELLER; E-mail: billkeller@nytimes.com

 BODY:
Now that we've all had a good laugh at the spectacle of our fastidious treasury secretary touring African misery with a middle-aged rock star, now that we've snorted at Paul O'Neill and Bono in matching Ghanaian robes and tortured all the obvious U2 lyrics, it's time to ask whether anything is going on here besides soliciting MTV votes for the Republican Party.
 Before I try to answer that, a caveat. Whenever I set out to write something hopeful about the current administration, I hear a cynical voice whispering "Sucker!" in my ear. And on the subject of compassion, President Bush has more than the usual burden of proof. You don't need Ralph Nader to tell you this is an administration that has methodically exalted corporate power and fortified the obscene gap between America's rich and poor. So my credulity alarm tingles at the idea that the administration cares about the far more remote and powerless poor of Africa. 
 And yet, something interesting seems to be happening. Something we've seen before. 
In the early 90's an improbable consensus came together on the issue of America's own poorest citizens. After a period of fatalism that hit bottom with Charles Murray's classic indictment of welfare, "Losing Ground," some conservatives shook off the deep pessimism that had become an excuse for doing nothing and began asking what would work. Some liberals, in turn, took off their blinders about the failings of welfare. Bill Clinton brought forth a tough-minded law pushing welfare recipients into jobs.
Whatever you think of those welfare-to-work reforms, and most experts agree they did far more good than harm, that hard compromise changed the politics of poverty. As Jason DeParle, who covered all this for The Times, points out, the compromise created a belief that progress was possible, and thus took much of the poison out of the poverty debate. Suddenly there were serious, competing visions of how to help the poor -- and a shared assumption that this was actually a worthwhile thing to do.
Is something similar happening to our attitude toward the rest of the world's poor? Can we do for Congo what we did for Milwaukee?
On one side you have (to oversimplify a bit) the conservative Cassandras, defeatists, moral scolds and free-market zealots who believe that until poor countries get a grip on their own bootstraps, any amount of foreign aid will be money wasted. This idea flowered in the Reagan/Thatcher years, and led the major development lenders to a policy of "structural adjustment": If you want loans, shrink your government, cut your deficits and tighten your belts. And as for those people dying of AIDS and malaria -- not our problem. This approach was not only heartless but mindless; countries being eaten alive by disease, hunger and regional warfare were bad candidates for tough love. Their failures, of course, simply confirmed the pointlessness of aid. American donations shriveled, and not just under Republicans. During the Clinton years, our meager contribution to the world's poor dropped by nearly half. Nowadays your annual share of our aid to the 40 most pitiful countries is about the price of a fancy coffee and a pastry at Starbucks.
If there is a Charles Murray of this debate it is William Easterly, an apostate World Bank economist who wrote an authoritative book last year outlining the failure of foreign aid to generate economic growth. His skepticism has helped stimulate some conservatives to look for new ways up from despair.
On the other side you have (again, to oversimplify) the liberal Pollyannas, populists and romantics who regard aid as a simple humanitarian obligation, even a guilty debt we owe for our exploitation. Putting conditions on aid is a form of colonialism -- except for conditions that suit a liberal agenda, such as empowering women or protecting the environment. Development strategies that feature trade and global business play into the hands of multinational capitalists. If you just pump in the money, countries will get better.
What we are seeing now is an awareness among the Cassandras that foreign misery and chaos breed real dangers to our national interest; and among the Pollyannas, a recognition that more discriminating aid works better and does not necessarily amount to big-business imperialism. You have the Bush administration advocating debt relief and offering a little more money for the most desperate countries; you have Oxfam talking about the importance of lowering trade barriers as part of the war on misery.
It's too early to celebrate a consensus, but it is possible to see some points that might be part of a compromise leading to more help for countries in lethal distress.
One new common theme is a large-scale forgiveness of old debts -- in effect, allowing the poorest countries to declare bankruptcy. This is not the magic bullet the Bono-ites make it out to be, and in a sense it unfairly rewards countries that squandered their loans on corruption and patronage. But the loans are not going to be repaid anyway. The Bush administration and many liberals embrace this idea, along with an important corollary: Stop making these make-believe loans in the first place. Give grants instead, which don't carry burdensome interest, and save loans for countries that will actually repay them.
A second possible point of agreement is that we should no longer give money to governments we know will steal or misspend it. The late economist Peter Bauer famously described foreign aid as the phenomenon of taxing poor people in rich countries to support the lifestyles of rich people in poor countries. Even liberal aid economists, like Jeffrey Sachs of Harvard, say that as a general rule, aid should go to foreign governments that are democratic (or at the very least, responsive), that live by the law and that have more or less free markets. These are the countries with a hope of turning aid into economic growth, which may ultimately get them off life support.
The tricky part is judging which countries qualify and, over time, measuring whether they are making good use of their aid. Mr. O'Neill talks about "productivity growth" as the litmus test of whether aid is effective, which sounds sensible in theory but a little simplistic. James Wolfensohn, president of the World Bank, notes that Mr. O'Neill seems to be setting a standard of effectiveness we don't even apply to our own government.
At the same time, there is enormous good that can be done in failing countries without sending money through their bad governments. As Mr. Sachs points out, relief agencies can immunize children even in war zones.
A third area of agreement is that aid should be more nimble and less bureaucratic. Mr. Easterly counts at least 10 annual reports that every World Bank country officer has to file on every project -- impact on the environment, on indigenous peoples, on waterways, etc. Now the World Bank and its meaner sister, the International Monetary Fund, are everybody's favorite scapegoats -- to the left, handmaidens of rapacious multinationals; to the right, an empire of waste. In fact, the bank does what the big donors, mainly Washington, tell it to do, and it has already begun some serious internal reforms. But it could use more competition. Mr. Bush has announced a $5 billion "Millennium Challenge Account," new grants to poor countries with good governments. We'll see if the U.S. can teach the World Bank some new tricks.
A fourth principle should be to separate aid from geopolitical expediency. We used to give money to corrupt thugs -- Mobutu Sese Seko in Zaire and Daniel arap Moi in Kenya come to mind -- just because they were anti-Communist. Now we will inevitably give money to some unsavory autocrats for their cooperation against terror. But let's at least not do it out of the aid account. Let's put it in the homeland security budget, or somewhere else.
One other important component of a new middle ground is a recognition that trade is at least as important as aid. Mr. O'Neill was rightly chewed out at every stop on his Africa tour because the latest American farm bill, signed by Mr. Bush, lavishly subsidizes American-grown food that competes with farm products from the poorest countries. On that point you'll find Bono and Oxfam singing perfect harmony with the Wall Street Journal editorial writers. Rich countries spend $350 billion a year on farm subsidies -- six times what they spend on foreign aid.
Will Mr. Bush veto the next farm bill for the sake of free-market principles and a few million African lives? Not until Ugandans vote in Florida. So here's an easier compassion test: Once we've got American aid focused on things that work, let's double it. Then double it again. That would finally catch us up to France in terms of national generosity (Que Bono!) and leave a lot of cynics speechless.

HEADLINE: Enron's Ready Access 

 BODY:
Pressed by Congressional Democrats, the White House has begun disgorging new information about the administration's extensive contacts with Enron executives. Alberto Gonzales, counsel to President Bush, asserted recently that the evidence showed that officials had responded in "appropriate and responsible" ways whenever they were in touch with the giant energy company, which collapsed last winter. But Mr. Gonzales's comment reflects precisely what is wrong with this picture. In Washington it is considered perfectly "appropriate" for officials to grant access to a company that used vast campaign donations to influence policy. 
 The administration says there is no evidence that Enron appealed to White House officials during its financial crisis. Last fall the administration said that Treasury Secretary Paul O'Neill and Commerce Secretary Donald Evans had rebuffed Enron's requests for help. Quite properly, however, investigators are seeking evidence that Enron sought to influence policy in less explicit ways that would have helped its balance sheet. The administration's penchant for secrecy, including Vice President Dick Cheney's refusal to provide records of contacts with his energy task force, has not banished suspicions in this regard. Enron and its employees gave more than $1 million to Mr. Bush's campaign, the Republican Party and the Bush inaugural. The company jet was used by Bush aides in the campaign and the post-election dispute in Florida. 
 The most generous Enron donor was Kenneth Lay. The latest information shows that while Mr. Lay was Enron's C.E.O. he was practically a fixture at the White House, attending the inaugural, the Easter egg rolling, T-ball games and other events large and small. The Senate Government Affairs Committee, headed by Joseph Lieberman, would like to know more about Mr. Lay's role in lobbying for policy and personnel changes at the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission and the Tennessee Valley Authority. The commission was crucial to Enron's hopes to reduce or eliminate regulation in energy markets in California and elsewhere. The T.V.A. had fought with Enron over electricity contracts. Also, the administration supported Enron's position in opposing energy price caps during the California power crisis. 
The administration needs to be more forthcoming on the evolution of its energy policies as well, many of which mirrored Enron recommendations. The White House likes to point to the number of instances when it did not take Enron's view on energy. That's fair, but the public is entitled to all the information so that cases of undue influence can be identified and examined. The phenomenon of a wealthy company using its riches to influence government policy and protect itself from financial ruin needs to be understood in all its dimensions.
