HEADLINE: COOKING 

BYLINE:  By Dwight Garner; Dwight Garner is an editor at the Book Review.

 BODY:
POTS and pans are a lot like sweaters, the novelist and food writer Laurie Colwin once wrote: "You may have lots of them, but you find yourself using two or three over and over again." Colwin might as well have been talking about cookbooks. It's never hard to tell, when you walk into someone's kitchen for the first time, which few have been put to good, honest use. (Ignore any pert titles, unblemished in their dust jackets, written by of-the-moment chefs -- those are up there for show.) The cookbooks that get used in my house tend to look like they've been pickled in malt vinegar and then shot from a cannon. They resemble scarecrows as much as they do books.
 The battered survivors on your shelves can be embarrassing. They're like looking at photo albums from that period, circa 1983, when your haircut was modeled on Bono's. One glance is all it takes to chart the sometimes sorry arc of your life in front of the stove. I own, to give just one example, a frightening number of well-thumbed Moosewood cookbooks (and books by their veggier-than-thou imitators). Did I really force my wife to eat that spinach-feta-chickpea mush I was so pleased with? And she hung around? 
 In recent years, I've fallen the hardest for cookbooks by people who can actually write -- books by people like Colwin, John Thorne and M. F. K. Fisher, for whom recipes are almost an afterthought. Literary snobs are nearly as bad as food snobs, and a decent style doesn't necessarily make for a decent recipe, but I can't help it. I'm the kind of food-book consumer who would rather know about Kingsley Amis's hangover cure (he recommends a rereading of "Paradise Lost," Book XII, lines 606 to the end) than the foolproof one suggested by a SWAT team of elite gastroenterologists. The prose in cookbooks has become even more important to me since I married into a food family. (In the 1970's and 80's, my father-in-law, a self-trained chef, ran restaurants in Aspen, Colo., and St. Helena, Calif., that foodies still remember.) With an expert in the family and a spouse who received a nearly full set of his culinary genes, we consult recipes a bit less often than most people, believing along with Colwin that a phone call to a brilliant friend or family member "beats a cookbook hands down: you can't cross-examine a cookbook." This season's best cookbooks aren't always the best written, but they're the ones we wanted to cross-examine the least.
Breakfast would seem like a logical place to begin, if a single cruel fact didn't stand in the way: it's the one meal few of us consult cookbooks to prepare. (Some mornings, just grinding your own coffee beans can feel like a stretch.) If you're among those who agree with A. J. Liebling that for serious eaters each day brings "only two opportunities for fieldwork" -- Liebling liked "a whacking lunch and a glorious dinner" -- let A REAL AMERICAN BREAKFAST: The Best Meal of the Day, Any Time of the Day (Morrow, $34.95), by Cheryl Alters Jamison and Bill Jamison, change your mind. The Jamisons are inquisitive guides through the world of breakfast foods past, present and future. They've done their homework; their book is littered with cheerful old menus (like the 1910 one from the U.S.M.S. St. Louis that features something called Yarmouth Bloaters) and well-chosen tips from antiquated cookbooks. The Jamisons can be sticklers -- I'm not sure they're ever going to persuade me to make my own cottage cheese or granola. But they also offer lots of unpretentious advice, like the best kind of store-bought English muffins (Wolferman's) or the smartest thing to order in a boring breakfast place (a BLT). This book may remind you of some seriously good, simple dishes (shirred eggs, multiple healthy varieties of hash). The Jamisons also smuggle in an absurd number of meat recipes -- notably a "Prime-Time Breakfast T-Bone" -- few of which, frankly, we're ever going to be in the mood to stare at (much less eat) at 9 a.m. Hence this book's not-so-dirty secret: almost everything in it, including the terrific pancake recipes, can make for a whacking lunch or a glorious dinner.
Summer's almost here, and so is the inevitable landslide of books about cooking meat over open fire. (Thoreau could have used this year's selection to build a cabin.) The only one of them that strikes me as essential -- even if you own their previous books -- is Chris Schlesinger and John Willoughby's LET THE FLAMES BEGIN: Tips, Techniques, and Recipes for Real Live Fire Cooking (Norton, $30). It's been 12 years since these guys (Schlesinger owns two restaurants in Massachusetts; Willoughby is executive editor of Gourmet magazine) published their classic, "The Thrill of the Grill"; their new book is, if anything, even tastier. Schlesinger and Willoughby are unfussy cooks who go for big, knock-you-down flavors. Better yet, if you're not a natural caveman, they persuade you that you can, under their tutelage, "go out in the backyard and act as if your awesome culinary performance is no big deal." They don't stint on the basics -- the equipment you need, how to build a proper fire -- and they have a nice, epigrammatic style: "When you're checking your food, remember that it is going to be underdone for a long time, perfectly done for just a minute and overdone for the rest of its existence." If you know all this stuff, just move to the recipes.
Most of them are pretty simple, largely because Schlesinger and Willoughby prefer last-minute rubs to overnight marinades. Everything we made from this book -- the cumin-crusted chicken breasts with orange-chipotle barbecue sauce, the Thai-style thin pork chops with a hoisin sauce glaze, the chipotle-grilled pork medallions with cilantro-peanut sprinkle -- is easier to prepare than it sounds, and is something we'll make again. We also liked the interesting vegetable and fruit concoctions that Schlesinger and Willoughby call "hobo packs": dishes you toss together, wrap in layers of foil and then bury in the coals to cook while your meat does. You will, however -- trust us -- feel like idiots when you're caught using the phrase "hobo pack" in front of dinner guests.
Two other meat books are worth knowing about. The first, Robb Walsh's LEGENDS OF TEXAS BARBECUE: Recipes and Recollections from the Pit Bosses (Chronicle, paper, $18.95), is a pleasantly nostalgic tour through that state's 'cue lore, with great photos and better recipes. (Lady Bird Johnson's barbecue sauce, included here, calls for a half-stick of butter; it's a knockout.) And I can't neglect to mention the only cookbook I've ever read that made me laugh out loud, and more than once: KILL IT & GRILL IT: A Guide to Preparing and Cooking Wild Game and Fish (Regnery, $21.95), by Ted Nugent and Shemane Nugent. Ted Nugent is, of course, the 70's-era gonzo rock star ("Cat Scratch Fever") who's become the Charlton Heston of the VH1 "Behind the Music" generation. You wouldn't want to actually cook from this book -- an alarming number of recipes call for Lipton onion soup mix and Accent seasoning. But it's worth a look, for the simple reason that it's a terrific parody, more incisive than you'd think, of those touchy-feely cookbooks that demand you know the personal history of every ingredient that enters your kitchen. Nugent agrees, except he demands that we become as intimate with our flesh intake as we are with our nuts and twigs. As he puts it, in tones that resemble "Diet for a Small Planet" until you get to the last line: "It is good to know exactly where one's food comes from. Hands-on cause and effect provides valuable lessons in environmental responsibility. You can't deny a gutpile." And here are Nugent's delirious (and pretty accurate) riffs on poultry, which I recommend reading while doing your best Yosemite Sam impression: "Free-range chicken ain't free and that ain't no range. Venison is free-range. Pheasant is free-range. The almighty Ruffed Grouse is free-range. I'm free-range. Chickens are incarcerated. . . . If it can't get away, it ain't free-range and I ain't interested." Someone give this man a show on the Food Network, if not MTV; he's 37 times more interesting than Ozzy Osbourne.
Life doesn't provide many opportunities to mention Ted Nugent and Alice Waters in the same sentence, so I'm doubly grateful that Waters has chosen this season to publish CHEZ PANISSE FRUIT (HarperCollins, $34.95), a book she's written with the cooks from her Berkeley restaurant in collaboration with Alan Tangren and Fritz Streiff. Like all of Waters's Chez Panisse books, this one is lovely to look at -- thanks to Patricia Curtan's delicate color relief prints -- and even more pleasant to read. (Though I could have done with fewer sentences of the "fruit teaches us the meaning of time and eternity" sort.) It was a bit early in the season to put "Chez Panisse Fruit" to proper use -- our farmers' market hasn't opened yet -- but I have a hunch that it may do for some kinds of fruit what Eric Schlosser's "Fast Food Nation" did for cheeseburgers.
Waters and company sort through every kind of fruit you've heard of (and some you haven't) and warn you about the varieties that have been ruined by either chemicals or the infelicities of mass production. You can almost read this book as poetry. Think watermelons are just watermelons? Let Waters tell you about Charleston Gray, Crimson Sweet and Jubilee. Or dates: she likes the Black Sphinx, the Medjool, the Khadrawy and the Zahidi. My only real complaint? In addition to the intuitive and accessible recipes, Waters's book is packed with advice about selecting fruit, yet it's too bulky actually to lug along to your market. All of her books are as much about good shopping as they are about good cooking. How hard would it be for the publisher to tuck a small detachable pamphlet -- Alice's Cliffs Notes -- into the paperback version?
Another book to keep handy this summer is Deborah Madison's LOCAL FLAVORS: Cooking and Eating From America's Farmers' Markets (Broadway, $39.95). Madison, the founding chef of San Francisco's celebrated Greens restaurant, is good company (I like her advice for telling who the real farmers are at your farmers' market -- look for the ones who seem really tired), and her recipes are just as agreeable. By necessity, we cooked mostly from her cold-weather chapters and can report that her leek, scallion and fennel gratin made a vegetarian dinner guest, as well as the rest of us, downshift into a Zenlike state of grace.
It's always fun to eat at Babbo, Mario Batali's earthy Italian restaurant in downtown Manhattan. For many home chefs, however, it may be somewhat less uplifting to cook from THE BABBO COOKBOOK (Clarkson Potter, $40). There are a few excellent and simple recipes here -- we loved the mustard-crusted salmon, to name one -- but quite a lot of them will be difficult to pull off unless you're unemployed and happen to live above a slaughterhouse. Batali is fond of dishes that call for items like caul fat or boar sausage or calf's brains or lamb's tongue -- or the beef cheeks that go into his justly famous beef cheek ravioli. (We like these things, too, but we're as disinclined to spring them on guests as we are to whip them up before an episode of "The West Wing.") The recipes that omit these sneaky bits -- I wonder what Ted Nugent does with his? -- often work some other kind of hard-to-find ingredient, like cardoons or fennel pollen, in at the last minute. The ones that don't do that frequently require some preparation a day or two in advance. There's nothing wrong with any of this -- we sometimes want our cookbooks to be challenging. But we rarely felt up for this book, particularly after encountering too many not-ready-for-Emeril-Lagasse lines like, "We like to get jiggy with strong flavors." In Italian, babbo means "daddy"; this book may simply make you want to cry "uncle."
After Mario Batali, picking up IN THE HANDS OF A CHEF: Cooking with Jody Adams (Morrow, $34.95), by Jody Adams and Ken Rivard, is like encountering Emma Thompson's cookbook after you've fought your way through Quentin Tarantino's. Adams is the co-owner and chef of Boston's Rialto restaurant, but this isn't really a restaurant cookbook; each of these recipes, she writes, "is something we do at my house." Everything we cooked from her book, from the iconoclastic salads (bibb lettuce with creamy mustard dressing and herb-stuffed eggs) and vegetable dishes (glazed carrots in honey and orange juice with black sesame seeds and mint) to several lovely duck preparations, was first rate. It would be swell if Adams would stop referring to sun-dried tomatoes as SDT's, though. Yikes. She makes them sound contagious.
This season's award for the cookbook that reads most like a work of agonized moral philosophy is DAMON LEE FOWLER'S NEW SOUTHERN KITCHEN: Traditional Flavors for Contemporary Cooks (Simon & Schuster, $26). Fowler, a former architect who is also the author of "Classical Southern Cooking," wrestles with Southern food the way James Agee wrestled with the plight of tenant farmers in "Let Us Now Praise Famous Men." He gives you the history of Southern cooking and its myriad influences while worrying about issues like: Are the words "new" and "Southern" oxymorons? Does Southern cooking, as a style, really exist? Can Southerners eat goat cheese without feeling wussy? How about appetizers? ("Southerners have not, historically, been a nation of grazers," he observes dryly.) Must all fish be fried? Do all salads have to include mayo and aspic? Fowler is aware that he can sometimes go a little overboard on the meta-think. After one ponderous section about Southern food lore, he admits: "Well, all of that may seem irrelevant when you are faced with a pork chop." The good news about his new book is that it will help you out when faced with a pork chop, or almost anything else. His pecan-crusted catfish is worth running out and making tonight; his veal stew is an elegant low-country masterpiece, and any chef who splashes this much bourbon around his recipes is welcome in our kitchen anytime.
Here's a lively and extremely uncomplicated cookbook that, almost overnight, became one of our favorites: THE JIMTOWN STORE COOKBOOK: Recipes and More from Sonoma County's Favorite Country Store (HarperCollins, $32.50), by Carrie Brown and John Werner, with Michael McLaughlin. Brown and Werner (her husband, who died before the book went to press) were New Yorkers who moved to Sonoma County and opened a general store in the early 90's. There's zero food theory here, just a lot of recipes that we felt like making more than once. Their terrific and simple "Indian Cashews" -- raw cashews roasted in a pan with spices and Worcestershire sauce -- are now something we have warm and ready before dinner parties; their maple-glazed meat loaf, which is baked while covered with thick slabs of bacon, almost made us crumple with gratitude; the grilled pork tenderloins with citrus glaze is a dish worthy of the best ones in "Let the Flames Begin" (we mopped up the leftover glaze with bread over the next two days); the roasted carrots with three kinds of ginger (fresh, crystallized and ground) is equally nifty. We're just sorry we haven't gotten around to their pan-fried Petaluma duck burgers -- yet.
A few final notes: THE ULTIMATE SHRIMP BOOK: More than 650 Recipes for Everyone's Favorite Seafood Prepared in Every Way Imaginable (Morrow, paper, $16.95), by Bruce Weinstein and Mark Scarbrough, sometimes made us groan -- it's full of lines like "everyone's crazy about shrimp" -- but it happened to arrive in our house at the same time that some obscenely fresh rock shrimp began turning up in our local fish market. Weinstein's recipes for shrimp chowder and shrimp frittata did them full justice. (Weinstein's book is also full of faded classics we'll probably never make but wish someone would share with us when they do: things like Shrimp Diane, General Tsao's Shrimp and Shrimp Newburg.)
Avoid Tamara Weiss's POTLUCK AT MIDNIGHT FARM: Celebrating Food, Family, and Friends on Martha's Vineyard (Clarkson Potter, $32.50), which arrives with a foreword by Carly Simon, unless you really need to know Mary Steenburgen's recipe for corn spoon pudding or are desperate to fix the fried chicken that William Styron claims Bill Clinton loved. Weiss's book is full of chatter like: "Oh, and Mike and Diane" -- that would be Mike Nichols and Diane Sawyer -- "are here and I invited them to come, too. Diane's bringing her favorite cherry pie. Is that O.K.?" This book makes Martha's Vineyard sound like a minimum-security prison for the criminally self-absorbed.
THE CHEESE PLATE (Clarkson Potter, $32.50), by Max McCalman and David Gibbons -- McCalman is the maitre fromager at the New York restaurants Picholine and Artisanal -- can occasionally read like an eighth-grade science textbook. ("Each and every fine cheese has its own distinguishable aromas and flavors. Where do they all come from and what causes them to develop?") But McCalman is so full of good advice about choosing and serving cheese that you'll envy him his rare and surely painful medical condition -- something he calls "cheese elbow." We should all be so lucky.
Finally, Pascale LeDraoulec's AMERICAN PIE: Slices of Life (and Pie) From America's Back Roads (HarperCollins, $23.95) tells the story of the author's road trip, from San Francisco to New York in a Volvo named Betty, looking for great pie recipes. LeDraoulec, the restaurant critic of The Daily News in New York, weighs her book down with too many tired observations of the I'm-off-to-find-America variety, and too many evocations of usual suspects like Kerouac and de Tocqueville. But the recipes she picks up, often from women with reassuring names like Edna and Dorothy Lou, are homey and idiosyncratic. The Turtle Pie recipe, which comes from an Abbeville, La., resident named Libby Bollino, calls for one and a half bags of caramels and a cup of chocolate chips, among other things. It made us feel like we'd been whacked over the head with a Milky Way bar -- and I mean that, I think, in a very good way.

GRAPHIC: Drawing: The Simpsons and copyright 2002 20th Century Fox Film Corporation. All rights reserved. (Matt Groening)

HEADLINE: TRAVEL 

BYLINE:  By Maria Russo; Maria Russo is a writer in New York.

 BODY:
KEEPING alive the romance of travel is a tougher job than ever. Like a long, comfortable relationship, travel these days is all too easily taken for granted: its rhythms are well established, its pleasures familiar and predictable. Is there a spot left on earth that could possibly whisper into a traveler's ear, "You're the first; there's no one like you"?
 Tourism has become the world's biggest industry, and no one has felt the resulting loss of spontaneity and innocence more than travel writers. Certain notions sacred to the profession appear to be breathing their last: That you can still find some "authentic" contrast to our own overprocessed culture. Or that there's still a meaningful distinction to be made between "traveler" and "tourist." With even the remotest destinations featuring strategically located A.T.M.'s, we're all tourists now. 
 When the present state of a place leans toward the depressingly well trodden, one excellent plan is to indulge in a little mental time travel. The Australian writer Tony Perrottet's first book to be published in America, ROUTE 66 A.D.: On the Trail of Ancient Roman Tourists (Random House, $25.95), takes a running leap directly into the problem of centuries of tourist saturation. Perrottet, who now lives in New York, confesses that while he had always been fascinated by antiquity and wanted to visit Greece and Italy, he so loathed the idea of being part of a swarm of visitors that he "had been to just about every place on earth except the Mediterranean."
For someone who prided himself on originality, it was a problem: "How could you see anything new there?" But when he came upon a surprisingly abundant cache of material relating to ancient Roman tourism in the New York Public Library, he hatched a scheme to retrace the steps of ancient travelers, who, it turns out, were every bit as predictable and herd-bound as we are. As Perrottet points out, tourism can flourish only during periods of peace and prosperity. The Pax Romana lasted from 27 B.C. to A.D. 180, during which a mind-expanding -- and programmatic -- sojourn in Greece, Asia Minor and Egypt became practically de rigueur for wealthy young Roman men (and, very occasionally, women).
Perrottet's book is an appealing, if sometimes exhausting, mix of the zany and the arcane, juggling an energetic account of ancient Roman travel habits with a witty record of his own modern journey -- accompanied by his incredibly accommodating (and pregnant) girlfriend, Lesley -- from Rome to southern Italy, then on to Greece, Turkey and Egypt. The idea is to have a last travel blowout before becoming parents, a plan Perrottet feels has "a certain ring to it: heavy with child in the cradle of civilization."
His insistence on seeing what the ancients saw, no matter the filth, decay and craven commercialism obscuring most ancient sites, becomes a terrific running gag. Again and again, he beats his head against intransigent, indifferent or simply lazy local guides. One scuba impresario thinks he's crazy to want to attempt a dive in the Bay of Naples in the rain, but Perrottet won't be deterred, and when he finally sees, underneath a layer of "verdant slime," the remnants of the Roman resort of Baiae, he makes you understand his excitement: "Up on the surface, spitting out a laboratoryful of bacteria, I felt like -- at last! -- I'd beheld the Roman past directly."
"Route 66 A.D." is also, finally, a reflection on the inescapability of the travel industry, and Perrottet's journey seems to have left him with a sober yet optimistic perspective. He points out that while rampant tourism has helped speed the destruction of whole chunks of the ancient world, tourism tied to antiquity can also be a means of renewing a once grand, now scruffy city like Alexandria. While he finds that this ancient center of learning is visited mainly by Egyptian middle-class families looking for a seaside holiday, Perrottet also meets some ambitious young Alexandrians who are pinning their hopes on a new archaeological marine park that may attract "rich European tourists" to the city's submerged cultural riches. "It's archaeology in reverse," he decides. "The past is deftly salvaging the ruins of the present."
Frank Clifford is on a similarly high-concept trip in THE BACKBONE OF THE WORLD: A Portrait of a Vanishing Way of Life Along the Continental Divide (Broadway, $24.95). Clifford, the environment editor of The Los Angeles Times, set out to travel on foot, mule and horse (and now and then by truck) all 3,200 miles of a newly established trail along the Continental Divide, a geographical feature that is, as he puts it, "the part in the hair of a hemispheric watershed that reaches from Alaska to the Strait of Magellan." Clifford maintains that "it would be hard to find a route in this country that offers a more extensive immersion in time travel"; and while he knows plenty about the land, and shares this knowledge judiciously, his main goal is to come into contact with a Western way of life that has survived for centuries in the forbidding terrain near the divide. Now, however, a new economy built on tourism, real estate and recreation is encroaching on this wilderness, with ominous consequences.
Clifford writes with grace and poise about confronting natural hazards. (On horseback in northwestern Wyoming during a snowstorm, he's feeling sorry for himself and the wind-swept trees when an enormous pine suddenly "uproots itself and arcs noiselessly through the air" to land directly in front of him.) But he's more interested in human-created problems. Along the trail, he hooks up with a memorable cast of characters, including a proud old rancher who lives in the Tularosa Mountains of southwestern New Mexico with a dwindling herd of cattle; an impassioned Yellowstone Park ranger who has declared war on poachers and rogue hunting-tour operators; and a shrewd, voluble old surveyor who knows Wyoming's Teton Wilderness inside out after spending four years searching for his son's downed plane. Clifford lets all his traveling companions have a say about what's happening to the West, and so he documents with rare equanimity the politics of land, water, gun control, religious freedom, conservation and mining that have become more and more entrenched and vicious.
Ultimately, though, Clifford's subject is the wilderness ("the great clarifier," as he sees it) and the blend of fear and fascination it inspires -- which, paradoxically, threatens to obliterate its last vestiges. At the end of his trip, he makes his way through the Canadian Rockies with an ex-cowboy and environmental activist who tells him dolefully that "there's no good argument for wilderness. . . . If there were, we'd be winning." Yet Clifford's subtle and heartfelt book is itself an articulate brief for saving land that humans touch only lightly or not at all. "I cannot imagine that if the design of the world were ours to do over," he writes, "we would leave out wilderness any more than we could conceive of Athens without the Parthenon."
Another version of modern time travel animates Isadora Tattlin's CUBA DIARIES: An American Housewife in Havana (Shannon Ravenel/Algonquin, $24.95), an inspired record of four years in Fidel Castro's Cuba, where the past is present -- both tragically and hilariously -- at all times. Tattlin is the pseudonym of an American who, with her two young children, lands in Cuba because of her foreign-born husband's job as an energy consultant. (The book disguises many details, understandably if sometimes irritatingly, as when Tattlin refers throughout to her husband's native country as "X--.") Her position makes possible both an outsider's overview of a tattered but still vibrant culture and an insider's look into the stupefying complications of navigating its day-to-day life. She comes to realize that there is an art to survival in Cuba. "It's an elusive door you have to find," she explains, to locate "motivated Cubans, edible food and charm."
Written in a tone that moves between compassion and outraged incredulity, "Cuba Diaries" is organized as a series of vignettes of such unconventional (at least in Cuba) activities as building a swimming pool and taking a weekend excursion to the beach: in this case, the stunningly beautiful beach near Baracoa, where Columbus landed in 1492 and where the amenities haven't improved all that much. (The best hotel in town has water -- cold water -- for only an hour a day.) An almost surreal walk through a bustling, garbage-strewn, decaying yet still architecturally grand Old Havana calls to mind nothing so much as "Berlin, 1945." Early on, Tattlin realizes that a huge, decrepit, practically merchandise-free department store is "one of the weirdest places on earth . . . not so much because it is stuck in the 50's and is empty, but because it is open, staffed and routine."
Elsewhere, the weirdness approaches the pathetic -- women and children begging tourists for soap, a long line forming in front of a store that has received a shipment of talcum powder -- or the stomach-churning. A search for a "plausible" veterinarian to neuter a cat leads Tattlin to one apartment where the doctor, wrapped in a chenille bedspread, shows her his operating room, with "bloodstains on the walls and on books in bookshelves lining other walls," and another where the vet operates "on a carved mahogany coffee table, next to a Louis XVI-style display case." He assures her that he'll cover the table with a towel.
The book's high point is an appearance by Castro himself at one of the Tattlins' dinner parties, and by this point the bizarre aspects of the visit barely register. Before El Senor arrives, the members of his security detail demand that Tattlin show them the toilet paper he will be using -- they sniff disapprovingly when she tells them it's Cuban -- then instruct her to put it in a plastic bag, tape the bag shut and leave it beside a toilet that can be used only by Fidel. After dinner, he downs several Cognacs as he talks, uninterrupted, in bursts that last almost a half-hour at a time.
"Cuba Diaries" can be a little too free-form, but it's always striking -- above all, as a testament to the human capacity to endure and even flourish under terrible conditions. Food is often scarce for those who don't have dollars, but Tattlin's Cuba is full of art openings and mojito-filled parties where foreigners and Cubans debate world politics and watch painfully lovely sunsets. And, as deplorable as the unnecessary deprivations are, they also foster a moving, almost childlike sense of wonder. "How large the world is!" exclaims a deliveryman who comes into Tattlin's kitchen one day and beholds, with awe, a zucchini.
Even without being subject, like Cuba, to a time-stopping embargo, certain places appear to have changed so little over the centuries that they call out to a traveler who's eager to look back into history. Theresa Maggio's second book about Sicily, THE STONE BOUDOIR: Travels Through the Hidden Villages of Sicily (Perseus, $25), is a record of her rapturous quest for the kind of isolated mountain towns that "didn't rate a dot" on any map. Maggio's paternal grandparents emigrated to New Jersey from a Sicilian village called Santa Margherita Belice at the beginning of the 20th century. They never returned, but she has spent much of her adult life arranging long and short stints on the island they were pushed by poverty to forsake.
Maggio's Sicily is a place where "the bedrock hums with hidden energy." She is especially enamored of the old, now semi-abandoned towns in the fertile area sloping down from Mount Etna, in the eastern third of Sicily, and of a friendly town in the Madonie Mountains in north-central Sicily called Polizzi Generosa, where "my kitchen balcony hung out over a valley so deep it made me dizzy." Wherever she went, she looked for villages whose remoteness or indigence saved them from the wrecking ball of modernization and therefore still boasted buildings made of "creamy yellow sandstone, or black lava, or dense blue stones, or pink clay rocks."
At one point, Maggio spends a night in "the ultimate stone house," a cave in the Nebrodi Mountains in north-central Sicily, where the naturally temperature-controlled, often wood-paneled apartments are furnished with dining-room credenzas, VCR's and microwaves. These dwellings, like all the Sicilian homes Maggio visits, are cleaned furiously and proudly by members of a fierce army of Sicilian housewives. One tells Maggio that her cave was too dark until the morning "I sent my husband off to work, found his sledgehammer" and "made the window into a door."
Maggio mentions at the outset that her favorite movie is Giuseppe Tornatore's "Cinema Paradiso," which is fair warning that her sensibility is on the sentimental side. But if her passion for Sicily sometimes seems to threaten some kind of scary detonation ("This was my blood, conceived deep in a Sicilian mountain," she says as she drinks from a stream), there is no questioning her sincerity. Her book ends up delivering an economical, if episodic, trip through centuries of complicated Sicilian history.
The eloquent British travel writer H. V. Morton, who died in 1979, specialized in transforming a seemingly predictable journey into a fantasy trip back to the past. Learned without being pedantic, dignified but curious about all walks of life, Morton could have made the White Plains Mall seem well worth a visit. Da Capo Press is gradually reissuing paperback editions of his travel books with new introductions by contemporary writers: just out are IN SEARCH OF ENGLAND ($16), with an introduction by Jan Morris; IN THE STEPS OF ST. PAUL ($16), with an introduction by Bruce Feiler; and IN THE STEPS OF THE MASTER ($16), with an introduction by Richard John Neuhaus. It's both exciting and sad to see that Barbara Grizzuti Harrison, the author of "Italian Days" (among several other books), contributed a brief but characteristically intelligent and sumptuously written introduction to Morton's sweeping volume A TRAVELLER IN ITALY ($18). Harrison died in April -- this may have been among the last things she wrote -- but her prose is as unforgettable as ever. She praises Morton for writing books that are "complete and welcoming" and notes how contagious his exhilaration is. The same, of course, could be said of her.

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN; 
Lake Champlain

BYLINE:  By JUDITH YARNALL; JUDITH YARNALL teaches at Johnson State College in Vermont.

 BODY:
Stretching 125 miles from southern Quebec to the tiny Vermont town of Benson's Landing, Lake Champlain is inland New England's answer to the Atlantic. Stay by it long enough, and your eye will expect tiers of mountains on the far side of large bodies of water. Seascapes may forever disappoint.
 The Adirondacks press close to Champlain's western shore. To the east, Vermont's slightly more angular Green Mountains hold off for 20-odd miles, creating a lush interval of flat to mildly rolling land that was once the bottom of the Champlain Sea. Now that the sea creatures have been reduced to tiny fossils still found within garden rocks, the area has become a boon to apple growers, dairy farmers and bicyclists. 
 The region is also home to Burlington, whose civic energy and natural beauty regularly cause it to be listed among America's most pleasant, livable small cities. Burlington has a vital downtown pedestrian mall (the Church Street Marketplace), a community boathouse and waterfront park triumphantly reclaimed from industrial decay, the state university atop a hill studded with homes of prosperous 19th-century lumber and marble barons, and a host of summer festivals. Together with Shelburne, seven miles south, it's the Champlain Valley's biggest cultural draw. 
Virtually anywhere by the lake, however, is a fine place to be in summer -- from the pastures and coves of the Champlain Islands in the midst of its broad northern expanse to the orchards of Shoreham near its slender southern tip. You may find a sandy beach, but more likely one made of smooth, flat pebbles -- some with zebra stripes of slate and quartz -- which fit beautifully in the hand. Best to wear water shoes, though.

Events
The Vermont Mozart Festival, July 14 to Aug. 4, (800) 639-9097 or www.vtmozart.com, has long been the area's premier summer celebration. This year's program of 24 performances -- by the Festival Orchestra, the Paris Piano Trio, and the violinist Hamao Fujiwara, among others -- includes a new Family Series. Several favorite sites (the South Porch at Shelburne Farms, Basin Harbor, Kingsland Bay) are by the lake and allow picnicking beforehand. Tickets vary from $22 to $35 for concerts; $3 per child at a Family Series event.
Tents for the Burlington Waterfront Art and Craft Festival, (802) 985-3648, fax (802) 425-3711, www.craftproducers.com, will occupy much of Waterfront Park at the foot of College Street from July 26 to 28. This juried show will present the work of 120 crafts experts, painters and photographers -- with music, wine tasting, cooking demonstrations and kids' events, too. Friday 10 a.m. to 8 p.m., Saturday and Sunday 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; general admission, $6.
Those with a yen to see old-fashioned horse power will enjoy the Green Mountain Draft Horse Field Day at Shelburne Farms, (802) 985-8686 or www.shelburnefarms.org, on July 27 from 11 a.m. to 3 p.m. The $6 Shelburne Farms admission fee ($4 ages 3 to 14) gives you access to Field Day events as well as to walking trails on the estate designed in 1886 by Frederick Law Olmsted with Lila Vanderbilt Webb and her husband, Dr. William Seward Webb. Turn west onto Harbor Road at the light in the village's center.
The Green Mountain Chew Chew Food Fest, also at Burlington's Waterfront Park, June 21 to 23, (802) 864-6674, features local restaurants' fare and music by groups such as the Vermont Jazz Ensemble. Tokens are nine for $5, with all food items three tokens or less. Hours are 11 a.m. to 11 p.m. Friday and Saturday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. on Sunday.
Kingsland Bay State Park in Ferrisburg will be the gorgeous site of the Champlain Valley Folk Festival on Aug. 2 to 4, (800) 769-9176 and www.cvfest.org. A celebration of Yankee, Quebecois, Celtic and bluegrass music, the festival will include workshops, dancing and performances by the Greenbriar Boys and more than 30 other groups. Admission is $25 (evenings or Sunday), $35 (all Saturday) or $65 (all weekend).
The Lake Champlain Maritime Museum, on the grounds of the Basin Harbor Club near Vergennes, (802) 475-2202 or www.lcmm.org, will hold its Annual Small Boat Show on July 6 and 7. This year's theme is the living tradition of boatbuilding in the Champlain Valley. Not only can visitors view and test unusual craft, they can see them being created in the museum's wonderfully resinous boat-building shed. Workshops on blacksmithing, framing, and paddlemaking will be going on all weekend. The museum admission fee of $10 ($5 for ages 5 to 17) gets you into grounds, show and main building, with its reconstructed Lake Champlain horse ferry and exhibits on the Battle of Valcour Island.

Sightseeing
There's no better place to fully sense the lake than the wind-swept deck of a ferry. The Lake Champlain Transportation Company, (802) 864-9804, runs three of the area's four ferries: between Grand Isle, Vt., and Cumberland Head, N.Y., outside Plattsburgh; between Burlington and Port Kent, N.Y.; and between Charlotte, Vt., and Essex, N.Y. The Charlotte crossing, at the lake's loveliest part, takes 20 minutes and deposits you in the small, architecturally interesting town of Essex, with restaurants near the dock. The round trip costs $13.50 for a car and driver, $4 for adults, $1 ages 6 to 12.
The fourth ferry, the 1759 Limited or Fort Ti, (802) 897-7999, runs on an underwater cable between Shoreham, Vt., and Ticonderoga, N.Y. -- next to the site where Ethan Allen and his Green Mountain Boys stormed the fort in 1775. Its short run occurs on demand, 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. in summer; $12 round trip for a car.
The second-best place for lake viewing is Mount Philo State Park in Charlotte, (802) 425-2390. A one-mile hike or drive from the entrance yields the sweep of the valley and Split Rock Point beyond. Other parks can't match Mount Philo's panorama, but they do offer good swimming places. Try Knight Point State Park on the causeway-connected island of North Hero, (802) 372-8389, or Sand Bar State Park in Milton, (802) 893-2525; they have sandy, gradual beaches ideal for young children.
Permanently docked at Waterfront Park, the barge that has been transformed into the Burlington Community Boathouse, (800) 458-9301 or www.windsofireland.com, rents small boats and books two-hour sailing cruises, captain provided, for $25 a person. The snack bar by the boathouse's upper sundeck is pleasant for lunch. The Burlington Bikepath, eight miles long, runs through the park just across the lawn from the boathouse.

Where to Stay
The Vermont Department of Tourism Web site, www.travel-vermont .com, lists most lodging places within the state. Although choices abound in the Burlington area, few are within the city itself. An excellent nearby alternative is the Heart of the Village Inn, 5347 Shelburne Road in Shelburne, (877) 808-1834, fax (802) 985-2870, www.heartofthevillage.com. This welcoming Victorian B & B, with nine spacious rooms, several in the carriage house out back, is restored with fine attention to detail and is an easy walk from the town's restaurants. Doubles begin at $115.
At opposite ends of the lake, the Shoreham Inn, near the town green since 1799, and the Shore Acres, a small resort on North Hero, offer distinctive accommodations at good value. Popular with bicycle tour groups, the Shoreham, (800) 255-5081, www.shorehaminn.com, has 10 large doubles filled with eclectic antiques -- and two carousel horses. All rooms are $95, including breakfast. Some nights the dining room is open, and if it's not, Middlebury is an easy drive.
Most of the 23 air-conditioned rooms at Shore Acres, (802) 372-8722, fax (802) 372-8314, www.shoreacres .com, have views of the lake and Mount Mansfield, as well as attractive watercolors by Vermont artists. Rates run $119.50 a double and include use of the docks, beach, tennis courts, pool and nine-hole pitch-and-putt course. The restaurant, open to the public, offers well-prepared American fare such as apple island chicken with a reduced cider sauce; dinner for two, with wine, about $75.
Budget: The Days Inn, well set back from traffic at 3229 Shelburne Road (Route 7) in Shelburne, (802) 985-3334, fax (802) 985-3419, has 58 well-maintained rooms and an outdoor pool. Rates for doubles vary from $62 to $85.
The EconoLodge is across the road at No. 3164, (800) 825-1882, fax (802) 985-3377, also with an outdoor pool. Its 53 rooms include doubles from $55 to $125, but its two-room suites with kitchenettes, on the back lawn, are more enticing for $80 to $165.
Luxury: The Basin Harbor Club near Vergennes, (800) 622-4000, fax (802) 475-6545, or www.basinharbor .com, has been delighting its guests for several generations. This 700-acre resort, opposite scenic palisades on the New York side, has 38 rooms and 77 one- to three-bedroom cottages, some set among shoreline cedars. Amenities include five tennis courts, an 18-hole golf course, a 40-foot excursion boat, lake and pool swimming, and all-day programs for kids (with a water trampoline for the rambunctious). Summer rates are American Plan, ranging from $230 to $460 a couple a day. Basin Harbor's dining room, requiring coats and ties, is open to nonguests by reservation; the flat fee for a dinner of several courses is $35, excluding wine. The resort's less formal Red Mill offers a cafe menu.

Where to Eat
The finely prepared French food, soft lighting and quiet atmosphere of Cafe Shelburne, 5573 Shelburne Road (Route 7) in the village, (802) 985-3939, never disappoint. Specialties include lobster bisque and sole with a saffron sauce. A three-course dinner for two with wine is about $110.
Most of the many restaurants in the Church Street Marketplace in Burlington have outside tables as well as pleasant interiors. Look for Leunig's Bistro at 115 Church, (802) 863-3759, by now a Burlington institution, where you can dine seriously on French and Italian fare, order off the cafe menu, or read a newspaper by the antique mirrored bar; dinner for two with wine runs from $45 to $80.
Sakura, two blocks away at 2 Church Street, (802) 863-1988, has delicious, delicately prepared Japanese food at reasonable prices. Especially appealing are dinner boxes, offering a choice of sushi, tempuras, and other specialties. Dinner for two with Japanese beer, about $50.
The elegant dining room of the Inn at Shelburne Farms, 1611 Harbor Road, (802) 985-8498, once the Webb family's lakeside "summer cottage," takes reservations for breakfast Monday through Saturday, brunch on Sunday, and dinner daily. On a terrace overlooking English gardens, you can choose from a menu highlighting organic produce, herbs, baked goods and cheeses produced or grown on the estate. Among the entrees is pan-roasted venison accompanied by a ragout of fiddlehead ferns, morel mushrooms and baby turnips. A three-course dinner for two with wine is about $120. Should you not want to go home, there are 24 fresh, antique-filled rooms upstairs, ranging in summer from $100 to $325 a night.
Gillian's, 97 Falls Road, Shelburne, adjacent to the village green and open until 9 p.m., (802) 985-2830, is an upscale diner. Dinner entrees like maple walnut chicken run about $11; wine is available.

HEADLINE: Ports That Reflect a Grand Era 

BYLINE:  By JAKE MILLER; JAKE MILLER writes for children about science, history and the outdoors.

 BODY:
OUT of the thick fog swirling around Winter Island, a lone brown pelican soared into sight, flew silently past the small sailboats anchored offshore and disappeared back into the mist. Nearby, a solitary fisherman cast his line at the foot of the Fort Pickering Lighthouse as small waves lapped the rocky beach.
 Winter Island, a five-minute drive from downtown Salem, Mass., is a city park where you can launch a boat or explore the Civil War-era earthworks of Fort Pickering. But just up the shore from the park, there's a coal-fired power plant and a municipal sewage treatment facility. 
 New England has always had a complex relationship with the sea. For centuries the ocean has served as a source of great wealth for merchants and fishermen. Even in today's tourist-driven economy, the sea is as much hardscrabble workplace as playground. In a pair of day trips from our home in Boston last September, my wife, Rose, and I explored the wharves and waterfronts of Salem and Gloucester, Mass., two places where this heritage can still be seen. 
From the 1640's until the early 19th century, Salem was one of the most important trading ports in America. The Central Wharf of the Salem Maritime National Historic Site is the home of the Friendship, a reproduction of a three-masted East Indiaman that was originally completed in 1797. Construction on the new Friendship began in 1996.
Crews of carpenters and riggers are still outfitting the ship, and visitors can go aboard to watch their progress and to get an inkling of what it felt like to sail to China or Russia on a vessel powered by nothing but muscles and wind, hemp rope and canvas sails. The main mast is nearly as tall as a 10-story building, but the cramped spaces of the 'tween-deck seemed like an awfully small place to live with a dozen other souls for months at a time.
Park rangers are stationed on the ship to answer questions. The ranger we spoke with was eager to talk about Salem's history of privateers, the government-licensed pirates who operated as a sort of freelance American navy during the Revolutionary War and seized cargo from British ships. The ranger deferred one of our questions about some of the Friendship's ropes -- Kevlar coils thicker than my forearm, dyed black to resemble traditional tar-coated hemp lines -- to the master rigger, who happened to be working on board at the time. As we talked, he pointed out the splintered section of the main mast, which had recently been struck by lightning.
After lunch at the nearby Lobster Shanty, a typical seaside snack shack, Rose and I headed around the corner to the Peabody Essex Museum on Essex Street. Founded in 1799 by Salem's merchants at the height of the China trade, the museum celebrates the intersection of New England and the cultures of the world. Merchant ships like the Friendship made their owners wealthy by hauling cargoes of luxury goods from around the world back to Salem. The museum has a stunning permanent collection of Chinese export goods, including porcelain bowls still wrapped in their original straw packing material.
One gallery is dedicated to Cleopatra's Barge, a pleasure boat built in 1816 for George Crowninshield Jr., a shipping merchant. The Peabody Essex also features temporary shows, and on our visit we saw an enchanting exhibition of American needlework art with 19th century embroidery by schoolgirls and sailors as well as work by contemporary textile artists.
Ready for a break from the galleries, we were happy to find the museum's Asian Garden, a welcome, leafy retreat. A helpful, knowledgeable museum cashier later outlined a walking route for us through one of Salem's architecturally rich neighborhoods where mansions sprouted in the 18th and 19th centuries. We walked by dozens of gorgeously preserved homes just a few blocks from the museum. One of the true gems was the formal garden at the Peabody Essex-owned Ropes Mansion, where three gardeners tended the beds of hollyhocks, sunflowers, and dahlias with blossoms the size of my head.
Salem's luxurious homes and gardens are shining reminders of a maritime prosperity that has since faded. International commerce dried up fast during the Napoleonic wars and the War of 1812, and Salem's port never recovered. Nevertheless, the waters off New England continued to provide a bountiful living -- not from trade, but from fish. After all, when the Pilgrims arrived in Massachusetts in 1621 they weren't just searching for religious freedom -- they also came looking for cod. Gloucester was one of the Pilgrims' first fishing stations. More than three centuries later, although the fisheries have been in serious decline for years, Gloucester is still very much a commercial fishing town. 
Walking along the town's waterfront from St. Peter's Park to the Harbor Loop, we saw lobster boats, trawlers and long-liners (commercial fishing boats) moored alongside whale-watching vessels and windjammers. The buoys and floats on the working boats are so colorful that it's easy to forget that they're not decorations but serious tools used every day to wrest a living from the sea.
That's why, in spite of its name, the Cape Ann Historical Museum is as much about Gloucester's living relationship to the sea as it is about the past. The first floor of the museum features the sublime landscapes and maritime paintings of Fitz Hugh Lane. Painting in the mid-1800's, Lane captured real moments and accurate details of the architecture and rigging of the ships he painted. In one work, a schooner awaits a pilot to take it out to sea; in another, a ship rolls in the raging sea. 
Upstairs galleries detail the history, culture, politics and ecology of fishing in Gloucester. The exhibit opens with a series of genre-bending impressionistic wildlife specimen paintings of commercially exploited fish species. Painted in 1995 by a local artist, Debbie Clark, each image is accompanied by legal, ecological and biological information. Farther on, there are displays chronicling changing fishery regulations, a statue of the Virgin Mary cradling a Gloucester schooner (originally displayed at Our Lady of Good Voyage Roman Catholic Church, a traditionally Portuguese church in Gloucester) and a collection of oars decorated for the feast of St. Peter.
We bought sandwiches at Virgilio's Bakery and Deli on Main Street, a few blocks from the museum, and then drove to Halibut Point State Park and Preserve on the other side of Cape Ann. After our picnic, we walked down to the rocky shore and sat in the sun. Just offshore, a lobsterman in orange bib pants tended his traps. Each lobsterman's traps are marked with a buoy in a distinctive color pattern. Most old-timers still prefer combinations of traditional greens and reds, while up-and-comers often choose more striking neon colors.
Halibut Point isn't named after a fish. It got its name from the fleets of schooners that used to "haul about" off shore to round Cape Ann. Thousands of those ships were built in the nearby town of Essex at the mouth of the Essex River. Our next stop was the Essex Shipbuilding Museum, on the site of a boatyard that has been in use since 1668. Our tour began with a 1940's docu-drama video with a contrived story about shipbuilding but fantastic footage of a wooden-hulled, diesel-powered fishing schooner being built by hand, with axes and adzes.
After the video, a guide led us around the museum grounds. We walked through the shipyard itself, past a rusty band saw and piles of wood scraps. To encourage traditional boatbuilding, the museum rents space here to private individuals working on wooden boats. In the museum's hands-on educational center, I used a heavy mallet and something that looked like an overgrown apple-corer to turn a scrap of wood into a treenail, a wooden peg that would have been used to fasten planks to a ship's frame. We saw the salvaged remains of the Evelina M. Goulart, one of only seven old Essex-built schooners still in existence, awaiting restoration in drydock. There was also a small house full of antique tools and maritime models.
Back in the shipyard, our guide pointed out the old door of the rustic paint shed. For generations, the men cleaning their brushes in the shed had flicked paint on it, and the paint had dried in layers creating thick, flowing streams of color. Like the floats on a long-liner or the sleek hull of an Essex schooner, it was never meant to be a work of art. But it was.

Exploring the North Shore of Massachusetts
The North Shore towns of Salem, Gloucester and Essex are within a 45-minute drive of Boston and a few miles of one another. For more information, contact the Salem Office of Tourism, 59 Wharf Street, Salem, Mass. 01970, (877) 725-3662, (978) 744-3663, fax (978) 741-7539, www.salem.org, or the Gloucester Tourism Commission, 22 Poplar Street, Gloucester, Mass. 01930, (800) 649-6839, www.gloucesterma.com.

What to See
Winter Island Marine Park, Winter Island Road, Salem, (978) 745-9430, $5 a car. Fort Pickering Lighthouse, campsites and beaches for swimming. Open daily.
Salem Maritime National Historic Site, 193 Derby Street, Salem; (978) 740-1650, $5, children $3. Besides the Friendship, there's Derby House, home of one of America's first millionaires. Open daily.
Peabody Essex Museum, East India Square, Salem; (800) 745-4054 or at www
.pem.org; $10, children free. Decorative arts and several restored houses. Open daily.
Cape Ann Historical Museum, 27 Pleasant Street, Gloucester; (978) 283-0455, $5, students $3.50. Seascapes, decorative arts and exhibits about life on Cape Ann. Open Tuesday through Saturday.
Halibut Point State Park and Preserve, Gott Avenue off Route 127, Rockport; (978) 546-2997, $2 parking fee. Walking trails, historic quarry and rocky shore. Open daily.
Essex Shipbuilding Museum, 66 Main Street (Route 133), Essex; (978) 768-7541, $4, children $2.50. Working boatyard. Open Wednesday through Sunday, noon to 4 p.m. 

Where to Stay
The Hawthorne Hotel, 18 Washington Square, Salem, (800) 729-7829, (978) 744-4080, fax (978) 745-9842, www
.hawthornehotel.com, has 89 rooms and suites from $104 to $309. It is within walking distance of most Salem attractions and is decorated with reproductions of 19th-century furniture. Small fitness center.

Where to Eat
Many North Shore restaurants feature seafood, but there are other options.
In Salem, the Lobster Shanty, 25 Front Street, (978) 745-5449, offers fish sandwiches and hamburgers for about $5. Open daily.
For more refined dining, the Grapevine, 26 Congress Street, Salem, (978) 745-9335, www.grapevinesalem.com, is often mentioned. Entrees include pumpkin and smoked mozzarella ravioli. Dinner for two with wine is about $75. Open nightly.
In Gloucester, Virgilio's Bakery and Deli, 29 Main Street, (978) 283-5295, has fresh bread and pastries. Sandwiches like eggplant with fresh mozzarella and peppers are about $5. Open Monday to Saturday.
Fifteen miles north of Essex in Newburyport, Scandia, 25 State Street, (978) 462-6271, www.scandiarestaurant.com, serves dishes like haddock stuffed with crab and lobster in a casual, elegant atmosphere. Dinner for two with wine is about $100. Lunch and dinner daily. JAKE MILLER

SECTION: Section 6; Column 1; Magazine Desk; Pg. 38

LENGTH: 2988 words

HEADLINE: His Really Big Show 

BYLINE:  By Adam Shatz; Adam Shatz last wrote for the magazine about the economist Glenn Loury.

 BODY:
On a cool, drizzly spring evening, Okwui Enwezor is sitting in La Frasca, an intimate Italian restaurant in Kassel, Germany. People at neighboring tables, mostly fair-skinned, stare at him as if he were a matinee idol. Enwezor, a tall, long-limbed Nigerian who moves with balletic grace, takes this in stride, nonchalantly ordering a bottle of Champagne. He sticks out here, and not just because he is the best-dressed man in a small provincial city. Kassel is the home of Documenta, the most prestigious exhibition of contemporary art in Europe and perhaps the world, and Enwezor, the show's artistic director this year, has become one of the town's most famous residents. "The Germans are very inward-looking," he says, when I remark upon the startling effect he has on the room. He gazes around him at the sea of blond hair. "You can't really find a cosmopolitan city in Germany, not even Berlin." 
 Enwezor is one of the most influential and controversial curators on the international art scene, but he stumbled into his profession virtually by accident. He has no background in art history and has never held a full-time museum job. He was born 38 years ago in a small city in Nigeria, and his only degree is a B.A. in political science from a college in New Jersey. While living in Brooklyn, he made a name for himself as a poet and supported himself as a waiter and security guard. It wasn't until the mid-90's, after he started up a hip African arts magazine, that museums began asking him to curate shows. Enwezor comes, in short, from a very different place, geographically and intellectually, than most of his curatorial peers. 
 Far from being intimidated by his lack of traditional credentials, however, Enwezor has been emboldened by it. He says he is trying to redefine the ideas of what it means to be a curator, of what kind of work belongs in an art show and of what a museum exhibit is supposed to accomplish. The aim of curating, he argues, is not to be a taste maker but to "produce knowledge" -- not just of art, but of the world in which it is made. As he puts it, "I can't really explain why instead of preparing the next Documenta, I'm not working at the U.N." Enwezor is probably the only curator who has ever been compared to Kofi Annan, and it's not only because he is an African. He sees himself less as a curator than as a free-floating cultural ambassador who just happens to be doing his work in museums. 
Everyone in the art world has an opinion about Enwezor. Glenn D. Lowry, the director of the Museum of Modern Art, calls him "an extraordinarily intelligent and insightful man who has opened many people's eyes." Enwezor's admirers think his exhibits are both thought-provoking and beautiful. But his critics find his taste in art bland and politically doctrinaire, and they argue that it converges all too neatly with the art establishment's radical-chic proclivities. According to the influential and outspoken art critic Dave Hickey, Enwezor is "a perfect product of the system" -- a postcolonial radical who, deep down, shares the values of his Old World peers. "Here's a critic with third-world roots and a party-line Northern European vision of art practice," Hickey says. "It's basically a Protestant view of art, and it's less concerned with art than with the ideas that inform it." 
Complaints have arisen over Enwezor's managerial style, which is messy at best and tyrannical at worst. As one of his friends told me, "Okwui is lucky to have always had people, primarily very capable women, who create order in the midst of whatever chaos he's constructed." But Enwezor has a rare talent for the curatorial theater of promotion. He talks up each of his shows as if it were epoch-making, and Documenta XI, which opens later this week and which he has transformed from a single-site exhibition into a worldwide "constellation" of seminars and happenings, is no exception. As one curator puts it, "Okwui has been able to theorize his practice in a way that makes him seem very grandiose." 
Enwezor is also adept at playing the part of the hypersophisticated expatriate African intellectual. Both his admirers and his detractors evoke not so much a real person as a character of the times -- a curator so demographically perfect, and so polished, that he would have to be invented if he didn't exist already. "If I called central casting and said, 'Send me an international curator,' they'd send me Okwui," Hickey told me. David A. Ross, the former director of the Whitney Museum and a fan of Enwezor's, agreed: "You couldn't have created a fictional character better than Okwui." 
When we had dinner at La Frasca, Enwezor radiated serenity. He chatted authoritatively about German philosophy, Arabic poetry and Italian wines. (He wasn't happy with the bottle we were drinking.) He ordered his meal with curatorial precision: an arugula salad, followed by half-portions of pasta with prawns and sauteed sea bass. ("Am I the only one taking half-portions?" he asked, as if he were disappointed by my lack of creativity.) He seemed a man entirely at peace with himself, unburdened by doubts. "I've always had an incredible sense of my place in the world," he told me, folding his arms around his chest. You would never have guessed that he faced a punishing deadline, with less than two months to go before Documenta opened, or that he had an appointment after dinner: a meeting with advisers in a Documenta van, parked by the side of the road, that would last until 3 in the morning.
Enwezor, a strikingly handsome man, cut an impossibly cool profile in his loose-fitting, black Yves Saint Laurent coat, dark Raf Simons slacks and squeaky leather shoes, which were custom-made at a fashionable London shop. ("Okwui has always had this regal sense of entitlement," a friend says.) He carries two cellphones, a Kassel number and a New York one. His wife, Muna el Fituri, an art therapist who is raising their daughter in their loft in SoHo, is a Libyan-Polish woman raised in France. A product of British boarding schools, Enwezor speaks in a formal, almost aristocratic style, spreading out his syllables in a charmingly affected way. He is the ultimate cosmopolitan, and his nomadic lifestyle embodies the very kind of globalism that he has championed in the art world since he burst upon the scene a decade ago. 
Documenta, which takes place every five years or so, is often described as the Olympics of contemporary art, the show that everyone in the art world has to attend if they want to keep up with what's new. Historically associated with the European and North American avant-garde, it helped make the reputations of artists like Gerhard Richter and Bruce Nauman in the 1960's and 70's. In his proposal, Enwezor argued that it was time for the show to move beyond Kassel, indeed beyond Europe. And move it is exactly what he has done, turning Documenta into a traveling international symposium on art, politics and culture. 
Working with a team of six curators, he has divided Documenta XI into five "platforms." The Kassel exhibit -- the biggest, most sprawling show in Documenta's history -- is the only platform concerned with what most people think of as art. The other platforms, which took place over the last year and a half in Berlin, St. Lucia, Vienna, New Delhi and Lagos, brought together high-profile academics to talk about truth and reconciliation commissions, the future of democracy and other lofty themes. Thomas Wagner, an art writer for the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung and one of Enwezor's toughest critics, has mocked the platforms as a wasteful series of didactic seminars in cultural studies -- the "International Enwezor Tours," he sneers. 
At first glance, Documenta XI seems like a nostalgic return to the banner-waving days of early-90's political art. Wagner has said as much, lashing out at Enwezor for being "interested in art only insofar as it can be attached to topics that circulate in the debates of certain in-crowds." And sure enough, there's no shortage of race-class-and-gender work in Documenta XI, which includes some of that school's most celebrated representatives, notably Mona Hatoum, a London-based Palestinian conceptualist, and Renee Green, a black American installation artist. Conspicuously absent from Enwezor's list, moreover, are white male art stars like Richter, Richard Serra and Matthew Barney. The subjects addressed by the show are almost relentlessly topical: the Rwandan genocide, Palestinian history, United States-Mexico border tensions, racism in Europe and labor disputes in South Africa. More than half the artists on Enwezor's list come from the developing world, and while many of these artists, like Hatoum and Green, have big careers on the international scene, a handful don't even make art, in any traditional sense of the word. 
Huit Facettes, for instance, is a group of Senegalese visual artists who conduct workshops in rural villages. Most of their work comes in the form of slides, videos and photographs documenting the workshops. Le Groupe Amos, an association of ministers, lawyers, doctors and professors in the Congo, makes videos, radio broadcasts and pamphlets promoting human rights, sexual equality and nonviolence. There's not an artist among them. 
Enwezor often talks about his commitment to "work that wages a productive resistance" to the culture industry. But the most intriguing question about him is whether his radical approach is actually establishment-approved. In the art world today, the language of rebellion is in many ways the language of power and ambition, and Enwezor is especially masterly at blurring the lines between the two. Though he speaks in insurgent rhetoric, he is part of an increasingly influential group of international curators, a new establishment that is beginning to feel its influence and to propose its own canon of artists. He is both an outsider and an insider -- or rather, he's an insider precisely because he is an outsider. As Thelma Golden, the deputy director of the Studio Museum in Harlem, put it, "The outside is the new inside." 
What's new about Enwezor is the way he bridges the gap between the art world's two self-appointed vanguards -- one aesthetic, the other ideological. One camp believes that art's future lies in discovering new forms of beauty; the other has argued, no less passionately, that beauty is a bourgeois ruse, that art's future lies in radical political engagement, in breaking down the walls between the museum and the world outside. Enwezor transcends this divide, or carefully walks its fault line, by spotlighting work in which protest and visual pleasure are often deeply interwoven. The political artists Enwezor champions are just as preoccupied with the formal design of their art as with getting their message across. And though Enwezor may utter the word "connoisseur" as if it were a relic of a naive, bygone age, he curates his shows with the kind of painstaking attention that connoisseurs bring to objects they love. 
Enwezor's vision of the world, and of art's place in it, is rooted in his personal history and in the history of his nation. The themes in Documenta XI -- ethnic and social conflict, forced migration, political instability, urban unrest -- are ones that have shaped his own life. Enwezor was born into a prosperous Ibo family in Calabar, a small city in southeastern Nigeria. During the Biafran War, which broke out in 1967, the family moved 45 times. "Through these moments of extremity, of deterritorialization," he says, "I learned what it means to be the Other, even within the rooms of one's own home." After the war ended, in 1970, the country's oil boom began, and Enwezor became aware of a wider world beyond Nigeria. "It became clearer and clearer that one's milieu was international," he recalls. (Enwezor has a habit of referring to himself as "one.") 
In 1982, after a semester at the University of Nigeria, Enwezor moved to the Bronx, where he shared a comfortable one-bedroom apartment with a Nigerian friend. While working toward a bachelor's degree in political science at Jersey City State College, he wrote experimental poetry and hung out below 14th Street with writers, artists and musicians. He began paying close attention to the white club that calls itself the art world, and like any shrewd intellectual -- or businessman's son -- he quickly identified the gaps in the field. There was almost no African art to be found in New York's galleries, even though, as he knew, some of the most exciting artists at work were Africans. 
Rather than wait around for the art world to catch up, Enwezor started a magazine. Teaming up in 1993 with two fellow African critics, he launched Nka from his Brooklyn apartment. It soon became trendy to read Nka, or to at least know of it, and the magazine's success raised the profile of its stylish, forceful editor, who began to turn up at panel discussions on contemporary art, and, no less important, at parties and openings. 
"I never really set out to be a curator," Enwezor says. "But once I started publishing my magazine, I knew very clearly what interventions had to be made." Nka gave him the confidence to curate his own shows, and museums began lining up to give him the opportunity. Most institutions lacked the vaguest idea about art in post-independence Africa, and they were desperate for a guide, preferably a native informant, even if he wasn't professionally trained. After putting on a couple of small museum shows, Enwezor had his breakthrough as a curator of "In/sight," a ravishing exhibit of 30 African photographers that opened in the spring of 1996 at the Guggenheim Museum. 
Though Enwezor was untested, timing worked in his favor. The Guggenheim was scheduled to present "Africa: The Art of a Continent," a survey that was controversial because it included little work from the 20th century. When the show opened at the Royal Academy of Arts in London, it drew fire for ignoring contemporary African art. Enwezor and his fellow curators adroitly positioned themselves in their talks with the Guggenheim as a way to fill the gap created by the arriving show. Perhaps to insulate itself from charges of neocolonialism, the museum embraced his proposal. 
A landmark exhibit despite its intimate scale, "In/sight" heralded a new vision of African art -- a uniquely African vision -- through a distinctly nontraditional medium. The show led directly to Enwezor's appointment as curator of the Johannesburg Biennale, as well as to "The Short Century," his highly praised traveling exhibition on postwar African art and politics. Nine months after the Biennale, he was named artistic director of Documenta XI, beating out several candidates with distinguished careers in major museums. 
Enwezor's rapid ascent through the ranks of the art world has provoked a fair amount of grumbling from those he has passed by. The fact that he is a powerful black man in a field with very few black power brokers adds to the tensions surrounding him, but that is only part of the picture. Enwezor has a distinctly postcolonial understanding of race and a manner of negotiating conflict that makes him something of an enigma to many of the people he encounters. "People in the art world misinterpret him as arrogant because they've never met an African who is assertive," says Salah Hassan, an art historian at Cornell University and a founder of Nka. 
On June 8, when Documenta XI officially opens, Enwezor will be at the peak of his influence in the art world. Yet the show also renders him more vulnerable than ever. He will not be the first Documenta curator to come out of the experience feeling depleted because of the grueling labor it involves and the controversies it invariably generates. Many people in the art world regard Documenta as a career-capping event. It is enshrouded in superstitions, the cruelest of which is that once you've done Documenta, you're creatively spent. "No one survives Documenta," Enwezor told me.
After Documenta closes in September, Enwezor will find himself in a difficult and fascinating predicament. By directing the show, Enwezor has fulfilled every curator's dream, which leaves him in a bit of a bind as he considers his next move. It is hard to imagine him running a museum in the Netherlands, as his Documenta predecessor Catherine David is doing; that wouldn't satisfy his global ambition. Then again, there aren't many art-world jobs that would. When I asked him if he'd consider taking a full-time job as a curator in a museum, he nearly lost his cool: "If you're asking me whether I want to go waste my time in a museum with a show every five, six years, the answer is no, I do not. I have no interest in standing on line." He would almost certainly be interested in directing a major institution, but in order to do that, he may, paradoxically, have to temporarily abandon the art world, so that he can reclaim his outsider status. 
One way of doing that would be to make his mark in Africa. He talks about establishing a think tank somewhere in West Africa -- an international global situation" where artists, historians and social scientists could trade ideas about the kinds of issues discussed in Documenta's platforms. He's extremely vague -- deliberately vague, one suspects -- about where he wants to do this and what he hopes to accomplish. Enwezor could well grow tired of curating art shows and recast himself as an activist, as Huit Facettes and Le Groupe Amos have done. When you ask Enwezor's friends where they see him in 10 years, their answers are more direct -- and still more grandiose. Isaac Julien, an artist in Documenta XI, told me he could easily imagine Enwezor as secretary general of the United Nations. Golden said, "I wouldn't be shocked if he ran for president of Nigeria." Judging by the career he has made for himself so far, he'd be a very savvy campaigner.

HEADLINE: Democrats Say No To Assembly Veteran 

BYLINE:  By STEWART AIN 

 BODY:
ASSEMBLYWOMAN Earlene Hill Hooper insists that a personal grudge against her by a prominent Nassau Democrat was the reason she was denied the party's nomination last month for an eighth term in the 18th Assembly District. But Seretta C. McNight, who won the nomination, said that party leaders simply believed it was "time for a change."
 Democratic leaders said they could not recall when a longtime incumbent had been denied the party's designation. Ms. Hooper is challenging Ms. McNight, a former president of the Roosevelt School Board, in the Sept. 10 primary. Ms. McNight has unsuccessfully run for three offices, twice for the County Legislature and once for the State Senate. 
 Jay Jacobs, who became party chairman in October 2001 after successfully managing Thomas R. Suozzi's primary victory for county executive, said he had done as much arm-twisting as possible in Ms. Hooper's behalf.
"I wanted Earlene Hooper to win and to win for the speaker," he said, referring to Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, who actively supported Ms. Hooper. "But we believe in running an open and fair convention. Those are my values and principles, and I can't compromise them to unduly pressure the convention. I wouldn't do it -- not that anybody was asking me to do it."
Mr. Silver said he supported Ms. Hooper and believes she will win the primary because "she's a friend, a supporter and is right on the issues in her district."
He credited her with pressing the state to take over the failing Roosevelt School District and with getting an additional $6 million in aid each year for the district. "She insisted on the $6 million and would not permit a state takeover of the district without it," Mr. Silver said. 
"She was pushing Mills to do what had to be done," he added, referring to Richard P. Mills, the state education commissioner.
Mr. Suozzi, who won Ms. McNight's support in his primary race against Assemblyman Thomas P. DiNapoli, said that he believed Ms. McNight was "a good person and an effective community advocate."
But Mr. Suozzi said he was supporting Ms. Hooper because "she can get things done in Albany and deliver for the people in Nassau County."
Asked what he thought about Ms. McNight's winning the party's designation, he said: "As Hooper says, everyone is entitled to run, and this is a Democratic system. Primaries are not necessarily a bad thing. I didn't get my party's nomination, and I won the primary."
Ms. McNight, who won the designation by a vote of 124 to 103, got all of the 58 weighted votes from Roosevelt. 
Perre Smalls, a Democratic zone leader in Hempstead, where Ms. Hooper lives, said the vote in his district was 38 to 0 for Ms. McNight. 
"I didn't play a part in the process," Mr. Smalls said. "I told the people that they could make their own decision, and the people clearly stated that they were not happy with the leadership. They said they plan to challenge everybody who does not serve their interests."
Mr. Smalls added that Ms. McNight won their support because "she talks of empowerment, and that resonates with that area."
Ms. McNight, 43, said she decided to run after conducting what she described as a "listening tour" of the district. "When you are as active in our community as I am, it is easy to gain access and to listen to the concerns of residents," she said. "I knew how dissatisfied I was with respect to the leadership that had been lacking in our community, so I wanted to reach out and go to the people to see if they had the same experience."
Ms. McNight said that many people thought that Ms. Hooper was "inaccessible." 
"And then there were the conditions in the 18th with our educational system, with seniors and employment and economic development," she added. "I found that there were a whole lot of folks who thought like I did -- that it's time for a change, time for representative government."
Ms. Hooper, who was first elected in March 1988, accused Hezekiah Brown of mounting a campaign to deny her the nomination. Mr. Brown, the deputy county executive for general operations, "has been displeased with me on a personal level for over a decade," Ms. Hooper said. 
"Mr. Brown has a personal issue with Earlene, not the Assemblywoman Earlene," Ms. Hooper continued. "Mr. Brown said I have done things to him, but he has not told me what they are."
Asked to comment, Mr. Brown said: "I don't care to respond. I don't think I should make a statement."
Ms. Hooper said Mr. Brown "organized a small group of disgruntled Roosevelt citizens, and they, with their weighted votes, denied me the party designation."
"The group from Roosevelt is comprised of those persons who were removed from the Roosevelt School Board in 1996 and 2002," she said.
Ms. McNight was president of the Roosevelt board in 1996 when she and the rest of the board were removed by the state as a result of legislation Ms. Hooper sponsored. A state panel then ran the district until new elections were held a few months later. Ms. McNight, along with other ousted board members and former board members, were barred by the legislation from running.
Roger Corbin, Democrat of Westbury, a member of the Nassau County Legislature, said the Hooper-McNight race was shaping up as a grudge match with Ms. McNight blaming Ms. Hooper "for all the ills of Roosevelt."
Ms. Hooper said the fact that Roosevelt residents passed the school budget on May 21 was proof that her stands on the school district have support in the community. 
"I just delivered $12 million to the Roosevelt School District this year, and three schools at no cost to the community that by law must be ready for occupancy by Aug. 15, 2005," she said. "This was my idea, my legislation, and I fought for it alone. I call that leadership based on efficiency and experience. Look at the results. The people said yes to the school budget because they knew that the assemblywoman had kept her word."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Assemblywoman Earlene Hill Hooper in her Albany office. She will face Seretta C. McNight in the Sept. 10 Democratic primary. (Will Waldron for The New York Times)
