HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE; 
At Least in One Respect, Washington Is a Stable Place to Do Business

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLUSHA 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
Underpinned by a recession-proof federal government, the demand for office space in the District of Columbia has remained strong at a time when many markets around the country have grown distinctly softer. In fact, successful office developments are leading to the revival of once-neglected areas on the eastern end of downtown Washington.
 "The federal government stabilizes the economy here," said Brian T. McVay, a senior managing director at Cushman & Wakefield, the national real estate brokerage and services company. "You do not see 40 to 50 percent rent spikes. You do see a steady rent escalation of 3 to 5 percent a year, which is why Washington is always one of the top two or three markets in the country." 
 Despite a one percentage point increase in the vacancy rate, to 5.7 percent in the first quarter, office rental rates have remained firm, with the average asking rate increasing 7 percent from a year ago, to $39.50 a square foot a year. 
This predictability has attracted the attention of investors, who paid an average of $244.85 a square foot for properties in the first quarter, an increase of 28 percent from the level in 2001, according to Cushman & Wakefield. The city has 107 million square feet of office space that is privately owned, with the federal government leasing 17.8 million. In addition, the government owns 32.8 million square feet.
Although private-sector employment has surpassed the number of government jobs in recent years, the stability of government demand for real estate provides a firm basis of demand. But it is also a quirky market. Because of rules that limit the height of buildings to less than the dome of the Capitol (about 130 feet downtown) architecture here is largely undramatic boxes. 
Because of security concerns, Pennsylvania Avenue, a major east-west artery, remains blocked in front of the White House, snarling already heavy traffic. Because there is parkland to the north and south of the White House, the closing of the avenue put a multiblock plug in the middle of the city.
"People have to decide whether they want to be east or west of the White House," said Audrey Z. Cramer, an executive vice president of Cushman & Wakefield. 
Increasingly they are looking east.
For decades the city's commercial core ran along K Street from 22nd Street in the west to 13th Street in the east. Although the prime retail area of Washington, including the onetime Garfinckel's and Woodward & Lothrop department stores, lay to the east, the area had little allure for office tenants and not much development took place there in the years after the civil unrest of 1968.
It was the lawyers who got things going, real estate executives said. Rapidly growing law firms were outgrowing the relatively confined spaces in the office buildings lining K Street and were looking for a place to put hundreds of partners and associates, even if it meant moving to an unfamiliar part of town.
"The law firms started moving out of K Street in the late 1980's," said Thomas M. Fulcher Jr., a senior vice president in the Washington office of Julien J. Studley, a brokerage firm that has specialized in representing tenants. "These were big deals," he said. "One firm, Wilmer Cutler, took 450,000 square feet of space."
One reason the move was relatively easy was the presence of the Metro, Washington's quiet, clean subway system that can quickly deliver commuters from the suburbs to the heart of downtown.
The area of town known as the East End got a further lift in 1997 when the MCI Center opened on F Street between 6th and 7th Streets. The arena is home to two professional sports teams, the hockey Capitals and the basketball Wizards and is where the Georgetown University Hoyas play. Concerts and other events are held there as well.
The center helped lure people downtown in the evenings and convinced them that the streets were safe. "The arena is driving development because people will hang out in the area now," said Brian C. Sullivan, a retail specialist at Cushman & Wakefield. 
Now a vast $750 million convention center is under construction just to the north and due to open next year. While no final decisions have been made, plans are being drawn up to convert the existing convention center, which is scheduled to be torn down, into a Lincoln Center-like cultural hub.
Real estate executives say the recent changes in political leadership of the city and the rebuilding of municipal finances have gone a long way toward improving the confidence of investors and businessmen.
Increased street traffic is attracting restaurants and retailers to the area and particularly to F Street, the traditional retail focal point. One developer is proceeding with a plan to restore the 100-year-old Woodward & Lothrop store, with its elaborate, landmarked facade, as a mixed retail and office development. The store, at 10th and F Streets, was long the anchor for the F Street corridor and may again fill that function.
Douglas Jemal, the head of Douglas Development, which is doing the conversion of the building universally known as Woodie's, said the city was trying to recapture some of the sales lost to suburban malls. "In 1950, 90 percent of all the retail sales in the metropolitan area were in the District," he said. "In 2002, it is about 2 percent."
Although the existence of the Metro subway means that his location, as he puts it "is 15 minutes away from five million people," he said the construction of the subway downtown in the 1970's and 80's had a lot to do with a retail decline that ended with all the major department stores except Hecht's disappearing.
"They tore up the streets and displaced merchants -- everything was a Metro bomb zone," Mr. Jemal said. "The merchants moved to the suburbs and never came back."
He said he planned to install a mix of nationally branded retailers in the basement and first floor of the 550,000-square-foot building and office tenants in the eight higher floors. The stores, which may include Crate & Barrel, H & M and the Container Store, would replicate the diversity of goods once offered in department stores.
Other, smaller buildings in the area are being redeveloped. To preserve the look and feel of the area, developers are being required to limit the scale of their projects. On some streets in the East End, building facades stand alone supported by steel framework as builders prepare to erect new structures and re-attach the facades.
Retail and restaurant development is changing the look of the East End and making it a more attractive place to live, real estate executives say. Some 10,000 units of housing are under construction or in advanced planning in the downtown area, which could transform it from a 9-to-5 office location to a 24-hour neighborhood.
There has been some slippage of government agencies to the suburbs, where real estate prices are cheaper. Many health-related agencies migrated to the Maryland suburbs where the National Institutes of Health is located, and some related to the military headed to northern Virginia where the Department of Defense has its headquarters in the Pentagon.
But military contractors have begun moving into the southeastern part of the city as a result of a decision to move the Navy's major procurement agency to the old Navy Yard along the Potomac River.
After flirting with a move to Maryland, the Securities and Exchange Commission recently signed a lease for 650,000 square feet of space in Station Place, a planned 1.5 million-square-foot development by the Louis Dreyfus Property Group adjacent to the Union Station railroad terminal.
A presidential executive order bars cabinet-level agencies from leaving the city, said the District's congressional delegate, Eleanor Holmes Norton. She said she uses her position on watchdog subcommittees to make sure that lesser-ranking agencies do not stray.
"There is some interest in backup computer space in other locations since 9/11, but it is expensive and comes out of the agency's budget," she said. "Most agencies want to be close to Congress and 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue."

HEADLINE: Canadians Are Focusing on Curbing Inflation 

BYLINE:  By BERNARD SIMON 

DATELINE: TORONTO, June 4 

 BODY:
Pointing to an unexpectedly robust economy, the Bank of Canada raised its crucial overnight interest rate today for the second time in less than two months.
 The central bank's lifting of the rate, from 2.25 percent to 2.5 percent, indicates that the bank is more concerned that accelerating growth will unleash new inflationary pressures than about political uncertainties stemming from Sunday's abrupt ouster of Paul Martin, the finance minister. 
 Canadian banks responded to the Bank of Canada's move by raising their prime lending rate from 4 percent to 4.25 percent.
In today's statement, the central bank said that "with the economy showing strong momentum and moving back toward full production capacity more quickly than had been expected," the bank would take whatever action was necessary to hold the inflation rate to its 2 percent target. The core inflation rate, which excludes volatile food and energy prices, accelerated to 2.2 percent in the year ended in April. 
Statistics Canada reported last week that the economy grew at an annual rate of 6 percent, after adjusting for inflation, in the first quarter of 2002, up from 2.9 percent the previous three months. Just two months ago, the central bank estimated that first-quarter growth would be 4.5 percent.
Although Canada's economy has become increasingly integrated with that of the United States, growth has recently outstripped that in the United States. Real gross domestic product in the United States expanded 5.6 percent in the first quarter.
George Vasic, chief economist at UBS Bunting Warburg in Toronto, said the divergence resulted because there was "less exuberance" in Canada in the late 1990's and Canadian businesses were now cutting back less aggressively than were their American counterparts.
Mr. Vasic said that tax cuts announced by Mr. Martin before the last federal election in fall 2000 and carried out last year had also "kept us on an even keel."
Aron Gampel, deputy chief economist at the Bank of Nova Scotia, said that with interest rates low, Canadian consumers "have really decided to go on an epic shopping spree." For instance, sales of new motor vehicles jumped 10 percent in May from a year earlier, the fourth monthly double-digit gain so far this year.
Craig Wright, chief economist at the Royal Bank of Canada, described today's statement by the central bank as "a little more hawkish" than in the recent past. Echoing several other analysts, he forecast that the bank would push up interest rates by about another 1.5 percentage points this year, with more increases probable in 2003.
Meanwhile, the government has moved quickly to reassure financial markets that Mr. Martin's departure will not affect its economic policies. Prime Minister Jean Chretien dismissed Mr. Martin because of his efforts to rally support within the Liberal Party for his bid to succeed Mr. Chretien as party leader.
In a speech on Monday night, Mr. Martin's successor as finance minister, John Manley, said: "Although individuals might change within government, our priorities and objectives have not and will not change. That means balanced budgets, reduced debt, low and stable inflation, tax cuts and key investments." Mr. Manley is also deputy prime minister.
Although Mr. Martin has been widely praised as one of the best finance ministers in recent Canadian history, his departure has had little impact on financial markets. "Nothing is going to change with Mr. Martin on the sidelines," Mr. Vasic said.
The Canadian dollar, which has firmed markedly against the United States dollar the last month, was above 65 United States cents today, a bit stronger than the level it settled at on Monday. It touched a low of 62.1 cents in January.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Paul Martin was recently removed as finance minister of Canada. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: A New Welfare Policy for New York 

 BODY:
Mayor Michael Bloomberg took a courageous stand when he announced that he was moving away from a welfare policy fixated on reducing the number of people on welfare toward one that would encourage education and training and provide vital support like child care. The new policy will do more to help New York City's welfare recipients find real, lasting jobs. It also reflects a growing awareness that the Giuliani administration's so-called "work-first" policies were less effective than they might have been, and in some instances harmful. 
 Under Mr. Giuliani, the welfare rolls were dramatically reduced. But a shortage of training and education programs for former welfare recipients left many of them with make-work or dead-end jobs that keep them in poverty. It is possible to train workers for jobs that actually exist, though the city will need to confer with the business community more closely than it has. 
 The Giuliani administration's indifference to job training was further reflected in its response to the 1998 Workforce Investment Act, which was aimed primarily at low-income and displaced workers. The city failed to spend as much as $100 million during the initial phase of the program, which was aimed at helping workers acquire marketable skills. Local governments were supposed to set up one-stop centers where the jobless could find a full range of services. Workers could learn English or receive vouchers to underwrite training for specific jobs or instruction leading to a junior college degree in, say, computer technology. Most cities have since set up systems to move displaced workers into real jobs. New York is known in Congress as having one of the worst records in the country. 
The city's disappointing record with former welfare recipients was revealed in a City Council hearing last month when officials were forced to produce statistics showing how many unemployed workers and former welfare recipients had been placed in lasting jobs. Council members listened in disbelief as a deputy commissioner for the Human Resources Administration testified that the city's elaborate and expensive job training and placement services had found jobs lasting more than 90 days for only 10 percent of those people who went through processing. 
The 90-day mark is significant because that is one of the points at which job-search agencies get paid for placing people. Some critics suspect that placement companies manipulate the process so that they get their payment and then dump job candidates back into the market. 
Mr. Bloomberg has wisely moved to cut back placement contracts for agencies that have done a poor job. The main question now is what will happen to the various streams of federal money that are intended to move idle workers and former welfare recipients into the economy. Details of the new policy are not yet clear. But Mr. Bloomberg is clearly on the right track.

HEADLINE: Facing Veto Threat, Senate Debates Counterterror Funds 

BYLINE:  By CARL HULSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 4 

 BODY:
The Senate today took up a $31.4 billion emergency counterterrorism measure that Republican critics called too expensive and replete with spending that had little or nothing to do with responding to the Sept. 11 attacks. The White House threatened a veto.
 The administration, lawmakers and outside analysts said the measure, which exceeded President Bush's request by $4 billion and what the House approved last month by $2 billion, included items like relief for New England fishermen, coral-reef mapping in Hawaii and a new home for museum specimens. 
 "Nonemergency pork barrel spending continues unabated," said Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona and a Senate scold on the subject. "It is unfortunate that in a time of war my colleagues cannot curb their appetite." 
Democrats defended the spending as justified and said critics were nitpicking a measure that would improve national security.
"Why some people would come to the floor and attempt to be critical over monies that are for the defense of our homeland is beyond me," said Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia and chairman of the Appropriations Committee.
As debate began, the Senate moved quickly to respond to a lobbying campaign by US Airways against restrictions on airline loans created after Sept. 11, easily passing an amendment that would remove the limits and help the airline seek federal aid.
Senators were also considering using the bill as a vehicle to resolve other sticky financial matters, including a raise of the federal debt ceiling.
Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., director of the Office of Management and Budget, delivered the administration's view on the bill in a luncheon meeting with Republican senators. "The president requested all that is needed and all that is affordable," Mr. Daniels told reporters later.
In carving out a negotiating position to push the spending level down, the administration used tough language in a statement, saying it "strongly opposes this bill." 
Republican leaders also took aim at the supplemental bill, with Senator Trent Lott, the minority leader, telling a group of visiting builders that some in Congress were treating the terrorism emergency "like a cookie jar."
Representative Dick Armey, the Texas Republican who is House majority leader, also ridiculed aspects of the bill, singling out "spending like $2 million for worm collection, enough said."
In fact, the $2 million will go to the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of Natural History for planning of a new storage facility for animal specimens in the Maryland suburbs.
Also singled out as extraneous was $11 million in economic assistance to be provided to fishermen in four New England states who suffered losses due to new fishing restrictions.
Tom Schatz, president of Citizens Against Government Waste, pointed to the $2.5 million for coral-reef mapping. "Last I heard, Al Qaeda was not swimming around coral reefs," he said.
Supporters of the measure in the Democratic-controlled Senate said that some provisions being criticized had been originated by Republicans and that the bill was a serious attempt to improve domestic security.
"It is time we understand this bill is important," said Senator Harry Reid, Democrat of Nevada and the assistant majority leader. He said that money in the measure would go toward food safety, border security, cybersecurity, postal protection and guaranteeing the safety of the water supply. --------------------

Air Hijacking Drill
DENVER, June 4 (AP) -- Two jets packed with people took off today from Salt Lake City and Whidbey Island Naval Air Station at Oak Harbor, Wash., in a twin hijacking drill designed to improve coordination among American and Canadian agencies. Fighter jets from the North American Aerospace Defense Command scrambled to respond to the simulated hijackings, and ran through several scenarios, including one that involved shooting down the planes.

HEADLINE: Market Place; 
Edison Schools Gets Reprieve: $40 Million In Financing

BYLINE:  By JACQUES STEINBERG and DIANA B. HENRIQUES 

 BODY:
Edison Schools Inc., the nation's largest commercial manager of public schools, announced yesterday that it had arranged to borrow the $40 million that it needs to finance its takeover of 20 struggling public schools in Philadelphia. But the company will pay a stiff price -- interest rates that are expected to range into the low teens.
 The deal ends, at least for now, a financial crisis that had threatened to derail Edison's expansion into Philadelphia, by far the largest and most ambitious experiment in the short and stormy history of private management of public schools. 
 It also buys time for the company's founder, H. Christopher Whittle, to try to demonstrate that public schools can be operated at a profit, although he has not done so since Edison started managing schools in 1995. While the infusion seems to assure that Edison will be able to open its new and existing schools in the fall, the company's financial condition remains uncertain. 
With high overhead and start-up costs, Edison consumes a large amount of cash each year. Without profits, it will continually need financing to increase its roster of schools and repay its debts. Edison will use some of the new money to expand its presence in about a dozen other school districts in September, including Indianapolis and Kansas City, Mo. But its primary focus in raising the money has been Philadelphia, because of its scale and its significance in the debate over the role of for-profit companies in public education. 
"This fulfills our promise to Philadelphia," Mr. Whittle said yesterday. "But mostly, it removes what was a very significant uncertainty for the company and our customers." 
Edison will receive $30 million in loans from Chelsey Capital, a New York investment fund started by Stuart D. Feldman, a venture capitalist. Chelsey approached Edison through its general counsel, William B. Wachtel, a New York lawyer whose father, Harry, was a legal adviser to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and whose own clients have included the Lefrak Organization and the family that founded Zabar's, the food store.
The younger Mr. Wachtel, who joined with Martin Luther King 3d in 1999 to found the Drum Major Institute for Public Policy, an organization committed to advancing civil rights, said in an interview last night that Chelsey was helping to finance Edison "with the firm belief it will bear two dividends -- one, in terms of an economic return; two, helping to see the public schools in America get some very-much-needed help." 
"We firmly believe," Mr. Wachtel said, "that this is exactly the opportunity Edison presented." He added that he had been friends for 20 years with Benno C. Schmidt Jr., the chairman of Edison. 
The remaining $10 million will come from Merrill Lynch, Edison's longtime investment adviser, which had already extended a $35 million line of credit to the company.
The loans, although expensive, nevertheless seemed to encourage investors. Edison's shares closed yesterday at $1.60, up more than 60 percent since Monday's close of 98 cents but still 90 percent below its January levels of about $20 a share.
Word of the deal was greeted with relief in many circles in Philadelphia, where officials had made Edison's assignment contingent on raising the cash it needs to buy new computers and textbooks, and train teachers -- upfront expenses that Edison must try to recoup from its revenues from the district. Edison and the district are still negotiating how much Edison will be paid. 
"The last thing we would need is significant disruption or significant uncertainty about the plans we're trying to implement," said Michael Masch, a vice president for budget and management at the University of Pennsylvania who is one of five members of the state panel operating the Philadelphia district.
But Mr. Masch and others in Philadelphia expressed caution, noting that the new financing, while critical in the short run, does not answer the question of whether Edison's business plan is viable in the long run.
"It's the same as the average citizen who is able to apply for six credit cards," said Jerry T. Jordan, a vice president of the Philadelphia Federation of Teachers, which has opposed Edison's presence in the city. If Edison were to exhaust its credit, Mr. Jordan said, then schoolchildren might face sudden belt-tightening. "Our kids can't afford to have the belt tightened any more than it already is," he added.
Edison, which educates about 75,000 students in 22 states, has relied on the sale of fresh shares to finance its rapid expansion since it began managing schools. But that option evaporated this spring, when a regulatory investigation and widespread investor disappointment -- Edison had indicated that it would get more than twice as many schools in Philadelphia as it did -- drove the company's stock to lunch-money levels.
"We knew this would be costly, and it was," Mr. Whittle said yesterday morning, after negotiating through the night and finally getting to the handshake stage at dawn. 
Edison has traditionally paid top dollar to borrow -- on some loans, as much as 20 percent -- and this occasion is no exception. Although the final terms of the deal have not yet been announced, Edison expects to pay interest rates ranging as high as the low teens, Mr. Whittle said. By contrast, the national average rate for home equity credit lines, which roughly parallels a commercial line of credit, is 5.35 percent.
Like a consumer, Edison has pledged substantial assets as collateral, including the loans it has made to help charter schools finance construction. Although the deal's fine print is not yet available, Edison's creditors could wind up taking over those school mortgages if Edison were unable to repay its debts.
Mr. Whittle said that although the new lines of credit were expensive, the deal was not as damaging to shareholders as would have been the case if Edison tried to raise the $40 million by selling new stock at recent prices. Besides promising to pay high interest rates and pledging substantial collateral, Edison also gave Chelsey Capital and Merrill Lynch a contract, called a warrant, that gives them the right to buy up to 10.7 million Edison shares for $1 apiece.
Edison is one of seven outside entities, including the University of Pennsylvania and Temple University, that have been assigned responsibility for managing 42 struggling public schools in Philadelphia this fall. But with nearly 15,000 students in 20 schools, Edison will be running more than twice the number of schools it manages in any other district, and at least four times any other entity in Philadelphia.
In the next few weeks, Edison and the other vendors are expected to sign contracts with the state panel overseeing the district that will specify how much vendors will be paid per pupil. The organizations will then begin the process of preparing those schools for next fall's openings. 

GRAPHIC: Photo: H. Christopher Whittle, right, the founder of Edison Schools, addressing the board recently. The stock has fallen from about $20 to $1.60. (G. Paul Burnett/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Speaker Watches Backyard In Battles on Tax Incentives 

BYLINE:  By SHAILA K. DEWAN 

 BODY:
One of the things holding up approval of the city's $400 million tax package in Albany is a $3 million disagreement, according to state and city officials. The Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, has said that a tax incentive zone for business investment should encompass everything below Houston Street.
 Mr. Silver said the Senate wants the zone to be confined to below Canal Street, a difference of roughly 1.5 square miles and $3 million in tax revenue. Complicating matters is the fact that Mr. Silver represents Lower Manhattan, and his district extends to a few blocks above Houston. 
 "He's looking basically for his own little tax package in his district," said John McArdle, a spokesman for Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader, adding that the issue was not holding up the legislation. 
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg supports Mr. Silver's position, a spokesman said.
The quibbling is but one of many reasons that have been offered for the delay in passing the city's package, a delay that has already hurt the city. But it also illustrates the odd position Mr. Silver has found himself in since Sept. 11. 
Mr. Silver is the most powerful politician from the city in Albany, and thus perceived as an important voice for the city's needs. But providing aid to businesses and residents in ravaged Lower Manhattan is in effect the same as providing benefits to Mr. Silver's constituents. 
Mr. Silver has not gone out of his way to dispel that impression. He has made posters, featuring a photo of himself, advertising three periods of sales-tax-free shopping downtown, the first of which begins on Sunday. He persuaded the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation to expand the area eligible for grants to include Chinatown and Little Italy. Then he followed up with letters in three languages telling residents that they could now apply for $1,000 each if they would stay put for two years.
Mr. Silver said his efforts had only one motivation. "We are trying to get it done so that the financial engine of this state is repaired," he said, adding indignantly, "Our ability to provide the Senate with the pork that they exist for is very dependent on the revenue that we generate."
Some have perceived Mr. Silver's interest as limited to what he can do to help his constituents and political allies like Unite, the garment workers' union, whose industry is centered in Chinatown. But others say that with Wall Street interests, the World Financial Center and TriBeCa well represented in planning for downtown, Mr. Silver has been a needed flag carrier for residents with less of a voice.
"I think the press has been unfairly cynical about Silver, who I think is absolutely serious and committed on representing the interests of people that he feels will otherwise be ignored," said Kathryn S. Wylde, president of the New York City Partnership and Chamber of Commerce.
Thanks to the speaker's urging, Madelyn Wils, the chairwoman of Community Board 1, became the only resident of Lower Manhattan to serve on the board of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, which controls much of the federal money flowing in. 
But Mr. Silver's power to do anything at all has been closely circumscribed. Gov. George E. Pataki, not the Legislature or the mayor, controlled the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, although Mr. Silver, who has spent 26 years representing the district, has sent a representative to every meeting. 
His staff argues that the speaker has consistently anticipated problems and has worked tirelessly to ensure that agencies mesh and Washington comes through with aid. His aides said that it was his blueprint, they point out, that initially laid out a larger role for the mayor, which Governor Pataki eventually agreed to allow. Mr. Silver had, aides said, the first hearing on air quality, and elected officials from Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton to the City Council followed suit. 
Yet Mr. Silver has been left to do things like issue news releases that say: "The governor plans later today to announce $20 million in economic development grants for small businesses in Chinatown, Little Italy, the Orchard Street area and all of Lower Manhattan. These grants are part of an economic development package that I insisted upon."

HEADLINE: General Motors Chairman Announces He'llRetire Next Year 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 4 

 BODY:
John F. Smith Jr. said today that he would step down next year as chairman of General Motors when he reaches the company's retirement age of 65.
 During his decade-long tenure at the top of the world's largest automaker, Mr. Smith was credited with greatly improving efficiency and transforming G.M. from a disparate group of competing brands to a unified company. Of late, the company has even halted a long decline in market share. 
 But Mr. Smith was also criticized for having no eye for catchy designs. Analysts praise Rick Wagoner, who took over as chief executive in 2000, for hiring Robert A. Lutz, the former Chrysler president, as vice chairman and resident taste maker. 
"G.M. has come a long way from the dark days of the early '90's, and I take enormous satisfaction that I am leaving the company in good hands," Mr. Smith said at the shareholder meeting in Wilmington, Del.
Though the board recently waived its retirement policy to hire Mr. Lutz, 70, Mr. Smith said he would retire in April and help his son run a small grocery business on Cape Cod. No successor was named, though Mr. Wagoner is a likely candidate.
"I've got 42 years in," Mr. Smith said in an interview. "I'm ready to go."
He started working at a G.M. plant in Framingham, Mass., while working on a masters in business administration at Boston University. He worked for the financial operation and at posts in Europe and Canada, and oversaw international operations. 
If the company can maintain its profit and sales momentum, Wall Street will view Mr. Smith's tenure as a success. Last year, G.M. was the only Big Three automaker to make money. Earlier this week, an initial quality survey by J. D. Power & Associates ranked G.M. third in the industry, the highest for a domestic automaker since the study's methodology changed in 1998. 
"What I'd give him credit for is dismantling General Motors as we knew it," said Gary Lapidus, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs. "Jack took on the confederacy of car companies that was General Motors and turned it into one company with six brands."
Mr. Smith said "it wasn't rocket science that told us we had a great opportunity to centralize." 
"We have a manufacturing plan that is consistent across all of our manufacturing operations," he added, while earlier "we probably had eight or nine different plans." 
Mr. Smith also had a less domineering personality than previous executives and played a central role in establishing a joint venture with Toyota in the 1980's. 
"Because Jack had spent so much time outside of Detroit, he was much broader in his thinking and less insular," said Wendy B. Needham, an analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston. "He brought the Toyota principles over and understood the need for lean manufacturing."
Analysts are skeptical of some of his biggest foreign deals, like the purchase of 20 percent of Fiat. Mr. Smith has also not been much liked by environmental groups, who watched G.M. continue to lead battles against higher fuel economy standards. John DeCicco, a senior fellow at Environmental Defense, called Mr. Smith's environmental record "utterly undistinguished."
But most criticism focused on the blandness of G.M. products during most of his tenure.
"It's a mixed bag," said Gerald Meyers, the former chief executive of American Motors, now part of DaimlerChrysler. 
"On the good side, he was at the helm when the company stabilized and, of late, stopped the losses," he said. "On the other side, he was unable to improve its market penetration and showed an extraordinary skill in spitting out lousy products, one right after the other."
The company has shown glimmers of attitude with newer vehicles, and Mr. Lutz has Detroit buzzing about G.M.'s invigorated designs.
"I spent the last half of my career in turnaround operations, first in Europe and then in North America," Mr. Smith said. "Hopefully, the next 10 years will be to the upside."

HEADLINE: ARTS ABROAD; 
Commerce Follows Artists Into the SoHo of Shanghai

BYLINE:  By Anna Esaki-Smith 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, June 5 

 BODY:
An artists' community is growing here along the meandering Suzhou Creek, which empties into the Huangpu River at the northern tip of this city's riverside esplanade. Abandoned waterfront warehouses, hulking memorials to the manufacturing days of Shanghai, provide artists with huge work spaces.
 Last year newspapers heralded the return of fish to the creek, suggesting that an ambitious billion-dollar city cleanup had improved upon a past when raw sewage and chemicals were routinely dumped into its waters. More recently, vast apartment complexes have sprung up in a place where residents used to keep their windows shut year-round because of the stench. 
 This creekside area that has been revitalized is often called Shanghai's SoHo. But as was the case with its namesake in Manhattan, the tug of commercial possibilities may uproot the growing artists' community. The land beneath the warehouses containing studios and galleries has recently been sold to developers, artists say, and the warehouses could be razed for commercial development and a park. 
"We live in a commerce-driven society," said Li Liang, the owner of Eastlink Gallery, which covers 6,500 square feet on the second floor of a former grain warehouse along Suzhou Creek. "You try to do new things, influence society, but in the end you pretty much know what the results will be."
Two years ago the Shanghai Biennial, a government-sponsored art show designed to put the city on the cultural connoisseurs' map, took place at two sites in town, but a band of intrepid artists with no official ties put on a series of their own shows, including one at Eastlink.
Their exhibitions included a video of three artists walking around town as their blood dripped into tubes from catheters in their arms, and a live performance of a diaper-clad artist floating down the Huangpu in a plastic bubble. Some of the shows were shut down by city authorities, which frayed the relationship between the local government and rebel artists.
The art at Eastlink is not the sort favored by the nouveau riche of China. Some of it is installation art, like a pyramid of layered blue-green glass shown at an exhibition earlier this year, paired with a television screen enclosed in a wooden box. Mr. Li said he focused more on exposing people to forms of modern art than on actually selling it. Officials at the Shanghai Cultural Bureau would not comment on development plans for the Suzhou Creek area. 
Teng Kun-yen, 52, a Taiwanese architect, also has a vision about how to marry art with commerce as he works in a former rice warehouse thought to have once belonged to a local gangster. He has given city officials his proposal to transform 30 waterfront warehouses into eight cultural centers focusing on music, fashion, architecture and other arts. Although he doesn't know the status of his proposal, he said he felt that some officials might be leaning in his direction. He said his hopes were buoyed by the suspension of plans to build a garbage-disposal plant next to his studio, where three old buildings were demolished. 
He admitted, however, that conflict seemed to reign. City and district authorities are unclear about how to develop the Suzhou Creek area, Mr. Teng said, and are "entangled in disputes."
The warehouse containing Mr. Teng's studio was built in 1933 and has an Art Deco facade, massive wooden beams and high ceilings. Mr. Teng spent around $100,000 renovating the roughly 25,000-square-foot space, and the yearly rent is just over $40,000. The infrastructure was so solid that little basic reconstruction was needed. 
The appeal of the warehouses is not just their large size and affordability, but their embodiment of Shanghai's history as a bustling international trading port. Mr. Teng said he believed that his building was designed by Americans.
In the early 1990's many old factories along the creek closed or their operations moved to rural areas as the state-run economy of China began to implode and Shanghai started to reinvent itself as a financial center. 
During the subsequent development boom here, blocks of historic buildings were razed to make room for modern offices. Many people fear that the same fate awaits the warehouses.
But Mr. Teng said he saw a promising precedent in the preservation of the hall where the Communist Party was born and of nearby buildings in central Shanghai, which now house upscale restaurants and cafes. If the government wants to go ahead with a preservation project, "the speed of doing things is unimaginable," Mr. Teng said, adding, "Democratic countries can't do that." 
In a last-ditch effort to save the historic warehouse area, preservationists are mounting a letter-writing campaign to this city's mayor. Even if construction of modern buildings gains momentum, there is optimism that some buildings will be preserved. Most artists realize, however, that the lure of commerce over culture may be too mighty for city authorities to resist. 
A woman who works at a gallery in the Suzhou Creek district said, "Only a sliver of hope remains." 

GRAPHIC: Photo: Teng Kun-yen envisions transforming warehouses into a cultural hub in Shanghai. (Yan Weihuang/Chuech Studio)

HEADLINE: POP REVIEW; 
Funky Mystic Who Longs For Freedom Of All Kinds

BYLINE:  By JON PARELES 

 BODY:
Funk has its share of pragmatists who just want to make people dance. It also has mystics like Meshell Ndegeocello, who hear sex and revolution, culture and nature in the ways instruments mesh to share a groove. Her set on Sunday night at the Bowery Ballroom was a series of unhurried vamps that left room for her to sing, to rap, to talk and to moan. She was introducing songs from her new album, "Cookie: The Anthropological Mixtape" (Maverick), persuading and seducing side by side. 
 Ms. Ndegeocello has a lot on her mind. "God bless America," she mused. "Why just America?" 
 Her new single, "Pocketbook," observes a woman with money in her pocketbook, an eye on the world and the urge to "shake that thing." Other songs ponder bisexual flirtations, success and the cliches of hip-hop video; in "God, Fear, Money," she envisions a returned Jesus thrown in jail while the Devil appears on MTV's "Total Request Live." 
What her songs share is a longing for freedom of all kinds: civil, economic, sexual. She sees obstacles, but she is too hard-headed to gripe. With her deep, husky voice, Ms. Ndegeocello matter-of-factly observes the follies around her, but then she lets herself sing, dropping her defenses to melt into intimacy. In her songs, common sense and sensuality keep close company. "I ain't gonna pay your rent/ 'Cause all I got is love," she sang.
Funk is the songs' universe: their pulse, their colors, their atmosphere. Ms. Ndegeocello, who played bass every so often during her set, knows funk from the rhythm section on up, and she can make even the slowest tempos dance. She and her band look to other funk mystics -- George Clinton, Marvin Gaye, Prince, latter-day Miles Davis -- who used wide-open spaces and jazz harmonies, but she comes up with her own hybrids. 
In the course of her set, she led the band in funk with the snapping beat of Washington's go-go music and funk that oozed like a bubbling tar pit. She led funk that twinkled with jazz chords on electric piano and funk that bristled with fuzz-tone guitar. She led funk that throbbed deep and low, funk that rolled in as smoothly as a fog bank and funk that slithered with rattlesnake cymbal accents. 
Before Ms. Ndegeocello sang "Earth," which is full of vows like "let my sweet, sweet ocean caress your shore," she had her spotlight turned off, as if she wanted to disappear into the groove. Her fans were ready to join her, dancing along.

HEADLINE: SoHo Design Store Closes After 20 Years 

BYLINE:  By MARIANNE ROHRLICH 

 BODY:
AD HOC SOFTWARES, the original resource for industrial-style housewares, is going out of business on June 23. The closing comes two years after its unsuccessful move off West Broadway, SoHo's main shopping drag. 
 Ad Hoc, now on Wooster Street, opened in SoHo in 1982, then virgin territory for retailers, to sell merchandise like Metro Wire shelving, restaurant-grade dinnerware and laboratory glassware. Industrial buildings were being developed for residential use, but the neighborhood was still mainly inhabited by artists and designers living in large manufacturing lofts. "SoHo was going gangbusters then," said Judith Kress Auchincloss, who owns the store with Julia McFarlane. 
 Joan Kron, a co-author with Suzanne Slesin of "High Tech," the bible of industrial style, said: "It was a time when for design purists, finding a plain black shower curtain was nirvana. Ad Hoc was the only place to find these things."
Ms. Kron admired the owners' taste and fast reflexes, but said that inevitably the big stores -- Bloomingdale's, Macy's and even Bed Bath & Beyond -- were jumping on the same trends. "Ad Hoc became like roadkill," she said succinctly. "Even though everyone stole from their style, nobody ever did it as well as they did."
But neighborhoods and styles change. Ad Hoc, along with other early retailers, fell victim to the recent malling of SoHo by high-end merchants like Chanel, Louis Vuitton and Prada that can pay astronomical rents. 
"We had to move off that hot corner of West Broadway and Spring Street in June 2000," Ms. Auchincloss said. "The landlord refused to renegotiate our lease and rented instead to Emporio Armani."
The new SoHo location on Wooster Street, somewhat off the beaten path, combined with the falling economy and the decline in tourism after Sept. 11, led to a significant loss of business. Ms. Auchincloss said the store's revenues dropped 35 percent last year from the previous year, and another 15 percent this year from last.
"It's 2002 and it's time for a change," Ms. Kron said. "I give them high marks, though. They had a great vision and they led the way."
The store's closing sale starts today. Everything is 50 percent off (40 percent off with a credit card), and the store's fixtures, computers and office supplies are also for sale. Area linen-and-cotton-blend king-size duvet covers are now $210; standard-size pillow cases, $45 each. King-size duvet covers in cotton by Yves Delorme are $206, and standard pillowcases are $84 a pair and cotton bath sheets $47. 
Bathroom stainless-steel shelves, 5 inches wide by 30 long, are $54; stainless steel wastebaskets, $21 to $84; vinyl shower curtains, $33. Prices for Colorstone dinnerware designed by Vignelli for Sasaki are: dinner plates, $13.75, platters $45. Throw pillows in suede are $56 to $225. The sale ends when the store closes, or when supplies run out.

HEADLINE: Creating Dots and Connecting Them, Too 

BYLINE:  By MEL GUSSOW 

 BODY:
Andrea Barrett's new collection of stories, "Servants of the Map," sweeps through the 19th and 20th centuries and crosses several continents, moving from the Himalayas to the Dakotas, while conjuring portraits of adventurers and pioneers. In common with her earlier collection, "Ship Fever," and her novel, "The Voyage of the Narwhal," Ms. Barrett's new book mixes real people (like Charles Darwin and the naturalist William Bartram) with fictional figures, as she weaves a rich tapestry of science and history. Oliver Sacks once quoted a 17th-century naturalist referring to "the secret mysteries of nature." That could stand as an apt description of Ms. Barrett's creative territory.
 Now 47, she has been greatly honored. "Ship Fever" won the National Book Award in 1996, and a Guggenheim Fellowship allowed her to travel to the Arctic to finish the research for "The Voyage of the Narwhal," about a 19th-century polar expedition. Last year she was given a MacArthur award of $500,000. Despite such recognition, she retains her modesty and a sense of equilibrium. Six feet tall with long silvery hair, she has a soft-spoken, almost ethereal manner. 
 Although the stories are widely diverse, they overlap as characters or relatives of characters turn up in alternate situations, often over generations. At the center of three of the stories in "Servants of the Map" and "Ship Fever" are two sisters, Rose and Bianca Marbury. Ms. Barrett's next novel will focus on the sisters' grandparents and will be set mostly in a tuberculosis sanitarium in Saranac Lake, N.Y., in 1916. With a nod to Thomas Mann's "Magic Mountain," she said in a recent interview, "I laughingly call the project 'The Magic Molehill.' "
Because of the intricate relationships of her characters, she was asked if she had compiled a genealogical chart. She has, and she said, "It looks like the workings of an insane person, but I understand it." For the purpose of clarity, she plans to insert a version of it as an endpaper in the forthcoming novel. Then she confided: "Here's the big secret. Everybody in those four books is related to everybody else."
Max Vigne, a cartographer in the Himalayas in the 1860's and the protagonist of the story "Servants of the Map," sends letters home to his wife, Clara, who years later is a character in "The Cure," the last story in the collection. Ned Kynd, an emigre to the United States from Ireland, appears in all three books. Other characters are less obviously connected by marriage or descent. When the next novel is completed, the books will form a kind of tetralogy.
"Ship Fever," coming first, was a major breakthrough for the author. Early in her career, she had spent several years rewriting a novel. In 1984, she went to the Breadloaf Writers Conference at Middlebury College in Vermont, where as an unpublished neophyte, she said she felt like "somebody who had fallen off the turnip truck." The novelist Nicholas Delbanco expressed an interest in her writing, but when he read her novel, he told her to throw it away and start something fresh.
Following his advice, she began writing "Lucid Stars," published in 1988. That novel and the three that followed were contemporary family chronicles. In terms of reviews and sales, they were barely noticed. The fourth, "The Forms of Water," sold fewer than 2,000 copies: "It didn't get reviewed anywhere," she said. "Nobody read it and everyone was so discouraged, including me."
Looking for a new direction in her writing life, she decided to concentrate on short stories. "I had always thought of myself as a novelist," she said. "Having failed so firmly at one genre, I had to try and learn to do something else. It was a real sea change, a kind of courage of complete despair."
Searching for a subject, she reminded herself that her background was in science. "That material was always there since I had been a girl growing up on Cape Cod." She had done graduate work in zoology and had thought about becoming a biologist. Her husband, Barry Goldstein, is a biophysicist (and photographer), and many of their friends are scientists. For years, she has been a close reader of the scientific writings of Oliver Sacks, Jonathan Weiner and others.
"I don't know why it took me so long to see that it might be material for fiction," she said. Unifying her primary interests, she wrote "The Behavior of the Hawkweed," in which contemporary characters recount incidents in the life of the botanist Gregor Mendel.
Her models as short story writers were Alice Munro and William Trevor. Ms. Munro's work in particular taught her "how to compress and be economical" and how to "move through time very quickly." The next step was "to let go of the present and the biographical grounding" and invent characters and write "with no safety net." In common with Tom Stoppard in "Arcadia," she became a time traveler -- and discovered her natural metier.
One by one the stories appeared in small literary magazines, The Missouri Review, The New England Review. At the McDowell Colony for artists in Peterborough, N.H., she finished "Ship Fever" with the guidance of the novelist Margot Livesey (author of "Eva Moves the Furniture"), whom she had met at Breadloaf. As close friends they remain each other's reader and editor.
Published in 1996, "Ship Fever" might have disappeared along with her previous books except for a review by Thomas Mallon in The New York Times Book Review. Mr. Mallon said that "her work stands out for its sheer intelligence, its painstaking attempt to discern and describe the world's configuration," and was "quietly dazzling, like looking at handmade paper under a microscope." This was, Ms. Barrett said, her "first grown-up review."
As an artist writing fiction about science, she is well aware of the disparities and the similarities: "Scientific questions are very precise and very directed. A scientist poses problems that can be answered if one works hard enough." In contrast, writers "pose question after question, and none of them get answered," she continued, adding, "A lot of what I write about in science and history serves as a metaphor for the discoveries we make as writers." In both areas, she said, "there is that sense of pushing at boundaries, of trying to discover new ways of looking at things."
In contrast to the astronomers, archaeologists and marine biologists who populate her fiction, she is not venturesome, regarding herself as a timid person, someone who is "hilariously afraid of bugs" and has suffered from altitude sickness. In other words, she lives vicariously through her characters.
Asked where the Marbury sisters come from, she said, "Like everyone else in contemporary America, I have a multiply divorced and remarried family. I have a whole sister, a half sister and stepsister, and the same things with brothers." She added that she herself was both Rose and Bianca: "Rose's fussy, worried nature is mine. I'm obsessive. But something in me is also Bianca, or wants to be, that attachment to nature, that sense of wanting a larger life, of being more open emotionally and spiritually."
Speaking about her breakthrough as a writer, she said, "It was like someone just opened a big double door into this huge palace that I didn't even know was there. Now all these rooms are open and I can just walk around the place and say: 'Oh, there's Max! And there's Clara -- and Ned. Rose is next to Bianca . . . and they're all having a party." 
As she named them, it was evident that they had become an extended family, continuing characters in the world of her imagination.

HEADLINE: Reclaiming Art Caught in the Cuban Revolution; 
In Cases Reminiscent of Looted Nazi Art, Emigres Trace Fate of Their Collections

BYLINE:  By CELESTINE BOHLEN 

 BODY:
As a young bachelor architect in Havana, Manuel De La Torre used to buy paintings from his artist friends, members of a small circle later known as the Cuban avant-garde. "Whenever I had a good commission on a building, I would buy a painting," recalled Mr. De La Torre, now 84. "When I married, I wanted to have a good home with good paintings and sculptures."
 But in 1960, as the Cuban revolution gathered force, Mr. De La Torre, married by then, left Cuba for the United States. All he could take with him was what fitted in a suitcase. His paintings and sculptures were left in the custody of relatives who later left Cuba themselves, further dispersing the remarkable collection, like so many leaves in the wind. 
 Then one day a year ago, Mr. De La Torre, who now lives on Long Island, was reading through The New York Times when he suddenly stopped. There on Page E31 was a photograph of one of his paintings, "La Hamaca" by Mariano Rodriguez, advertising a sale of Latin American art at Sotheby's auction house. The asking price for the painting was $150,000 to $200,000. 
Mr. De La Torre and his family quickly informed Sotheby's of their claim to the painting (his name was in the catalog as the original owner), which, as it turned out, had been sold once before by Sotheby's, in 1997. Startled by the claim, Sotheby's pulled the painting from last spring's auction. A legal correspondence ensued.
A year later, "La Hamaca" is still being held by Sotheby's, awaiting a settlement between the competing claimants -- a familiar standoff for works of art from Cuba that were lost, abandoned or directly confiscated as Fidel Castro's government took control.
Over the last decade, a growing number of these works have surfaced outside Cuba and been put up for sale. Some left the island via diplomatic channels, others were exported privately and illegally, and some, particularly in the early 1990's, were put on the international market by Cuba itself as it sought hard currency.
As these paintings emerge, Cuban families are increasingly active in trying to reclaim what was once theirs, in the way that European Jews and their heirs have sought to recover works seized by the Nazis during the Holocaust.
Provenance issues in the Cuban cases tend to be murkier than those involving art looted by the Nazi, given the various and obscure ways artworks have left the island. And some lawyers say that United States trade embargo laws against Cuba -- especially those enacted in the last 10 years -- could add a new twist in cases where art dealers or auction houses are found to have "trafficked" in works expropriated by the Cuban government.
No one knows how many legal claims have been brought by Cubans seeking to recover lost art or how many have been settled privately. But experts agree that Cuban emigres are now paying more attention.
"There is more information now, with the Internet, where you can find out where the stuff is," said Nicolas Gutierrez, an international business lawyer in Miami. "There is more of it coming out of Cuba than there was before, and then there is the success of the cases where art was confiscated by the Nazis and the Communists in Europe."
The effort to recover lost art may be the first drop in what could become a flood of restitution claims if Cuba sheds its Communist government and moves toward democracy and free markets. "There is definitely a greater interest in people positioning themselves for the day when the end of this regime is less remote," Mr. Gutierrez said.
Manny J. De La Torre, 42, the architect's son, said: "My father had no idea that he could do anything about his paintings. He had no idea that these things were coming out of Cuba."
The art cases are rarely clear-cut. The Fanjul family of Palm Beach, Fla., heirs to one of the great Cuban sugar fortunes, has been trying since the mid-1990's to reclaim a painting by Joaquin Sorolla y Bastida that was confiscated by the Cuban government in 1959 and, in the early 1990's, was quietly brought out of Cuba for a possible sale through Sotheby's.
The painting, "Castle Malaga," valued at $300,000 to $400,000, was one of more than 100 works in the family collection that were turned over to Havana's National Museum of Fine Arts. In 1994, when rumors spread that this painting and perhaps others were being put up for sale, the Fanjul family registered the collection with the Art Loss Register, which lists stolen or missing works and puts the art world on alert.
Matthew Weigman, a spokesman for Sotheby's, said a client brought "Castle Malaga" in for an appraisal in the mid-1990's and it was held for several years. "Sotheby's took the picture to a recognized Sorolla expert, but we could not agree on an estimate for the picture," he said. "So we never offered it for sale, and the picture was returned to the client." He would not pinpoint the date of the painting's return.
He said Sotheby's did get an inquiry from the Art Loss Register. "They simply asked us if we had sold it, which we hadn't," he said, "and we said we hadn't. I don't know where it is now."
The Fanjul family has since learned that "Castle Malaga" is being held by a dealer in Italy, said Shanker Singham, an international trade lawyer in Miami who represents the Fanjul family in the case. Based on correspondence with the Italian dealer's lawyer, Mr. Singham said, he wonders if Sotheby's played a more significant role in the aborted sale. "We still don't know exactly what role Sotheby's played in this, or why they can't be up front about it," he said.
Lawyers in Miami who specialize in cases involving the United States trade embargo against Cuba say that art auction houses and dealers could be running big risks if they handle the sale of art from Cuba.
Laws passed by Congress not only bar United States citizens from dealing in property seized by the Cuban government, but also put foreign citizens at risk of losing their visas to the United States for such activities.
As far as any of the lawyers contacted know, no case has gone to court seeking to reclaim art with the help of the embargo laws. But Mr. Singham said that as more cases of sales by the cash-hungry Cuban government come to light, the option of invoking such laws may become more real.
Typically, as Cubans left Castro's Cuba, government agents would compile an inventory of possessions left behind and consign artworks, books, furniture and other valuables to museums and other public institutions. Several Cuban emigre groups have contended that many of these items were later pilfered and sold illegally. Although some of this has taken place, allegedly with the help of corrupt officials, many experts say that Cuba's museums have in fact been very conservative about selling works from their collections.
Much of the art that has come out of Cuba is thought to have drifted out of the hands of family members, perhaps winding up in commission stores run by the government, then being smuggled out by tourists, diplomats or Cubans themselves. 
"There is a very difficult situation with Cuban art, because many families left their valuables with other family members, thinking the revolution was going to last only a few months," said Ramon Cernuda, a Miami gallery owner who specializes in Cuban art. "Then at some point, some of these people got rid of things. It is a very complicated process -- not as simple as the World War II confiscated material, because it is not as clear-cut."
Mr. Cernuda cited two cases, one at Christie's in 1994 and another at Sotheby's in 1996, when Cuban families who laid claim to paintings put up for auction discovered that the works had in fact been sold by relatives. In both cases, the families agreed to accept compensation rather than pursue claims.
Manuel De La Torre was unusual because he was a passionate collector of contemporary Cuban art, which at the time had little value. In 1956, he showed his collection, which then numbered 48 works, at the Lyceum gallery in Havana. The exhibition, fully documented, anticipated the boom to come some 40 years later in works by artists like Wilfredo Lam and Rene Portocarrero.
Mr. De La Torre lost track of his collection over the years, with the exception of a few portraits that he and his relatives could plausibly claim to be paintings of family members, and thus eligible for export from Cuba. But only recently did he realize just how widely dispersed his collection was: at least two paintings are in Cuban national museums, and another turned up in the private collection of Mr. Cernuda, who in an interview said he bought it through Sotheby's in 1984 for $4,675.
How "La Hamaca" left Cuba is still a mystery. All that is known is that it ended up in Spain -- perhaps by way of a Spanish diplomat, a friend of Mr. De La Torre's sister-in-law, who was the last in the family to leave Cuba, in 1973. A Spanish family consigned it to Sotheby's in 1997, where it was bought by the current owner, who last year consigned it to Sotheby's for resale.
When Sotheby's was first informed of the De La Torre claim, the auction house offered to proceed with the sale, retain its fee and put the proceeds in a special account to be divided later in a settlement between the rival claimants. The family, noting that Mr. De La Torre never divested himself of the painting, rejected the offer out of hand, arguing that Sotheby's had been negligent in accepting anyone else's claim to the painting.
"You would think Sotheby's would have the resources to do the research," Manny De La Torre said. "If they didn't, they are not doing the homework."
Mr. Weigman noted that Sotheby's requires consignors to guarantee that they have clear title. In this case, he said, Sotheby's tried to further investigate how the Spanish family wound up with "La Hamaca." "We even had people sit down with a priest, but we have been unable to cast any light on how the painting came into their collection," he said.
"The truth is, a lot of people don't have bills of sale for everything in their house," he said. "We don't settle these cases; we just hold the paintings."
Glenn Kerner, lawyer for the De La Torre family, said the family was surprised by the auction house's "hands off" approach. "My client is disappointed that Sotheby's appears to be indifferent to this entire situation," he said.
Manny De La Torre added: "We have been trying to deal with this in a friendly manner. We were hoping to have the painting returned in time for my father's birthday on July 4 last year. Then we thought it would be a great Christmas present. Now my goal is for him to have his painting back within his lifetime."

An article in The Arts on June 6 about efforts by Cuban emigres to recover artworks they left behind when they fled the revolution misspelled the given name of an artist whose work has experienced a boom in prices. He is Wifredo Lam, not Wilfredo.

HEADLINE: Australia Raises Rates by a Quarter-Point 

BYLINE:  By JOHN SHAW 

DATELINE: CANBERRA, Australia, June 5 

 BODY:
Like a skilled surfer, the Australian economy is staying on top of the wave.
 To buffer the buoyant economy from the risk of inflation, the Reserve Bank of Australia today lifted its benchmark interest rate a quarter-point, to 4.75 percent, the second such move in a month. The earlier quarter-point increase was the bank's first adjustment since August 2000. 
 The central bank's fine-tuning came as key business indicators, including retail spending, housing starts, auto sales and real estate prices, reached new peaks. And it followed a quarter-point rate increase by Canada's central bank. 
Most analysts say the Reserve Bank of Australia has now tried to slow down the growth generator of historically low borrowing costs and is likely to raise the rate further in the next 12 months.
Official figures released Tuesday show that gross domestic product was 4.2 percent higher in the first quarter than it was a year earlier. (Canada's year-over-year rate was 2 percent; in the United States, the rate was 1.5 percent.)
In his half-yearly report, published last week, the bank governor, Ian Macfarlane, forecast that the economy would grow 3.5 to 4 percent in the fiscal year ending June 30, 2003, and said this would give Australia its twelfth consecutive year of economic expansion. The official bank rate could reach 6 to 6.5 percent in the next 12 months, the report said. This would lift basic mortgage rates from 6.3 percent now to about 8.3 percent, slowing the rapid rise in real estate prices and residential construction.
The report predicted that the jobless rate would fall below 6 percent and inflation would stay around the current rate, 2.9 percent.
Mr. Macfarlane said that growth, jobs and inflation indicators proved that interest rate moves have been effective. "Barring some unforeseen international event it is hard to see serious risks on the downside for the Australian economy," he said. "We can safely claim Australia has weathered a world recession without itself experiencing one."
He warned, however, that the ratio of household debt to income has doubled, from 50 percent to 100 percent, in the last decade, bringing the risk of overcommitment for many borrowers.
Senior government advisers differ marginally on inflation forecasts but otherwise there is consensus that the good times can continue into 2004, perhaps beyond, without any overheating. Some economists sound notes of caution, but few express concern that the economy will overreach itself -- at least anytime soon.
Recent business surveys support the bullish outlook. So do current figures on productivity and trade, and the rising value of the Australian dollar.
"The economy is going gang busters," said Prime Minister John Howard, a conservative who has been in office since 1996. His treasurer, Peter Costello, said, "We have a nice set of numbers." 
Mr. Costello predicted economic growth of 3.75 percent, but most business and banking economists forecast 4 percent growth.
Mr. Costello, 45, is favored to succeed Mr. Howard, 63, who may step aside as prime minster next year after steering the country to balanced budgets and solid growth amid international recessions.
Business confidence is at its highest overall level in almost a decade, according to the National Australia Bank. The bank, which increased its half-year net profit 11 percent, to a record 2.26 billion Australian dollars ($1.29 billion), said its latest research shows particular confidence in the areas of construction, services, plant capacity use, hiring and investment.
Other recent surveys showed business activity up 7 percent, company profits increasing 1.5 percent on average in the last quarter, retail sales expanding at an annual rate of 11 percent, and industrial sales growing by an average of 5 percent.
According to Dun & Bradstreet, sales expectations are the best they have been in two years. A major local employment agency says that 30 percent of companies expect to hire more workers this year. Another report says the number of advertised skilled job vacancies is 6 percent higher than last year, with health, accounting and construction workers in strongest demand.
The average price of houses sold in Sydney in the last year jumped 16 percent. The prices for some harborview residences soared 30 to 40 percent. In other Australian cities housing prices also rose, although not as fast. The national new-home construction rate has jumped 12 percent in the last three months.
Banking profits, university enrollments, domestic tourism and movie attendances are all breaking records. The number of millionaires has doubled, to 3.6 percent of the population, in the last four years, according to research by the University of Canberra.
According to John Edwards, chief economist of the Hongkong and Shanghai Bank in Australia, "The economy is certainly doing a lot better than many expected."
Still, Paul Braddick, senior economist of the ANZ Bank, sees some reasons for caution. "While the near-term outlook is good, several risks are emerging" for the next year he said. "Housing growth will wane as higher interest rates increase the cost of mortgages." Mr. Braddick predicted that growth in net trade levels -- steady exports minus growing imports -- would slow next year, and he said an increase "in business investment is critical to the economic outlook."
Then there is the drought. Many farm regions have had no useful rain since February, and scientists are reporting the apparent approach of a new El Nino cycle of mid-Pacific warming -- an event that can bring exceptionally hot, dry periods, which could reduce farm production and exports, including grain and meat.

PERSON: Fernando Belaunde Terry 

HEADLINE: Fernando Belaunde Terry, 89, Who Was Twice Peru's Chief 

BYLINE:  By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
Fernando Belaunde Terry, the soft-spoken idealist who was ousted from the Peruvian presidency by the military in 1968 but won it back in 1980, died on Tuesday in Lima. He was 89.
 Elected in 1963 with only 39 percent of the vote, Mr. Belaunde, an American-educated architect who became a symbol of democracy, cut an attractive and charismatic figure as he called on citizens to "reconquer Peru" by fully exploiting its economic potential, promising them "a revolution without bullets." 
 But his Accion Popular party was outnumbered in Parliament by opposition groups that succeeded in blocking much of his plan for agrarian reform, which would have entailed opening up the country's interior for settlement and farming by building an extensive road network.
This deepening political impasse left the military increasingly frustrated with politicians in general and Mr. Belaunde in particular. But what immediately precipitated his downfall was his attempt to settle a long-running dispute with the International Petroleum Company, an Exxon subsidiary -- an attempt denounced by the head of the Peruvian national oil company as a surrender of national wealth to foreigners.
On Oct. 3, 1968, a column of army tanks commanded by Gen. Juan Velasco Alvarado entered Lima's historic Plaza de Armas, arrested Mr. Belaunde and sent him into exile in Argentina, from where he moved to the United States.
Mr. Belaunde spent the next 10 years lecturing on architecture at American universities including Harvard, Columbia, Johns Hopkins and George Washington. Meanwhile, economic conditions deteriorated in Peru under the radical and repressive rule of the Velasco junta.
In 1975 a new junta headed by Gen. Francisco Morales Bermudez seized power, promising a return to democracy and more moderate policies.
The next year, Mr. Belaunde moved back to Peru and in May 1980 he presided over the country's return to democracy; this time his Accion Popular led a majority coalition in Parliament.
Mr. Belaunde campaigned carrying a shovel to symbolize his pledge to create a million new jobs through agricultural projects.
But while he embraced more liberal policies, he made little impression on the country's deep economic problems, which included an annual inflation rate surpassing 100 percent, a growing burden of foreign debt payment and high unemployment.
These difficulties were worsened by the terrorist activities of the Shining Path, a band of Maoist revolutionaries who greeted the return to civilian rule by starting a campaign of violence in the impoverished Ayacucho region.
Within four years more than 4,000 guerrillas, soldiers and civilians were dead and 1,000 people were reported missing after detention by the security forces.
In the April 1985 elections, Mr. Belaunde and Accion Popular were swept from power by their traditional opponents, the Apristas, or supporters of the Alianza Popular Revolucionaria Americana, who gained control of both houses of the legislature.
Their presidential candidate, Alan Garcia Perez, replaced Mr. Belaunde on July 28 -- the first time in the 20th century that power had been transferred from one elected Peruvian leader to another.
That same day Mr. Garcia announced that Peru would henceforth restrict foreign debt repayments to 10 percent of export earnings.
Fernando Belaunde Terry was born in Lima on Oct. 7, 1912. He came from a distinguished family of lawyers and diplomats. When Fernando was 12, his father was exiled from Peru. The youth pursued his education first in Europe, then in Florida at the University of Miami, and finally at the University of Texas, where he studied architecture.
Returning to Peru in 1943, Mr. Belaunde was elected to Parliament in 1945 and became a successful architect. He kept himself firmly in the public eye, fighting a duel with sabers against one political opponent and attempting an escape by swimming from an island prison where he had been sent for holding an illegal rally.
He is survived by a daughter and two sons, Maria Carolina, Fernando and Rafael, from his first marriage, which ended in divorce. His second wife, the former Violeta Correa, died last year.

HEADLINE: McCall Urges Upstate Voice in 9/11 Recovery Agency 

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
H. Carl McCall said yesterday that upstate and suburban New Yorkers should have a direct say in planning the reconstruction of Lower Manhattan, and that the state agency overseeing the rebuilding effort should be enlarged to include members from outside New York City.
 Mr. McCall, a Democratic candidate for governor, said he would revamp the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, the 16-member agency created by Gov. George E. Pataki to help New York recover from the Sept. 11 attack. He also said Mr. Pataki had excluded "too many important groups" from the agency, which will shape the future of downtown New York. 
 In particular, Mr. McCall said, new members should represent hotel and retail workers, religious and civic groups, and "upstate and suburban interests."
Mr. McCall's remarks were part of a speech at Pace University in Lower Manhattan intended, he said, to lay out his views on how to rebuild downtown New York and the state economy. 
Mr. McCall also echoed an attack that his Democratic rival, Andrew M. Cuomo, made in a similar speech three weeks ago by criticizing Mr. Pataki's role in overseeing the redevelopment effort.
"We need a long-term vision for the future of New York," Mr. McCall said. "And the governor, I believe, has failed to provide that vision and that leadership."
In his speech, Mr. McCall, the state comptroller, sketched out a vague vision of what a rebuilt Lower Manhattan should look like. It reflected what has already emerged as a rough consensus among New York officials and planners: a mixture of residential and business development, along with a memorial.
Mr. Cuomo had proposed anchoring downtown New York with some sort of major project -- he suggested moving the New York City Opera or the World Bank there -- as a way of guiding development there. Mr. McCall declined to offer any details of what shape that development might take, saying he would prefer to leave that to advisers.
"I'm not trying to say, 'This is the plan,' " he said. "I want to bring together the best talent to develop that plan. I want to bring diversity out there."
Mr. McCall said he thought that the downtown area should have a transportation hub linking various subway, commuter and ferry lines, an idea that has already found wide agreement among city planners. Mr. McCall declined to say whether he would endorse another central part of that plan -- extending commuter train lines from Westchester and Long Island into that downtown transportation center -- over long-standing attempts to build a Second Avenue subway.
"I think we will have to look at all these issues and decide what our priorities are," Mr. McCall said. "Downtown Manhattan is important, but it's not the only thing."
Mr. McCall said the redevelopment effort should try to bury part of West Street so Battery Park City is linked to the trade center site. Both Mr. Pataki and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg endorsed that idea two months ago.
Mr. Pataki's spokesman, Michael McKeon, disputed Mr. McCall's assertions, saying that the development corporation board, which includes members appointed both by Mr. Pataki and by Mr. Bloomberg, was representative. "We will leave the partisan attacks to the Democrats and stay focused on ensuring that Lower Manhattan is stronger and more vibrant than it was on Sept. 10," Mr. McKeon said.
Mr. McCall is the first to call for representatives from the suburbs and upstate on the board. In explaining his reasoning, he said, "I don't want people there to be left out, to feel that this is all we are doing, that this is only what we are paying attention to."
He added: "And people from outside New york, if they come and see what we're doing here, they might get some ideas that they can apply where they are as well. I just want, I think we need to be as inclusive as possible in this process."
