HEADLINE: Several U.S. Allies Criticized in Powell Report on Slave Trading 

BYLINE:  By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 5 

 BODY:
South Korea, Romania and Israel all stepped up efforts to stop slave trafficking within their borders last year, but some of the United States' closest allies, including Turkey, Saudi Arabia and several Persian Gulf states, did not, according to a State Department report issued today.
 Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said that the United States was resolved "to stop this appalling assault on the dignity of men, women and children," that victimizes an estimated 700,000 to 4 million people a year worldwide through coercion and outright kidnapping -- most of them women and children -- including some 50,000 in the United States. 
 But the law that mandated creation of the report two years ago does not provide for imposition of penalties until next year, when countries judged not in compliance with certain minimum standards will face penalties in the form of withheld aid, and votes by the United States against loans from international organizations like the World Bank. 
In the current report, the 19 countries in that category, called Tier 3, include Afghanistan, Bahrain, Myanmar, Greece, Iran, Lebanon, Qatar, Russia, Saudi Arabia, Tajikistan, Turkey and the United Arab Emirates. They were judged to have made no real effort to stop a commerce in human beings who are forced to work in brothels, sweatshops and other involuntary servitude.
"There were absolutely no political considerations entering into this," said Nancy Ely-Raphel, who presented the report and is a senior adviser to Secretary Powell on the issue. "Some of our closest allies are on Tier 3, and they were on Tier 3 last year. This is a straight-out, objective report determining whether a country meets the minimum standards and whether it's making serious and sustained efforts to meet those minimum standards."
Countries that make such efforts can move up to Tier 2, which this year includes such American allies as India, Israel, Japan, Mexico, Morocco, the Philippines and Pakistan, which rose from the lowest category last year, angering some human rights groups. South Korea, a key ally, leapfrogged from Tier 3 to the top level.
Representative Christopher H. Smith, Republican of New Jersey, who sponsored the law requiring the report, expressed disappointment that "both last year and this year, the report omits from Tier 3 countries including India, Thailand and Vietnam -- all of which have serious trafficking problems in which government officials appear to be actively involved."
He noted that "several of the nations omitted from Tier 3 have governments with which the United States is trying to improve relations." But, he added, "For governments whose own high-ranking officials are deeply involved in trafficking, holding an occasional training session with an international organization, or even a few ineffectual prosecutions, do not amount to 'significant efforts.' "
Ms. Ely-Raphel noted that the number of Tier 3 countries decreased to 19 from 23 last year, and praised Romania, South Korea and Israel for taking significant steps to crack down on the practice. 
Theresa Loar, president of Vital Voices, a nonprofit organization that promotes human rights and democracy for women, said the government needed to do more to work with nations and nongovernmental organizations to provide training and tools to fight trafficking.

HEADLINE: Here, Gatsby Would Be Just Ordinary 

BYLINE:  By BRUCE LAMBERT 

DATELINE: NORTH HILLS, N.Y., June 5 

 BODY:
Driving by, it is easy to miss this small, secluded community on the North Shore of Long Island. There is no real center or downtown. Most of its residents are hidden in costly enclaves of town houses -- one is actually called The Enclave -- and million-dollar homes on private cul-de-sacs. Gates, guardhouses and private-road signs discourage the uninvited. 
 But now the village is getting nationwide attention for its new ranking as the richest community in the Northeast, with an average per capita income of $100,093 a year, according to figures reported Tuesday by the Census Bureau. North Hills was the only spot in the Northeast to earn a place on the list of the nation's 10 wealthiest communities, ranking No. 8, alongside some better known places like Palm Beach, Fla. 
 No one here seems surprised. "There's a lot of wealth in this community," said Mayor John M. Lentini. "It's such a blue chip area. I don't know of any area of Long Island that has this kind of concentration of wealth. There's no place like this." Actually, the village's current very-rich status is a bit of a comedown from its origins -- it was incorporated in 1929 -- as the domain of a few super-wealthy families. For decades, much of North Hills was occupied by the estates and horse farms of the likes of the Whitneys, the Paleys and the Graces. "They were the very wealthy icons of the Gold Coast," the mayor said.
Modern North Hills began taking shape in the 1970's, when the old estates began to break up and be redeveloped. Despite zoning restrictions that allow only two houses per acre, the population has flourished -- from 200 or 300 in the 70's to about 4,500 today. 
"We've had a phenomenal growth pattern that to my way of thinking is unrivaled," Mayor Lentini said. 
Why did the well-to-do flock to North Hills? Mayor Lentini, a real estate manager, has a one-word answer: "Location." 
The western end of the village is only a mile from the Queens border, yet its terrain is a bucolic respite of gently rolling hills with plenty of trees. The transportation is hard to beat: The village straddles the Long Island Expressway and the Northern State Parkway, and the Long Island Rail Road provides an under-30-minute commute to Manhattan.
Some older residents are drawn to the condominium life, and some are snowbirds who spend winters in the Sun Belt. Other residents work in the financial industry or as doctors, lawyers or executives. "There are even sports professionals here," said Tara Acciardi, who has lived in the community two months. "They practice at Hofstra, and Darryl Strawberry used to live here." 
There is no reason why North Hills cannot rise to first place nationally, Mayor Lentini said, especially if he succeeds in his plan to buy the Deepdale Golf Course and open it to residents only.
"That would make North Hills that much more desirable, which would make the properties that much more valuable, which will bring in that many more affluent people," he said. "It can only get better."

HEADLINE: Perot Systems Shares Drop Over Accusations on California Energy Role 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 5 

 BODY:
Shares of Perot Systems plunged 19.1 percent today after a California lawmaker accused the firm of using knowledge gleaned from its work in setting up the deregulated California power markets to instruct energy-trading companies on how to exploit vulnerabilities in those markets.
 In another energy-trading development, the House Energy and Commerce Committee, which has been investigating the collapse of Enron, has widened its inquiry to review allegations that Enron and others manipulated California energy prices. Investigators are preparing to interview people about the allegations, a spokesman for the panel said. 
 The California lawmaker, State Senator Joseph Dunn, a Democrat who is heading a legislative committee's investigation into market manipulation, cited a 44-page presentation that he said Perot Systems made to energy traders who did business in California. Mr. Dunn said the presentation appeared to be at the core "of what ultimately became the economic rape of California consumers." 
The presentation discussed how Perot Systems had "discovered a 'hole' " in the state grid operator's system that "allowed strategies that would destabilize the market." The presentation also discussed how market players could have "caused wild swings" in certain electricity prices. Another page of the presentation, titled "Strategic Decisions in California," stated that one decision was to "bid capacity in one market and withhold in others."
Perot Systems, a computer services company founded by the Texas billionaire and former independent presidential candidate H. Ross Perot, said in a statement this afternoon that it "did not reveal or sell any confidential information of any kind."
The company, whose chief executive is Mr. Perot's son, Ross Perot Jr., also said it had worked with the California Power Exchange to "correct the defects" in the market. "The defects that were identified by Perot Systems in the document were corrected before the California Power exchange became operational, as the document itself indicates," the statement said. It added that it had provided "no energy trading services to any California market participant."
A company spokesman, Eddie Reeves, said he could not answer many questions because the business unit that was involved had been shut and its employees had left the company. He said he could not say when the presentation was made or to whom it was made. And he said he could not say whether any sales pitches made by Perot Systems included a discussion of how to exploit flaws in the California markets.
Mr. Reeves also said he could not say why the presentation was made . "It's not clear whether this is an analysis of what happened in the market, or whether it was an analysis of what could happen in the market," he said.
Shares of Perot Systems, which halted trading for about an hour in the afternoon, closed at $14.55, down $3.43.
Mr. Dunn obtained the document from Reliant Energy, a trader active in California. Today, a Reliant spokesman said: "We believe this document was provided to Reliant as part of a Perot Systems sales presentation. We don't yet have definitive information, and further comment would be premature."
A spokesman for the California Independent System Operator, which manages the state's electricity grid, said today that the presentation appeared to highlight a previously identified flaw related to the ability of companies to use their bidding strategies to affect the market-clearing price for electricity. The spokesman, Gregg Fishman, said Perot Systems had signed a contract with the grid operator that included a confidentiality clause. But he said an initial reading of the document by I.S.O. officials suggested that the documents contained "what had all been available market data.
"There's nothing in there that appears to be proprietary information," Mr. Fishman continued.
Meanwhile, in Washington, the chairman of the House panel, Representative Billy Tauzin, Republican of Louisiana, sent a letter on May 24 to the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, asking the agency to respond to questions about the status, findings and methodology of its investigation into market manipulation.
"We're trying to determine if these practices were isolated incidents involving Enron and several other companies or whether this was an industrywide norm," Ken Johnson, a spokesman for Mr. Tauzin, said.
"We are in the process of setting up interviews with people who may have intimate knowledge of some of these shady practices," he added. "We're trying to gather as much information to determine how to proceed."
House Democrats have for weeks been seeking a House investigation into the matter, and today the Democratic leader, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, called on House Republican leaders to "end the Enron cover-up and hold hearings now into the mountain of evidence indicating Enron might have conspired to create last summer's energy crisis."
Mr. Johnson replied, "We have not ignored anything, except for the Democratic leadership's hyperbole."

HEADLINE: Service Economy Grows, Survey Says 

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
A survey of activity in service industries released yesterday showed that the sector grew last month at its fastest pace since August 2000.
 The survey by a trade group, the Institute for Supply Management, yields a nonmanufacturing index of activity in a wide range of services, like entertainment and financial services. 
The index rose in May to 60.1 from 55.3 in April. 
 It was the highest level since the economic downturn began in late 2000. Nonmanufacturing businesses account for a majority of the economy.
But economists cautioned that the results overstated strength in some of the survey's other components and that the data reflected only moderate growth in the second quarter.
"It's consistent with a decent growth rate in the economy," said Stephen Stanley of Greenwich Capital Markets in Greenwich, Conn. 
Earlier this week, the trade group's manufacturing index showed that that sector grew in May at its fastest pace since February 2000. 
Another gauge reported yesterday, the institute's index of new orders, rose to 56.8 in May from 56.4 in April, while the order backlog index posted its first growth in 17 months -- signaling rising demand for future services. 
The employment index rose in May to 49.5 from 48.9 in April, still the 15th consecutive month of job losses, but moving closer to the 50 threshold that would signal job growth. 
The prices-paid index fell in May to 55.5 from 59.5, indicating that prices were rising at a slower pace and soothing some worries about a possible buildup of inflation. 
The trade group compiles its nonmanufacturing index, which is seasonally adjusted, by surveying some 370 purchasing executives in more than 62 service industries once a month.

HEADLINE: BLOCKS; 
Streets Vanish From Master Plans

BYLINE:  By David W. Dunlap 

 BODY:
MORE streets, smaller blocks.
 That city planning mantra, reflecting the conventional wisdom of recent years, has dominated thinking about the World Trade Center site. 
 But even as strategists figure out how to divide the 16-acre trade center superblock with a small-scale street pattern, planners elsewhere have been assembling large-scale parcels by eliminating proposed new streets and replacing them with parkland. 
They are not so much repudiating a precept laid out in 1961 by the activist and critic Jane Jacobs -- "Most blocks must be short" -- as they are recognizing that not every new street enlivens a neighborhood or expands public space. And that even conventional wisdom cannot offer a "one size fits all" planning solution. 
At Battery Park City, which purposefully revised its master plan in 1979 to create a westward extension of the Lower Manhattan street grid, two blocks will be united by the omission of a planned street called Park Place West. In its place, a park will be built at the center of the superblock.
And at the north end of the 74-acre Queens West project on the East River, the Rockrose Development Corporation has won approval to consolidate what were to have been four discrete new city blocks into a single waterfront park with apartment towers and stub-end streets along one edge.
"We saw a lot of unnecessary streets that weren't going anywhere, and we saw the opportunity to eliminate them and increase the open space," said Jon McMillan, director of planning for Rockrose, the developer of the new north residential neighborhood at Queens West, where Pepsi-Cola once had a bottling plant.
Rockrose could not quite reconcile its design, by the Miami architectural firm Arquitectonica and the Manhattan landscape architectural firm Abel Bainnson Butz, with a master plan drawn up in 1990 by John H. Beyer of Beyer Blinder Belle and Jordan L. Gruzen of Gruzen Samton Steinglass.
(Beyer Blinder Belle was chosen last month to conduct an urban planning and transportation study of Lower Manhattan and the trade center site. Mr. Gruzen is a member of New York New Visions, a design and planning coalition that has involved itself in downtown rebuilding. And Arquitectonica has just been designated by city officials, with Cooper, Robertson and Partners, to prepare a planning study of the far West Side of Manhattan.)
The original Queens West plan called for seven blocks in the north neighborhood, oriented along Center Boulevard, a new north-south thoroughfare. A street called East River Road was to divide the blocks from the waterfront.
This approach seemed to embody a central principle of "The Death and Life of Great American Cities," the influential critique by Ms. Jacobs that was published when planners were enamored of superblocks.
"Most blocks must be short; that is, streets and opportunities to turn corners must be frequent," she wrote. "Frequent streets and short blocks are valuable because of the fabric of intricate cross-use that they permit among the users of a city neighborhood."
But Rockrose looked at all the streets planned for Queens West and saw a lot of infrastructure that would have to be built to serve a circulation system that might not be needed.
Rockrose proposed at first to eliminate every building on the west side of Center Boulevard and concentrate all of its 2.8 million square-foot project on the east side, creating something like Riverside Drive. But the Queens West Development Corporation, a unit of the Empire State Development Corporation that is overseeing the project, insisted that buildings line both sides of the boulevard.
In the end, East River Road was eliminated and three through-streets were turned into cul-de-sacs, while sight lines and pedestrian access were preserved.
"It's not so much that it is a superblock as that the city context ends and the waterfront context begins," Mr. McMillan said.
ASKED about the revisions, Mr. Gruzen said they showed that although some assumptions of the master plan -- the skeleton, he called it -- were not to the developers' liking, it was resilient enough to allow change. "It didn't corrupt the idea," he said. "The idea was strong enough to sustain these modifications."
The Battery Park City master plan was modified by the architect Ralph Lerner to eliminate a one-block stretch of Park Place West in the north residential neighborhood, thereby creating a two-block development parcel on which four towers are to rise. For the cruciform space among the towers, Michael Van Valkenburgh Associates has designed the 1.8-acre Teardrop Park.
The idea behind Park Place West was "a sentimental belief in the virtue of the old grid," Mr. Lerner said. "I don't think one should automatically presume its virtues," he said. "You shouldn't mistake the claim for the result."

HEADLINE: Reporters at Washington Post Withhold Bylines 

BYLINE:  By FELICITY BARRINGER 

 BODY:
Virtually all the reporters who wrote articles appearing in The Washington Post yesterday refused to allow their names to appear over their work, in protest of the newspaper's position in contract talks.
 The "byline strike" is the first at The Post since 1988. 
 The three-year contract at issue would cover 1,400 Post employees -- most of them journalists and advertising sales personnel -- who are represented by the Newspaper Guild, an affiliate of the Communications Workers of America. 
Rick Weiss, a science reporter who is co-chairman of the Guild unit at The Post, said the two sides were at loggerheads over raises, employees' right to save unused vacation time and whether employees represented by the Guild can quit it at any time.
"The company's efforts to undermine the strength and the very existence of the union here are obviously very important to us," he said.The byline strike continued with Thursday's editions.
Asked management's stance on the negotiations, Patricia Dunn, vice president for labor relations, said: "Our focus is on resolving contract issues at the bargaining table. That's where we'll reach an agreement."
The previous three-year contract, which gave reporters the right to withhold their bylines, expired on May 18. Negotiations on a new contract began about three months ago.
Mr. Weiss cast the union's demand for average pay increases of 3 percent a year in the context of the $230 million in net income reported by the newspaper's owner, the Washington Post Company, in its most recent annual report. Post management sources, on the other hand, pointed out that unlike some other newspapers, The Post had not laid off workers in response to the advertising recession that has hit the industry.
The guaranteed pay increases offered by The Post, the Guild says, would average 1.3 percent a year; the first year's payment would be given as a lump sum, which would not be counted in base pay, the figure on which future percentage increases would be calculated.
A Post source briefed on the talks, however, indicated that the offer amounted to 2 percent a year.

HEADLINE: India Success In Software Is Set Back By War Talk 

BYLINE:  By SARITHA RAI 

DATELINE: BANGALORE, India, June 5 

 BODY:
The tensions and war fears mounting in South Asia are taking a toll on one of India's major economic success stories, its software industry.
 New business is drying up because foreign clients -- mainly Americans -- are avoiding travel to the region. And though India's main technology center here is more than 1,000 miles from the frontier with Pakistan, leading companies are nonetheless bracing for the impact of war and are rushing to make sure disaster recovery plans are in place. 
 "The last time India went to war was with Pakistan in 1971, when India was a closed economy," said N. R. Narayana Murthy, chairman of Infosys Technologies, India's largest publicly traded software exporter. "Today we are a globalized economy, and prolonged talk of war is not going to help business at all." 
Neither side in the current crisis seems to want war, especially a war that might involve use of nuclear weapons, and there has been some retreat by each side from its most aggressive postures. But until a diplomatic formula can be found for substantially relaxing the tensions with Pakistan, India is likely to be seen by the world as a high-risk place to do business, a perception many here hope will prove only temporary.
In the meantime, software service companies are doing their best to reassure clients. "We are showing our customers our disaster recovery plans, complete with hot-site backup centers and higher levels of security, to contend with threats of terrorist attacks," said Phaneesh Murthy, Infosys's global chief of sales and marketing, who is based at the company's American offices in Santa Clara Calif. Phaneesh Murthy and N. R. Murthy are not related.
Visits from foreign clients are vital to the Indian software industry, which must sell itself against the more familiar names of rivals in the developed world. Customers travel here in teams to tour the gleaming suburban office campuses, meet with executives and engineers, sit in on presentations and see for themselves what the industry can do, compiling short lists and learning what differentiates one Indian software company from another.
In normal times, a dozen or more customer teams might be visiting Infosys's sprawling 50-acre headquarters in the Bangalore suburbs. But in recent weeks, they have all but disappeared.
Phaneesh Murthy said he did not think the deferred client visits would permanently harm Infosys's business. "We are convinced that the strategic reason why companies outsource work to India will remain and that will continue to bring in business," he said.
But the picture may change. "If the standoff does continue for long, it could begin to affect business," said Kiran Karnik, president of the industry's main trade group, the National Association of Software and Service Companies, known as Nasscom, in a statement on Tuesday.
More than 200 major American corporations now buy software services from Indian companies, a number that has risen steadily in the last few years, according to Nasscom. India's annual software exports, $150 million a decade ago, grew to $7.6 billion in the 12 months from April 2001 to March 2002, accounting for one-sixth of India's total exports; about two-thirds of the software exports go to the United States.
For the moment, Indian companies like Ishoni Networks are trying not to let disruptions in travel between India and the United States hold back business. The company is still actively hiring, and has just finished recruiting two new employees from the United States. "But a nuclear war could change all this and render us dysfunctional," said Vivek Mansingh, the company's chief executive.
Sanjay Kalra, chief executive of DSL Software, a joint venture between Deutsche Bank and India's top software exporter, HCL Technologies, said he thought American companies that already used Indian software suppliers would not break off business. "But decision-making concerning growth will not happen immediately," he said. "The business cycle will slow down." 
Like many companies here, DSL Software said it was doing what it could to prepare for trouble, including backing up its systems and archives here and in the United States and working from two locations within India. Others have backup sites in Singapore or other places outside the country. Cognizant Technologies, with four programming centers in India, said it had special teams ready to travel to the company's New Jersey offices or to Europe on short notice if necessary. 
CCC Information Services, one of Cognizant's United States clients, says it has its own contingency plan. "We are extraordinarily concerned about the situation and have looked into Cognizant's contingency plans," said Jim Beattie, executive vice president. "We have a very high-value relationship with the company, and we are not considering forsaking them at the moment. But if the situation becomes grave, we will have to look at options elsewhere."
Several Indian companies said that they were putting to use lessons they learned last September from the terror attacks. The events of "9/11 taught most large companies not to rely on any one location fully, and that is helping companies in times like this," said Phaneesh Murthy of Infosys.
Executives here expect few problems with international communications if war breaks out, citing the wealth of available satellite links and undersea fiber optic cable capacity. "Every company has redundancy built into its communication infrastructure," said a network specialist at a leading exporter. "We have factored in the possibility of multiple hits in different cities during a war." 
Cool-headed calculation like that is what the industry is counting on from clients. Gerhard Watzinger, chief executive of Mascot Systems, an important Indian software exporter, said sheer value for money would keep the American orders coming in. Mascot has 35 project proposals pending in the United States, he said.
Other industries in India are also feeling the effects of war fears. Among garment makers, another important export sector, the mood is sober. "We are not panicking, even though a lot of buyers have canceled visits in the last few days," said Ashwin Hinduja, director of Gokaldas Exports, a leading garment exporter based here.
June is the month when buyers come to India to see goods and place orders for the next spring season, and Manu Chablani of Krishna Krishna Knitworld said that a number of American buyers had canceled sampling visits. "The situation bodes ill," he said.
The evacuation of staff from the embassies of the United States and several European countries was compounding the problem, he said. "If buyers don't come, we will have to travel with samples. But if missions are understaffed, will visas be available?
"This whole India-Pakistan thing is a nightmare for us."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Breaking Pace, Major Gauges Rise on News From Oracle

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Wall Street had its first winning session in more than a week yesterday after encouraging news from Oracle started a last-minute rally in technology shares. The Dow Jones industrial average surged more than 100 points.
 The increases came late in the day, with technology stocks having strong gains only after reports that Oracle did not plan to issue an earnings warning for its fourth quarter. Analysts said the response reflected Wall Street's hunger for something to rally on and did not signal an improvement in market conditions. 
 "People had been betting Oracle would warn," Stephen Massocca, president of Pacific Growth Equities, said. "When it didn't, it became an excuse for people to buy." 
The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 108.96 points, or 1.1 percent, at 9,796.80, after losing 237 points over Monday and Tuesday.
Broader stock measures also rose, particularly the Nasdaq index, which increased 17.14 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,595.26. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 9.21 points, or 0.9 percent, to 1,049.90. 
It was the first session since May 23 in which all three indicators closed higher.
The day started quietly. Wal-Mart Stores reported stronger-than-expected sales in May, and Avon Products, the direct seller of makeup, reaffirmed its earnings forecast. But that news failed to ignite a broad rally. Although blue chips were higher for much of the session, technology did not catch up until the Oracle announcement. 
Shares in Wal-Mart rose 96 cents, to $54.96, as shares in Avon gained $2.69, or 5.2 percent, to $54.64.
Although many analysts expect that May retail sales will be disappointing over all, the buying spread to other retailers. The Gap rose 63 cents, to $15.18, after Prudential Securities upgraded the stock. 
Technology stocks received a lift from Oracle, which gained 84 cents, to $8.66. Microsoft rose $1.68, to $51.66, and Intel jumped 68 cents, to $28.18. Intel is scheduled to release a midquarter update today. The stock is considered an indicator of where the broader technology sector is headed, and Oracle's announcement might have allayed investors' fears that Intel's news would be terrible. 
Shares in Philip Morris dropped 36 cents, to $57.36, after the Oregon Court of Appeals reinstated a $79.5 million punitive damage award against the tobacco maker in a lawsuit that accused the company of knowing that smoking was harmful and concealing the facts. 
The market responded to Oracle's announcement, analysts said, because few companies have felt confident enough to forecast solid business ahead. Earnings reports that will be released next month could alleviate or intensify Wall Street's concerns about the pace of a recovery. 
Investors are also uneasy because of the number of companies, including Microsoft and the oil services company Halliburton, that have faced questions about or made changes to their accounting practices because of government scrutiny. --------------------

Treasury Prices Decline
(By Bloomberg News)
Treasuries fell yesterday as an industry report showed that services, the biggest part of the economy, grew more than expected in May.
Some investors sold government debt and bought stocks, as a bet that the economy's recovery from recession would bolster corporate profits.
By late in the day, the 10-year note had declined 4/32, to a price of 98 21/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, increased to 5.05 percent from 5.03 percent on Tuesday.
The 30-year bond also dropped, falling 11/32, to 96 2/32. Its yield increased to 5.65 percent from 5.63 percent.

HEADLINE: New York's Arts Budget 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the City Council face a challenge in adopting a new budget (news articles, May 30 and 31). Although every constituency must sacrifice, it would be wise to minimize the cut to the cultural budget. 
 Nonprofit cultural organizations employ 20,000 people throughout New York City. In fact, the city gets back in tax revenue as much as it contributes to these groups, according to a new report commissioned by the Alliance for the Arts. Further, they raise $6 for every dollar the city provides. In return for $100 million in city support, nonprofit arts groups generate $5 billion in economic activity. 
If we keep our museums and theaters and zoos open, we proclaim the values that symbolize New York to the world and remind everyone that we are undefeated. Culture is New York's calling card and our main attraction to tourists. These messages need to be heard now, more than ever.

RANDALL BOURSCHEIDT
President, Alliance for the Arts
New York, May 31, 2002

HEADLINE: 'Freedom to Farm' Law Becomes Freedom to Add Subsidies 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 5 

 BODY:
Farmers who raise lentils, a crop so ancient it is mentioned in the Book of Genesis, have survived for years without government assistance. But Congress has decided they need a little help.
 In the farm bill that President Bush signed last month, it created subsidies for lentil growers, guaranteeing them prices substantially above current levels, which are the lowest in 15 years. It provided similar guarantees for growers of small chickpeas. 
 So how is it possible that six years after Congress tried to wean farmers from subsidies and let the market dictate prices, a new subsidy was born? 
The noble experiment in market-driven policy, the 1996 Freedom to Farm law, fell victim to powerful economic forces and election-year jockeying that catered to every region of the country. 
Subsidies beget subsidies, and that is where lentils came in.
Supporters argued that lentils and chickpeas needed help to compete with other crops subsidized by the federal government, or with crops subsidized by foreign governments.
They found a champion in Senator Kent Conrad, Democrat of North Dakota, where farmers grow lentils and chickpeas in rotation with crops like wheat and barley, already subsidized by the government. Growers of lentils and chickpeas said it was difficult to compete with Canadian farmers because Canada had lower freight rates and better crop insurance as well as a weak currency, which makes its exports more affordable. 
The farmers found allies in a half-dozen nearby states that grow lentils and chickpeas. Conservative Idaho Republicans fought for the new program, alongside liberal Minnesota Democrats.
"Every country that produces agricultural products subsidizes them in some way," said Senator Conrad, whose family has been in North Dakota for five generations. "This is a little like the cold war. You have to build up to build down. If you don't fight back, you consign American farmers to failure."
The U.S.A. Dry Pea and Lentil Council, based in Moscow, Idaho, hired a Washington lobbyist who specializes in farm issues.
The lobbyist, John D. Gordley, said: "It's always difficult to establish a new farm program. A lot of people think we ought to get rid of these programs instead of setting up new ones."
The lentil program is one of many subsidies and benefits sprinkled through the farm bill. Growers of ginseng, onions, apples and catfish all receive benefits. Even in a time of shrinking budget surpluses, such measures passed with little trouble.
Under the program for lentils and chickpeas, if market prices fall below levels specified in the new law, ($11.94 for 100 pounds of lentils and $7.56 for 100 pounds of chickpeas), the government will make up the difference. With these "deficiency payments," farmers are assured of a certain income and can obtain the loans they need to stay in business. In the past, many lenders discouraged farmers from growing lentils and chickpeas because the government provided no price supports for them.
Representative Dan Miller, Republican of Florida, who opposed the new subsidy, said: "Lentils make good soup. But why is the federal government getting into the subsidy business? It makes no sense to keep expanding the size and scope of the federal government."
That sentiment, however, was relatively rare in the farm bill debate. It was more common for lawmakers to argue that the money could be better used to subsidize other crops.
In addition, Californians feared that the new subsidies, by stimulating production in the Midwest, could take business from their state. "The new payments will result in subsidized competition against California garbanzo farmers," said Representative Cal Dooley, Democrat of California. (Chickpeas are often called garbanzos, especially when referring to larger ones used in salads and soups.)
As chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, Mr. Conrad has been a zealous advocate of fiscal discipline. But he had no apologies for the farm bill, which he expects to increase farm payments to North Dakota by 68 percent, to $676 million this year.
The Congressional Budget Office puts the cost of assistance for lentils and chickpeas at nearly $12 million a year, or $116 million over 10 years -- a pittance in a bill expected to increase farm spending by $79 billion over 10 years, to $242 billion. 
Now, farmers and ranchers are coming back to Congress, seeking at least $2.3 billion in disaster assistance, mainly to cover losses caused by severe drought in the last year. 
Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana, the senior Republican on the Agriculture Committee, questioned the need for such aid so soon after passage of the farm bill.
But Larry Barbie, president of the Montana Grain Growers Association, said, "Without disaster assistance, many of Montana's producers won't be around to participate in the benefits of the farm bill." 
Senator Michael B. Enzi, Republican of Wyoming, said that ranchers in his state were in dire need of disaster assistance. "What's the use of the farm bill if my farmers have been sucked dry and my farms are out of business?" Mr. Enzi asked.
The Midwest and Great Plains states were not the only ones to benefit from the farm bill. Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, secured assistance as well.
Section 10106 of the new law says, in its entirety: "The secretary of agriculture shall use $10 million of the funds of the Commodity Credit Corporation to make a grant to the State of New York to be used to support onion producers in Orange County, N.Y., that have suffered losses to onion crops during one or more of the 1996 through 2000 crop years."
Mr. Schumer said the overall law would also provide a "a giant stimulus package" for New York agriculture, with federal payments averaging $15,200 a year for each dairy farmer and $12,925 this year for each apple grower.
Other provisions of the new law benefit ginseng growers in Wisconsin; catfish growers in Arkansas and Louisiana; and the John Hancock Life Insurance Company, the biggest owner of peanut-growing licenses. 
Ginseng, used for centuries as a folk medicine in China, has gained new popularity in the United States. Wisconsin produces 97 percent of the ginseng grown in this country, and its high-quality product commands a premium in world markets.
Senator Russell D. Feingold, Democrat of Wisconsin, said plant products imported from Asia had been mislabeled as ginseng root when, in fact, they came from a bush of a different species.
The farm bill stipulates that products may not be labeled or advertised as ginseng unless they are derived from a particular type of plant. It prohibits use of the term "Siberian ginseng," which refers to a bush of a different species.
"Ginseng is a root, not a bush," Mr. Feingold said. "Consumers have a right to know that when they reach for a high-quality ginseng product, they are buying just that -- ginseng, not some ground-up bush."
Another provision of the farm bill, which generated intense debate, says that food labels must show the country of origin for most meat, fish, fruit and vegetables.
Senator Tim Johnson, Democrat of South Dakota, and Representative Mary Bono, Republican of California, insisted on this requirement, saying that if American consumers had a choice, they would buy meat and produce from the United States.
The Grocery Manufacturers of America and the National Food Processors Association opposed the requirement as a form of protectionism, saying it would raise costs without providing consumers any useful information about food safety.
When it became clear that Congress would adopt some requirement, food companies lobbied successfully for an exemption to make clear that they did not have to identify the source of every ingredient in a can of soup or a frozen pizza.
"The tomatoes, meat, spinach and cheese in frozen lasagna could come from 16 different countries," said Michael D. Gill, vice president of the American Frozen Food Institute.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lentils and chickpeas have become eligible for subsidies. This farmer in North Dakota, planting spring wheat last month, also grows chickpeas. (Will Kincaid for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Accord Nears To Give Mayor School Control 

BYLINE:  By ABBY GOODNOUGH

 BODY:
With possibly just one last sticking point delaying an agreement to give Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg control of New York City's vast school system, Mr. Bloomberg and Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver are to meet this morning in hopes of reaching a quick compromise on the historic deal.
 Officials on both sides said the two political leaders were still divided over whether people who lack education credentials could be named chancellor without getting a waiver from the state. Current state law requires such a waiver, but Mr. Bloomberg, who has hinted that he will seek a new chancellor from the business world, wants that provision abolished because it dilutes his power to choose whomever he wants. 
 Although Assembly Democrats said their opposition to removing the waiver requirement was philosophical -- they said it would be unfair to allow people with no education background to run the nation's largest, most complex school system -- it is also politically motivated. The state education commissioner, who decides whether to grant waivers to chancellor candidates, is appointed by the State Board of Regents -- whose members are chosen mostly by Mr. Silver and the Assembly.
According to both sides, all the other disagreements that had muddled negotiations and even threatened to blow up a deal in recent weeks had been effectively resolved by late yesterday. (The meeting was to have been held last night, but Mr. Silver's flight from Albany was delayed.)
Mr. Silver, they said, had relented to Mr. Bloomberg's demand that the chancellor alone hire district superintendents, and that local school boards be stripped of all or most of their role in the process.
In return, Mr. Bloomberg has agreed to let the reconfigured Board of Education, which he will control and which will lose almost all its powers, approve the school system's expense and capital budgets. That power means little, however, because the board's disapproval cannot block those budgets, which are controlled by the mayor.
Mr. Bloomberg has also assented to Mr. Silver's demand that the board, which will expand to 13 members from 7, vote on certain policy changes, according to people on both sides of the negotiations. But the chancellor, who will be appointed by and presumably loyal to the mayor, will decide which policies merit a board vote, these people said. (Since 8 of the 13 members on a new board would be appointed by the mayor, and could be removed by him at any time, they would almost certainly follow his wishes, anyway.) Aides to Mr. Bloomberg and Mr. Silver were still negotiating the language of these provisions yesterday.
Finally, Mr. Bloomberg has agreed to guarantee that New York City will not cut its share of school spending from year to year except in times of major financial crisis, according to both sides. But here, too, the language was still being worked out yesterday.
Steven Sanders, chairman of the Assembly Education Committee, said in an interview that the Assembly felt strongly about not removing the waiver requirement for chancellors.
"That is a slippery slope that could go downhill very quickly," said Mr. Sanders, who has been negotiating the details of an agreement with Deputy Mayor Dennis M. Walcott. "Maybe some day we won't have a mayor who's as scrupulous as this one, who will want to appoint his biggest fund-raiser or favorite adviser as chancellor."
Asked about the waiver question, Deputy Mayor Marc V. Shaw, who has also been immersed in the negotiations, said, "It is an outstanding issue."
Both sides have agreed to abolish the 32 community school boards by next June, and to solicit ideas from the public on what to replace them with. The Justice Department must approve any changes to the boards -- including their reduced role in hiring superintendents -- to ensure that they do not dilute the voting power of minorities in the Bronx, Manhattan and Brooklyn. Officials said that Mr. Silver and Mr. Bloomberg might appoint a task force to solicit public opinion and plan the boards' replacement starting this fall.
Any agreement would have to be approved not only by the Assembly but by the Republican-controlled State Senate and Gov. George E. Pataki, who is also a Republican. Officials in Albany warned yesterday that passage of a law could be delayed if Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader, was not satisfied with Mr. Bloomberg's and Mr. Silver's agreement.
In another sign that a deal was imminent, the Bloomberg administration yesterday scheduled collective bargaining sessions with the city teachers' union for today and Friday. The city's 80,000 teachers have worked without a new contract for 19 months and have threatened to strike, but Mr. Bloomberg has been reluctant to approve a contract deal until he knows whether he will control the schools. The issues still in dispute are how the teachers will spend the extra 100 minutes they have agreed to work each week -- either in instruction or in training or some combination -- and whether to add 20 minutes to each day or bundle the extra time into two 50-minute sessions.

HEADLINE: Technology Briefing Software: Manugistics Shares Fall After Loss Is Posted 

BYLINE:  NYT (Compiled by Gary Bradford) 

 BODY:
 Shares of the Manugistics Group, a software company in Rockville, Md., dropped almost 26 percent yesterday after it said it recorded a first-quarter loss because of weakened sales. The company had predicted a profit. Shares fell $2.04, to $5.90. Sales declined in April and May, company officials said on Tuesday, compared with March when demand appeared to be recovering. Gregory J. Owens, the company's chief executive, said "financial performance this quarter was adversely impacted by the continuing global economic downturn." The company said it lost $16 million to $18 million in the period that ended Friday. While sales were $71 million to $73 million for the quarter, the company had predicted a range of $84 million to $85 million. Mr. Owens said he would consider some job cuts. Manugistics, makes software that helps companies share inventory, pricing and planning information with customers and suppliers over the Internet.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

Goldman Sachs Chief Urges Changes in Corporations
In a rare public appearance, the chairman and chief executive of Goldman Sachs, Henry M. Paulson Jr., called for changes in how public companies are run, audited and regulated to help restore investor confidence. He said faith in executives was at a low and was slowing a recovery in financial markets.
 In his speech, Mr. Paulson was surprisingly critical of the corporate executives and directors who make up the client base of major investment banks like Goldman. Seldom does such a powerful Wall Street executive take on corporate America so directly. Page A1.

Chris Matthews, the host of the nightly talk show on MSNBC, has signed a contract extension through June 2009. C4.

Legal Costs at Issue at Adelphia
Outside directors of Adelphia Communications are refusing to cover the legal costs and expenses for four members of the Rigas family and another former employee in any litigation related to the management of the company, people briefed on the situation said. C2.

War Talk Disrupts Business in India
The tensions in South Asia are taking a toll on India's software industry. New business is drying up because foreign clients -- mainly Americans -- are avoiding the region. Though India's main technology center is more than 1,000 miles from Pakistan, companies are bracing for war. World Business, Section W.

Waksal Relatives Said to Sell Shares
ImClone Systems has found that more than one relative of its former chief executive, Samuel D. Waksal, sold shares in the days before the company received an unfavorable ruling from the Food and Drug Administration. C2.

Vivendi Said to Be Trying to Sell Unit
The News Corporation is negotiating with Vivendi Universal to acquire control of Telepiu, a satellite-television company in Italy, for about $1 billion, people close to the talks said. The negotiations appear to be in the early stages. Vivendi is under pressure from investors to pare its roughly $30 billion in debt. C4.

Securities Marketing Is Questioned
A Treasury official has questioned the way Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac are marketing debt securities to small investors. C7.

Services Index Rises in May
The Institute for Supply Management reported that its monthly index of the services industry increased in May to 60.1, from 55.3 in April, reaching its highest level since late 2000. C2.

The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 108.96 points, at 9,796.80. The Nasdaq increased 17.14 points, to 1,595.26, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 9.21 points, to 1,049.90. It was the first session all three indicators closed higher since May 23. C7.

Odd Couple in an Odd Recession
In the last six months, output has barely grown but hours worked have fallen sharply. As a result, labor productivity has grown at a healthy pace. While that may be good for the economy, it may not necessarily be good for business. Hal R. Varian: Economic Scene. C2.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; 
An Antic Outsider Turns Two Worlds Inside Out

BYLINE:  By MICHIKO KAKUTANI 

 BODY:
THE RUSSIAN DEBUTANTE'S HANDBOOK
By Gary Shteyngart
452 pages. Riverhead Books. $24.95.
 The "Russian debutante" in Gary Shteyngart's very funny, very deft first novel is one Vladimir Girshkin, a feckless 25-year-old Russian-American who works as a junior clerk at an immigrant assistance agency in Manhattan. He's what Kingsley Amis's Lucky Jim would be, if he were a Russian emigre trying to cope with the confusions of life in America of the 1990's and the incessant demands of an ambitious and endlessly aggrieved mother. 
 Vladimir is an engaging enough fellow, but he's also a shameless opportunist and self-loathing nerd: envious of those more attractive and successful than he is, self-conscious about his imperfect command of Western manners and mores, and eager to buy himself a portion of the American Dream at any cost.
In "The Russian Debutante's Handbook," Mr. Shteyngart tells the uproarious and highly entertaining story of how Vladimir journeys from St. Petersburg to Scarsdale and back to Eastern Europe, and how he becomes in the interim a kingpin in the Russian mafia. But at the same time the author -- who, like his hero, was born in Leningrad and moved to the United States as a boy -- also uses Vladimir's picaresque adventures to satirize Americans' and Russians' preconceptions about their former cold war enemies and to send up their illusions about themselves.
Like Salman Rushdie and Bharati Mukherjee, Mr. Shteyngart uses his appraising outsider's eye to examine the bizarre, weightless state of exile (its conferring of freedom, but also rootlessness and dislocation); and like Victor Pelevin, he proves himself a nimble cultural magpie, borrowing street argot from both the East and West to create a wonderfully idiomatic, jet-fueled prose. His voice, however, is thoroughly his own, by turns ironic and earnest, farcical and melancholy, as attuned to the exhilarating possibilities of the English language as Martin Amis, as deadpan funny as the young Evelyn Waugh.
Vladimir, Mr. Shteyngart writes, was the "enduring victim of every practical joke the late 20th century had to offer." This "coddled single child" of parents who had left Russia for the wilds of Westchester and who had "paid $25,000 a year to send him to a progressive Midwestern college" will journey through the hip provinces of downtown Manhattan and, on the run from money problems and an amorous member of the Catalan cartel, will wind up in a small Eastern European country, in the employ of a gangster known as the Groundhog.
Raised in Russia, schooled in America, Vladimir is a knowledgeable but itchy outsider wherever he goes. "Vladimir was 50 percent functional American, and 50 percent cultured Eastern European in need of a haircut and a bath," Mr. Shteyngart writes. "He was the best of both worlds. Historically, a little dangerous, but, for the most part, nicely tamed by Coca-Cola" and "blue-light specials."
In New York, college Marxists and politically correct liberals adopt Vladimir as their pet, and he soon becomes an avatar of "Immigrant Chic," embraced by his girlfriend Francesca's parents and courted by her Slavophile friend Frank, who says things like, "Don't forget that Vladimir has an expansive Russian soul," and "Camaraderie and salvation, that's his game." In Eastern Europe, where he is regarded as an expert on America, Vladimir sets about giving the Groundhog's troops "American Lessons," goading his students to rid themselves of their kitschiest possessions: "the nylon track suits, the Rod Stewart compilations, the worn Romanian sneakers, everything that had qualified the Groundhog's vast crew as Easterners, Soviets, cold war losers."
To Vladimir, "Americans were too keen to invent their own troubles," Mr. Shteyngart writes. "To paraphrase an old Russian expression, they were wild with their own fat." As for Russians like the Groundhog, Vladimir sees them as history's casualties: "Everything they grew up with is gone. So what are their options now? They can either shoot their way through the gray economy or make $25 a month driving a bus in Dnepropetrovsk."
Mr. Shteyngart's depiction of Vladimir's adventures is so manic that his poor hero sometimes seems like a billiard ball careering from one head-on collision to another. His billowing money woes in New York; his encounter with the Groundhog's madman of a father, who has conversations with electric fans; his flight from America, pursued by a convoy of thugs driving peach-colored Cadillacs; his Ponzi scheme for making the Groundhog's organization even richer by selling horse tranquilizers and literary dreams to young, well-heeled Americans: all are delineated with the antic glee of a natural farceur. 
And the people Vladimir meets along the way are sketched with an equally wicked and comic hand: his two impossible New York girlfriends, the pudgy, grudging Challah, and the snooty, doctrinaire Francesca; the jovial but deadly Groundhog, and his nutty, irascible father; and Morgan, the beautiful, plain-spoken terrorist with whom Vladimir falls in love.
Together these people populate the black comedy world in which Vladimir pursues his dreams, and they help the very talented Mr. Shteyngart expose the absurdities that exist on either side of the former iron curtain.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gary Shteyngart (Ioana Bontea/Riverhead Books)

HEADLINE: Greve Journal; 
Sometimes Slowing Down Can Really Get Hectic

BYLINE:  By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: GREVE, Italy 

 BODY:
Since Paolo Saturnini declared this old market town, in the heart of Chianti country, a slow city, life has never been so hectic.
 Mr. Saturnini, 52, has been mayor of Greve for 13 years, and his inspiration came from the Slow Food movement that arose in the 1980's to oppose fast food and its values of homogeneity, impersonality and haste. 
 When McDonald's began to open in Italian cities, Slow Food proponents set up tables in the street in front and served traditional dishes like pasta in meals lasting hours. Next came long lunches, a movement in Tuscany that fosters old-style lunches, stretched out over hours, with traditional dishes that often take as long to prepare as unhurried diners take to consume them. 
If Slow Food and long lunches, Mr. Saturnini reasoned, why not slow cities?
"Cities are becoming all uniform; they are losing their identity, their souls," Mr. Saturnini lamented in a recent conversation. In commerce, he added, chain stores triumph, creating sameness in food and customs. "It's a negative uniformity," he said.
A slow city, by contrast, would preserve its architectural heritage, typical dishes and inherited customs. So two years ago, Mr. Saturnini founded the International Network of Slow Cities. Today, five Italian cities belong, and 40 more want to join.
But Greve -- once known for little more than being the birthplace of the explorer Giovanni da Verrazano -- now finds itself with little time to slow down. 
"Everyone's running," complained Alessandra Molletti, Mr. Saturnini's assistant, taking time to show a visitor around, since the mayor's calendar was full. Being a slow city, she said, "is a two-edged benefit -- it helps us live better, but it's also commercially useful."
Mr. Saturnini says he wants to leave his son something of his grandparents, Ms. Molletti explained, and in a world full of uniformity, Greve finds that individuality sells well. So like much of Tuscany, Greve is thriving selling its uniqueness. Unemployment has been replaced by a labor shortage, and while the young once emigrated for jobs, they are returning. Ms. Molletti is an example: a native of the region, she spent eight years working in the theater in New York, before settling in Greve.
Stefano Falorni never left. For eight generations, his forebears ran the pork store on the main piazza. But Italy's opening to the rest of Europe, which led other local butchers to import pork from the Netherlands and beef from Denmark, nearly drove the Falornis out of business.
So five years ago, Mr. Falorni, now 55, revived a near-extinct race of local free-ranging hogs to produce salami and ham. Now, Mr. Falorni employs 40 people raising the distinctive black and white hogs and producing meat products. Local restaurants feature pasta with meat sauce from the hogs, and tourists fill his store. The meat is shipped throughout Europe, and orders come from as far as Hong Kong.
"We put our soul in this salami," Mr. Falorni says, tugging at a bushy moustache. "Not just pork." Asked whether he found time for long lunches, he confessed he usually sneaks off for a sandwich.
Greve's backwardness, he said, became an asset. His competitors, he went on, "are outside biting their nails, while we're making money."
For decades after World War II, Ms. Molletti said, the people of Greve, like so many Italians, sought modernity in neon signs to replace old hand-painted ones, and aluminum front doors, rather than wood. Now Mr. Saturnini campaigns against neon and aluminum. He urges store owners to put out flower boxes of geraniums, and rewards with diplomas those who paint their facades. He has banned big hotel chains, like Sheraton, and sought to instill a taste for tradition in the young by asking school cafeterias to serve the kind of bread soup their grandmothers used to cook, and teachers to take their pupils on field trips to the grape harvest to learn about wine.
Of course, no one here mistakes this return to past ways with the real thing, whose main features were poverty and unemployment.
Sandro Checcucci, 35, ran a quiet wine bar until two years ago. Then, local investors, including Mr. Falorni, restored a block of quaint wine cellars that had stood unused for 30 years. They installed one of Tuscany's biggest wine shops and hired Mr. Checcucci to run it. Now, streams of visitors taste the 1,100 Tuscan wines that Mr. Checcucci offers. In place of unemployment, he said, "we now lack workers, especially in the tourist season." The 15- to 20-year olds often leave, tired of the quaintness, he said, though many return in search of work. What's missing now, he added, is "social life -- not jobs."
Still, Rossella Rossi, who runs the 10-room hotel on the piazza, said there was no mistaking the new Greve with the town of her youth. Around Greve, fields once terraced with grape and olives that were tended by hand are now sloped to allow for tractors and other mechanized equipment, Ms. Rossi, a woman in her 30's, said. "Where the bookstore is, there was a greengrocer," she said, "and a poultry shop where they now sell souvenirs."
"It's developed," she added. "But it has lost that aspect of genuineness."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Above, the main square of Greve, whose mayor founded the Slow Cities movement to bring back something of the past. That produced a commercial boom, helped by tourists who now crowd cafes to sample the 1,100 Tuscan wines on offer. HEADLINE: Group Says Course Training Still Breaks Along Sex Lines 

BYLINE:  By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 6 

 BODY:
Three decades after Congress passed Title IX, the law meant to end sex discrimination in publicly financed education, vocational and technical courses remain as heavily segregated by sex as ever, according to a report released here today.
 The report, by the National Women's Law Center, a nonprofit group representing women on economic, education and workplace issues, analyzed enrollment figures in high school vocational and technical courses nationwide. It found that 96 percent of the students training for jobs in cosmetology, for example, were female. Young women account for more than 85 percent of the students taking child care and health aide courses. 
 Training for traditionally male fields, too, showed little change, with young men accounting for 94 percent of students in plumbing and electrical work, 93 percent of the students in welding and carpentry, and 92 percent in auto mechanics courses. The patterns were the same in every state and region.
The group also filed a dozen complaints, one for every regional office of the federal Education Department's Office of Civil Rights. The complaints detailed segregation in vocational and technical courses by sex and demanded investigations into whether public schools were violating Title IX. 
"The evidence is clear; far too many schools are providing inferior opportunities for their female students," Marcia D. Greenberger, co-president of the National Women's Law Center, said at a press conference today. "What we found was unconscionable."
In a statement, C. Todd Jones, deputy assistant secretary for enforcement in the Office for Civil Rights, said the office was "committed to ensuring that girls and boys have equal access to the vocational programs that interest them" and would "vigorously investigate each of the complaints filed by the National Women's Law Center and determine whether the schools are in compliance with Title IX."
Along with the enrollment data, the group released federal wage figures showing that workers in the heavily female service fields earned a fraction of what workers earned in the building trades and computer support, both fields dominated by men. The median income for health aides, for example, is $11.06 an hour, and for beauticians, it is $8.49 an hour. In contrast, the median wage for electricians is $19.29 an hour, while computer support specialists earn $17.53 an hour.
More conservative groups like the Heritage Foundation did not instantly support the law center's conclusions. Krista Kafer, senior policy analyst at the Heritage Foundation, said that while discrimination might crop up, "I don't think that it's a conspiracy or a pattern of discrimination, of people not enforcing Title IX, or teachers and guidance counselors dropping the ball."
"In the end," Ms. Kafer said, "it does come down to personal preference."
The complaints, however, say that more than personal taste creates the disparities. 
They said that counselors often steer young women away from vocational and highly technical courses. 
The group also cited recruitment drives that send messages both subtle and overt that girls are not welcome. At one vocational school recruitment fair, Ms. Greenberger said, the display for Samuel L. Gompers Vocational School in New York featured a banner that read, "Gompers Builds Mechanical Men."
Geri Harston, a Chicago electrician, said she had been turned down when she wanted to learn electrical work in high school and was steered toward nursing courses instead. Ms. Harston said she was discouraged from a construction-related job on the grounds that as a woman, she could not lift heavy objects. But as a nurse, she handled patients that weighed up to 600 pounds.
"Just the act of turning them from side to side to prevent bed sores was as physical as anything I've experienced as an electrician," she said.
It was not until seven years after graduating from high school, Ms. Harston said, that she found the course that trained her for the job she really wanted.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Negativity Reigns Again, Wiping Out Wednesday Gains

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Wall Street's fortunes turned negative again yesterday as a downgrade of chip makers by Merrill Lynch and disappointing sales by retailers gave investors more reasons to doubt the strength of an economic recovery. Shares fell sharply, with the technology sector suffering the heaviest losses.
 After a respite on Wednesday, the market resumed a decline that has lasted more than a week, giving back gains from the previous session. Investors are selling on worries about earnings, mistrust of corporate accounting and the conflicts in the Middle East and between India and Pakistan. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 172.16 points, or 1.8 percent, at 9,624.64. The loss easily wiped out the Dow's gain of 108.96 points on Wednesday, when all of the major indicators finished higher for the first time in nearly two weeks. 
The broader market also fell sharply yesterday. The Nasdaq index dropped 40.38 points, or 2.5 percent, to 1,554.88, losing all of its 17.14 advance from Wednesday. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 20.75, or 2.0 percent, to 1,029.15, more than erasing Wednesday's gain of 9.21. 
Analysts said the market's persistent selling was no surprise because earnings remained depressed, jeopardizing the recovery investors had hoped would happen in the second half of 2002. 
Fears of improper bookkeeping, involving Tyco International and several other companies in the wake of the Enron debacle, and worries about tensions overseas have also given investors little reason to buy, analysts said. 
The chip maker Intel fell $1.18, to $27, after Merrill Lynch lowered its near-term rating on the stock. Shares in two other chip makers that were downgraded by by Merrill also declined; Texas Instruments fell 75 cents, to $27.69, and Triquint Semiconductor fell 91 cents, to $7.47. 
Weak retail sales for May also drove the market lower. Shares in AnnTaylor, a retailer of women's career clothing, fell $1.28, to $26.80 after the company reported a 5.2 percent decline in sales from stores open at least a year. Shares in Sears, Roebuck stumbled $1.76, to $56.26, after the company reported a 4.4 percent drop in sales at its department stores. 
Tyco International plunged nearly 16 percent, down $2.70 at $14.60, on concerns about its former chief executive L. Dennis Kozlowski, who has been indicted on charges of evading New York sales taxes. New York prosecutors are investigating whether Mr. Kozlowski tapped company accounts to buy his $18 million Manhattan apartment or whether he received interest-free loans from Tyco to buy artwork. 
Oracle fell 51 cents, to $8.15, yesterday, losing some of its 84-cent gain from Wednesday when the chief executive, Lawrence J. Ellison, said the company would meet fourth-quarter expectations for earnings of 12 cents a share. 
Many analysts see no signs of a reprieve for Wall Street. 
Earnings are the biggest factor weighing on stocks, said Gary Kaltbaum, market technician for Investors' Edge Partners in Orlando, Fla. "To get things going, you have to beat earnings and beat them good." 
Meeting already lowered expectations, he said, is not enough to inspire investors to buy and hold onto shares. --------------------

Treasury Prices Increase
 By Bloomberg News
Treasuries gained yesterday as investors fled a declining stock market for government-guaranteed debt even as signs point to stronger economic growth. 
By late in the day, the 10-year note had increased 18/32 , to a price of 99 /32 . The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, declined to 4.98 percent from 5.05 percent on Wednesday.
The 30-year bond also increased, rising 21/32 , to 96 3/32 . Its yield decreased to 5.61 percent from 5.65 percent.

HEADLINE: Half the Afghans, the Women, Fight to Establish Their Rights 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

 BODY:
When Afghanistan's grand council convenes next week to begin creating a new political order, one task will be to select the writers of a new Constitution. There has never been a moment with more promise -- or long-term danger -- for Afghan women.
 Three of them -- a lawyer, a law professor and a judge -- brought that message to New York this week, along with an urgent plea for help, meeting with American foundations, law firms and the Bar Association of the City of New York. 
 Soraya Paikan, a lawyer and member of the grand council, or loya jirga, said in an interview on Monday that there are signs that newly won women's freedoms are already under threat, and that women must take part in writing the Constitution if they are to achieve protection. 
The task of drawing women into the process can seem overwhelming. "Afghan women don't know their rights," said Ms. Paikan, 42, a founder of the Afghan Women Lawyers and Professionals Association, which emerged in January from four years underground. 
She is in New York with two colleagues from the association's board -- Hangama Anwari, a law scholar, and Nafisa Kabuli, a judge in the struggling juvenile justice system. The association has trained 40 women in basic human rights. It wants to send dozens more across Afghanistan to explain to women in towns and rural villages about the evolution of political life and how they can work to ensure that developments work to their advantage. 
The women brought a meticulous list of what their association needs, from chairs and kitchen items to a car and eight computers, to open a center in Kabul. All told, they need $237,600. It seems a lot to them.
Visibility is equally important. Ms. Anwari, 26, said, "One of the purposes of our visit here -- beside getting some financial and material support from outsiders -- is to introduce the aims and the goals and the dreams of Afghan women lawyers to the international community." 
The women spoke at the offices of Equality Now, an organization that works on women's rights in more than 100 countries. 
Afghanistan once had hundreds of women trained in law. For 57 years, before women were banned by the Taliban, Kabul University graduated coeducational law classes that included 20 to 40 women a year. But they were not active in political life and women's rights. Many also left the country during the last 23 years of war. 
Ms. Kabuli, 41, was among those who stayed and worked underground, and she is now a judge dealing with youthful offenders; girls as well as boys are often charged with robbery in these difficult economic times, she said. During Taliban rule, from 1996 until last fall, she ran one of hundreds of clandestine home schools for girls.
"One of the first violations of the Taliban against women was that they instantly got rid of the female judges," Ms. Kabuli said. "As a consequence of that, and because the schools were closed, I had a home school and taught up to 300 students. The girls had to come one by one to school because if they came a group, they might have been arrested." 
Ms. Kabuli said the problem with the Taliban was not that they were Muslims. "Islam brought a certain equality to men and women," she said. "The laws that the Taliban brought were from pre-Islamic times, based on traditional law."
Those traditions die hard, Ms. Paikan said.

HEADLINE: Zimbabwean Court Grants Bail To Lawyers Held for Subversion 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: HARARE, Zimbabwe, June 6 

 BODY:
Facing growing international censure, a Zimbabwean court granted bail today to two top lawyers who had been arrested on subversion charges.
 Sternford Moyo, president of the nation's Law Society, and Wilbert Mapombere, a former magistrate who is the society's secretary, have denied accusations that they urged the opposition to topple President Robert Mugabe. 
 The United States government, the United Nations and the International Bar Association have all strongly condemned the arrests. 
Magistrate Dominic Musavazi dismissed police requests to hold the two in custody pending their next court appearance in August, said Joseph Mafusire, acting for the lawyers' group.
He freed Mr. Moyo and Mr. Mapombere on $95 bail each and ordered them to surrender their passports.
Under strict new security laws, subversion carries a penalty of up to 20 years in jail.
The lawyers' arrests Monday and their detention in police cells for two nights followed a government crackdown on those viewed as critics. The government has used new security and media laws to arrest journalists, opposition leaders and prominent members of civil society.
The International Bar Association, a global body of jurists and lawyers, expressed its "shock and deep concern" over the arrests, saying they were directly related to Mr. Moyo's strong stance on the rule of law and judicial independence.
The Law Society recently published a report condemning "sustained abuse, defamatory remarks and threats of violence" by the state and ruling party militants against independent judges.
The State Department protested the arrests, denouncing Zimbabwe's "continuing harassment of the free press and now lawyers through repressive legislation."
The United States and the European Union have imposed travel restrictions against Mr. Mugabe and high-level Zimbabwean government officials.
"The U.S. is reviewing additional measures aimed at bringing pressure to bear on Zimbabwe's leadership," the United States government said in a statement. "We are consulting with others in the international community who are similarly concerned about the situation in Zimbabwe."
The United Nations special investigator on the independence of judges and lawyers, Param Cumaraswamy, said today that the arrests breached international legal standards.
He said he had "grave concerns over the deterioration of the rule of law and acceleration of governmental lawlessness" in Zimbabwe.
Zimbabwe has been suffering its worst political and economic crisis since the country gained independence from Britain in 1980. Local and international human rights organizations have criticized government efforts to suppress dissent.
