HEADLINE: Torricelli and Forrester Senate Campaigns Point Fingers Over Prescription Costs 

BYLINE:  By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 6 

 BODY:
Striving to make the high cost of prescription drugs a prominent issue in New Jersey's United States Senate race, Senator Robert G. Torricelli's campaign charged today that the Republican nominee, Douglas R. Forrester, made his fortune in business by unfairly inflating the price of medications.
 But Mr. Forrester denied the allegations and said the giant pharmaceutical companies, which have contributed heavily to Mr. Torricelli's campaign, were the ones driving up drug prices. 
 Mr. Forrester, who financed his own primary campaign and is expected to spend millions more before the general election, is president of BeneCard Services Inc., which manages pharmacy benefit plans for employers. He has declared his stake in the company at more than $50 million. The entire pharmacy benefit management industry has come under fire in recent years amid complaints that the companies steer patients toward certain higher-priced medications in return for rebates from drug manufacturers.
In a news briefing at the State House today, Mr. Torricelli's campaign staff, several Democratic colleagues and an assortment of doctors and critics of the health care system asserted that companies like BeneCard have become a predatory part of the drug delivery system and had failed to deliver the savings they promised consumers. Mr. Torricelli's supporters said they could not cite specific examples of BeneCard's advising clients to use expensive drugs because the company's records are private, but insisted that it was common practice throughout the industry. Walter Worgacki, the mayor of Wallington, N.J., said that the school board in his community pays BeneCard to administer its prescription plan and that the price per employee has jumped to $90.74 this year, from $26.82 in 1995.
"BeneCard isn't putting people first, it's putting profits first," Mr. Worgacki said.
But Mr. Forrester's advisers vehemently disputed the notion that companies like BeneCard are to blame for prescription costs. Bill Pascoe, Mr. Forrester's campaign manager, said that much of the increase has been driven by the pharmaceutical manufacturers, and that Mr. Torricelli accepts more campaign money from drug companies than any other member of Congress. 
"Bob Torricelli appears to be a vacuum cleaner when it comes to accepting PAC money from pharmaceutical companies," Mr. Pascoe said. "For him to be criticizing Doug Forrester, who finds ways to make prescriptions more affordable for his clients, is outrageous. "
According to the Center for Responsive Politics, an independent watchdog group, Mr. Torricelli has received more than $85,000 from pharmaceutical companies and their political action committees this year, the second-highest of any federal legislator.
The clash over prescription costs, which came just two days after Mr. Forrester won the Republican nomination, is likely to be repeated frequently between now and Election Day. By focusing on Mr. Forrester's business activities early in the campaign, Mr. Torricelli can deflect attention from questions about his own ethics: whether he took improper gifts from a contributor in exchange for political favors. Talking about prescription drugs will also allow him to indicate that he is attuned to the economic pressures facing the elderly and middle-class families, political analysts say. 
But it is unclear whether the issue will resonate with voters in New Jersey, a major center of the pharmaceutical industry, especially because the Torricelli campaign's criticisms are about the industry in general rather than specific actions involving Mr. Forrester. In the Democratic Senate primary two years ago, Jim Florio, the former governor, made little headway by assailing the business ethics of Jon S. Corzine, the former co-chairman of Goldman Sachs, accusing him of underwriting gun manufacturers and profiting from slavery in Sudan.
Prescription drug benefits were a major issue in the 2000 presidential race, when both Al Gore and George W. Bush promised voters to push for a national plan. Because no plan has been enacted, many Democratic candidates for Congress are making prescription costs a major theme this year. In his kickoff speech Tuesday, Mr. Torricelli described it as one of the defining issues of the campaign.
After today's briefing, Mr. Torricelli's campaign manager, Ken Snyder, said there was an enormous difference between drug manufacturers and companies like BeneCard. "Pharmaceutical companies in New Jersey have great labs that produce life-saving drugs and they provide jobs for tens of thousands of New Jersey residents," Mr. Snyder said. "But Doug Forrester's company only employs 18 people and he makes enormous profits for processing claims and making average people pay exorbitant prices for medicine." 
Mr. Forrester's campaign countered that companies like BeneCard helped to slow the rise of prescription costs by cutting administrative costs. 
"Either Bob Torricelli is hopelessly ignorant about the prescription business and should be removed for office for incompetence," Mr. Pascoe said, "or he understands, is misleading the public and should be removed from office for throwing around such scurrilous lies."

HEADLINE: Initial Claims for Jobless Benefits Decline Sharply 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 6 

 BODY:
In a sign that the job market in the United States might be picking up, the number of workers filing first-time claims for state unemployment benefits fell last week to the lowest level in more than a year, the Labor Department reported today.
 Initial jobless claims, which offer an early glimpse into the health of the labor market, dropped 32,000 last week, to 383,000, from a revised 415,000 the previous week, the report said. 
 The size of the decline surprised some Wall Street analysts, who had forecast a slight decline, to 407,000. 
"The economy was showing some signs of improvement from the start of the year," said Gary Thayer, chief economist at A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis, "but now we're beginning to see a little more of that work its way into the labor market."
But Carey Leahey, a senior economist at Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown, said the report offered little insight into the report on May unemployment, due on Friday, which some saw as a factor in interest-rate decisions by the Federal Reserve at its next meeting June 25-26.
The Fed's policy group, the Federal Open Market Committee, is expected to leave rates unchanged. 
Unemployment claims filed last week were at the lowest level since falling by 27,000, also to 383,000, in May 2001, the Labor Department said.
The number of people applying for benefits also broke a 10-week run above 400,000, which began on March 23. Economists regard the 400,000 mark as a sign of a lackluster labor market. 
The four-week average of claims, which is considered a more accurate gauge of longer-term labor conditions because it smooths out week-to-week gyrations, fell for the sixth consecutive week, to 411,250, down from 419,750 the previous week and the lowest since 398,750 in the week ended March 23. 
But in a sign that unemployed workers were struggling to find jobs, the number of continued claims -- those collecting benefits for more than a week -- rose to 3.82 million in the week ended May 25, the latest week for which those figures were available.

HEADLINE: Japan Reports 1.4% Growth, Signaling End To Recession 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Friday, June 7 

 BODY:
Japan's economy expanded by 1.4 percent during the first quarter of this year, the government said today, ending a recession that had dragged on for a year.
 A 6.4 percent rise in exports and a 1.6 percent increase in consumer spending -- which together account for more than half the economy -- helped to revive Japan's economy, the second largest in the world after the United States. The return to economic growth was slightly less robust than analysts had forecast because corporate capital spending dropped 3.2 percent compared with the last quarter of 2001. But it was the strongest growth in two years. 
 If it continues to grow at the rate it did in the first quarter, Japan's economy would expand at an annual rate of 5.7 percent, slightly better than the 5.6 percent annual rate in America in the first quarter. In the fiscal year that ended in March, Japan's economy contracted by 1.3 percent.
The numbers confirm the widely held view that Japan is emerging, if only perhaps temporarily, from an 18-month recession, its worst in a series of slumps since 1990. The report gives a minor lift to Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi, whose disapproval rating in public opinion polls is now higher than his approval rating. With approval ratings around 43 percent, Mr. Koizumi has only two weeks left in the current parliamentary session to pass bills privatizing the highways and the postal system.
But today's growth numbers do little to ease doubts about the sustainability of Japan's recovery, which is still largely driven by exports rather than domestic spending. Production has picked up -- particularly of cars, electronics and semiconductors -- but most of these products are being shipped overseas rather than used in Japan. Exports account for only about 10 percent of Japan's total economic output. Should economic growth slow in the United States, traditionally Japan's biggest export market, Japan would probably fall back into recession.
Last year, publicly traded companies in Japan lost about $100 billion, according to calculations by the Nihon Keizai newspaper. During the first quarter of this year, corporate profits generally were down 14.6 percent over the quarter a year ago.
In addition to providing a monthlong distraction from the economy, the World Cup soccer championship is also attracting about 400,000 foreign visitors to watch the games. But skeptics doubt that the tournament, which is being shared with South Korea, will give more than a temporary boost to Japan's economy.
Economists at the Dai-Ichi Life Insurance Economic Research Institute forecast that soccer fans will spend about $1.8 billion on hotels, restaurants and related purchases, providing an additional three-tenths of a percentage point of growth in the April-June period. Dentsu, Japan's largest advertising agency, is more upbeat, saying the economy will receive three times the benefit if Japan makes it into the quarterfinals of the monthlong tournament. Last winter, Dentsu estimated that soccer fans would spend $26.6 billion, a figure now seen as wildly exaggerated.
Over the last five years, Japan spent $4.6 billion to build or refurbish 10 stadiums, a government-led spending spree that may have eased past recessions. Three weeks from now, the soccer championship will be over and Japanese taxpayers will be looking at the bills.
"A lot of money has been invested in the games, but it was spent years ago on stadiums and fewer fans are coming to Japan" compared with other World Cup championships, said John Lilley, director of analytical operations at Standard & Poor's MMS International in Tokyo. "Even if the economy gets a push in June, there's no evidence it will be sustainable."
Although Japan's government officially declared last week that the economy had "bottomed out," it is unclear if the economy will be able to reorient itself in time to cope with a rapidly aging population. In 20 years, about a third of Japan's population will have reached retirement age.
To generate the self-sustaining recovery that has eluded Japan since 1990, consumers and companies must spend more and save less, Mr. Lilley said. That is unlikely to happen soon since companies are retrenching and moving operations offshore, where costs are much cheaper.
Despite a 1.6 percent rise in consumer spending in the quarter, consumers are still hunkering down. Unemployment remains relatively high, at 5.2 percent; wages are eroding; and 173,000 people filed for personal bankruptcy last year, four times the number in 1995. Graduates face the worst job market in half a century as manufacturers shift operations to China, where young engineers can be paid a fraction of what Japanese earn.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Tobacco Company Ordered To Pay a $20 Million Fine
A California judge has ruled that R. J. Reynolds Tobacco violated a 1998 settlement agreement by pursuing an advertising strategy that focused on children. The company was fined $20 million and ordered to stop putting cigarette ads in magazines with a disproportionate number of teenage readers.
 The decision was the first legal test of the tobacco settlement's prohibition on reaching out to young people and encouraging them to smoke. Page A18. 

Something Extra for a Triple Crown
Visa, which owns sponsorship rights to the Triple Crown, is rooting for War Emblem, who can win a $5 million bonus by winning the Belmont Stakes. Advertising. C6.

Shares Fall as Perot Fights Claims
Shares in Perot Systems plummeted for a second day as the company fought accusations in California that in 1998 it advised energy traders on ways to manipulate prices in the state's fledgling power markets. C5.

Questions on ImClone Share Sale
Martha Stewart, a friend of the former chief executive of ImClone Systems, sold her shares in ImClone a day or two before the company announced an unfavorable ruling on a cancer drug, people close to a Congressional investigation of the company said. C4

Rules Proposed for Corporations
The New York Stock Exchange, hoping to restore confidence in the market, has issued recommendations intended to tighten corporate governance rules. C4.

Deloitte Consulting to Go Private
Deloitte Consulting, the consulting arm of Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu, plans to become an independent firm, privately held by its partners, by the end of the year. C5.

European Court Won't Stop Merger
Europe's second-highest court has refused to block a merger of two British companies. It is the first time in 12 years that a court has overturned a European Commission decision to block a merger. World Business, Section W.

Intel Won't Meet Sales Forecast
In an announcement that surprised analysts and threatened to dispirit investors, Intel said it would not meet its expectations for sales or gross profit margin for its second quarter. The company cited weak demand in Europe, and the fact that microprocessor sales did not rise to seasonal norms. C2.

House Votes to Repeal 'Death Tax'
The House, by a margin of 256 to 71, has voted to make permanent a repeal of the estate tax, often referred to as the death tax. A1.

Partisanship Dissolves Tax Hearing
The Congressional hearing on offshore tax havens dissolved in a partisan meltdown before the issue could be fully discussed. C6.

CORRECTION-DATE: June 12, 2002

 CORRECTION:
A front-page headline on Friday about House approval of a measure to make a repeal of the estate tax permanent misstated the vote in some copies, as did an entry in all copies of the Business Digest. The vote was 256 to 171, not 71.

HEADLINE: Where Have All the Artists Gone? 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 We may have thought New York City was the cultural capital of the world, but according to Prof. Richard Florida, we slipped up somewhere along the line ("The Cities and Their New Elite," Arts & Ideas pages, June 1). 
 This is not a surprise, since the arts were withdrawn from the school curriculum starting in the 1970's. Creative development must start in the primary grades with sequential training that values the arts equally with academic subjects. Otherwise, we deny children access to higher education and to the creative labor force that drives the communications economy. 
The good news is that since 1997 we have seen an infusion of private and public money to bring the arts back to the schools. That momentum must be maintained.

JOAN D. FIRESTONE
New York, June 2, 2002

The writer is special adviser to the New York City schools chancellor for arts education.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Metro Briefing New York: Manhattan: Sales-Tax Holiday Set 

BYLINE:  By Terry Pristin (NYT) (Compiled by Anthony Ramirez) 

 BODY:
In an effort to increase retail and other sales in Lower Manhattan, city and state officials said yesterday that they had agreed to a moratorium on the 8.25 percent sales tax for nine days during the summer. The temporary exemption applies to shops, restaurants and hotels below Houston Street, where business has been hurt since the Sept. 11 terrorist attack. Goods and services costing up to $500, including restaurant meals and hotel rooms, will be exempt from the tax from this Sunday to Tuesday; July 9 to 11; and Aug. 20 to 22. The tax relief will not apply to gasoline and cigarettes and other tobacco products.
 Terry Pristin (NYT)

HEADLINE: U.S. Decides to Recognize Russia as MarketEconomy 

BYLINE:  By SABRINA TAVERNISE 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, June 6 

 BODY:
President Bush told President Vladimir V. Putin by telephone today that the United States would begin regarding Russia as a market economy, a change in semantics that has significant practical consequences for Russian-American trade.
 The move, after a similar step last week by the European Union, addresses one of Moscow's main complaints about the West, that Russia's Communist past is used as an excuse to treat it unfairly in trade disputes. 
 American antidumping laws, meant to protect American industries from unfair import competition, turn on whether goods are sold in the United States for less than they cost to make at home. For nonmarket economies, the law assumes that domestic prices are meaningless, and American trade officials use figures for a surrogate market economy country instead -- generally to the great disadvantage of the country accused of dumping. 
That provision has been especially costly for Russia in commodity goods like steel and fertilizer. In 1998, Russian steel producers agreed to deep cuts in their shipments to the United States to avoid punitive duties.
With the market economy designation, Russian companies will get to use their own cost figures in arguing dumping cases, and not be saddled with figures from third countries that may bear little relation to Russian reality. 
Russian steel makers applauded. "This is a very important and long-awaited decision," said Aleksei Mordashov, general director of Severstal, a major producer, through his spokesman. "It is a real example of the easing of tensions in Russian-American trade relations." 
The change in status is one of the economic rewards Russia has been expecting for backing the United States in its response to the Sept. 11 attacks. People here were disappointed that it was not granted when Mr. Bush and Mr. Putin met in Moscow last month.
Tonight, a statement by Mr. Putin's press office said he "hailed this step, noting that it would give a powerful impulse to the development of bilateral economic ties."
German Gref, the minister for economic development and trade, told an interviewer on Russian television that the nonmarket status had denied the country $1.5 billion a year in sales of goods to the United States.
"For Russian companies, this means more possibilities to enter the American market, and for the Russian people it means the creation of new jobs, and for the Russian economy it means new opportunities and new production of domestic goods," Mr. Gref said.
There are drawbacks, too, experts said. As a market economy, Russian state subsidies will come under greater foreign scrutiny than before. 
For example, gas and electricity, provided free in Soviet times, are still partly subsidized, and that subsidy may count against Russian producers in future dumping-related cost calculations.
"We've always told them that this is a double-edged sword," said one Western specialist in Moscow working on the issue.
Russia is also waiting for the United States Congress to scrap the Jackson-Vanik amendment, a 1974 economic sanction intended to press Communist-bloc nations to allow free emigration.
The Bush administration has asked Congress to exempt Russia from the sanctions, saying Moscow dropped discriminatory emigration practices long ago.
The amendment is one obstacle to Russia's joining the World Trade Organization, which it hopes to do as soon as next year. It is by far the largest country still outside the organization, which sets global trade rules.
A Commerce Department official told reporters on a conference call today that legal, regulatory and tax changes in Russia since 1991 had laid the groundwork for membership in the organization, Bloomberg News reported.
But there is some resistance on Capitol Hill to upgrading Russia's status, partly because Russia banned imports of American chicken for more than a month earlier this year and has been slow to grant new import licenses since the ban was lifted in mid-April. A number of lawmakers have told the administration they believe that Russia is not ready to abide by international trade rules.

HEADLINE: Bush Is Said to Be Set to Back Patients' Bill 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 6 

 BODY:
Representative Charlie Norwood, a leader of the six-year campaign for legislation defining patients' rights, said today that the White House had expressed a new willingness to support a compromise letting patients sue health insurers for medical injuries caused by substandard care.
 Mr. Norwood said he and the White House favored the proposal, which would allow patients to recover up to $4 million for pain and suffering and other noneconomic damages resulting from serious injuries. 
 "This is the best deal Congress will get," Mr. Norwood said, expressing hope that the idea would open the way to final approval of the legislation. 
The Senate, defying a veto threat from President Bush, passed a patients' bill of rights 59 to 36 last June. The House passed a different version, with a much more limited right to sue, last August by a vote of 226 to 203. Mr. Bush supported the House bill.
Under the Senate bill most cases would go to state courts, subject to any limits of state law, while the House bill would limit pain and suffering to $1.5 million.
The White House and several senators have engaged in quiet negotiations for months, especially over the legal liability of health maintenance organizations and other insurers.
Mr. Norwood, Republican of Georgia, said the negotiators had made significant progress on all other issues, and the White House confirmed that.
"Both sides have come a million miles," Mr. Norwood said. "They are down to the last inch."
In an interview, Mr. Norwood said White House officials had assured him they would accept a $4 million cap on damages for serious injuries. 
"Most everybody is willing to go along with this deal except a few people in Congress," he said. 
A White House spokesman confirmed the discussions but declined to be more specific. 
Mr. Norwood said Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona and the chief sponsor of the Senate bill, which would give patients broad new rights to sue, has seen the proposal. The two Democratic sponsors of the Senate measure, Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and John Edwards of North Carolina, have not accepted the idea of a $4 million cap, and many plaintiffs' lawyers oppose any limit on damages as unfair to patients.
Frustrated with the pace of negotiations, Mr. Norwood asked, "What is this fight about? Many states already have caps lower than $4 million. The average jury verdict and the average out-of-court settlement in medical injury cases are much less than $4 million."
Senator Kennedy has been tight-lipped about the negotiations, indicating that he was more interested in enacting legislation than in scoring political points.
"While I remain hopeful that we can reach an agreement that fully protects all patients from H.M.O. abuse," Mr. Kennedy said tonight, "we are well into the ninth inning, and time is running out on our discussions."
Scott McClellan, a White House spokesman; Nancy E. Ives, a spokeswoman for Mr. McCain; and James P. Manley, a spokesman for Mr. Kennedy, would not discuss details of any proposal.
Mr. McClellan said the White House has been working to reach a bipartisan consensus.
"We believe it was within reach, and could still be," he said. "The real question now is whether the interests of powerful personal injury trial lawyers will prevail over the health care needs of the American people."
The White House and Senate negotiators said they had discussed proposals that would set different limits on lawsuits for serious injuries and other, less severe injuries. Under the proposal described by Mr. Norwood, the limit would be $1.5 million for less serious injuries.
For serious and less serious injuries, Mr. Norwood said, there would be a $1.5 million cap on punitive damages but no limit on economic damages, which reimburse patients for medical expenses and lost wages.
Lawmakers said they had not reached agreement with the White House on how to define the difference between more serious and less serious injuries.
If negotiations with the White House fail, Congress could appoint a conference committee, the usual mechanism for resolving major differences between the House and the Senate.
Supporters of the legislation have been trying to avoid a conference committee. An earlier version of the patients' rights bill died in such a committee in 2000, after countless hours of negotiations that frustrated members of both parties.
Tom Daschle, Democrat of South Dakota, the Senate majority leader, said on Wednesday that he was close to seeking a conference committee because of "the intransigence that we have had from the Republicans and the White House."
"We're getting very mixed signals," Mr. Daschle said, "and I don't know that the White House wants to press ahead. They don't appear to want an agreement, and we're left with really no choice, it seems, but to appoint conferees."

HEADLINE: Blunt Talk by an Investment Banker 

 BODY:
For much of corporate America, Goldman Sachs has long epitomized the discretion and solicitude of a Wall Street investment bank. That is what made Wednesday's call for corporate governance reforms by Henry M. Paulson Jr., the firm's chief executive, so compelling and unusual. Amid the gathering storm of corporate scandals that threatens to thwart the stock market's comeback, Mr. Paulson delivered a stern warning to his clients and to other major companies in a speech at the National Press Club: Either clean up your act or we are all in serious trouble. He ought to be heeded. 
 "In my lifetime," Mr. Paulson said, "American business has never been under such scrutiny. To be blunt, much of it is deserved." This scrutiny and a sense of alarm triggered by such spectacular corporate scandals as Enron and Tyco have rattled investors, and help explain the markets' puzzling decline at a time of apparent economic recovery. 
 Mr. Paulson, who rarely makes public appearances, called for reforms to bolster the integrity of financial markets and public confidence in them. His recommendations reflect what is by now a growing consensus of what is needed. He was especially adamant about the need to overhaul accounting rules -- such as those relating to off-the-books entities made infamous by Enron -- and the way the accounting profession is regulated. On this issue, he rightly said: "If the outcome of all that we have been through in the past six months, all the soul-searching and debate, is business at usual . . . then we will have missed an enormous opportunity."
Mr. Paulson acknowledged that Wall Street needed to address the conflicts of interest affecting the research of firms like his own. He said boards of directors needed to become more independent of management. News of the extravagant payoffs owed to C.E.O.'s ousted in recent scandals is evidence that some boards have been negligent about protecting shareholder interests. Mr. Paulson acknowledged that some C.E.O.'s were overpaid. He believes that companies will have to report executive stock options as an expense affecting the bottom line, and that chief executives should have to hold on to their company stock for a long time, and should be forced to give back any gains realized by selling company stock on the eve of a bankruptcy filing. Plenty of Mr. Paulson's clients will be none too pleased with his speech. 
Throughout the 90's, American consultants parachuted into a liberated Eastern Europe and elsewhere to preach the virtues of American-style accounting and corporate governance rules that champion transparency. The integrity of its financial markets was one of this country's economic strengths. A Wall Street insider like Mr. Paulson understands the economic significance of losing this advantage, and of the serious effort that is required to maintain it. 
So do others on Wall Street. Yesterday the New York Stock Exchange announced new rules to strengthen directors' independence that listed companies will have to follow. Not wanting to wait for the accounting profession to act, Standard & Poor's has said it will report "core earnings" for major companies in the future, a figure that will treat stock options as an expense. The Nasdaq market is barring Wall Street analysts from participating in their firms' marketing of initial public offerings. 
Self-interest is forcing meaningful, if piecemeal, reforms. This crisis of investor confidence is a serious economic threat. In order to advance the national interest, Congress ought to join the reform effort.

HEADLINE: The Global Warming Dropout 

BYLINE:  By Eileen Claussen; Eileen Claussen is president of the Pew Center on Global Climate Change.

DATELINE: ARLINGTON, Va. 

 BODY:
In its business-as-usual approach to climate change, the Bush administration is increasingly out of step not only with other industrialized powers, but also with the growing support in this country for action to prevent global warming. The administration's oddly two-sided report last week to the United Nations brings the White House into the scientific mainstream on the subject -- acknowledging that human activity is probably the cause of global warming and that America itself faces serious consequences -- but at the same time lays out a strategy ensuring that American emissions of greenhouse gases will continue rising sharply for at least a decade.
 Last week the European Union and its 15 member states completed en masse their ratification of the emissions-limiting treaty that President Bush has rejected, the Kyoto Protocol. This week Japan followed suit. Russia expects to ratify by the end of the year, meaning only one or two smaller countries would be needed to put the treaty into effect. (Ratifying countries must account for at least 55 percent of developed country emissions in 1990.) 
 The administration is also ignoring a growing domestic recognition of the need to act. Persuaded that the risks of climate change are real and that restraints on emissions are inevitable, many American companies are working on carbon reduction. To be sure, many others, especially in the energy and oil businesses, are strongly resistant. But dozens of major corporations like Alcoa, DuPont and Intel are among those setting their own targets for lower emissions. For many, there are financial payoffs, too -- improved efficiencies, lower costs and increased sales of energy-saving products.
State governments are also moving ahead. New Hampshire recently became the third state to adopt mandatory controls on carbon emissions from power plants. New Jersey is aiming to reduce statewide emissions by 3.5 percent from 1990 levels in the years before 2005. All six New England states, in a compact with five Eastern Canadian provinces, have pledged to reduce their emissions to 10 percent below 1990 levels by 2020.
Even in Congress, the tide is beginning to turn. Twice as many climate change measures were introduced in the past year as in the previous four years combined, many with strong support from both Democrats and Republicans.
Scientists project that a century's worth of greenhouse gas releases, mostly from burning fossil fuels, have already bought us a few degrees of warming in the decades ahead. The challenge is heading off further warming by gradually weaning ourselves from fossil fuels. This transition to a low-carbon economy will require a new industrial revolution.
We must look to the marketplace to carry it out. Only the market can mobilize the ingenuity, investment and productive capacity needed to develop and disperse new technologies on such a large scale. But the marketplace will deliver only if it perceives a demand, and providing that demand is a role for government.
A modest but logical first step in the U.S. is a measure passed unanimously by the Senate in April encouraging companies to disclose their greenhouse gas emissions voluntarily. If after five years less than 60 percent of emissions are being reported to the public, the measure would change this voluntary reporting system to a mandatory one. A similar approach helped dramatically reduce toxic air and water pollution nationwide. This legislation should be accepted by the House and signed by the president. 
Ultimately, though, the market must be driven by policies that set realistic, binding targets for reducing emissions and give companies the flexibility to achieve them as affordably as possible. The Bush administration's own report shows the danger in its remaining stubbornly out of step. The longer the United States waits, the graver the risks -- and the cost of averting them.

HEADLINE: The Many Faces Of Amr I. Elgindy 

BYLINE:  ByDAVID BARBOZA and ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
The faces that Amr Ibrahim Elgindy offered the world were as different as the names he used.
 To the investors who paid him hundreds of dollars a month for stock tips that were often uncannily accurate, Mr. Elgindy was Anthony Pacific. 
 To the Muslim refugees he brought from Kosovo to the United States, he was Tony Elgindy, a benefactor who provided cars, apartments and even cash -- and asked for little in return.
But to the regulators and prosecutors who chased him throughout the 1990's, he was Amr I. Elgindy, a man they considered a liar and thief who avoided prison mainly because of his willingness to turn in co-conspirators in stock frauds. 
Now Mr. Elgindy is moving from a San Diego jail to one in Brooklyn, charged with running a stock manipulation ring that is said to have included two F.B.I. agents who tipped Mr. Elgindy to current criminal investigations. Meanwhile, the investigation is widening, as the authorities publicly question whether Mr. Elgindy, who is Muslim and was born in Egypt, had advance knowledge of the Sept. 11 attacks.
So far, evidence backing that suspicion is scant. Jeanne G. Knight, Mr. Elgindy's lawyer, said that he had done nothing wrong and that he had no prior knowledge of the Sept. 11 attacks. In an interview, Ms. Knight accused the government of a form of racial profiling for denying Mr. Elgindy bail in part because of Sept. 11.
Still, the arrest and the charges against Mr. Elgindy, 34, have put him in the public eye and on the edge of ruin. He has been both places before.
Over the last decade, Mr. Elgindy chiseled a small fortune out of the often sleazy world of penny stocks, the shares of tiny companies that can double in a day and fall just as fast on waves of rumor and speculation. Along the way, he played off the fringe brokerage firms that pump penny stocks up against the short sellers who try to take them down, and he became a source of tips for both regulators and journalists.
"He always had an in with somebody," said Stuart R. Allen, a former investigator with the Securities and Exchange Commission. "If it wasn't the authorities, it was the press."
In the backwaters of the securities industry, where brokers can look more like bouncers and criminal records are common, the battles between long sellers and short sellers can be vicious and personal.
Mr. Elgindy seemed to thrive on the tension. On ABC's "20/20" five years ago, he said with relish that he carried a handgun and had "received a bullet in the mail, a bullet with my name on it."
"Three-hundred-pound guys walking into an office beating you up, making you do this, do this," he said. "It's happening. It's happening on Wall Street. That's not going to happen to me."
As his fortune grew, Mr. Elgindy acquired the trappings of wealth, including a Ferrari, a Bentley and a Hummer. Last year, he moved with his wife and three young sons into a $3 million house in the wealthy northern suburbs of San Diego.
But the money apparently did not change Mr. Elgindy's behavior. His own lawyers have called him "edgy" and "intimidating." Several neighbors recalled being irritated by his speeding along the narrow, hilly streets near his new home.
"It was obvious he had achieved a certain level of success," said one neighbor, Rick Engebretsen. "You'd think a certain amount of maturity would come along with that. But it didn't as far as I could tell."
Mr. Engebretsen watched one day last month as F.B.I. agents stormed Mr. Elgindy's mansion.
"He seemed squirrelly, wiry. On the surface level he was O.K., but my wife and I had a terrible feeling about him," Mr. Engebretsen said. "Was I surprised that I saw his house raided? No, I wasn't. I'd thought he was going to come out of there in a body bag or a raid."
Before the million-dollar homes and flashy cars, Mr. Elgindy was struggling to make his mark in a new world after his family moved from Egypt to the suburbs of Chicago when he was 2 or 3.
From an early age, he had trouble living up to the high expectations his family set, he told friends. His father was a professor, his mother was a pediatrician; his two brothers went on to earn advanced degrees, and a sister became a teacher. His own path, he conceded, was more tortured.
He dropped out of high school and got an equivalency degree in 1985. He enrolled at the University of Southern California to study biomedical engineering and later studied biology at San Diego State, but he completed less than two years of course work, university records show.
Trouble found him early. In 1986, at 18, he was arrested for assault with a deadly weapon in Los Angeles; the charges were later dropped. He worked as an auto salesman at three different Chevrolet dealerships within a year before entering the murky world of buying and selling penny stocks.
His resume includes some of the most notorious brokerage firms in the industry, the "pump and dump" shops that had long histories of manipulating stock prices and leaving investors out in the cold. Among these firms he joined, now defunct, was Blinder Robinson, nicknamed "Blind 'em and Rob 'em."
Mr. Elgindy later confessed to the authorities that he and brokers at another firm had accepted bribes from stock promoters seeking to manipulate shares. According to court records, in 1995 he was granted immunity in exchange for information about the scheme.
With his cooperation, federal prosecutors won convictions against four people on tax evasion charges. That was the beginning of Mr. Elgindy's life as a government informant, documents show. At a time when Wall Street was overrun by penny stock fraud and even the influence of organized crime, he helped government agents navigate the terrain. In court, the government has acknowledged that his tips were valuable.
Mr. Elgindy, who moved to Texas in 1994 to run his own brokerage firm, liked to boast about how he began wearing a wire. He also started carrying a gun, a small .380 Colt, because he had been repeatedly threatened, he said. When reporters visited his home, he would play tapes of secretly recorded conversations and show off his gun collection.
By the late 1990's, Mr. Elgindy had repackaged himself as a short seller who blew the whistle on crooked companies and wise guys. He was mentioned in a 1997 Business Week article about corrupt brokers. He was also written up in Wired magazine and featured on the Discovery Channel program "Justice Files."
Though many journalists were suspicious of Mr. Elgindy's motives, his information was often useful and provocative to them.
Bill Alpert, a longtime reporter at Barron's, the financial weekly in New York, remembers visiting Mr. Elgindy in 1996 at his home in Fort Worth and seeing stacks of cassette recordings he had made with people from the underbelly of Wall Street.
By then, Mr. Elgindy was driving a Ferrari and living comfortably in a home decorated with statues on columns, draped in velvet.
"Everyone in his family was accomplished, an achiever, and he'd gone astray," Mr. Alpert said. "But by helping the government and helping get swindlers, this would help redeem him."
When stock trading moved to the Internet and day trading became a fad, he moved his soapbox to the Web. On popular sites like Silicon Investor, an online stock forum, he plied his trade with great bravado.
He later set up a Web site and sold tips for a $600-a-month subscription fee. Few complained about the price.
"Most of the people on that site were doing 20 to 30k a week -- what's 600 bucks/mo.," one fan, who called himself Tool Dude, wrote in a recent post on the Silicon Investor site.
As early as 1997, though, Mr. Elgindy began to run into legal troubles. He had worked briefly for Bear Stearns in 1994 and later lost a civil suit over his firing by that firm. He was also sued by the insurance company MassMutual, which accused him of fraud for accepting disability checks worth $7,500 a month in 1994 for unemployment attributed to "emotional stress" even though he was employed at Bear, Stearns and another brokerage firm at that time.
That case was referred to the Justice Department and in 1999, while living in San Diego, he was indicted by a federal grand jury in Texas. He pleaded guilty to insurance fraud and was sentenced to four months in a California prison. 
When he was released in October 2000, Mr. Elgindy resumed his position as a prominent short seller on the Internet. He also began assisting the government in investigating cyberspace scams, he said.
At a probation hearing last January, his lawyer told the judge that Mr. Elgindy was a good citizen who had traveled to Kosovo and helped resettle refugees in the United States.
His case was supported by a letter from Jeffrey A. Royer, an F.B.I. agent in Gallup, N.M., who said that Mr. Elgindy had "gone above and beyond to assist law enforcement and civil regulatory agencies in combating fraudulent activities."
The F.B.I. now says the letter, which was undated and not on official letterhead, is suspect. "It is highly unlikely that as an agent Royer worked on any significant white-collar cases in Gallup," said H. Douglas Beldon, an F.B.I. spokesman.
Indeed, by the time of that letter, the Justice Department had opened an investigation into Mr. Elgindy's activities. After Sept. 11, the government said, a Wall Street broker told federal officials that Mr. Elgindy had tried to sell $300,000 in stock in anticipation of a market plunge. He placed his order on Sept. 10.
As part of that inquiry, the government said it uncovered a broader plot that involved Mr. Royer, who had left the F.B.I. in December to work for Mr. Elgindy.
In a 33-page indictment handed up over two weeks ago, the government portrayed Mr. Elgindy as a con man's con man. For the last two years, the government contends, Mr. Elgindy led a double life: He told people he was helping the government uncover stock market manipulation, but instead, the indictment charges, he was bribing F.B.I. agents to supply him with information to commit his own frauds.
Mr. Elgindy and four others, including Mr. Royer and another F.B.I. agent, were charged with obstruction of justice and securities fraud. They have all pleaded not guilty. Mr. Elgindy's lawyer, Ms. Knight, declined to comment except to accuse the government of using a "race based" notion to deny Mr. Elgindy bail.
Mr. Elgindy's Web sites have gone dark; his tip sheets are blank. But questions remain: Was he really tipped off to Sept. 11? Or is the government trying to get back at a longtime informant who proved untrustworthy?
Some people who know Mr. Elgindy best say that if he was tipped off, he would not have simply pulled his money out of the market, he would have taken out a big bet that the Dow Jones industrial average would fall.
"Tony was too damn selfish to be involved in anything that wouldn't turn into a buck in his pocket," said Richard Edward Hill, a lawyer in Texas who once represented Mr. Elgindy. "Tony is a smart guy, very intelligent, very gifted. But he didn't seem to have a lot of guidance."

HEADLINE: Jobless Rate Fell 0.2 Point Last Month 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN 

 BODY:
Offering a glint of hope to out-of-work Americans and further evidence of an improving economy, the unemployment rate fell to 5.8 percent in May, from 6 percent in April.
 But an unimpressive gain of just 41,000 in the number of people on business payrolls -- often considered a more reliable measure of current conditions than the unemployment rate -- led experts to caution that the nascent economic recovery is unlikely to produce many new jobs until businesses start investing again. 
 "The corporate sector will still take several more months before they build up confidence on the sustainability of the recovery and make permanent hirings," Elaine L. Chao, the secretary of labor, said in an interview.
In the meantime, the burden on the unemployed grows heavier. The number of long-term unemployed -- those looking for jobs for more than six months -- rose to 1.64 million last month, an increase of 45 percent from the beginning of the year and the highest figure since 1994. (All figures are adjusted to take account of normal season variations.) 
Yesterday's report followed a series of encouraging indicators about the economy this week. On Thursday, the Labor Department reported that first-time claims for unemployment benefits fell 32,000, to 383,000, the lowest level since May last year. Consumer borrowing also increased solidly in April, the Fed reported yesterday, indicating that Americans remain in a buying mood. And measures of manufacturing and service sector activity from the Institute for Supply Management, which closely follows purchasing patterns, gained ground in May.
Services -- particularly the health care industry -- was the source of most of last month's improvements. Manufacturing continued to lose jobs, though the 19,000 positions shed in May were the fewest losses in a month since November 2000.
Despite the mildly positive report from the Labor Department, the stock market fell yet again on Friday, still smarting from disappointing news from Intel and Biogen and the widening investigation of Tyco International and its former chief executive, L. Dennis Kozlowski. The Dow Jones industrial average fell nearly 35 points yesterday to close at 9,589.67, down 3 percent for the week.
Although forecasters had earlier predicted that the Federal Reserve might begin increasing interest rates once unemployment started declining, the mixed signals in yesterday's report helped to assuage fears of tighter credit. While some others still predict that the Fed might start raising rates as early as August, Goldman, Sachs issued an advisory yesterday suggesting that the Fed would not adjust rates until next year.
Economists said yesterday's report offered possible evidence of a turn in the economy's fortunes, though they agreed that widespread hiring was at least several months away. 
"In the first year of an expansion, productivity gains tend to dominate, not job gains," said Daniel E. Laufenberg, chief United States economist at American Express Financial Advisors. Eventually, he said, companies will need to hire more workers to keep growing.
A combination of rising productivity and stable wages has allowed companies to increase profits without expanding their work forces.
But a variety of risks are hampering business confidence, according to Ian Morris, an economist at HSBC Securities, the Wall Street arm of the global bank. "What seems to be happening now," he said, "is that all these terrorism threats, and uncertainty about the genuine level of earnings, are driving the stock market down." 
The disjoint between consumers, who have been buoyant of late, and business executives, who remain cautious, may continue for some time. Until companies can catch up to consumers, they may rely on temporary workers, whose number rose 0.9 percent, in May. "Businesses are looking to hire people, except they're not ready to hire permanent people," Mr. Laufenberg said. "They're using temporary workers until they're convinced that things are really better."
For now, the number of long-term unemployed is mounting, having risen by 142,000 in May. "As the unemployment rate increases, it takes longer for people to find a job," said Robert Shimer, a professor of labor economics at Princeton University. But that is not entirely unexpected. After a recession, the number of long-term unemployed typically continues rising even after the total unemployment rate begins to recede, Mr. Shimer said. 
Extensions in unemployment benefits could explain part of the trend in the current cycle. People who collect unemployment benefits, Mr. Shimer said, may look harder for work or settle for lower-paying jobs just before their benefits expire. "When benefits last for six months, a lot of people tend to find jobs in the sixth month," he said. "Now benefits are up to nine months for a lot of people, so I would expect to see that a little farther down the road." Nine-month unemployment benefits for people who lost their jobs after Sept. 11 will begin to expire next week.
Financing those benefits has not been easy for New York State, which has already taken out (and repaid) $215 million in loans from the federal government to pay claims. If the relatively high unemployment continues, New York and other states, including Alabama, Texas and Illinois, might exhaust their reserves and resort to more borrowing.
"States are fairly flush with funds at the beginning of each year," said Richard A. Hobbie, unemployment insurance director of the National Association of State Workforce Agencies. "It isn't until later on that they might run into trouble."
Ms. Chao said she expected the unemployment rate to stay near 6 percent until companies have built up enough productivity-based profits to start hiring in earnest.
But Mr. Morris said that the unemployment rate has historically switched between high and low levels extremely quickly. "When it goes up, as it has done over the past 18 months, it tends to shoot up fairly quickly," he said. "Once it peaks, it actually comes, initially, straight back down again."
Yesterday's report also ushered in new measures of employment in several service industries. The new statistics incorporate probability-based estimates as well as hard data. As a result of the change, the Labor Department lowered its count of business payrolls for April 2002, from 131.2 million to 130.7 million.

HEADLINE: Sweet on Times Square, Hershey Is to Open Store 

BYLINE:  By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
The maker of Hershey's Kisses, Reese's peanut butter cups and Milk Duds plans to open an interactive candy store festooned with an elaborate electronic billboard at the northern end of Times Square. 
 Hershey Foods Corporation officials say they hope that the store will become an international tourist attraction. The company's decision to locate its first major store outside its home in Hershey, Pa., is an ambitious and expensive undertaking and a tribute to the allure of Times Square as an intersection of marketing and retailing. 
 But Hershey is one of few glamorous exceptions to the retail tenants making their way to what promoters call the crossroads of the world. The second wave of retailers since the resurgence of Times Square in 1997 is more likely to include retail banks, sneaker stores and fast food. A 7-Eleven outlet will be serving Slurpees and the Big Gulp in the best-known Times Square tower of all, 1 Times Square, site of the New Year's Eve ball drop. 
Despite the revival, there are risks. The Museum Store on 42nd Street, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, is the latest retailer to succumb to high rents and slow sales. The Disney and Warner Brothers stores are long gone, as are Cosmetics Plus and the All Star Cafe, the sports-themed restaurant.
But the tens of millions of tourists and the tens of thousands of office workers who course through Times Square are too good an audience to pass up, said Wynn Willard, chief marketing officer of Hershey Foods. 
The Hershey store and its 15-story billboard -- one of the largest signs in Times Square -- will be at the northwest corner of Broadway and 48th Street, in the Crowne Plaza Hotel.
"Times Square is a showcase that is all of America," Mr. Willard said. "We want to create the image and delight of a Hershey chocolate factory in Times Square. We want to add to the rich layers of icons that have existed in Times Square over the decades."
The store, which will open in November, will mimic the company's chocolate factories in Hershey, Mr. Willard said, while the billboard will incorporate the company's smokestacks, a giant chocolate bar, a Jolly Rancher wind vane and a pile of Hershey Kisses. The company is hoping to duplicate the success of the giant Toys "R" Us store and its operating Ferris wheel at Broadway and 45th Street.
But why would Hershey do better than Disney and Warner Brothers, which both closed their large Times Square stores? "You can only have so many T-shirts and plush toys," Mr. Willard said. "When it comes to the range of Hershey products, we think we'll have an enduring appeal."
Tourists and New Yorkers have made their way back to Times Square since last year, when the sluggish economy and the attack on the World Trade Center cut sales by as much as 40 percent. Brokers disagree on whether rents are rising or leveling off, but they all say that retailers are hunting again for space and billboards.
"Times Square is hot again," said Robert K. Futterman, a broker. "There's a lot of demand for space."
C. Bradley Mendelson, a broker at Insignia ESG, said that retailers make expensive deals in Times Square that are as much about marketing and brand identity as retail sales.
But Mr. Mendelson, Mr. Futterman and most other brokers, landlords and store owners say that retailing is much tougher on 42nd Street, west of Times Square, where a number of stores have had disappointing sales or gone out of business. Madame Tussaud's museum on 42nd Street does attract large numbers of tourists and New Yorkers and, across 42nd Street, the PastaBreak restaurant has signed a lease.
"The street is still a challenge," said John L. Livingston, president of Tishman Urban Development Corporation. "Retailers view it as an entertainment area, but there aren't that many entertainment tenants."
Ripley's Believe It or Not has been scouting locations in Times Square. For the most part, however, the current crop of retailers is less exotic.
According to real estate brokers and landlords, Footlocker is signing a deal to open a showcase sneaker store on Broadway, next door to Toys "R" Us, and Champs, the sports chain, is headed for the Ernst & Young Building at 42nd Street and Seventh Avenue. J.P. Morgan Chase is opening a retail bank in the Reuters Building, and Skechers, the shoe store chain, is negotiating for space in that building to return to Times Square. Adidas is still looking for a spot.
The executives said that 7-Eleven, Two Boots Pizza and the Times Square Brewery are signing deals to move into 1 Times Square, the space once occupied by Warner Brothers. Given the 24-hour nature of Times Square, the 7-Eleven chain expects that the new store will be as popular as their highway and suburban outlets. But not everyone agrees.
"I think 7-Eleven will be disappointed," said Mr. Mendelson. "It's the most visible signpost because it's an island in the center of Times Square and it's the worst retail site because it's an island. Visible yet invisible."

CORRECTION-DATE: June 13, 2002

 CORRECTION:
A map on Saturday about plans for stores around Times Square, including a Hershey candy outlet in the Crowne Plaza Hotel, gave an erroneous location for the site that will include a 7-Eleven store. It is 1 Times Square, north of 42nd Street at the junction of Broadway and Seventh Avenue. The map also misstated the name of a store that recently closed. It was the Museum Company, not the Museum Store. The name of an avenue was also misstated. It is Eighth Avenue, not Eighth Street.

SUBJECT: SUGAR & CONFECTIONERY MFG (90%); RESTAURANTS (90%); CONFECTIONERY & NUT STORES (90%); RETAILERS (90%); CONFECTIONERY MFG (90%); THEME RESTAURANTS (89%); FOOD INDUSTRY (89%); FOOD MFG (89%); TOYS & GAMES (88%); FOOD & BEVERAGE (78%); HOBBY TOY & GAME STORES (78%); DESTINATIONS & ATTRACTIONS (77%); HOTELS & MOTELS (77%); TOURISM (77%); SHOE STORES (73%); INTERNATIONAL TOURISM (72%); COMMERCIAL RENTAL PROPERTY (70%); RETAIL BANKING (70%); COSMETICS (65%); MUSEUMS & GALLERIES (52%) CANDY 

COMPANY: MARS INC (92%); HERSHEY CO (86%); 7-ELEVEN INC (56%)

HEADLINE: Argentine Ex-Minister Freed After Jailing on Arms Sale Charges 

BYLINE:  By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 7 

 BODY:
A federal appeals court in Argentina today ordered the release of Domingo Cavallo, a former economy minister who was jailed more than two months ago on charges that he approved more than $100 million in illegal arms sales while in office during the early 1990's.
 Mr. Cavallo was the most powerful of several cabinet ministers under Carlos Menem, the president at the time, who were required to sign decrees authorizing the sale of 6,500 tons of munitions to Panama and Venezuela. The armaments ended up going to Croatia and Ecuador at a time when both countries were under an international arms embargo, leading to a government investigation into what was termed "aggravated contraband." 
 One of Mr. Cavallo's lawyers, Eduardo Oderigo, cautioned that despite today's ruling, the case against his client had not been totally closed. The investigating judge who ordered the arrest of Mr. Cavallo was told by the court that he had acted improperly on the basis of the evidence. But he could still file new charges. 
Mr. Cavallo has been held for 65 days at a military base outside Buenos Aires. Mr. Oderigo described the charges against him as "without merit." He said his client "is relieved and satisfied and sees no reason why he should be called on again" to testify in the case.
Mr. Cavallo, a Harvard-educated economist, was economy minister from 1991 to 1996 and again for nine difficult months last year. During his first period in office, he was widely praised on Wall Street and in Washington for carrying out free-market reforms that led to a burst of rapid economic growth, which made Argentina a model emerging market.
But after the collapse of the Argentine economy in early December, he resigned and was quickly blamed for the crisis. He was especially unpopular for issuing an order, still in effect, that virtually froze bank deposits, which now have lost more than 70 percent of their value because of the devaluation of the Argentine peso.
A new government led by a rival of Mr. Menem has fanned sentiment against Mr. Cavallo even as the economy continued to disintegrate. Mr. Cavallo's release from jail, however, was announced on a day when most of Argentina's 37 million people had their attention focused on a crucial World Cup soccer match against England and were paying little attention to politics. (Argentina lost.) 
Mr. Menem was also arrested in connection with the smuggled arms and held under house arrest for five months last year. But charges against him and a former army commander, Gen. Martin Balza, were dropped because of insufficient evidence, leaving Mr. Cavallo as the only prominent former government figure still under scrutiny in the case.
Mr. Cavallo and his lawyers have argued since the beginning that the charges against him were politically inspired. In an advertisement published last month in The New York Times, more than 70 international economists and scholars called on the government to treat Mr. Cavallo fairly. His lawyers have also filed a complaint with the Inter-American Court of Human Rights, seeking a ruling that would end official "harassment" of him. 
Mr. Oderigo said that complaint would go forward. Mr. Cavallo "has been the object of persecution not only in this case, but in various others," he said.

HEADLINE: THINK TANK; 
Snobs: They're Made, Not Born

BYLINE:  By EMILY EAKIN 

 BODY:
Joseph Epstein drives a Jaguar S-Type. His son went to Stanford. He has hobnobbed with Saul Bellow and shared meals with five other Nobel laureates (three in economics, two in physics). He's been to a Chicago Bulls game with Gene Siskel ($350 front-row seats), exchanged greetings with Oprah Winfrey and had Lynne Cheney to his apartment for supper. He's on friendly terms with one of Monica Lewinsky's lawyers and receives the occasional note from former Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan. 
 Oh, and he wants you to know that on a recent visit to New York City, he was put up at the Plaza. 
 Impressed? Mr. Epstein certainly hopes so. An essayist, author and former editor of The American Scholar, he is also, by his own bashful admission, a snob. Those celebrity names and status brands glinting from the pages of his new book like Swarovski crystals on an Armani gown are just his way of letting you know that he is a person of superior taste and social standing. And since the book is "Snobbery: the American Version" (Houghton Mifflin), they're also intended to encourage reader confidence that Mr. Epstein is just the man to tackle an affliction apparently as slippery as it is ubiquitous.
Everyone knows a snob when he sees one, he notes. But there is considerably less agreement about exactly what makes one a snob. Virginia Woolf, who confessed to uppity impulses -- like keeping letters from her titled friends in conspicuous view -- in her 1936 essay "Am I a Snob?," claimed that "the essence of snobbery is that you wish to impress other people."
Marcel Proust, a famous snob from a country generally thought to be teeming with them, defined snobbery as "admiration of something in other people unconnected with their personality." He also called it "the greatest sterilizer of inspiration, the greatest deadener of originality, the greatest destroyer of talent." Perhaps, Mr. Epstein suggests, the philosopher George Santayana put it best when he said that to call someone a snob "is a very vague description but a very clear insult." 
Lexicographers can provide no further help. The origins of the word snob are a total mystery, though Mr. Epstein comes up with four intriguing theories: 1) it is derived from a Scandinavian term for dolt or charlatan 2) it comes from an abbreviation of the Latin sine nobilitate, supposedly used to distinguish commoners from bona fide nobles on official lists 3) it is an antonym for the word nob, British slang for a person of genuine wealth and stature or 4) it is derived from French peasants' elision of the phrase "c'est noble," meaning "it's noble." 
But whatever its roots, scholars generally agree that before the 19th century, the word snob simply did not exist. And in Mr. Epstein's view, this makes sense. Snobbery, he contends, is a peculiarly modern disease: a byproduct of democracy. "The social fluidity that democracy makes possible, allowing people to climb from the bottom to the top of the ladder of social class in a generation or two," he writes, "provides a fine breeding ground for snobbery and gives much room to exercise condescension, haughtiness, affectation, false deference and other egregious behavior so congenial to the snob." 
In the past, he argues, such behavior was pointless -- and little indulged in. Who was going to mistake a scullery maid's daughter for a lady, no matter how skillful her piano playing or fluent her Latin? Your place in the rigid social order was fixed at birth. And this, Mr. Epstein says, explains why Shakespeare, Dante, Aristophanes and the Bible are basically snob-free: "Snobbery as we know it today, snobbery meant to shore up one's own sense of importance and to make others sorely feel their insignificance, was not yet up and running in a serious way."
By 1848, however, when the English novelist William Makepeace Thackeray wrote his "Book of Snobs" -- the first major literary use of the term -- they were apparently everywhere. Thackeray's comprehensive treatment includes chapters on every possible strain: royal snobs, city snobs, country snobs, military snobs, literary snobs, club snobs and "dining-out" snobs. "It is impossible for any Briton, perhaps, not to be a Snob in some degree," he remarks at one point. 
According to Mr. Epstein's theory, such an explosion of snobbery was only to be expected. By 1848, a large and prosperous commercial class was wreaking havoc on England's old caste system. 
But no place, he insists, proved a more ideal incubator of snobbery than the United States. Living in a country with few built-in class distinctions, Americans turned to snobbery as compensation, a means of clarifying what the Constitution failed to: just who was better than whom. (Alexis de Toqueville, who saw this phenomenon up close, wrote that "democratic institutions most successfully develop sentiments of envy in the human heart.")
Nor did it hurt that America was predominantly middle class. "Vague and wide-ranging though the term middle class may be," Mr. Epstein writes, "it does render anyone who is part of this class capable of, if not intrinsically susceptible to, snobbery in both directions. To be middle class positions one nicely to be both an upward- and a downward-looking snob, full, simultaneously, of aspiration to rise to the position of those above and of disdain for those below." 
Mr. Epstein traces snobbery's fickle path through American history, noting the changing status of brand names, people and objects -- from neighborhoods and cities to music, beverages, colleges and dogs. (King Charles spaniels and golden retrievers are out; half-Labs are the new status symbol.)
Along the way, he finds a dizzying array of new snobbisms, including "reverse snobbery," which amounts to asserting your superiority over other snobs by embracing what they disdain and disdaining what they embrace. Calling "The Simpsons" high art and The New Yorker a middle-brow rag is the sort of thing Mr. Epstein has in mind. (His own reverse snobbism is mostly limited to expressing a strong aversion to the work of Susan Sontag, a writer generally held in high esteem by the literary establishment.) 
If Mr. Epstein is right, as social barriers fall away and more Americans of diverse backgrounds join the middle class, the nation's snobbery quotient is likely only to grow. But perhaps that's not such a bad thing. If snobbery flourishes where freedom and social mobility are great, maybe it's less a symptom of disease than a sign of health.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Maturity is not a prerequisite for snobbery. This 1937 photo is from "Those Impossible English," by Quentin Bell and Helmut and Alison Gernsheim (Crown, 1952). (Central Press Photos)(pg. B9); An illustration by William Makepeace Thackeray from the chapter on country snobs in his "Book of Snobs," published in 1848. (pg. B11)

HEADLINE: Insuring Against Terrorism 

 BODY:
Last fall, Congress responded energetically to the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. But the response was incomplete. When the fog of normalcy, with its paralyzing partisanship, again descended on Capitol Hill late last year, Congress had not yet enacted urgently needed legislation to provide federal help in insuring against similarly catastrophic terrorist attacks in the future. It must do so now, particularly in light of the constant stream of Bush administration warnings about new potential terrorist threats. 
 Before Sept. 11, insurance companies routinely provided businesses with coverage for terrorism-related losses as part of their general property and casualty policies. Not anymore; not after the attacks resulted in some $50 billion in insured losses. Unable to assess the risk of future attacks and their potential cost, some insurance companies and reinsurers have stopped providing terrorism coverage altogether; many others are charging astronomical premiums for very limited coverage. 
 In New York City and elsewhere, high-profile sites are finding it especially hard to insure against terrorism. Legal disputes between lenders and property developers about the adequacy of their insurance coverage, such as one involving the new Conde Nast office tower on Times Square, could become more common as more and more policies expire and companies are forced to proceed without terrorism insurance, or with an insufficient amount. Meanwhile, in the absence of a federal backstop, the prospect of potentially devastating workers' compensation liability in the event of future attacks may force many businesses to reconsider concentrating so many employees in Manhattan.
There is broad support across the political spectrum for the notion that the federal government must cover the bulk of any private losses that exceed $10 billion from a terrorist attack. Even if Congress fails to formalize the commitment, it will undoubtedly act after the fact. By passing a law now requiring the insurance industry to provide terrorism coverage in exchange for capping its potential losses, Congress can create a market for affordable coverage and protect potential terrorism targets, from New York City to San Francisco, from an exodus of business. 
None of this is seriously in dispute in Washington. What has produced a partisan stalemate on the issue was the House Republicans' decision late last year to transform the issue into a Trojan horse for their cherished tort reform agenda. Their bill, passed last November, was stuffed with items on a longstanding wish list of desired curbs on litigation, such as a cap on lawyers' fees and exclusions for non-economic damages. The restrictions would apply only to lawsuits that stemmed from a terrorist incident, but the Republicans wanted to make a political point.
This is an ideological showdown the American economy cannot afford. Senate Democratic leaders, eager to pass their own bill, must compromise, even if it means offending trial lawyer groups. Senate Republicans appear willing to accept far more modest curbs on terrorism-related litigation than their House brethren. Their proposals provide the basis for an eventual reconciliation of House and Senate efforts. 
It would be a reckless blow to America's economy for Congress to continue neglecting this wartime imperative.

HEADLINE: Religion Journal; 
Efforts to Ensure a Catholic Burial

BYLINE:  By JULIE FLAHERTY 

DATELINE: BOSTON, June 7 

 BODY:
It is not a sale, per se. And price slashing would be the wrong term. But there is no denying that the Archdiocese of Boston hopes to attract customers with the low-cost burial packages it introduced this year.
 The discount burial plots, which Roman Catholic cemeteries around Boston first began offering in January, start at $1,500, and while no signs in church windows scream "40 percent off," that is about what the average patron can expect to save. 
 The bargain price is part of the archdiocese's effort to fend off competition from crematories and private cemeteries. It has advertised on the radio and in parish bulletins, made presentations at churches and started filming a video on Christian funerals in conjunction with the local Catholic cable channel. The message is this: Because the body is considered sacred, burial in a Catholic cemetery is the church's preferred way of disposing of the faithful.
Five years ago, the cremation rate among Catholics in the Boston area began rising. With about a quarter of all deaths in Massachusetts now resulting in a trip to the crematory, the increase was enough to make Cardinal Bernard F. Law take notice.
"What he was concerned about was that people were being forced into cremation for economic reasons," said Anthony Rizzuto, a deacon who heads the archdiocese's cemeteries and burial services.
So last year, the archdiocese began converting parts of four of its cemeteries into more affordable burial plots. The reduced price comes from the design. For example, the grave markers are flat, so a lawn mower can run over them easily, reducing maintenance costs. 
Although Catholics are not refused a burial if they cannot afford to pay, offering lower cost plots is a way of recognizing that it can be expensive to follow church doctrine.
"That's an excellent way to approach this," said the Rev. Patrick J. Pollard, director of Catholic cemeteries for the Diocese of Chicago. "We're not only saying we believe in this as the proper way for burial, but we're going to support you in this."
In the Archdiocese of Los Angeles, above-ground interment is getting similar promotion.
"Because land is becoming more scarce, we are looking at pricing our crypts to make those more affordable," said James M. Tixier, director of Catholic cemeteries in Los Angeles. "At some point, cemeteries will eventually fill up." 
The Chicago diocese has not resorted to discounting, but Father Pollard has been educating Catholics about proper burial for years, helping to keep business stable. 
Father Pollard said many Catholics knew a good deal about Catholic burial. "Any time we attempt to teach," he said, "we're often times simply reminding people."
But what if Catholics still opt for cremation? Mr. Rizzuto is dealing with that as well. In addition to the new burial plots, Catholic cemeteries in Haverhill and Salem, Mass., are displaying new columbaria, stone edifices that hold 80 to 90 urns each. 
Cremation has always been a tricky subject for the Catholic Church. Before Bruno Brunetti, an Italian professor, introduced his cremation chamber at the Vienna Exposition in 1873, burial had been the only accepted method of disposition for some 1,500 years. But cremation quickly caught on, promoted by Protestant clergymen who wanted to reform burial practices and doctors concerned about the health risks associated with cemeteries. 
Once banned for Catholics, cremation is now allowed if it is done in keeping with the church's respect for the body. Remains must be buried in a grave or placed in a columbarium. 
While bishops in the United States have worked to make the rules on Christian burial clearer, explaining them to the bereaved can be a challenge. In Boston, Mr. Rizzuto has also been trying to reintroduce some of the funeral vigils and rituals that are sometimes passed over as old-fashioned or unnecessary by the bereaved. Once he finishes the instructional video, Mr. Rizzuto is considering filming a multipart documentary on the history of burial for Boston Catholic Television. 
"You can trace the roots all the way back to the first century and beyond," he said.
One important moment in burial history, Mr. Rizzuto pointed out, was Vatican II, which determined that Catholics could be buried in non-Catholic cemeteries as long as the graves were blessed. 
"The intent was to be more accommodating to people," Mr. Rizzuto said. "An unintended effect was to open up the Catholic cemeteries to competition."
Indeed, for several years the archdiocese's cemeteries -- with a budget of about $8 million a year -- have been losing money. When Mr. Rizzuto was hired three years ago, he began to standardize record-keeping and procedures among the local Catholic cemeteries, which he said had been "all over the map." 
"We had to take a look at our pricing structures, our maintenance and upkeep and what our cemeteries look like competitively," he said.
As he slipped into the occupational parlance, he admitted, "we are constantly walking the tightrope between business and ministry."
But the goal, Mr. Rizzuto said, is more about bringing a community of faith together than improving the bottom line, and so far the response has been good.
"People are coming and telling us they heard about the programs, or they were driving by and saw the billboard on the side of the cemetery," he said, adding that one family had just signed up for nine plots. "I think people are starting to notice."

American Hostage Killed In Philippines Battle
An American missionary, Martin Burnham, and a Filipino nurse being held by the Muslim extremist group Abu Sayyaf were killed in a gun battle between their captors and Filipino soldiers being trained by American troops. The United States has urged its citizens to leave India but most American businessmen have yet to depart, hoping that tensions between the nuclear-armed rivals India and Pakistan will dissipate. A3

A Pakistani court bowed to a demand by President Musharraf and released Zafran Bibi, who had been sentenced to death by stoning for having extramarital relations. The woman left her jail cell carrying her 7-month-old daughter, who had been conceived when her husband was in prison and was therefore described by the judge as proof of her crime. The woman has accused her brother-in-law of raping her. He has not been charged. A4

Killings in Israeli Settlement
Two gunmen slipped into a heavily guarded Jewish settlement south of Jerusalem and shot six people, killing two. One attacker was slain and the other escaped, an Israeli military spokeswoman said. Earlier, Israeli forces swept into Palestinian-controlled towns in the West Bank, firing machine guns and making arrests in what the army said were raids for wanted militants. The sweeps came on the eve of a visit to Washington by Prime Minister Ariel Sharon. A8
