 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section 6; Column 1; Magazine Desk; Pg. 82

LENGTH: 3033 words

HEADLINE: Houston Does Not Believe In Tears 

BYLINE:  By Randall Patterson; Randall Patterson, a former writer for The Houston Press, now lives in Asheville, N.C.

 BODY:
After the disaster, I got back to Houston as quickly as possible and at first could hardly tell anything had happened. It was not as if a bomb had exploded or a building had collapsed. There had been a disappearance, that is all, and the effect was not apparent until I got out of the car. It was the fear I noticed, and I saw it first when I sat down with Elyse Lanier.
 Lanier is the wife of the former mayor and the closest thing the fourth-largest city in the country has to a mother. In her enormous diamonds and green leather pants, she ate a hamburger and fries and spoke of "the setbacks we've had" -- Tropical Storm Allison and the floods it caused, the Andrea Yates murders and trial. What made it worse was that all these outsiders had come in to gawk and had not helped at all. And it was then, while the reporters were standing around, that the most embarrassing thing happened. 
 One morning, the pride of the town, the greatest example of what a business could do in Houston, woke up dead. 
The corpse was right out there in the front yard, Enron's hollow new skyscraper, sprouting out of the Y.M.C.A. parking lot. "It was really shocking," Lanier said. She and her husband, Bob, quickly composed themselves and hurried to tell reporters that this was nothing to be overly concerned about. Enron did not "economically affect the city at all," and this sort of thing happened all the time in Texas.
But the reporters kept standing around, poking the corpse, sniffing. It was as if they had never seen a bankruptcy before, as if they thought it was wrong to go bankrupt. "All the anger and emotion, it's ridiculous!" Elyse said. She just wished they would go back to where they came from, because they were not good for business. They were making Houston look like some unstable frontier boomtown again, like "a bunch of hicks," Lanier said. "It's not true. Houston is a diverse, cosmopolitan, international city."
She reached across the table for a thick folder, and though I told Lanier I had lived in Houston for eight years, she began reading the proof that it really is a city. "Please don't think I'm cracked," she said. "These are just things I happen to believe in."
The Port of Houston ranks No. 1 in the country for foreign tonnage. . . . The Texas Medical Center is the largest medical center in the world. . . . The new Reliant Stadium has twice the square footage of the Astrodome. . . . 
The longer Lanier went on with her evidence of life after Enron, the less convincing she became. It was a sales job; she was frank about that. Houston would never be recognized as a great metropolis, she said, until it had a great marketing campaign. This was the city's ruling credo: Nothing happens until you sell something. Enron was built on that principle, and certainly it was the guide to the New York flimflammers who founded Houston.
The city began as one of the country's great real-estate scams. In 1836, immediately after the battle that won Texas independence from Mexico, Augustus and John Allen began advertising a new port town, "located at a point on the river which must ever command the trade of the largest and richest portion of Texas."
The brothers crooned: "There is no place more healthy," and " none possesses so many advantages for building. . . . It is handsome and beautifully elevated, salubrious and well watered."
The single truth in that ad was that Houston was well watered, as swamps tend to be. A desperate sort replied to this ad, packing up their belongings and traveling hundreds of miles to arrive at absolutely nothing: a flat, hot, wet plain of no beauty whatsoever, cut through only by a sluggish creek, colonized already by flocks of mosquitoes and herds of snakes.
The moment presented choices. One hundred and fifty years earlier, in the 1680's, the followers of Cavelier de La Salle, on finding themselves lost in what is now Texas, chose to shoot their leader and stagger home. The settlers attracted by the Allen brothers were a different breed, and when they opted to pay the brothers and stick it out, the great city of Houston was born.
It has never been like other cities -- not like San Francisco or Denver or Palm Beach. People have never gone to Houston for its beauty or climate, or because it is in any natural way a good place to live. Houston from the start has been a place to make money -- the great interior commercial emporium of Texas," as the Allen brothers promised. And if money was Houston's singular attraction, then certainly the city would impose no heavy restrictions on the making of it.
"Does the Houston region have a business-friendly environment?" asks a recent brochure. "Oh, yes." No zoning. Pollution-control abatements. Tax exemptions. Laissez-faire as loose as you like it. When the F.B.I. arrested several city councilmen a few years ago for either accepting or giving bribes, no one was really surprised. As Mayor Lee P. Brown told me, government works very closely here with the private sector to create the "premier world-class city" that Houston is.
By the time I got there in 1992, the swamp had been fully air-conditioned, and people moved from bubble to bubble -- there were tunnels for this -- from one artificial environment to the next. Houston was a sprawling, twisting knot of strip malls and highways, and no one had the big picture here; no one was watching the store. The city that began as a scheme seemed to proceed as an uncontrolled chain reaction of schemes, the descendants of the Allen brothers preying on the descendants of the settlers, again and again.
They passed before me, and I wrote about them -- the director of beauty pageants who always kept the prizes, the delightfully conniving snail salesman, the gentle inventor of the perpetual-motion machine who thought the oil industry was keeping him down. I used to imagine them all working the same room together, and now I see Ken Lay there too.
Lanier reeled off her evidence and then at last sent me to visit "a jewel in the rejuvenation of the town" -- the place formerly known as Enron Field.
"I want you to look around," she said, "and feel the spirit of the city you're in." The diverse, cosmopolitan city. Lanier said the stadium was a "microcosm" of it, "a great visual." So I took her tickets and made my way there on a Saturday night and quickly saw what she meant: a coliseum with a 15-million-pound retractable roof is clearly something no cosmopolitan city should be without. As for the diversity, everyone was certainly here and in his place, arranged by income. The diverse rabble was up there in the nosebleeds, and here I was, directly behind home plate, surrounded by white guys who could afford $18,000 season tickets.
The area was known as the Diamond Box, and in ordinary times Ken Lay was said to be a Diamond Box man. He must have been watching the game on television that night, so I wandered over to the owner of the Astros, Drayton McLane Jr. Though Lay helped lead the fund-raising effort for the stadium and helped break the ground, McLane didn't seem to miss him at all. Unfurling from his seat, McLane said he was reared to believe that "you conduct yourself in a very dignified and respectable way in business." At the time he granted Enron a 30-year deal for naming rights to the stadium, he said, the company appeared to be one of the most dignified and respectable businesses in the world. When that appearance dissolved, McLane paid $2.1 million to detach the Astros from a loser. "Nobody's been wounded more than we have," he said, "but we're on our feet, and we'll go on."
I settled in to watch the game. When the waiter politely offered me a beer, I might have declined if I'd known the man beside me was a Baptist preacher. Duane Brooks looked fresh from the barber and the bath and began speaking of the "symbiotic" relationship in Houston between church and business. As I understood it, businessmen give money to the church, and the church in turn encourages businessmen to make more money. Jesus suffered and died so they might live well and prosper; Jesus wants everyone to maximize his potential.
I asked Brooks about what Jesus had said in the temple with the money-changers. "Is it not written," Brooks paraphrased, "My house shall be called a house of prayer for all nations? But you have made it a den of robbers."
Brooks acknowledged that "one of the dangers of being a Christian businessman is to worship God as the God of my success," but he seemed to think there was nothing he could do about that. Instead of sermons on greed, he had preached lately on the need to keep worshiping, even when "the Nasdaq falls through the basement." The current uncertainty was bringing people to church in droves. "These are really good times," he said. "Yeah, these are great days." And with excitement in his voice, Brooks told me of plans to move Tallowood Baptist Church into a shopping mall. 
Over the left-field wall the name Gallery Furniture was emblazoned. The owner has expressed interest in a "Gallery Furniture Field," but McLane said that "his involvement was never a serious consideration," presumably because the owner is a jumping, shouting businessman known as Mattress Mac (real name, James Franklin McIngvale).
Mac is Houston's most prominent citizen, and one of the few of any prominence publicly critical of Enron. After the game (the Astros lost, alas), when I went to Gallery Furniture to see him, it was like walking into the big top -- an imperial red-white-and-blue warehouse, shrouded in flags and Elvis signs, a giant bin by the door containing the free red-white-and-blue basketballs that came with every purchase. Mac, the elfish man on a leather sofa, explained that to work in retail, you have to live in your customers' world, "understand their needs and concerns and fears." The store, then, was like the church; the flags made people feel safe, Mac said, and he put up more of them after Sept. 11. "The amazing thing, after 9/11 and the planes hit the tower, I thought we were going to blink" -- one prepares for a remark on the resolve of a great country -- I thought sales would go down, but we did $250,000 that day."
Mac judged Enron's collapse as he seems to judge all things -- by its effect on sales. "Like dipping your hand in a swimming pool and pulling it out -- the hole fills in." But he seemed to have a personal reaction too, almost as if he himself had been cheated. Both he and Ken Lay started out with a desire, as Lay has said, to "make some money," but they went about it in different ways and as a result held different places in the town. Lay wore suits and worked big deals quietly; Mac was the flag-draped clown, appealing to the hordes, endlessly yanking a wad of cash from his pocket, screaming, "Gallery Furniture will save you money!" Since "money is a scorecard," Mac is pleased to divulge now that Gallery Furniture grossed $150 million last year alone. Lay, who is reported to have sold $180 million in stock from 1998 through 2001, may be the less wealthy man, but he was always considered the respectable one, the great city father whose charity work received the most attention, who got invited to all the rich parties.
Mac insisted that none of this ever bothered him, but when he heard that Enron reported hundreds of millions in phony profits and concealed billions in debt, Mac spoke of how the company had "hoodwinked" the city -- the incredible fraud of it!" And the failure of a cheat had vindicated his business instincts: to make money, you must sell "real things to real people," he said. 
"They had no idea who their customers were," Mac went on. "If you can't serve customers, you can't stay in business -- I don't care who you are."
My friend from the old Houston Post, the gossip columnist with the dark sunglasses and the rich laugh, knew what happened at all the parties to which Mac was not invited, and as far as she was concerned, Enron was "a dull business story." Betsy Parish said her eyes glaze over whenever people talk accounting to her, but she could not see that anyone had done anything terribly "bad or evil." No one comes to Houston to be poor, she said, and to get rich, you have to drill a well, take a chance. Enron's leaders had certainly taken a chance.
"People in Houston admire spunk," Parish said. "It's an action town."
I wanted to know what the future held for Enron's leaders. Parish was certain that whatever shame had attached to them was nothing money could not remove. "Everything is based on money," she said.
Its effect on court proceedings was clear already. Attorney General John Ashcroft, at least three federal judges and the entire United States attorney's office in Houston have recused themselves. If criminal charges do eventually come to trial in Houston, the case may well be presented to a jury of spunk admirers. As for civil cases, they will confront Texas laws that shield houses, cars, future earnings -- virtually everything -- from seizure. Which leaves the men of Enron time to contemplate their social lives.
In addition to exorbitantly priced defense lawyers (perhaps the greatest threat to their fortunes), Ken Lay, Jeff Skilling and Andrew Fastow have all worked with publicists. Parish explained that Skilling and Fastow were never more than businessmen. "They simply did not exist in the framework of those I know," Parish said.
But Lay was a different matter. He was the boldest of "bold-faced types." Businessmen typically enter the social set through their charitable good deeds, and Lay presided over Enron's $10 million-a-year "community relations" budget, buying relationships and prestige. Then in a plunge, it was gone. No one could remember a fall from grace like this. The city simply didn't know what to do with him. Steadfast friends could only insist he was incompetent, not criminal. ("He may not have been watching those balance sheets as he should," Elyse Lanier explained.) 
Lay groped about for his dignity. Instead of shutting his family away from the angry world, they came out, one by one, to defend him. His sister testified to Lay's "tremendous integrity." One son swore that he was "the most generous, ethical, giving man that I've ever met." But it was Lay's wife, Linda, who afforded the best theater, trotting out to avow not simply that her husband was "a moral human being who would do absolutely nothing wrong" but that he was a victim, too: "We've lost everything," she said, speaking from their $7 million condo. 
Lay was blessed by a visit from the Rev. Jesse Jackson, who flew in and compared him to Job. But elsewhere, the greetings were cooler. There was a report of an "E.F. Hutton moment," when Lay walked into the ballroom of the River Oaks Country Club. Spotting Lay at a party there, a waiter could not help but gasp, "Oh, my God!" And a doctor who saw Lay at the hospital boasted of staring the great man down. 
But Lay kept himself out there. He soldiered on and was rewarded when the pastor of the Oasis of Love reached out, squeezed his arm and said he was praying for him. The city wanted to forgive him, and as he returned to his old charity circuit, the absolution began. He arrived timid, not his old genial self, but usually met a warm reception. And finally the triumphal moment came at, of all things, the Holocaust Museum Houston benefit.
The evening's theme was "Our Nation's Courage," with Bob Dole to receive the Lyndon Baines Johnson Moral Courage Award. Lay seemed to have summoned everything he had for the event. He and his wife arrived dead last, and as an honorary chairman, he made his way to the front table, where he sat with the former senator from Kansas. How gratifying it must have been as a stream of well-wishers came forth to shake his hand. According to one account, the announcement of Ken Lay's continued support, that his family foundation had somewhere scrounged up a contribution of $100,000, brought "some of the most enthusiastic applause of the night."
"He'll be forgiven," Parish said, "not in the Christian sense, not by those he hurt, but by Houston. If they give, they'll be embraced by those they give to. They'll have the same friends they had before." 
Houston's old scandal was being played out again. Promotional literature referred to the city as "an expansive urban forest" with a "mild" climate, painted in "the blues of many lakes and the nearby Gulf of Mexico."
I was never aware of the lakes; the gulf is an hour away and brown; and the city's prevailing color is brown. For all its virtues, Houston is not a town of natural beauty, and when I said so to Elyse Lanier, she replied, "Oh, you must see my backyard!" That is how I came on a Sunday afternoon to the Laniers' new pink villa.
Until last summer, they had lived in a penthouse, one floor above Ken and Linda Lay. Now the former mayor sat beside the pool, in his bathrobe. Bob Lanier found it hard to explain what happened at Enron, but he could not simply blame greed. Houston has always been an entrepreneurial town, he said. It began as a real-estate speculator's dream, "and then people came here and made it nice." And for most of his life, Lanier himself had been an "acquisitor." The city was filled with acquisitors. And "what you do in a democracy," he said, "is you try to have regulations and restrictions that channel that greed toward constructive ends."
When he heard of Lay's "great personal tragedy," Lanier said, he faxed "words of encouragement and hope that he would straighten out his life and make a contribution again." Houston will go on regardless, Lanier said, because the need to make money will go on. 
"I want to show him our hill," Elyse said to her husband.
Bob Lanier rose to give a tour of the grounds. He took his time, proudly pointing to the rosebushes, the ferns, the carefully planted impatiens. "This used to be all wild," he said. At last we came to the hill, the work of a bulldozer. Elyse gazed over the black iron fence and across the rolling golf course to the trees. "Don't you feel like you're in the East here?" she asked. "Reminds me so much of the Berkshires."
I agreed that Houston is certainly very beautiful in her backyard. Elyse Lanier said it was pretty from the penthouse too.

HEADLINE: The Hangover Years 

 BODY:
That was some party we had. But the boom years are long over now, a rapidly receding memory, and we're still reeling a bit from our drunken excess. Unfortunately, this is one hangover that won't be cured with a couple of aspirins and a nap. In fact, this thing could last awhile. 
 There was some optimistic buzz about a recovery this winter, but that has died down. This isn't the typical recession in which a few interest-rate cuts perk things right up. In fact, there is no recent precedent for our current economic condition of anemic growth amid quiescent inflation and low interest rates. It happened last in 1957-58, when a slump was followed by a slow recovery and another drop. In the 1960 presidential campaign, John F. Kennedy promised to "get the country moving again," which he did, sort of. But it wasn't until 1965 that unemployment rates retreated to boom-era levels. 
 This is not to say that everyone is suffering. For a while after 9/11, economists worried that frightened consumers would stop spending. Not to worry. Three-bedroom fixer-uppers are going for $1 million in Silicon Valley, and sales of jewelry and high-end yachts are doing quite well, thank you. What's missing, though, is the capital investment that powered the expansion of the 90's. Businesses are saddled with too many routers and servers, too much useless software. The Internet now looks more like a Florida land deal than a New Economy gold mine.
Still, this is America, and we'll shake off the cobwebs and boom again. But before that happens, we need to attend a few recovery meetings to figure out what went wrong. There's plenty to discuss. In this issue, for instance, Harris Collingwood explains how many of the worst excesses of the 90's can be traced to an obsession with corporate earnings growth. And Roger Lowenstein shows how executives have niftily decoupled pay from performance. 
But some things also went right. Most Americans got to keep the bulk of their boom-time wealth, an abundance that David Brooks argues has made us more virtuous, encouraging us to work harder to get more. And much of America is impervious to cycles, anyway. Randall Patterson reports from Houston that a little thing like the Enron scandal isn't about to distract people from their God-given right to chase the almighty dollar. In "The Middle of the Middle Class" you'll find smack-center median-income families who are perfectly happy with their lot.
Occasionally, in the foggy years ahead, the deal will fall through, the job may disappear or, as in Melanie Thernstrom's case, the inheritance may end up in the Cleveland Museum of Art. But these relapses are to be expected, momentary setbacks as we exorcise the excesses of the 90's and prepare for the next great binge.

HEADLINE: The Middle Of the Middle Class

 BODY:
 The median American family income is $54,400 -- but that goes a lot further in small-town Louisiana than it does in New York City. Here are seven families, from across the country, who earn almost exactly the national median.

LENGTH: 2448 words

HEADLINE: Living Less Large 

BYLINE:  By George Kalogerakis; George Kalogerakis is a contributing editor at New York magazine.

 BODY:
Jayson Jackson is breaking it down. "Cars and jewelry come first," he says. "Maybe jewelry has become a bit passe, because with jewelry you can't outdo anyone -- no one takes the microscope and measures the clarity of the diamond. So the first thing is probably go out and buy a car. Or two. It's like sneakers, man -- you gotta have a pair of high-tops, and you gotta have a pair of low-tops. So they'll go get the convertible, and they'll go get the Range Rover." 
 As the senior vice president and general manager for urban music at Virgin Records and a veteran of several other labels, Jackson has seen one newly signed recording artist after another head down that path. "Then you graduate to watches," he continues. "You can buy a watch that costs 50 grand and doesn't have any diamonds in it, and that's an interesting thing for people to realize once they start coming into a lot of cash. After you've done that, smarter guys usually get a home. That's a matter of: 'Do I buy Park Avenue, or do I buy Saddle River? Or do I just go Connecticut?' Not too many people go Connecticut. Once you've got that, you get a home in the Hamptons and maybe one in Miami. And it's Miami that really gets you thinking about a boat. Folks are definitely moving into boats. I know a couple of people who've ventured into that, and it's not for the light in pocket." 
 The particular status details may vary from one genre to the next, but the thrill of blowing piles of newfound money has always been an essential part of the music industry's mythos. These extravagances are so widely publicized that they've even started to recalibrate the way mere civilians think about luxury. "At one point, if a guy had a $30,000 car, he was thought of as doing pretty well," says Al Gary, owner of Virtual Auto in Fort Lee, N.J., a dealership that caters to celebrity musicians. "But because of videos and movies and music, now if a guy's not driving something $75,000 or better, basically he can't get a date. He's not even getting a wink."
These days, however, the business that reset the standards for conspicuous consumption is in the midst of a wrenching downturn. According to the Recording Industry Association of America, record companies shipped 10.3 percent fewer units in 2001 than in the previous year -- a drop of more than half a billion dollars. The industry's mergers and takeovers, which left hundreds of employees without jobs, also left many artists without labels. Others saw their royalties shrink as the retail price of CD's went lower and lower in search of buyers. As a result, some of the business's most visible players are now finding themselves stretched between their own high profiles and their industry's lowering tides. And many of the professionals who used to help keep musicians' pockets full of spending money now feel obligated to help them conserve their funds, invest prudently and think about the long term.
"I try to advise artists before I sign them, because a lot of them come in with dreams," says Brian K. Jackson, a senior vice president at E.M.I. for creative/A&R. "They believe their life is going to be so incredible once they find a deal. But advances disappear quickly. I know a songwriter, practically the day after he signed for $350,000, he had a Bentley. And this newfound love for diamonds: I've seen people get a $200,000 advance and buy a $75,000 diamond watch. I know one big producer who stated that by having the jewels on, if he sat across the table from someone else who had jewels on that he would gain respect. It's a lot of values that are messed up."
The midtown offices of the Madison Smallwood Financial Group are modest, as if to signal the partners' determination to practice the fiscal restraint they preach. Like their most obedient clients, Horace Madison and Solomon Smallwood are probably doing much better than they let on: they have another office in Atlanta and a third opening soon in Los Angeles. Their clients, 50 or so, are mostly artists, producers, songwriters and executives in the music business (OutKast, Usher, Swizz Beatz, Pastor Mason Betha -- formerly Mase -- and the late Lisa Lopes, to name a few). The firm has been in business for all of two years.
Madison, an affable 37-year-old dressed in understated gray slacks and white sweater, sits at a marble conference table amid photographs of grateful stars he has guided toward financial responsibility. "I'm not completely altruistic," he admits. "I definitely do this for profit, but I really do enjoy teaching people and helping people." Oblivious to the sound of roiling Third Avenue traffic below, he is confident and easygoing. But on the subject of his professional mission, he is unmistakably serious.
"Most of our clients, excluding the executives, come from nothing and have relatively a lot," he continues, gesturing to an assistant to bring him a folder. "We have to remind them that if you just made a million dollars, but you spend $900,000, you're in the same place you were when you got it. The other thing is making them realize that the big-ticket items are a problem, because most of the ones our younger clients tend to purchase are a depreciating asset." He leans forward into the conversation. "You have to become an actor in the theater of the absurd: 'Can you live in that watch? If something happens to you -- your mother, your children, your wife, what are they going to be able to do with that $200,000 car?"' 
The purest example of Madison's methodology is "the stupid letter," a reproach he faxes to clients who are about to make an irresponsible purchase. Their signed response amounts to an acknowledgment -- and a legal record -- of Madison's profound disapproval. At the mention of his secret weapon, he laughs. "Customized every time," he says. "I'll say, you know, 'Is this more important than Cindy and Bobby's education?' Or, 'How can you justify buying this when you have yet to fund your trust accounts?' Or, 'You haven't even thought about your retirement."'
The letter engenders a variety of responses. "A few ignore it," Madison says. "A very few have taken offense. But far more often the clients appreciate what we're trying to accomplish. If, reluctantly, they decide not to complete the transaction, that's a coup. More times than not, they will at least tone it down." And in the current climate, toning it down seems smarter than ever. "A few years ago, any clown could make money," Madison says, holding a call. "As the market share gets smaller, people are going to have to be more careful with their finances."
Jimmy Maynes, Vice President for A&R/Music Publishing at Jive Records, has had his own share of experiences trying to save newly flush artists from themselves. It hasn't always worked. Maynes recalls one artist who called him right after landing a big deal and said, "Meet me at the Benz dealer."
Knowing that the artist was still deep in debt, Maynes replied: "Listen, how about I meet you at the BMW dealer? How about I meet you at the Lexus dealer?"
But the artist wasn't interested. "I've worked too hard and too long," he said. "So you may as well just come help me pick out the color." 
Maynes laughs. "So naturally -- 'cause I like a nice ride -- I go with him," he says. "I'm thinking, I can guide him to the affordable Benz. He didn't like that. He guides himself over to the biggest Benz there is. This car is $125,000." The artist paid in cash. "Long story short: now he only has the car," Maynes says. 
"You spend so much time trying to get a deal, you spend so much money on your demos, and your clothes, and your travel," he says, that when the first big check arrives, "you forget that your Con Ed bill was eight months behind. You forget that your cellphone bill was 15 months behind. You forget that you never paid the I.R.S. -- at all, ever, in life. And you know what? You can't really enjoy that car knowing that you have all those other bills. It's nice to be flamboyant and ride around and have everybody stare and look, but at the end of the day you have to go to bed knowing that in the morning the lights are going to go on."
That sort of logic had more traction with another of Maynes's artists, a woman who, having spent time sleeping in a car and living on shoplifted food, suddenly had several hundred thousand newly wired dollars sitting in her bank account. Maynes sat down and explained what lay ahead: months -- at least -- of hard work and tireless promotion before any more money could possibly come in. And even then there were no guarantees. "I was able to show this artist the long haul," Maynes says. "The label was looking at this money to last a couple of years. I said, 'I don't care if 17,000 people are looking at you every day, I'm going to give you $35 per diem."'
So she put half of the advance into a high-interest I.R.A. and spent another $50,000 or so building a recording studio, which in short order paid for itself and promises to yield much more. Eventually, Maynes says, "the artist did go to the Benz dealer -- for some reason or other, you just can't keep these people out of the Benz dealer -- but she got a used Benz, and she leased. So she gets the same 'oohs' and 'aahs' from the fame-watchers when she pulls up to the club or when she pulls up to the mall, but at a fraction of the cost." 
Maynes was confident that she'd stick with the program. He regards it as a matter of character. "I watched her spending habits," he says. "I'm not going to go out and get a bunch of clothes, because I'm going to get free clothes from photo shoots.' 'I'm not going to go to the hottest hairstylist -- I'm just going to go to somebody I know.' The thought of going broke again was a real fear factor. Look at the personality trait: even when she was shoplifting, she was shoplifting food. Not jewelry, not clothes."
In the rarest of instances, musicians learn to practice restraint not from a professional counselor but from fellow artists. "Stevie, my bass player, he was an accountant before we started this, so he's really good with numbers," says Dave Williams, the 28-year-old lead singer of Drowning Pool, a heavy metal band that has sold more than a million copies of its 2001 debut, "Sinner" (Wind-up Records). "Mike, my drummer, is really into a lot of investments. They look out for me."
Speaking from Germany, where the band is on tour with Ozzfest, he recalls: "The first thing off the bat was, 'I want to get a car, and I want to get a house.' And they're like, 'Just . . . wait a . . . minute. How much time do you think you're going to spend in that car and in that house over the next two or three years?' And I looked -- 'cause our career is pretty much mapped out for a while -- and I went, 'Wow, maybe you're right."'
He also credits Sevendust and Pantera, successful Southern metal bands, with inspiring Drowning Pool to stay on its casually shod feet. "Pantera is a constant moneymaking thing, as far as the trademarks and the merchandise," he says. "There's a constant flow of income, and I think that's awesome. They live comfortably. That didn't just come overnight, as I'm sure it won't for us.
"I don't know how to react to a lot of money 'cause I've never had it," he admits. Back in the old days, when the band all slept on the floor in the same one-bedroom apartment, "we had fun," he says. "As long as the money we made covered the gas to get home, we were cool with that. Enough to buy some beer and lunch meat. The thing that's different now is, now we're homeless. When we come off the road, we stay with friends, or Mom and Dad, or get a hotel room. I think everybody expected us to change with everything that's happened, but we weren't raised that way.
"We all bought some toys," Williams concedes. "I went out and got some tattoos and stuff, and I took some friends out to dinner and to some strip bars. A couple of the other guys want to get dirt bikes." But so far it hasn't gone any further. "Maybe when I sit down and watch a football game with all my friends in my house, for the first time, then maybe -- maybe -- it'll set in." 

Hollywood's Portfolio
Despite the temptations of luxury spending, many celebrities are focused on investment, a field in which they tend to have opportunities not open to mere civilians. Herewith, a selection of options favored by the very famous.

1. Production companies. The father of them all was Merv Griffin Productions, which was sold in 1986 for a reported $250 million. Oprah's 90 percent stake in Harpo Inc. is worth about $518 million. David Letterman owns Worldwide Pants; George Lucas owns Industrial Light and Magic.

2. Personal marketing. In 1999, George Foreman sold the rights to his name to the makers of the wildly successful George Foreman Grills for $137.5 million and stock. Many celebrities promote their own product lines on television; Joan Rivers, for one, has sold more than 15 million pieces of jewelry. Elle Macpherson owns a top-selling lingerie line.

3. Restaurants. Some of the very many high-profile investors: Jennifer Lopez (Madre's in Pasadena), Sean Combs (Justin's in New York and Atlanta), Michael Jordan (Michael Jordan's: The Steak House in New York) and Britney Spears (Nyla, opening soon in New York).

4. Fine art. Madonna's art collection includes more than 47 works by Frida Kahlo. Steve Martin's includes works by Hockney, Fischl, Hopper, Lichtenstein, Picasso and Seurat; Andrew Lloyd Weber collects Pre-Raphaelite paintings.

5. Stocks and bonds. Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia's I.P.O. raised $129.6 million. David Bowie raised $55 million
by issuing bonds backed by his song catalog's future earnings; Ashford and Simpson, James Brown, Dusty Springfield, the Isley Brothers and the estate of Marvin Gaye followed suit.

6. Cars and planes. Among the many who collect them, some make money: Frankie Muniz sends his customized 2000 Volkswagen Jetta to car shows; Latrell Sprewell opened a racing shop; John Travolta's movie contracts require the production company to pay for fuel and maintenance on his jets -- as well as two standby pilots, at $1,250 a day.

7. Racehorses. Toby Keith, the country-music star, owns more than 40 horses, several of which cost $150,000 each; they've already paid for themselves through winnings and sales. Alex Trebek, Burt Bacharach, Rick Pitino and William Shatner have major equine holdings.

8. Theme parks and resorts. Dollywood, the Pigeon Forge, Tenn., amusement park in which Dolly Parton has invested tens of millions of dollars, now generates estimated annual revenues of $84 million. Clint Eastwood bought a historic resort in Carmel, Calif.; Kevin Costner bought a South Dakota casino and plans to build a golf resort nearby.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY; 
Deals and Discounts

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH SIANO 

 BODY:
 BERMUDA FOR BUDDIES -- The Bermuda Department of Tourism has arranged five-night accommodation packages for two people with a $400 air-fare credit for the the companion. At the 47-unit Ariel Sands, for example, rates for the first person start at $1,568, the second, $1,168, including air fare from New York. At the 244-room Elbow Beach, it's $1,378 and $978; and the 43-room Rosedon, $1,263 and $863. You must book by June 30 and travel by Oct. 31. Call (800) 237-6832 and ask about the Compliments of Bermuda -- Companion Flies Free package. Taxes extra; subject to availability and good for travel Monday to Thursday. 

SCOTLAND SLEEPER -- It's more than 400 miles by rail from London to Scotland, and if passengers would rather save daylight hours for sightseeing, BritRail has reduced-rate tickets that include round-trip sleeper accommodations. By buying the rail ticket and sleeper as a package, the BritRail price between London and either Edinburgh or Glasgow is $199 round trip in standard class (versus $272 buying them separately) and $299 in first class ($406 separately). All sleepers are air-conditioned and have a sink. First-class compartments (for one person) have one lower berth and access to a lounge car, while standard class (for two) has one upper and one lower berth. The Caledonian Sleeper Package, as it is called, must be purchased before departure from the United States. Information: (877) 677-1066 or www.britrail.net.

CROSSING THE HUDSON -- For those who want to spend weekends in Manhattan but don't want to look for a parking spot, the Hyatt Regency Jersey City, scheduled to open July 2, will have introductory rates of $99 on weekends (Thursday, Friday and Saturday nights) through Sept. 15. The hotel is a short walk to Manhattan ferries and a 10-minute ride by light rail to the Grove Street PATH station. The 350-room hotel, at 2 Exchange Place, overlooks the Hudson on the Harborside Financial Center south pier. Call (201) 469-1234.

FAMILY SUITE -- Homewood Suites has a June-through-August weekend package good Thursday through Sunday nights. Two-room suites that can accommodate a family of four start at $69 a night. Breakfast is included. More than 100 properties nationwide are participating. Reservations must be made at www.homewood-suites.com. Tax and tips are extra; availability is limited and other restrictions apply.

CABIN FOR FOUR -- Through December, Cunard is offering an $899 rate for the third and fourth persons in a cabin, in any grade stateroom, on its six-day Atlantic crossings between Southampton, England, and New York; economy return air fare to any of 120 North American cities is included. Fares for the first two passengers in a cabin start at $999 a person; (800) 728-6273 or www.cunard.com. JOSEPH SIANO

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN; 
Istanbul

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS FRANTZ; DOUGLAS FRANTZ is chief of the Istanbul bureau of The Times.

 BODY:
There are two Istanbuls. One is historic, an ancient city where Byzantine churches, Roman walls and Ottoman monuments constantly remind visitors that this was the capital of three great empires.
 Then there is modern Istanbul, a vibrant metropolis of 15 million where traffic is controlled chaos, five-star hotels offer sumptuous accommodations and ambitious restaurants compare with the best of New York or London. 
 Istanbul today is the ultimate hybrid city, a beguiling conjunction of old and new, Asian and European, a place with options to fit the interests and budget of any traveler.
This summer, crowds should be sparser than usual and most prices are down. Turkey has been hit hard by the post-Sept. 11 travel decline and Mideast violence. Further, 18 months of recession have stripped the Turkish lira of 50 percent of its value against the dollar -- it is now nearly 1.5 million lire to the dollar. 
Prices are lower, though not half what they were a couple of years ago. And bigger bargains are available, especially for those willing to negotiate. Except in restaurants, bargaining is part of Turkey's entrepreneurial culture, and polite negotiation should not offend any shopkeeper or hotel owner. Even folks too shy to haggle should ask if they are getting the best price.

Events
 The high point on Istanbul's cultural calendar comes each June when the International Music Festival brings in musicians from around the world for three weeks. Most performances take place in Haghia Eirene, an atmosphere-laden jewel of a Byzantine chapel on the grounds of Topkapi Palace.
The festival, which opened Saturday, concludes July 1, when William Christie conducts Les Arts Florissants, the early-music vocal and instrumental group, in Haydn's "Seasons." Early music and period instruments are the emphasis this year, and the program includes I Solisti Veneti on June 19 and 20, and the Academy of Ancient Music from England on June 22.
Festival tickets, $10 to $100, can be ordered by phone, (90-212) 334-0700, extension 34 or 36, or by fax, (90-212) 334-0705. E-mail reservations: meric .soylu@istfest-tr.org. The schedule is at www.istfest.org.
On the heels of the music fest is the International Istanbul Jazz Festival, which opens July 5. There will be 35 to 40 acts over two weeks, ranging from favorites like Herbie Hancock to Antibalas, a New York group that is making a name with its blend of jazz and funk known as Afrobeat.
Performance sites are as varied as the music. Headliners perform in a 4,000-seat open-air theater and others play in more intimate settings like Babylon, a club at 3 Sehbender Street, just off Istanbul's busiest pedestrian boulevard, Istiklal Street. 
At least one concert will be at Kiz Kulesi, or Maiden's Tower. Legend has it that a sultan's daughter was locked in this 12th-century island tower in the Bosporus near the Asian side to protect her from a prediction that she would die of a snake bite. More recently, Pierce Brosnan was held hostage there in the 1999 James Bond movie "The World Is Not Enough." Refurbished and now a restaurant, the tower provides stunning views.
Festival tickets are $10 to $50. Information: (90-212) 334-0739, fax (90-212) 334-0705, and www.istfest.org. 
A stroll along Istiklal to the Tunel district on a Sunday afternoon can lead to some unusual sounds. Disciples of Mevlana Celaleddin Rumi, a Sufi mystic, perform a concert, complete with whirling dervishes, each summer Sunday at 5 p.m. Tickets are $6.80 and sell fast, so stop by the box office at Galata Mevlevihanesi, a museum at Galip Dede Caddesi, during the week because reservations are not accepted. Seating is also first come, first served. Information: (90-212) 245-4141, fax (90-212) 213-1059, www.emav.org.

Sightseeing
Few cities offer as much history as Istanbul, and no place in Istanbul offers more than the Sultanahmet district, where three major monuments and numerous others are within walking distance. 
Topkapi Palace, home to the Ottoman sultans for nearly four centuries, is worth a day itself for touring the grounds and exhibits like the harem and the treasury. At Babihumayun Caddesi, it is open daily except Tuesday. Admission is $10.20; (90-212) 512-0480. 
Nearby is the magnificent Haghia Sophia, built as a Byzantine church in the sixth century and now a museum at Ayasofya Meydani, (90-212) 522-1750. Restoration work has recently been completed on the stunning upper gallery. Closed Monday; general admission is $10.20 and another $10.20 for the upper galleries. 
Across a park from Haghia Sophia at Sultanahmet Meydani is the Blue Mosque, an active place of worship that is always open free. The mosque takes its name from the mainly blue Iznik tilework and is particularly magical at night. Proper attire is required: women should avoid shorts or short skirts and wear a scarf; donations are customary.
A Bosporus tour is delightful, especially in summer. The best -- and cheapest -- way to see the straits is by municipal ferries, which leave Bogaz Iskelesi dock in Eminonu at 10:35 a.m. or 1:35 p.m. daily for a 90-minute tour. You can get off for two hours in Kavaklar, a village on the Asian side famous for its fish restaurants. Tickets are $2. 
Shopping in Istanbul is entertaining enough to qualify as sightseeing, particularly at the Grand Bazaar (or Covered Market) on Carsikapi Caddesi in the Beyazit district. The 450-year-old collection of about 4,000 shops winds through a vast network of covered streets and buildings. Open 9 a.m. to 7 p.m. daily except Sunday, the bazaar is a cornucopia of wares, from mass-produced carpets and fake designer shirts to fine jewelry and antiques. By bargaining, expect to pay about two-thirds the asking price for most goods.
The best shops don't hawk their wares. At Eski Arts and Antiques, at Cevahir Bedestan, 7 Serifaga Street, Irfan Karatas sells antique jewelry and religious icons without moving from his cozy store. Stunningly detailed antique Russian icons can cost as little as $500 or as much as $5,000. 
Nearby, at 93-95 Takkeciler Street, Dogan Bilgili sits patiently in his shop, where a lightweight, butter-soft leather coat for a man or woman is about $225.
Carpets are popular purchases, but buy with care. For people with expertise and money, or just money, a handful of shops sell antique rugs starting at $1,000 and ranging to the stratosphere. One is Naturel, on Evkaf Street at Ekmel Han No. 1, near the Grand Bazaar, (90-212) 516-7601, fax (90-212) 516-7603. It specializes in old carpets from Turkey and the Caucasus, some of museum-quality and priced accordingly.

Where to Stay
 The downturn in tourism is keeping most hotel rates reasonable, and a number of high-end places have weekend and other specials.
The Conrad Istanbul, Barbaros Boulevard, Yildiz Caddesi, Besiktas, (800) 774-1500, (90-212) 227-3000, fax (90-212) 259-6667, www.conrad.com, was the first of the city's modern luxury hotels and many of its 592 rooms have wonderful Bosporus views. After June 15, a standard double will begin at $130, including tax.
In the heart of Sultanahmet is the 14-room Seven Hills Hotel, 8/A Tevkifhane Street, (90-212) 516-9497, fax (90-212) 517-1085, and at www .hotelsevenhills.com. Rooms have hardwood floors and lovely rugs from a shop below, owned by the same family. The rooftop restaurant has great views. A standard double is $140, with tax and breakfast.
Budget: The Side Hotel and Pension, 20 Utangac Street, (90-212) 517-2282, fax (90-212) 517-6590, Web site www.sidehotel.com, is across from the Seven Hills, with 43 tidy rooms and a friendly atmosphere. A double is $50, in the pension $35, both with breakfast and tax. Pension rooms are smaller and don't have phones; some share a bath. 
An interesting alternative for groups of three or four is Galata Residence, Felek Street, (90-212) 252-6062, fax (90-212) 244-2323, www .galataresidence.com. The hotel is in the city's oldest apartment building -- dating from the late 19th century -- and has 15 sparkling two-bedroom apartments, with a living room and full kitchen, for $100 a day.
Luxury: The Four Seasons Hotel, 1 Tevkihane Street, Sultanahmet, (90-212) 638-8200, fax (90-212) 638-8210, www.fourseasons.com, has 65 elegantly understated rooms in a renovated, century-old prison. A short walk from Sultanahmet's monuments, the hotel is an oasis of personal service, including spa treatments; the staff prides itself on knowing each guest by name. Summer rates are well below last year's: a standard double is $250 and a deluxe double, with balcony and view of the sea or Haghia Sophia, is $360.
Across town, directly on the Bosporus, is the opulent Ciragan Palace Kempinski, 32 Ciragan Caddesi, Besikstas, (800) 426-3135, (90-212) 258-3377, fax (90-212) 259-6687, Web site www.ciragan-palace.com. The Ciragan (pronounced chir-HAN) is actually two connected hotels -- a restored 19th-century palace that was one of the last homes of the sultans and a newer hotel built and decorated in similar style. The hotel takes full advantage of its location, with two pools, gardens and terraces on the Bosporus. Prices for the 315 rooms have not dropped; a standard double is $320, a superior with sea view is $430.

Where to Eat
When the hustle of Istanbul gets to you, Korfez Restaurant, 78 Korfez Caddesi, (90-216) 413-4314, fax (90-216) 413-4306, offers a respite. Tucked into an inlet on the Asian side of the Bosporus, it is best reached by a free shuttle boat from the dock near Rumeli Hisari fortress. The salt-encrusted sea bass may be the best fish dish in town, and the Turkish appetizers -- mezes -- are unusual and refined. Reservations are required; ask for a waterside table. Dinner for two with wine, $65 to $80. Open for lunch and dinner daily, except dinner only on Monday. 
Chefs is a more inventive, hipper place, especially in its new summer location in Park Orman, Buyukdere Caddesi, Maslak, (90-212) 328-2000, fax (90-212) 328-2038. The two chefs who run it, Mike Norman, a South African, and Marco Anzani, an Italian, transform traditional Turkish ingredients into dishes like sea bass wrapped in potato and risotto with seasonal vegetables. Mezes come in tiny bowls so diners can sample many. Dinner for two with wine is $50 to $65. Lunch and dinner daily, except dinner only Sunday.
Despite its tourist attractions, Sultanahmet has few good restaurants. One is Balikci Sabahattin, Armada Hotel, 1 Seyit Hasan Kuyu Street, (90-212) 458-1824, fax (90-212) 458-1802, where traditional fish dishes, like jumbo shrimp baked in clay pots, are specialties. A meal for two with wine: $45. Lunch and dinner daily. 
Sazeli Durum Evi, 76 Mualim Naci Caddesi, in Ortakoy, (90-212) 260-6969, serves outstanding grilled meat in a homey setting for great prices. The best dish is the Sazeli special kebap, a sizzling plate of minced smoked eggplant, grilled meat and cheese. A meal for two is about $8; no alcohol served, and no reservations. Lunch and dinner daily.
The Tarihi Nevizade Meyhaneleri is a collection of traditional restaurants serving mezes, fish, meat and raki, the national drink. They are off Istiklal, behind the Cicek Pasaji, or Flower Passage; finding them is half the fun, as you pass stands of fresh fish, vegetables and spices. Prices and quality are pretty uniform, though Demgah, 18 Nevizade Street, (90-212) 245-0964, is a cut above. A meal for two with wine or raki, $25; lunch and dinner daily.

HEADLINE: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 6-09-02: INVENTORY; 
Start Me Up

BYLINE:  By Ivar Ekman 

 BODY:
 In 2000, near the height of the economic boom, 8.6 percent of American adults -- about 15.7 million people -- were in the process of starting businesses. In 2001, that number fell to 7 percent, or 12.7 million. Here, in ascending order of capital invested, are some who braved the tougher climate and got businesses rolling in the past 18 months. The costs reflect only what the owners spent before opening their doors. The break-even dates represent their own (optimistic) predictions.

Syreeta McDaniel
Business Consultant, Dallas

McDaniel, 29, started McDaniel Consulting, writing business plans for small companies, in June 2001. She kept her costs very low by finding cheap office space, recruiting unpaid interns and bartering with a Web designer, who created a site for her in exchange for her help in securing him a business loan.

Investment
Office furniture $1,000
Office supplies and stationery, 550
Marketing, 450
Membership and registration fees, 360
Insurance, first two months, 240
Rent deposit, first month, 140
Total $2,740

Source of Financing
Personal savings $2,740

McDaniel says that she made back her start-up costs within three months and had revenues of around $50,000 the first year. This translates into writing roughly three new business plans per week.

Dana Wright
Dentist, Anderson, Ind.

Instead of going to work for another established dentist, as most new graduates do, Wright, 26, went straight from Indiana University's School of Dentistry to establishing her own practice in August 2001. Wright also got a couple of unusually big breaks from the dentist with whom she shares a space -- first, he let her use some of his equipment; second, he gave her the first six months rent free.

Investment

Drug Enforcement Agency number
and state licenses, 200
Total $169,900
Sources of Financing
Subsidized and unsubsidized government
student loans $139,000
Bank loan 30,900

Wright started making a profit after three months, on expected revenues of $180,000 in the first year. This translates to about 40 patients per week. (An established dentist with two assistants, three hygienists and two office workers handles about the same number of patients per day.)

Peter Sclafani and Kristen Hallett
Restaurateurs, Brooklyn

Sclafani, 36, and Hallett, 38, opened the restaurant Luce in Park Slope in October 2001. Hallett is a photographer and a photo producer. Sclafani has owned and run restaurants in New York before. The couple designed the restaurant themselves and did a lot of the interior work, which cut down on their expenses considerably.

HEADLINE: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 6-09-02: SALIENT FACTS; 
Down From the Peaks

BYLINE:  By J. R. Romanko 

 BODY:
The last economic golden age probably peaked not much more than two years ago. That's when the Dow Jones industrial average reached its all-time high of 11,723, on Jan. 14, 2000, just after a fourth quarter in 1999 in which gross domestic product grew at an annualized rate of 8.3 percent, the largest quarterly increase in just over 15 years. 
 But if that was the glorious then, we aren't necessarily in a leaden time now. The Dow is still bouncing around 10,000, and G.D.P. in this year's first quarter was 5.6 percent. Business bankruptcies have actually declined and productivity (output per worker per hour of work) rose an annualized 8.4 percent in the most recent quarter, the best performance in 19 years. So why does it feel as if we've experienced such a comedown? Here are some of the numbers that suggest it isn't all in our heads. 

Unemployment rate in April 2000: 3.9 percent (30-year low)
Unemployment rate in April 2002: 6 percent (8-year high)

Estimated decrease in the hiring of college grads from the class of 2002 compared with the class of 2000: 37 percent

Percentage of those surveyed in January 2000 who said that business conditions were good: 47.3
Percentage of those surveyed in April 2002 who said that business conditions were good: 19.7

Money invested by 916 venture-capital firms in 1,009 Internet companies in the first quarter of 2000: $15.7 billion (each figure a peak)
Money invested by 292 venture-capital firms in 202 Internet companies in the first quarter of 2002: $1.3 billion

Number of I.P.O.'s completed in the fourth quarter of 1999: 159
Number of I.P.O.'s completed in the first quarter of 2002: 16

Annual increase in giving by grant-making foundations in 2000: 18.2 percent
Annual increase in giving by grant-making foundations in 2001: 5 percent (smallest gain since 1994)

Annual increase in giving by corporate foundations in 1999: 15 percent
Annual increase in giving by corporate foundations in 2001: 2.6 percent (less than inflation)

HEADLINE: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 6-09-02: QUESTIONS FOR JOSEPH E. STIGLITZ; 
Think Global

BYLINE:  By Abby Ellin 

 BODY:
Q: Your new book, "Globalization and Its Discontents," which is being published this month, is already out in Germany and France. Why there first? To make a point about globalization?
 These issues are becoming more alive in Europe. So the German and French publishers really pushed to have it come out quickly. 
 What's the No. 1 "discontent"?
One charge, which has some validity, is that the International Monetary Fund undermines the democratic process, because it dictates policies. When Korea needed money, it was told, "Only if you open up your markets faster than had been agreed and only if you have a central bank independent and focused exclusively on inflation." 
In the United States, the Federal Reserve Board focuses on inflation, employment and growth. And yet the I.M.F. gave Korea no choice. 
It's not only that I think it's bad economic policy, but I think those are the kinds of things that countries should decide for themselves. The undermining of democracy, the lack of transparency, which results in particular interests being advanced often over broader interests -- that's one set of objections. And there is discontent as a result of the inequities in the global trading regime. For instance, many of the poorer countries produce agricultural goods, and advanced industrial countries have protected agriculture to the extent that the subsidies exceed the entire incomes in sub-Saharan Africa.
So you're probably no fan of the recent farm bill.
It is the worst form of political hypocrisy. The farm program had been originally prescribed to help poor farmers. Well, most of the poor farmers have left farming, and now the vast majority of the money goes to rich farmers and big corporations. That's the first moment of hypocrisy. At the global level, we have been going around the world telling countries that subsidies distort and lead to unfair competition. We have lost all credibility all over the world.
But what's wrong with taking care of your own before worrying about the rest of the world?
One of the aspects of globalization is the recognition that at one time we only had a responsibility to our own family, but as communities developed, your sense of moral responsibility went to your community, to your whole country. But that doesn't mean we shouldn't also feel a moral responsibility that goes beyond that. My sense is that most Americans do. It is part of the ethic of Americans, of every religion, to help people worse off than themselves.
Doesn't that make globalization as much of a moral argument as an economic one?
I also think that it's in our economic self-interest, because as the incomes of these countries increase, they will buy more of our goods. One of the major sources of our economic growth in the mid 90's was the growth of emerging markets. I also think it is a moral imperative -- both together. I sometimes worry that the economic argument takes attention from the moral argument.
Do you think it would be a good idea for the United States to write off debts of poor countries?
In many cases the debts are so large the prospect for reducing poverty is going to be very bleak unless we write off their debts. And some of the debts are cold-war debts. When we lent money to Mobutu, we knew the money wasn't going to the people in Zaire; it was going into Swiss bank accounts. And yet the people have to pay back the money. Another way of putting it is that every loan has a borrower and a lender. When the loan goes bad it's the lender's as much as the borrower's mistake. In the 19th century, when Mexico couldn't pay its debts, the French and British armies marched in. That's not the way we want to run things today. The result around the world has been bankruptcy laws, which are a form of debt forgiveness. That's the way we handle those questions of excess indebtedness within our country. Internationally, we have to do the same thing.
Last fall you won the Nobel Prize for work you started more than 30 years ago. While doing it, did you ever think it would get you a Nobel?
It sounds immodest, but the fact is when I was doing it, I knew that it would have profound implications for capital markets, labor markets, product markets. You know you make a step forward, but you don't know if it is just a half-step of what will be 20 steps or if this will be the big step. You never know the answer -- that's the nature of research. But 30 years later, you realize you were lucky.
Has winning the prize changed your life?
Yes and no. I had gotten a lot of honorary degrees already.
You hear about Academy Award winners who keep Oscars in their bathrooms. Where do you keep the medal?
The actual medal is gold -- I keep it in a safety deposit box. We have a replica. I don't know where it is right now, but I'll find it. Abby Ellin

GRAPHIC: Photo (Doug Kanter/Agence France Presse)

HEADLINE: DANCE; 
No Longer Defenseless, Dance Finds an Advocate

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER DUNNING 

 BODY:
YOU could almost hear the collective thud of sinking hearts when the first announcements of the new Jazz at Lincoln Center complex were made two years ago. What about modern dance, that other indigenous American art form? It badly needs a theater of its own, with a seating capacity large enough for performances by major dance troupes. And why was dance hardly mentioned as a possible use for the jazz theater on dark nights?
 Some things have changed since then. The Joyce Theater in Chelsea has been prominently mentioned as a possible participant in the planning of an arts complex at the World Trade Center site. The Joyce has for several years been searching for a site or an existing building for a 900-seat theater for dance. Such a theater could be part of the downtown project. 
 Last week, a promising lobbying effort began when a national dance service organization called Dance USA announced the opening of Dance/NYC in Manhattan. Robert Yesselman, the director of Dance/NYC, maintains that dance, which played important role in the city's culture in the 20th century, must make itself heard more clearly. Some 400 dance companies, of every aesthetic stripe, are at work in the five boroughs. Dance/NYC aims to give them a unified voice. 
"New York is the dance capital of the world," Mr. Yesselman said. "The whole world knows of the centrality of New York to dance." With one exception, he added: New York City itself has little inkling of its importance to the history and production of dance throughout the world.
It all started with "the George and Martha story," Mr. Yesselman said: after George Balanchine and Martha Graham, "no one danced the same." First came Graham. In the late 1920's, working out of a studio on Ninth Street just east of Fifth Avenue, she developed and codified what we know today as modern dance. Nearly a decade later, Balanchine arrived and settled into a studio in an old building at Madison Avenue and 59th Street, where Isadora Duncan had once worked. His patron, Lincoln Kirstein, had intended to open a school in Hartford. It had to be in New York, Balanchine told Kirstein. And it was here that he began to create a new-looking, American kind of classical ballet.
From the start, there have been problems that kept dance from fulfilling that potential. Balanchine, for the most part, kept a distance from his dancers emotionally and disdained excess. "Just do it," he told them, well before Nike thought up the slogan. But Graham's companies often resembled dysfunctional families. Without emotional pain, there could be little or no artistic gain.
That attitude set the pattern for modern-dance companies. It also made it easier for dancers and their profession to be overlooked by a culture that believes work is validated only by pay. Who could take seriously workers who subsidized their art by performing for pittances or for nothing? Early reviewers recognized that it would be a struggle for modern dance to survive and flourish in competition with the more glamorous, safely European art form of classical ballet. And so they tried to help, becoming advocates for a sometimes tiresomely fragile-seeming art. The smell of need settled into the flesh and bones of modern dance.
And there was a larger, inherent cultural problem for all dance forms in America. From Isadora Duncan's first near-naked gambols, the exposure of the body in dance has offended or worried a Puritanical nation. Immodesty had the delicious taint of sin on the burlesque stage but not in the concert halls. Then there was the problem of the insubstantiality of dance. In drama there are words. In music there is a score you can hold in your hands. Sculpture is three-dimensional. Paintings feature figures, recognizable or not, that do not flee from the field of vision.
Dance frightens some new dancegoers, who tend to worry about "understanding" the leg stretched out into an arabesque or the torso wrenching inward in a Graham contraction. Sadly, marketing sometimes plays right into those fears. What could the New York City Ballet have been thinking, for instance, when it described certain weekend matinees as "family friendly"? (On a happier note, once reluctant men in City Ballet audiences now volubly explain to the women accompanying them the intricacies of the performance they're watching, having awakened, it appears, from their fabled torpor at the ballet.)
BUT now, Mr. Yesselman contends, dance may be more ready to fight for its place at the table, in part because an increasingly bad economy has driven dance to catch up with the other arts. Dance/NYC is responding with a Web site aimed at audiences and dance professionals.
The Web site -- dancenyc.org -- includes up-to-date information on dance and dance-related events in the five boroughs, with links to sites for individual companies. Dance/NYC has created temporary sites for troupes that do not have their own. There are also mini-interviews and lively chunks of dance history tied to the places in New York City where they occurred.
Another site lists available rehearsal and performance spaces in the city. Members will receive regular e-mail messages about new grants and corporate projects. Dance/NYC has also commissioned a survey on the economic impact of the dance industry on the city. It intends to show how much money is spent by dance organizations and audiences and how that money is spent by the people who receive it.
The Joyce began to work with arts lobbyists three years ago. Linda Shelton, the executive director of the Joyce and a member of the Dance/NYC advisory committee, found that some of the mystery was taken out of the process of working with city and state governments. Dealing with politicians and finding new donor sources began to get a little easier. "They get our name out to people in the political world that we might not know even exist," Ms. Shelton said. "And they don't necessarily know that we exist." That may be changing.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robert Yesselman is director of Dance/NYC. (G. Paul Burnett/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: MUSIC; 
Adventurous Punk Of a Troubled Past

BYLINE:  By BARRY SINGER; Barry Singer writes frequently about music and theater for Arts & Leisure.

 BODY:
FROM Poison to Beck and Moby, today's pop artists are recycling the musical schlock of the 1970's and 80's. Their fascination with kitsch, however, can make us all myopic. Unambiguously good music from those years is being overlooked.
 Take the British band XTC. The release of "Coat of Many Cupboards," a four-CD boxed set from Caroline Records covering XTC's prolific early years, 1978 to 1989, is currently generating hosannas from the English music press. Here in the United States, though, it has barely been noticed, which is a shame. 
 XTC first appeared on the London punk scene in 1976, just as punk music was about to evolve into new wave. A quartet initially, the group had two primary songwriters, the guitarist Andy Partridge and the bassist Colin Moulding. Though each wrote his own songs, they shared a gift for catchy, three-minute pop tunes in the Lennon-McCartney tradition. It was Mr. Moulding's "Making Plans for Nigel" from XTC's third album, "Drums and Wires," that finally landed the band on the British charts in 1979. The song reached only No. 17 in England, but that was enough; XTC began touring internationally, performing in New York at CBGB alongside Talking Heads, to whom it was then compared.
Meanwhile, the band members were seeing no money from their increasing record sales and finding themselves deep in debt to their label, Virgin Records. The situation gave rise to a lawsuit, in which the band members accused XTC's manager of borrowing heavily from Virgin against the band's royalties. The suit was settled out of court, with both parties barred from discussing the terms.
It is this period of creative ferment, commercial breakthrough and economic catastrophe that the first two CD's on "Coat of Many Cupboards" document. The final discs offer up music from the years following what Mr. Partridge calls his "nervous collapse," in 1982, after which the band quit touring for good. This collapse, triggered by Mr. Partidge's paralyzing stage fright and compounded by his having just kicked a Valium addiction, became a creative turning point for both Mr. Partridge and XTC.
Over the next 10 years the band recorded six increasingly accomplished, adventurous and idiosyncratic albums. From the stiff-jointed, ska-influenced new wave of their early years, Mr. Partridge and Mr. Moulding blossomed. Mr. Partridge, in particular, produced richly textured, elegantly structured tunes that, on occasion, even became mainstream radio hits.
Challenging yet accessible, these perfectly simple pop songs, like "The Ballad of Peter Pumpkin Head" and "Dear God," wove together ingenious sonic experimentation, wordplay and chiming vocal harmonies redolent of the later Beatles and Brian Wilson's "Pet Sounds."
Listening to this music today, one wonders whether there would even be a Moby or a Beck without XTC. Absent Mr. Partridge and his band's pioneering intelligence and craftsmanship, these studio-obsessed latecomers would not sound nearly as interesting. And none of them is remotely in Mr. Partridge's class as a writer.
True to their iconoclastic form, Mr. Partridge and Mr. Moulding have deviated from the familiar greatest-hits package on "Coat of Many Cupboards." Many songs are represented not by their original album versions but by early demos, outtakes, rehearsal dubs or live recordings. The compilation is, as Mr. Partridge described it recently, "something of a Savile Row suit, but with lots of food stains."
At 48, Mr. Partridge has not stepped onstage before a concert audience in almost 20 years. This is perhaps the main reason XTC never caught on in America. Unlike Sting and the Police (who, in 1981, toured here with XTC), Mr. Partridge and his band never provided America with much of a flesh and blood presence.
Still, XTC did enjoy a small but devoted following here and in England. In 1993, though, at Mr. Partridge's instigation, the band went on strike against Virgin. "We had the world's worst record deal," Mr. Partridge recalled, seated serenely now in the garden of the tidy house in Swindon that he bought with Virgin's initial advance. "We were never going to make any money. I asked Virgin if we could go and Virgin said no."
THE strike lasted until 1997, when Virgin released XTC from its contract. "The most difficult years of my life," Mr. Partridge said. "And I wrote a ton. It's either extreme joy or extreme pain that gets you going."
The fruits of this productivity were finally released in 1999 and 2000 -- two XTC albums on the independent label TVT: "Apple Venus," which featured a 40-piece orchestra, and "Wasp Star," subtitled "Apple Venus Volume 2," a return, in Mr. Partridge's words, to "sonorous guitar bashing." Both discs were critically acclaimed, but neither sold well.
"I realize, of course, that audiences have changed dramatically," Mr. Partridge said. " Still, it really was a kick in the groin for me."
XTC is, today, a two-man enterprise; the lead guitarist Dave Gregory, the band's last original member, fled in frustration not long ago. Caroline Records is nontheless planning to follow up "Coat of Many Cupboards" by reissuing XTC's first 10 albums. Could this mean that the band is being rediscovered?
"Nah," said Mr. Partridge. "I think we're just going to discover as this century grinds on that the three-minute pop song was, in fact, a 20th-century art form. Why is it fading away? Computers. People don't want to put the years in, the apprenticeship, learning how to make a great chair anymore. They can just press a button and -- phhlooff! -- this inflatable piece of furniture flips up in front of them."
How would he describe his own music?
"The pop canvas," Mr. Partridge replied. "Songs that are immediate but go on forever saying a good thing. Songs with no spare flesh. Songs full of surprises that delight on first hearing but hopefully you don't tire of easily; like naive art or toys. Though some of my music can be miserable" -- he paused -- "but delightfully miserable."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Colin Moulding, left, and Andy Partridge in 1999. They performed as XTC. (Associated Press)
