HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Fauquier County, Va.; 
Flurry of Development at Former Intelligence Post

BYLINE:  By JAMES R. HARDCASTLE 

DATELINE: WARRENTON, Va. 

 BODY:
THE closing of a United States Army post used for decades to eavesdrop on military and diplomatic communications has become the unlikely catalyst for a burst of new development in a largely rural county 40 miles southwest of Washington.
 The post is the former Vint Hill Farms Station, a 700-acre compound surrounded by horse farms and rural dwellings in eastern Fauquier County. Until it was closed in 1997 and its intelligence-gathering equipment removed, the dominant feature of the base was a vast field of antennas inside security fences. 
 Probably the first antenna installed by the Army at Vint Hill was in July 1942, when a long wire was strung out a window from the first floor of the recently acquired farm's estate mansion to a nearby tree to intercept messages transmitted in Nazi Germany. By August, a barn complex behind the manor house had been converted into a permanent intercept station and powerful rhombic antennas were installed. 
In 1943, according to an Army history of the post, a soldier working in the barn copied a coded radio message from the Japanese ambassador to Berlin to his superiors in Tokyo that gave a detailed description of the German Atlantic Wall defenses at Normandy and Calais. Because the Japanese diplomatic code had been broken, the intercept provided Allied planners with details needed to overcome German defenses.
Over the years, the Army suspended miles of antenna wire from poles in the fields at the base. The antenna arrays, which eventually spread over 450 acres, could be tuned to collect high frequency radio messages being transmitted to and from embassies in Washington.
From the late 1960's to 1974, Army Security Agency troops with special wide-band receivers were recording all signals that reached the agency's field stations around the world on inch-wide audio tape. The tapes were shipped to a bunkerlike operations building at Vint Hill where "signals of interest," according to the Army history, were extracted using highly classified techniques developed by the National Security Agency.
Most of the wide-band signals processed came from the Soviet Union and its satellites, but the Army admitted that on at least six occasions the Vint Hill facilities were used to spy on antiwar activists' radio communications in the United States.
When the Pentagon announced in 1993 that Vint Hill Farms would be shut down, people in Fauquier County feared the worst, said Hunton Tiffany, chief executive of the Fauquier Bank in Warrenton and chairman of the economic adjustment task force created by the county to study the reuse of the base. With its 2,656 workers, Vint Hill Farms was far and away the largest employer in this bucolic county of 55,000 on the fringes of Washington's northern Virginia suburbs. 
With its fabled horse farms in the northern part of the county and median household income of $62,103, Fauquier County was too affluent to qualify for economic aid offered by the Commerce Department's Economic Development Administration to many communities faced with base closings. Instead, the closing "presented Fauquier County with the kind of opportunity that only comes once in a hundred years," Mr. Tiffany said. 
In 1999, the Defense Department sold the land; the base's water, sewer and telephone systems; and an assortment of more than 200 structures for of $925,000 to an authority created by the state to redevelop the property. 
After lengthy negotiations with the authority, the county rezoned the site to allow for office and industrial use and 300 detached homes. The development authority, in turn, agreed to deed a 30-acre middle-school site, the base's former clinic and 18.5 acres of developed recreation facilities to the county. Recreation facilities at the base include a movie theater converted into a theater, a gymnasium, tennis courts and lighted ball fields and basketball courts.
Shortly after taking title to the base, the authority scored a major success when the Federal Aviation Administration purchased a 30-acre parcel for $1.66 million. The F.A.A. plans to open a 95,000-square-foot Terminal Radar Approach Control Center on its Vint Hill site early in 2003. The new facility , will consolidate radar control centers at the Baltimore-Washington, Dulles, Reagan National and Richmond airports and Andrews Air Force Base at a single site. The F.A.A. center will employ about 300 people making an average of $90,000 a year.
The F.A.A. purchase gave the authority needed cash. Even more important, it gave Vint Hill great visibility and validated it as a business location, Mr. Tiffany said. 
Pat White, the authority's marketing director, said recreational amenities at the base are a major plus in attracting new tenants and owners to Vint Hill. The authority also hopes to add to Vint Hill's attractiveness by restoring the 1860's Colonial Revival mansion that served as an inn and the base's officers' club. The former club is now used by Scott and Dawn Donaldson for a catering operation. In time, they plan to open a pub, an upscale restaurant and a bed-and-breakfast on the mansion property. 
In more than 200 buildings on the base, the authority has identified 400,000 to 500,000 square feet of space suitable for reuse. About 300,000 square feet has already been leased. Besides the F.A.A., the largest employer at Vint Hill is Gaithersburg Cabinetry and Millwork, a manufacturer of premium corporate interiors, which employs about 50 in the base's former commissary. 
Other major employers at Vint Hill are the Science Applications International Corporation, a large-scale systems integrator, which employs about 30 Web designers in a leased 9,000-square-foot building, and Log.Sec, a startup logistical engineering and information technology company with about 30 employees. 
Last summer, the authority sold a bunkerlike 80,000-square-foot concrete structure and 12 acres to Zumot Real Estate Management Inc. of McLean, Va., for $1.2 million. The building's features include eight-inch reinforced concrete walls, a concrete ceiling and multiple backup power systems. The company's president, Rajai Zumot, said he planned to convert the structure into a conventional office building. 
IN many ways, Vint Hill's modest sewage treatment plant is the most important building on the base. The 240,000-gallon-per-day plant is old and in need of renovation, but the plant has a permit that allows it to be expanded up to 1 million gallons a day. 
When that capacity is available for public use, new home and commercial construction is likely to soar both within Vint Hill, where 300 homes are to be built adjacent to the F.A.A. center, and on nearby properties to which sewer lines can be extended. 
Last year, permits for 581 new homes were issued in Fauquier County, double the number issued the year the base closed. This number is expected to grow in the years ahead. 
Miller & Smith, a builder and developer in McLean, Va., has options from the authority to buy the 78 lots that make up the first phase of Vint Hill's 300-unit residential component. Its two model homes have recently opened, and the company has already sold 12 units, with nine of the homes under construction. The homes have been averaging about $400,000 after options are selected. 
A development plan for 967 detached units to be built on nearly 1,000 acres that have been assembled next to Vint Hill was approved by the Fauquier County Board of Supervisors in May. . The developer, Edward L. Miller, said the focal point of the development, to be called Brookside, will be an existing 65-acre lake. The target price for new homes there will be $350,000, with some costing more, some costing slightly less.

HEADLINE: Almost Everyone Gets a Piece Of the U.S. Open Business Pie 

BYLINE:  By DAVID WINZELBERG 

DATELINE: FARMINGDALE 

 BODY:
A COUPLE of months ago, few Long Islanders looked forward to this week's United States Open more eagerly than Kelly Hicks. She couldn't tell Ernie Els from David Duval, but she's a real estate agent in Farmingdale and could recognize a potential for profit.
 Thousands of out-of-town fans, contestants, officials, media people and business representatives are descending on Bethpage State Park for the championship, which begins with Monday's first practice round and concludes on Sunday. Ms. Hicks figured some of them might show up without a place to stay. 
 "There is nothing available here," Ms. Hicks said. "No hotels, no motels, not even a bed-and-breakfast." 
Hotels as far away as Ronkonkoma have been sold out for the Open for months, many at rates between 30 and 70 percent higher than normal. The $160-a-night rate for two people at the Hampton Inn in Commack becomes $250 a night this week. Hotels close to the Open have been sold out for years. The Huntington Hilton was sold out for this week in 1999. The Inn at Fox Hollow in Woodbury was sold out for the Open before the hotel was built last year.
"If you work it a little you can find a room," insisted Michael Hollander, president of the Long Island Convention and Visitors Bureau, who expected some last-minute cancellations to free up a room or two.
After going door to door in the neighborhoods surrounding the park, Ms. Hicks signed up nearly 50 homes to rent, asking anywhere from $10,000 to $55,000 for the week. But by midweek, every one of them was still available, though Ms. Hicks is still hoping for some last-minute business.
"It was worth a chance," said Edgar Glascott, who offered his four-bedroom colonial-style house off Bethpage Road for $40,000. "We have a condo in Maine, so we could disappear for 10 days."
Whatever market existed was mostly satisfied by the United States Golf Association, organizer of the tournament, which arranged its own housing by compiling a list of area homeowners who had applied to the championship office six months ago.
Debbie Cichon, whose backyard faces the park, said she turned down $25,000 from a corporate representative. "It's a tough week," she said. "I have three boys in high school, and they have Regents and finals. If I'm going to pick up and stay with family in Queens, there would be a lot of commuting back and forth. For us to do that, it's got to be really, really worthwhile."
Some of her neighbors on Parkview Court have relinquished only parts of their homes, so they can stay put and still cash in. One rented his driveway as a motor home berth, and another gave up his front lawn for two of the hospitality tents that have grown like mushrooms around the course.
"There is not a huge market for houses for spectators," said Jonathan Barker, tournament manager. He said "only about five players" had rented homes here for this year's tournament. As for the rest, he said, "ticket holders are local and companies have rented hotel rooms." 
But no one should imagine that interest in this Open is lukewarm. The 42,500 tickets for each day's play are the most ever sold for an Open, and they sold out faster than any other Open. The 76 corporate hospitality tents are the most ever. This event has one of the largest corps of volunteers in Open history, and they enlisted in record time. The organizers estimate that a record 60,000 people (ticket holders plus staff and paid and volunteer workers) will be coming to the tournament each day.
It all adds up to big opportunities for business, and big logistical headaches.
"There's been more work in this Open than any other," said the U.S.G.A.'s Steve Worthy, who has planned parking and traffic for the last 11 Opens. "It's difficult anyway around here on a daily basis. We just want to make sure that we can get our people back and forth."
Road closings include the section of Round Swamp Road, from Quaker Meeting House Road to Winding Road, that bisects the Black Course, Quaker Meeting House Road in front of the course from Round Swamp Road to Merritts Road, and the entire Bethpage Parkway, which will reopen from 9 p.m. to 5 a.m. this week.
"If people follow directions, I think the traffic plan will work," said Lt. Robert Nuzzo of the State Police.
The biggest part of the plan is limiting the number of vehicles in and around the golf course area. Which is why many of the 42,500 ticket holders will be heading to the beach. About 7,500 to 10,000 cars are expected at the parking lots at Jones Beach each day of the tournament, with shuttle buses taking them the rest of the way. About 5,000 cars, driven by some volunteers and some ticket holders with ZIP codes closest to SUNY-Farmingdale, will be using the park-and-ride service being offered from the university's lots off Route 110.
Organizers are urging ticket-holders to take the Long Island Rail Road to the Farmingdale station, where shuttle buses will also be waiting.
The police are hoping traffic tie-ups will be minimal. "We think there will be a trickle effect," Lieutenant Nuzzo said. "They don't come all at once. But I've heard about 40 percent of the crowd leaves when Tiger Woods finishes."
Mr. Glascott, whose home is a five-minute walk from the Bethpage clubhouse, was skeptical. "I think it's going to be a big inconvenience," he said. Residents of the area have been issued permits that will allow them access to and from their homes, but Mr. Glascott worried that no one would be able to visit him all week.
While traffic is a big concern, security is certainly another. The state, Nassau County and state park police, as well as the F.B.I., will have officers in and around the park during the week, and spectators are forbidden to bring backpacks, large bags, coolers and cellphones. Fanny packs and purses will be subject to search. And like at all P.G.A. Tour events, fans can bring cameras and camcorders only during the practice rounds on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday.
Much of the crowd management will be handled by a corps of 4,850 volunteers. The U.S.G.A. signed up its first volunteer for this week's event in October 2000. "Normally, it would take us about 14 months to sign up enough volunteers," Mr. Barker said. "Here it only took 7 months. It was the fastest we ever did it."
Volunteers are provided breakfast and lunch in their own hospitality tent. Of course admission to the tournament itself is the biggest perk. Volunteers can also cherish their official uniforms, although they had to shell out $140 apiece for them.
"They treat you very, very well, and we get to go in free every day," said Kathy Chagnon of Southold, who also was a volunteer at the 1995 Open at Shinnecock Hills in Southampton.
An additional 2,000 people were hired for trash pickup, to help build tents and bleachers, to help direct traffic and to wait tables or tend bar. And even though many of the companies providing services at the event are from out of town, plenty of business is done right here.
"We buy everything locally," said Susan Lacz Niemann, chief executive of Ridgewells, the Bethesda, Md., company that will cater the Open. Ms. Niemann said her company had hired around 800 people for the event, most of them from the Island.
Fred Heffel, a New York City fireman from Farmingdale, was hired along with several of his firefighter buddies to set up the hospitality tents with refrigerators, ice machines and other food service equipment. Mr. Heffel, who described himself as "a big golf addict," was a spectator at Shinnecock in 1995, but for this Open he has volunteered as a marshal.
Michael Rogers of Manhasset was hired to distribute beverages from tent to tent via golf cart. A recent graduate of Hofstra University, where he studied sports management, Mr. Rogers now works for the National Hockey League. He worked at Shinnecock in 1995. "I enjoyed the experience so I went for it again," said Mr. Rogers.
About 350 people, mostly college students and retirees, have been hired for parking lot duty by Country Club Services of Springfield, N.J. Charles Yeates, from Freeport, is a parking manager in charge of hiring and organizing the yellow-safety-vested attendants who will be directing traffic for $8 an hour.
Marie Kupfer, general manager of the Huntington Hilton, said she expected food and beverage sales to be at least 20 percent higher than a normal June week, when the hotel is usually only 80 percent full.
"The bigger picture is Long Island getting international exposure," Ms. Kupfer said. "Maybe it will help convince some people to move their businesses here."
Six years ago, when the U.S.G.A. first announced that the Black would be the site of the Open, experts estimated the tournament would pump at least $25 million into the local economy. Now Mr. Hollander said the figure should be closer to $85 million, with more in years to come.
"After the U.S. Open leaves, there will be people who will want to play a U.S. Open course," Mr. Hollander said. "This will get tourists coming out here from Manhattan. The repetitive business will be very substantial."

HEADLINE: A Personal-Injury Law Firm Is Shrunken by Sept. 11 Fallout 

BYLINE:  By MAGGIE JACKSON 

 BODY:
PROMPTED by personal and professional soul-searching after the Sept. 11 attacks, the senior partners of one of New York's pre-eminent personal-injury law firms have given away many cases, let much of their staff go and quietly transformed their big practice into a small boutique operation.
 Schneider, Kleinick, Weitz, Damashek & Shoot, a powerhouse of colorful personalities known for their multimillion-dollar verdicts, has shrunk from about 34 lawyers before the terrorist attack to 6 today, a downsizing that left some former employees bitter. Many of the firm's cases were given to two practices spun off by the senior partners' sons and a protege. One of those who left was Brian J. Shoot, a nonequity partner whose name was on the letterhead. 
 The restructuring of the firm, located in the Woolworth Building on lower Broadway just blocks from where the Twin Towers stood, shows how the attacks are still being felt in the local economy. They forced the firm to deal head-on with its future, including long-unresolved succession problems and differences among the senior partners. 
"This was the right time to say, 'Hey, let's stop the carousel and restart it the way we want it to be'," said Harvey Weitz, one of the four equity partners in the firm. "It made everybody reassess where they are and where they're going."
Mr. Weitz stresses that he and his partners, all in their 60's or older, are not closing shop, but rather are shifting gears. Lost business after the attacks made meeting the cost of the firm's overhead and 60-member staff "a headache," he said. "We had an empire," he said. "I'm frankly happy that we no longer have an empire."
Even though his wife has urged him to relax, "I don't intend to retire, nor does my partner Schneider," he said, referring to Ivan S. Schneider. Arnold L. Kleinick, however, wants to slow down, and Philip M. Damashek's plans are unknown, said Mr. Weitz, the only one of the four who agreed to be interviewed for this article.
In an area of the law known for showmanship and big verdicts, all four partners have long been major players. In 1993, in the largest verdict in New York State history, Mr. Weitz led a team of lawyers that won $197 million for five people injured when their rental car hit a parked truck, a case that was ultimately settled.
Mr. Schneider, Mr. Weitz and Mr. Kleinick became partners in the mid-1960's, then joined forces with Mr. Damashek in 1994. At that time, the newly merged firm had about 40 lawyers on staff. In 1999, in a move that made headlines, it allied itself with Johnnie Cochran, the West Coast lawyer best known for defending O. J. Simpson. That alliance remains intact, Mr. Weitz said.
Some of the firm's former lawyers regret the course that the senior partners have taken. "It's just a shame that a firm that appeared to have so much potential after the merger in 1994 should wind up in this position at this point of time, as opposed to growing and maintaining its position as the premier personal-injury firm in the city or state of New York," said Robert B. Jackson, a nonequity partner who ran the firm's medical malpractice department before joining Trolman, Glaser & Lichtman in April. "You'd think they'd have been training other lawyers to step into their shoes."
But Mr. Weitz said that after taking a hard look at the loss of incoming work after Sept. 11, the partners decided they could no longer rationalize keeping a big firm afloat. "We promised all these people we'd keep them on the payroll," he said. "We also said to ourselves, 'Let's take a look at this business.' We were saying that it's not worth the effort now that we're faced with the reality of cutting costs and cutting costs."
Sept. 11 brought many matters to a decisive point at the firm. For at least two weeks, employees could not return to their offices on lower Broadway, and some refused to return ever. Mr. Weitz said some phone lines were not restored until late May. 
A severe disruption in business is particularly damaging to a personal-injury firm, which depends on referrals from other lawyers and advertising, rather than on the long-term clients that fuel a white-shoe downtown firm. Also, personal-injury firms depend on unpredictable revenue from contingency fees instead of a steady stream of fees.
"It's a far more entrepreneurial business," said David Barnard, an adjunct professor at Columbia Law School who teaches a course on the legal profession. "They're being paid by the success of their litigation. They're only as good as the last case they've been able to obtain."
After the attack, the senior partners assembled their staff in Mr. Schneider's Fifth Avenue apartment and promised to keep them on the payroll, Mr. Weitz and former employees said. But as the disruptions continued, the layoffs and departures began. One who left was Mr. Shoot, who had been with the firm and its predecessor 23 years.
A number of lawyers laid off felt they were not given enough explanation and at least one felt betrayed -- especially because in 2001 the firm was awarded $98.4 million in fees from New York State over the next 20 to 25 years for suing the tobacco industry. "They sucked it all dry and they tossed us all out," said one former high-ranking lawyer at the firm, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "They used the excuse that they were having problems and financial difficulties internally when it turned out that they really just wanted to get out" of the business.
Mr. Weitz dismissed that criticism. "I wanted to get out?" he asked. "That's why I'm trying a case a month -- something most 40-year-olds don't do." He also rejected any idea that the settlement should have been used to keep the firm going at its former size. "To say, 'I'm going to reach into my pocket and pour money into this,' that doesn't make sense," he said. "Everybody who's ever worked for us who's been terminated, in the end will have benefited from whatever time they spent with us."
Still, he says he knows that the changes in the firm have left some unhappiness. "I know some people were clearly disappointed," he said. "We couldn't work out a succession." He said that it was not until March, when Mr. Kleinick brokered an agreement among the four, that the partners could agree on final arrangements for the future.
The senior partners will continue to try cases and the firm will continue to operate as Schneider, Kleinick, Weitz & Damashek until 2005, when Mr. Damashek will leave. But most of the caseload has been transferred to two new firms housed in the same offices: Weitz, Kleinick & Weitz, made up of three sons of the founders; and a firm led by Gregory J. Cannata, a close associate of Mr. Schneider for more than a decade.
The three sons -- Andrew L. Weitz, Paul B. Weitz and Keith A. Kleinick -- had previously worked or were working at the firm. But differences between their fathers had prevented effective planning for the future, a not-uncommon problem in a field full of somewhat flamboyant risk takers. After Sept. 11, the partners took a hard look at the business -- and their future.
"As long as the business was going along, nobody bothered looking," Mr. Weitz said. "We never thought twice about it. Then you wake up and say, 'Where are we going, and what's this all about?' "

HEADLINE: Center-Stage Living, at Balcony Rents 

BYLINE:  By NAHMA SANDROW 

 BODY:
IT took 10 years for Jim Houghton, the founding artistic director of the Signature Theater, and his wife, the actress Joyce O'Connor, to get their sunny two-bedroom apartment in the midtown luxury high-rise Manhattan Plaza -- long enough to have two children in the interim. But it was worth the wait. 
 Mary Jane Gibbons, principal dresser for the American Ballet Theater, calls Manhattan Plaza "a gentle society in the middle of the urban jungle." 
 The playwright Oscar A. Colon has a name for the entire city block that contains the project: 42nd to 43rd Street and Ninth Avenue to 10th. Besides the apartments, the building includes restaurants and shops, rooftop gardens and a health club; all of it, he said, adds up to "Happy Block." 
Sylvia Herscher, a theatrical manager, agent and music publisher who has lived here since it opened 25 years ago, calls it "the most talented village in New York City." The reason: roughly three-quarters of Manhattan Plaza's tenants are involved in the performing arts. 
Thus, notices in the lobby include announcements of the availability of voice lessons and collectible Playbills. Tickets for shows and concerts are available to tenants daily for a dollar, and there is a sign-up list for volunteers to give them out. A flier for a free "alternative health fair" is headed "Better Wellness and You" -- with the acronym, in giant capital letters, "BWAY."
As a cheerful young man carrying three full grocery bags plus a wiggly toddler passes through the lobby, a neighbor calls, "Hey, I saw you on 'Law and Order' last night!" Too encumbered to lift a hand or even turn his head, the young man turns once completely around and beams. "Yeah. Thanks." Then somebody pushes the elevator button for him, and he and his toddler ride up and home. He is not thinking -- and may not even be aware -- of the delicate combination of finance, politics and inspiration that produced this singular fusion of small town and Broadway.
Manhattan Plaza started going up in 1973: a pair of towers, 46 stories each, housing 1,689 apartments, from studios to two bedrooms. It was hoped that a Mitchell-Lama outpost in Hell's Kitchen, which was then dirty and dangerous, would stimulate economic revival, especially in the Times Square area. 
But costs and therefore prospective rents went up, and it was felt that nobody who could afford the spectacular views and plush amenities would be willing to live in a slum. The city government, riding out a fiscal crisis, had nothing to contribute. Construction stopped, leaving a completed tower and half of another beached like a shipwreck.
What rescued the project was what Irving Fischer calls a fluke convergence of circumstances. He and Richard Ravitch, general partners of Manhattan Plaza Associates, the limited partnership that owns the building, put together new financing, with a large public garage as the building's most important sustaining factor. Just then funds became available through the Department of Housing and Urban Development's Section 8 housing subsidy program in a one-time allocation to the city, and Manhattan Plaza was the only building in Manhattan to meet HUD's criteria. 
As a result, while 10 percent of the tenants would pay rents pegged to the market the remaining 90 percent would have their rent heavily subsidized by the federal government under the Section 8 program. And, at the suggestion of a builder, Daniel S. Rose, and the producer Alexander H. Cohen, Manhattan Plaza was reconceived as "the bedroom of Broadway."
A sampling of the negotiating parties gives some notion of how many constituencies the enterprise was supposed to make happy: the city's Housing and Development Administration; the Board of Estimate; the Settlement Housing Fund; Community Board 4;, the Clinton Community; the Broadway Association, an organization that promotes the economic health of the Times Square theater district; and eight performing arts unions. 
The formula they worked out after complex negotiations has held ever since. Of the 90 percent of the tenants subsidized by HUD, 70 percent must earn at least half their income as stage, film or television actors, singers or dancers; make-up artists, costumers or designers; voice coaches or composers of soap opera background music; stagehands or publicists or ushers. These stalwarts, who are essential to the arts but do not earn star salaries, can live somewhere decent and walk to work. (They may stay in the apartment even if they later change their professions.) 
The remaining 30 percent of the Section 8 tenants are drawn from Hell's Kitchen residents who are living in substandard housing or who are are elderly and disabled.
In 1977, when the building opened, theatrical unions and neighborhood churches posted fliers urging eligible tenants to apply for apartments. By 1978, Irving Fischer says with relish, Manhattan Plaza was "harder to get into than Harvard."
The final defining moment in shaping life in Manhattan Plaza came with the choice of Rodney Kirk, an Episcopal priest, as its first director. "Rodney," recalled Richard Hunnings, the late Father Kirk's companion and his successor as director of operations, "knew how to run a parish." 
SOON, there were tenant committees and get-togethers in the comfortable Ellington Room. December brought Christmas caroling, Three Kings celebrations and a menorah with candles. Summer brought free swimming for resident children in the health club pool. (The health club remains a private facility, but residents can take memberships at a discount.)
Like a bustling little village with about 3,500 residents, Manhattan Plaza has its own post office and polling place, its own preschool, Halloween pumpkins and Passover seders. 
For 25 years now, children have made friends in the playground between the towers and graduated from the slide to their big brothers' basketball team. Celine Havard from the West Tower and John Whitney from the East Tower, both married to other people at the time, met as parents on that playground; now they have a son together, and he's almost old enough to climb the slide himself.
Father Kirk's vision for Manhattan Plaza, Mr. Fischer said, "created the spirit and gave it a soul." In the early days, an elderly resident was discovered to have died and lain alone in his apartment for three days. Father Kirk was deeply shaken. Under his direction, the Staywell Center opened to guide elderly tenants to available services, help them in dealing with bureaucracy and coordinate visits and care, with the explicit aim of keeping tenants at home till the end of their lives. When one elderly resident, an opera singer, returned from the hospital in a wheelchair, the maintenance employees had already been alerted and had widened her doorway.
When a resident dies, the management places a vase of white lilies on the polished shelf just inside the lobby. A black-bordered card tells in careful script the name, dates of birth and death and apartment number. In this village, nobody lives or dies unnoticed.
And when Father Kirk died last year, the only memorial he wished was a vase of white lilies in the lobby.
More than one-third of the residents are 62 or older, Mr. Fischer said, and very few are inclined to move away.
Millie Pollio, who has lived her entire 83 years within a 10-block area, raised her children by herself in cold-water walk-ups in Hell's Kitchen. When she moved into Manhattan Plaza, her sister and her cousin got apartments too; she still cooks Sunday dinner for the family. She goes regularly to the senior citizens' coffee breaks in the Ellington Room and joins their bus trips to Atlantic City. For her, living in Manhattan Plaza is "vacation every day."
In 1985, when Manhattan Plaza was "the epicenter of the AIDS epidemic," Mr. Hunnings said, Father Kirk set up the AIDS Project to help stricken tenants feel part of the community. At lunches every Thursday, for example, resident clients share information about services and compare notes on drugs. Volunteers take AIDS patients to the theater. 
Dan Cronin expected to survive six months at most when the Actors Fund approved moving him into an apartment in Manhattan Plaza that had been designated for AIDS patients. That was seven years ago. Last St. Patrick's Day he was leading the Manhattan Plaza seniors in a program of Irish songs. For him, his new home turned out to be "absolutely a lifesaver." He added, "It's the little family things that when you're sick make a huge difference."
Manhattan Plaza's maintenance standards are high. "As far as we are concerned," Mr. Fischer said, "this is the Waldorf-Astoria."
Management maintains "constant vigilance." The corridors and back stairs gleam. Apartment walls are soundproofed -- important in a building with so many musicians. There are no forced break-ins. The head of security, Howard P. Slender, said, "We're better than the police."
At the same time, the property's management explicitly demands civic responsibility in residents. Mr. Hunnings, who has succeeded to many of Father Kirk's functions, recently explained it this way to a group of teenagers: "If we have to clean graffiti, we won't have time or money to improve the playground."
Actors make good neighbors, according to Jan Buttram, artistic director of the Abingdon Theater. "We sense people's feelings," she said. "It's our business. Besides, we do long tours in close quarters. We know how to give people space." 
Since performers are often free in the daytime -- in fact, they are often unemployed -- they are available to water a neighbor's plants when he is on tour. Or they understand that a last-minute audition callback means the need for an emergency baby sitter, fast. And if the actor does not get the job, they will sympathize.
It is natural that a new generation of Manhattan Plaza youngsters has stayed in the community by entering show business, among them Laron Holt, currently touring in "Stomp," and the pop singer Alicia Keys.
Although building etiquette forbids presuming on your status as a neighbor to try to get work, proximity often helps. Ms. Buttram was swimming in the health club pool when the director Peter Masterson suggested she check out auditions for the national tour of "The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas" -- and she got the role of Doatsey Mae.
The songwriter Susan Dias-Karnovsky loved the piano music she used to hear from behind a closed door opposite the laundry room. Needing an accompanist at the last minute, she knocked on the door, introduced herself and found not only an accompanist but also, eventually, a collaborator. Together, she and Armen Donelian created the improvisational singing segments that were a highlight of National Public Radio's popular "Kids America" in the 80's.
Miriam Cruz and Oscar A. Colon had been living in Queens when their apartment came through. "Out in the hinterlands," they recall, "you have to generate your own energy, but in Manhattan Plaza, there's that stimulating feeling of the arts." 
EVERY day there are likely to be people in the Ellington Room with its grand piano, in the basement practice room or in someone's living room, reading a new play or testing a new song or stand-up routine. "Here," the actor Michael Shelle explained, "we can take risks." 
As a result, a number of theater companies have begun in Manhattan Plaza, including Playwrights Horizons and Manhattan Punchline, which were pioneers on the emerging Theater Row across 42nd Street. (In fact, several of Theater Row's spaces got their first coats of paint from building residents who just stopped by to lend a hand.)
Kenny Kramer calls all this "cross-pollination." Yes, that's the Kramer from "Seinfeld." He and Larry David, both comedians, met when they participated in a cabaret evening planned as a new tenants' get-together. Next day at noon, Mr. David rang Mr. Kramer's doorbell for the first of many lunches. (In the process they tracked the commercial development of the immediate neighborhood from slum to chic, from a couple of take-out possibilities to a drawerful of menus.)
When Mr. David moved to the West Coast and co-created "Seinfeld," he included a character based on Mr. Kramer and named him -- Kramer.
Some apartments are museums of theatrical memorabilia. The actor Bruce Adler has a poster from his parents' appearance on the Yiddish stage in Paris. Harry Edwards has an autographed photo of an ineffably debonair Noel Coward whom he "dressed" in London half a century ago.
Ms. Cruz has a shelf of acting awards, including the ACE (Asociacion de Cronistas de Espectaculos, the Association of Hispanic Theater Critics) Lifetime Achievement Award for Contributions to Hispanic Theater. Linda and David Laundra, co-creators of the Writers Theater, which moved to Chicago in 1992 after almost 20 years in New York, have a pasteboard fireplace that they bought at a building rummage sale from a neighbor who built it as a stage set. 
HUD's Section 8 program specifies that tenants pay no more than 30 percent of their annual adjusted gross income up to the market price; the rest of their rent is subsidized.
Since people in the business generally have, as Mr. Fischer put it, "very little control over their income," the Manhattan Plaza system is extraordinarily flexible. If income suddenly falls or suddenly rises, the year's rent is adjusted. Tenants are not allowed to sublet while on tour, but they are allowed to deduct professional expenses, like answering service, glossy photos, musical arrangements, voice coaching and backstage gratuities.
The paperwork is intense. Every resident must verify income sources and assets annually through bank statements and notarized affidavits. In addition to this recertification process, the 90 percent who are eligible for Section 8 subsidies must annually file copies of federal and state income tax returns and forms, as well as of all contracts, receipts and other relevant documents. These documents fill hefty packages, and management scrutinizes each package every year because performers' working lives are likely to change every year. 
But the result for the Laundras is "freedom to do what we want to do with our lives because we know we have a place to live," Linda Laundra said. "Without it, we wouldn't be in theater." Certainly, with all the film and television jobs on the West Coast, she added, "We wouldn't be in New York City." 
Ms. Buttram thinks of it as "this wonderful grant to pursue a career in the arts -- the closest we have to a national theater."
Unfortunately, if you are a hopeful young artist thinking about living in Manhattan Plaza -- forget about it. As of June 1, the waiting list contained 1,195 names for the Section 8 apartments and 176 for the others. And the preliminary waiting list -- to get into the lottery for a place on the real waiting list -- is closed.

PERSON: DAVID N. SIEGEL 

HEADLINE: Private Sector; 
In a Hurry to Sell Bitter Medicine

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WONG 

 BODY:
DAVID N. SIEGEL'S days have become a whirlwind of speeches and hand-shaking. He served Gatorade to US Airways ramp workers on May 24 in Philadelphia. Last week, he delivered his pitch to employees in Boston, and Orlando and Tampa, Fla., his words honed and his throat made rough from hours of giving the same talk.
 Mr. Siegel, the chief executive of US Airways, has met with workers at nine airports and other sites in the last two and a half weeks. He knows that he does not have much time, and he wants his employees to know that, too. This is what he tells them: His plan for revamping the airline, which he drew up to apply for $1 billion in federal loan guarantees, requires him to cut more than $1.2 billion in annual costs -- $950 million of it from labor. The application is likely to fail if the unions do not agree to concessions by Saturday, possibly forcing US Airways into bankruptcy. 
 The talk is simple and direct and would never be mistaken for the battlefield oration of Henry V, though Mr. Siegel has as much troop-rallying to do as any besieged monarch.
"We all have a vested interest in the future of the company," Mr. Siegel said in an interview. "The employees want to keep it going as much as they can. What's not in their interest is to see us fail."
Mr. Siegel, 40, took charge on March 6 with one goal in mind: to get the sickest of the major airlines out of intensive care and at least into rehab, if not back on its feet. He took the chief executive's job at Avis Rent a Car System only a half-year earlier. But the offer from US Airways, the country's sixth-largest airline, gave him a chance to revisit some of the ground he had covered at Northwest and Continental, only this time with the opportunity to play savior. He is moving from Houston to a suburb of Washington with his wife, Melissa, and daughter, Emily, 11.
"He's acting more like a surgeon coming to the rescue of a company that's dying on the table," said Gordon M. Bethune, the chief executive of Continental.
No airline suffered after Sept. 11 as much as US Airways, which is based in Arlington, Va., and has most of its routes on the East Coast. The government shut down Ronald Reagan National Airport near Washington, one of the airline's busiest centers, for several weeks. Many business travelers, already angry about the high price of walk-up fares, switched to trains, cars or videoconferences.
The airline reported a loss of $269 million for the last quarter, its seventh consecutive loss, and $2 billion in red ink last year. Just as worrisome, its $561 million in cash at quarter's end was draining away at $3.5 million a day. 
Facing a government deadline of June 28 for the loan application, Mr. Siegel started presenting the proposed cuts to unions last month. He opened the airline's books for union leaders to scrutinize and was confident that the raw numbers would convince them that US Airways was in an "unsustainable situation."
The unions have yet to form strong opinions about Mr. Siegel's tenure. Several labor officials say he has been more open about the bleak financial situation than Stephen M. Wolf, a former chief executive who is now chairman. But the unions say that Mr. Siegel was too slow in presenting his plan and that he now expects them to rubber-stamp it in some form.
"We can't let US Airways as a company off the hook for forcing the workers into this corner," said Jeff Zack, a spokesman for the Association of Flight Attendants, which represents 7,500 active workers. "The demands are absolutely unreasonable because of the time line and the severity of the cuts within such a short period. That said, the carrier does need help from its workers in order to survive."
Roy Freundlich, a spokesman for the Air Line Pilots Association, which represents 4,800 active workers, said his union had met with executives several times and would try to work out reasonable concessions. But he said Mr. Siegel's talk of declaring bankruptcy if the loan application fails reminds employees of what he called the rhetoric of "deadlines and threats" used by Mr. Wolf.
The four largest unions say the concessions expected by Mr. Siegel are too much, although managers usually start with high figures and work down. But several executives who have worked with Mr. Siegel say they have faith in his ability to reorganize the airline. The travel industry seems to pervade his life, as evidenced by his interest in collecting antique maps.
Mr. Siegel graduated from Brown University magna cum laude, with a joint degree in applied mathematics and economics, and earned an M.B.A. at Harvard. He was a consultant for Bain & Company before landing at Northwest, where he was director of corporate planning.
But Mr. Siegel's trial by fire came at Continental, which underwent a broad restructuring after Mr. Bethune took over in 1994. Mr. Siegel helped close the airline's no-frills arm, Continental Lite, which had lost $140 million since it began. He later was president of Continental Express, the regional jet operator.
"Dave is an architect of our revitalized airline," Mr. Bethune said. "You couldn't ask for a better executive in charge of scheduling. He's no slouch on the other side either, when we had to make the company profitable and reliable. He put the investment in the maintenance programs that make the company work reliably."
When Mr. Siegel joined Avis, he brought along people he knew at Continental and Northwest. He set out to broaden Avis's customer base beyond business travelers and to raise revenue with an airline technique called yield management. "He's a rare combination of an excellent strategic thinker with very good operating skills," said John Chidsey, chairman of the vehicle services division of Cendant, Avis's parent. "He certainly helped us focus much more on the leisure business."
As he did at Avis, Mr. Siegel has hired colleagues from previous jobs. He says he needs people who can not only deal with labor, but can also carry out his other restructuring plans, which include finding a code-share partner, increasing the use of regional jets and strengthening hubs. 
When asked why they would join him at a floundering company, he said: "I don't know. Clinical insanity?" Then he gave what he said he believed to be the real answer -- the chance to experience the pure rush of transforming a company in a matter of months, something many executives yearn for.

HEADLINE: ENVIRONMENT; 
State to Buy Ski Area's Land To Preserve a Mountaintop

BYLINE:  By STEVE STRUNSKY 

DATELINE: VERNON 

 BODY:
After years of contention over plans to develop the top of Hamburg Mountain, the site of the Mountain Creek ski area, the state and the area's owners have come up with a arrangement intended to preserve the spot.
 In the deal announced last week by Governor McGreevey and other other officials here in Highlands in the state's northwest corner, the state agreed to pay $7.1 million for 1,700 acres atop the mountain, and the ski area's owners said they would drop plans to build a golf course. 
 "What we have put forward strikes the right balance between economic development in the valley and permanent preservation of the mountain," Bradley Campbell, the state's environmental commissioner, said in a telephone interview. 
Technically, Intrawest Corporation of Vancouver, British Columbia, will sell the state 467 acres for $7.1 million, and donate another 1,262 acres, on which it reserves the right to cut new trails within the existing ski trail system at Mountain Creek, New Jersey's largest ski area.
Intrawest, which owns with Stratton Mountain in Vermont and Whistler in British Columbia, had planned to put a golf course and more than 800 residences atop the mountain. Lorne Bassel, Intrawest's executive vice president, said the company still planned to spend more than $500 million on condominiums and shops, and perhaps a golf course, at the base of the mountain, in a plan that he insisted dovetailed with preserving the mountaintop. 
"Basically, its the right thing to do, environmentally and for business," Mr. Bassel said.
Last fall, the Sierra Club of New Jersey filed a lawsuit to block the company's mountaintop development plans, which had already been approved by the Vernon Township Planning Board. A state Superior Court judge issued a ruling in February sharply limiting development of residences on the mountaintop, but held off on the golf course after learning that the state was negotiating to buy the property. 
Meredith Robson, Vernon's township manager, said that though the mountaintop would not be developed and thus bring in taxes, local officials were satisfied with the agreement.
"We're always disappointed when we lose revenues," she said. But, she added, "I think we're satisfied with the results."
However costly the purchase, which used Green Acres money already set aside in a bond referendum, Mr. Campbell said it was a worthwhile remedy to the state's sale of 1,400 acres of the same property in 1988 for just $340,000 to a local developer who sold it to Intrawest for an undisclosed sum 10 years later. 
Another official at last week's announcement was the area's State Senator, Robert Littell, a Republican who is chairman the Senate Budget Committee. Mr. Littell's wife, Virginia Newman Littell, a former Republican state chairwoman, is a consultant whose clients include Intrawest. Mr. and Ms. Littell both denied that her business relationship with the company influenced the sale price or any other aspect of the deal. 
"I have never traded on my husband's name," Ms. Littell said. "There absolutely is no conflict." 
Jeff Tittel, the Sierra Club's executive director, said that the deal was an especially good one for Intrawest and Mountain Creek and that he was concerned about the environmental effects of the resort village Intrawest still plans at the mountain base.

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
These Vacations Are on the House

BYLINE:  By JANE L. LEVERE 

 BODY:
ALLEN HEMPHILL, a retired Navy officer and real estate broker from the San Diego area, recently returned from what he calls a fantasy vacation with his wife, Jean: a five-week stay in a 1,800-square-foot house on 10 acres overlooking the ocean on the Hawaiian island of Kauai.
 But the best part of the trip, he said, was that their lodgings were free. 
 The Hemphills, both in their late 60's, stayed at that tropical house this spring as part of a home-swapping arrangement made with the owners through the International Home Exchange Network of Daytona Beach, Fla. The network is among a growing number of businesses that provide home listings and help arrange exchanges. The owners of the Hawaiian home have also stayed at the Hemphills' home, near the sixth green of the Meadow Lake Golf Course in North Escondido, Calif. 
Home exchanges are certainly not new. The concept was first developed in Europe in the 1950's. But the arrangements have become more popular worldwide with the help of the Internet; about 50 home-exchange companies have started online in the last three years alone. Many agencies are reporting increased interest of late, especially in North America, because of the weak economy and reluctance to fly overseas.
Before most of the industry went online, people interested in home exchanges often had to wait for printed listings that came out two or three times a year. Now members of the online services can scan updated listings on an agency's Web site, then send e-mail messages to other members whose homes interest them. Deals can sometimes be completed in a matter of hours.
Of course, the main advantage to a home swap is the savings. Vacationers do not have to pay for a hotel, can cook as many meals at home as they want and, in some cases, can even borrow the homeowner's car. (Gasoline and long-distance calls may be extra.)
And you live not as a tourist, but as a native.
"You move into a nice little house in the middle of town; the neighbors invite you out for dinner," said Bill Barbour, a retired publishing executive from Fort Myers, Fla. who has written books about home exchanges. "You get a feel for the country." 
But there are obvious disadvantages. Many people may not feel comfortable having strangers staying in their homes, and there is a chance that personal property can be broken or stolen, although the agencies say that rarely happens.
A few steps can be taken to increase the comfort level. The first is to work with a reputable home-exchange agency. There are many agencies from which to choose, and most will charge an annual membership fee, usually less than $100.
The two oldest home-exchange companies -- HomeLink International (www.homelink.org) and Intervac International (intervac.com) -- list more houses than others, charge steeper fees and continue to publish directories, a service that many of their competitors have discontinued. HomeLink, which lists some 13,000 homes, mostly in Western Europe, charges an annual online membership fee of $60 and an additional $50 for its directories. Intervac, which lists 6,000 homes in 30 countries, offers a $50 Web-only membership and a $99 membership that also includes a printed directory.
Other home-exchange companies, all with Web sites, offer listings for anywhere from 500 to 5,000 homes and charge fees that range from $6 for a two-month listing to $50 for a one-year online membership. These include Digsville (digsville.com); the Global Home Exchange (4homex.com); HomeExchange.com (homeexchange.com); the International Home Exchange Network (home-exchange-network.com); the Landfair Home Exchange Club (landfair.com); Latitudes Home Exchange (home-swap.com); and Vacation Homes Unlimited (vacation-homes.com).
Exchange members prepare descriptions of their homes for the online listings, including details about the layout and furnishings, the neighborhoods and nearby attractions -- and their cars, if they intend to lend them. Photographs and videos are also useful.
Some members, of course, have far different considerations than others. If your home is filled with valuable antiques, for example, you may not want to arrange an exchange with a family with small children.
Once you find a suitable candidate, it is important to negotiate details and, if desired, to put them in writing, home-exchange experts say. Specifically, you must negotiate the dates; the exchange of a car; who pays for utilities, telephone and cleaning expenses; and who takes care of pets. The experts also suggest asking homeowners for references from previous home exchanges.
It's not always necessary to swap for a home of similar value. To many people, the location is most important.
"Although I've stayed in a $2 million home in London, my favorite home there was a small apartment in the middle of Kensington, because that's where my wife, Mary, and I wanted to be," said Mr. Barbour, who uses a home that he owns in Sanibel Island, Fla., for his exchanges.
INSURANCE is another issue. Although your homeowner policy usually remains effective when a guest stays in your home and the same should hold true for the house where you stay, car insurance can be trickier. Policies should be checked.
Lois Sealey, the owner of Home Base Holidays (homebase-hols .com), in London, says the most serious problems her clients have encountered concern "differences in housekeeping standards, which you can't legislate."
Pauline Frommer, a contributing editor to Arthur Frommer's Budget Travel magazine and a home exchange participant herself, said, "People who do this seem to be honorable, lovely people, and you both have each other's house as hostage." 

CORRECTION-DATE: June 16, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about businesses that help arrange home exchanges for vacations misstated the Web address for one of them, the International Home Exchange Network of Daytona Beach, Fla. It is www.ihen.com (www.home-exchange-network.com is the address for the Home Exchange Network, a similar, smaller business that is based in Glasgow).

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
First the College Diploma, Then the Internship

BYLINE:  By MELINDA LIGOS 

 BODY:
FACING one of the worst job markets in years, many recent college graduates are heading directly to graduate school or biding their time with volunteer work or temporary jobs outside their fields. An increasing number, though, are discovering another fallback: post-graduate internships.
 The arrangement seems to make sense for all parties involved, at least on paper. 
 The graduates get their feet in the doors of potential employers while building professional resumes. The employers, meanwhile, can supplement their work forces, many of which have been reduced, while building a pool of candidates for future hiring. 
But not everyone is happy with the trend. Some employment agencies complain that the postgraduate interns may be butting heads with temporary workers and professionals with one or two years of experience. 
"In taking these internships, they could be taking away work from these other two groups," said John A. Challenger, the chief executive of Challenger, Gray & Christmas, the outplacement firm. "Companies are definitely exploiting the situation; they're getting good-quality work for very low pay."
Some internships are unpaid, while many others provide only small salaries or stipends, without benefits. The highest salaries, experts say, are usually from larger companies, particularly in financial services.
John Gramer, branch director for the New York office of Spherion, a professional recruiting firm, says financial services companies have been stepping up their use of interns. Many of them, he said, have cut jobs because of weakness in the economy and on Wall Street. He estimates that large accounting firms like PricewaterhouseCoopers typically hire one out of every 10 interns they employ.
THE hope for permanent work -- not the money -- prompted Rona Cooper, 23, an honors student who received a bachelor's degree in communications from George Washington University in May 2001, to accept an internship recently at the Bohle Company, a public relations firm in the Century City section of Los Angeles. She is paid about $1,200 a month and receives no benefits.
But Ms. Cooper is grateful for the opportunity to work. She sent dozens of resumes and had many job interviews over the last year, but to no avail. The internship is her fifth; she had four as an undergraduate.
"Everybody is teasing me because I still don't have a real job," said Ms. Cooper, who lives in Beverly Hills, Calif., with her parents.
Forty-eight percent of college students graduating this spring said they did not expect any job offers by graduation day, according to a recent survey by MonsterTrak, an online job site. Eighty-five percent said that they would accept a part-time internship, paid or otherwise, just to be working this summer.
Employers are hiring 36 percent fewer new college graduates this year than they did in 2001, according to survey results released in April by the National Association of Colleges and Employers.
Hiring projections declined most among consulting firms, plummeting nearly 90 percent, followed by automotive and mechanical equipment manufacturers, down 63 percent, and computer and business equipment manufacturers, down 59 percent, the association found. 
Concerned about such prospects, Julie Claggett, 23, who graduated last month from the University of Central Oklahoma, extended her internship in the marketing department of Express Personnel Services in Oklahoma City. Ms. Claggett says she earns $300 a month for full-time work and has to wait tables at night to make ends meet. But she hopes to have a permanent job in September, when company officials say their hiring freeze is expected to end.
She is gaining job experience, she said, by working on projects normally handled by more senior employees. 
Ms. Claggett said she was recently asked to create a recognition program commemorating the anniversaries of the company's 400 franchisees.
"My boss told me to be as creative as I wanted," she said. "It's an opportunity to demonstrate my knowledge and interest in the company."
Of course, a postgraduate internship does not always translate into a full-time, permanent job. Interns must make themselves stand out if they hope to be hired, or at least receive good references. 
Judy Steele, who supervises Ms. Claggett at Express Services, says she hopes to hire the intern after the summer as a public relations specialist, in part because of Ms. Claggett's enthusiasm for the job and her problem-solving abilities. 
Ms. Steele oversees about 15 interns a year. She says she will consider hiring only those who treat their internships like real jobs and show initiative. That may include asking to attend strategic business meetings, asking questions of colleagues and observing problem-solving processes.
"There are some interns who sit at their computer waiting for something to do," Ms. Steele said. "They don't ask questions or talk to anyone outside of their department."
She said she has hired four interns in the last five years. Among them was Maurissa Buchwald, 23, of Frederick, Okla., who joined the staff about 18 months ago. Ms. Buchwald, who grew up on a farm, apparently impressed her superiors with take-charge abilities and her knowledge of horses.
As an intern, she was assigned to help Ms. Steele coordinate a media tour that involved Clydesdale horses visiting some of the company's franchises. Rather than just following orders, Ms. Steele said, the intern identified a major problem with the tour.
"The franchise owners were responsible for taking care of the horses when they arrived, and she realized that they were baffled at how to do so," Ms. Steele said.
Without being asked, she said, Ms. Buchwald created a checklist to help the owners make arrangements for the horses, which included everything from stables to finding the right kind of hay.
Ms. Buchwald is now a permanent public relations coordinator -- and part of her job is to lead the Clydesdale tours.
EVEN if they are not hired permanently, interns can meet networking sources who can eventually lead them to other jobs.
Debra Condren, a clinical psychologist and career strategist in San Francisco, advises recent graduates to make a list of all the people they have worked with as interns and to select a few to consult for help in finding a job, creating "an informal career advisory board."
"Then, hold a 'quarterly board meeting' in a nice restaurant, and pick their brains about what you should be doing to find a job, and who you should approach," she said. "Bring a tape recorder so that you can capture all of the good ideas that will be flying across the table."

HEADLINE: Investing; 
Bond Funds, Now Up to the Minute

BYLINE:  By ABBY SCHULTZ

 BODY:
EXCHANGE-TRADED funds, which track the equity markets like indexed mutual funds but trade throughout the day like stocks, have been among the most popular Wall Street innovations of recent years.
 Barclays Global Investors is now preparing to introduce in the United States the first exchange-traded funds that track bond indexes. Late last month, the Securities and Exchange Commission gave Barclays tentative approval to offer seven fixed-income funds in late July. ETF Advisors, a new investment firm in New York, is also seeking approval to start its own such funds. 
 The funds are intended to provide investors with many benefits of stock E.T.F.'s, which offer a relatively inexpensive, tax-efficient way to buy and sell investments with continuously updated prices.
Barclays has been offering exchange-traded bond funds in Canada since November 2000. There, small investors can effectively buy a portfolio of 5-year or 10-year government notes by buying only a few fund shares. Because they are in a huge investment pool, the investors receive the same discounted bond prices as big traders, said Steve Rive, general manager for iUnits, the E.T.F.'s offered by Barclays in Canada. "That's the real value proposition of these funds," Mr. Rive said. "People are able to get access to wholesale pricing," he said.
Still, exchange-traded bond funds may face a more difficult reception in the United States than E.T.F.'s that track stock indexes. Some of the selling points of such stock funds may not be as compelling for bonds.
"Two of the big supposed advantages of E.T.F.'s, that apply strongly with equity E.T.F.'s, don't shine as brightly in the fixed-income area," said John Loftus, a managing director at Pacific Investment Management, referring to intraday trading and tax advantages. The firm manages $254 billion in bond assets, but he said it has no immediate plans to start such funds.
Yet exchange-traded funds have advantages. Costs tend to be lower than those for actively managed mutual funds, because the E.T.F.'s track indexes and trade infrequently. Unlike conventional indexed funds, exchange-traded funds must be bought through a broker, so investors pay a commission each time they make a trade. 
In 2001, the average expense ratio for exchange-traded stock funds was 0.48 percent, according to Morningstar Inc., compared with 0.89 percent for traditional stock index funds. Bond index mutual funds had an average expense ratio of 0.35 percent.
Barclays has not disclosed the pricing on its new funds. But the firm's exchange-traded stock funds often have the lowest cost among E.T.F.'s, and the firm intends to price the bond funds "aggressively," said Lee T. Kranefuss, the chief executive of Barclays's individual investor business.
Day traders have embraced exchange-traded funds because they can be traded often. By contrast, a traditional mutual fund can be traded only at its price at the end of the day. Mr. Loftus contended that day traders are unlikely to flock to exchange-traded bond funds because the bond market generally does not fluctuate as widely as the stock market, and few traders would feel the need to capitalize on short-term moves.
That is generally true for most individual investors. "We don't give a hoot whether we get the 10 a.m. price or the close of market price," said Michael Fitzhugh, a financial adviser in San Francisco.
Still, Barclays says exchange-traded bond funds offer trading versatility. Someone who thinks stocks are undervalued, for example, could sell exchange-traded bond funds and buy exchange-traded stock funds at the same time, Mr. Kranefuss said.
Professional traders may find the continuous repricing of E.T.F.'s for bonds useful in large transactions, where tiny changes in price add up to big differences in profits. Institutions with large amounts at stake could use the funds to take advantage of sharp market moves -- if the Federal Reserve unexpectedly changed interest rates, for example. The new funds may also be useful to traders who want constant exposure to the bond market when moving cash from one investment to another, he said.
THE bond E.T.F.'s are also expected to give individual investors more access to price information on bonds. While investors can buy bonds directly from the Treasury, secondary market offerings and corporate bonds are sold through brokers, and prices of most of these securities are not centrally listed, as stocks are. "By packaging these bonds in the form of an E.T.F. you are pulling that bond trade out into the daylight," said Mr. Rive at Barclays.
Because many bonds are not widely traded, brokers typically add a fee to the price. "You can pay a 5 percent premium -- a year's worth of interest," said Mr. Kranefuss at Barclays, adding that his firm had the market power to minimize such fees.
Exchange-traded stock funds have generally not incurred the capital gains distributions borne by traditional mutual funds, but that is not likely to be a great advantage for bond investors. Except for municipal bonds, which are tax-sheltered, virtually all bonds and bond funds generate substantial taxes because most of their return comes from ordinary income, not capital gains.
The Vanguard Total Bond Market fund, which tries to match the performance of the Lehman Brothers aggregate bond index, has distributed 6 cents a share in capital gains since the start of 1994 while distributing $5.23 a share in ordinary income, said Eric Jacobson, an analyst at Morningstar. The actively managed Pimco Total Return Bond fund has a potential capital gains exposure of 1 percent, Morningstar says.
Before investing in a bond E.T.F., Mr. Fitzhugh, the San Francisco financial adviser, would consider whether the savings are enough to justify the brokerage fees. His firm, Kochis Fitz Tracy Fitzhugh & Gott, says investors in taxable accounts can save a tenth of a percentage point through lower expenses and higher tax efficiency in a stock exchange-traded fund if they have at least $10,000 in the account and plan to hold it at least two years. In this example, the investor would save about $100 a year, enough to justify brokerage fees.
He expects to make similar calculations before recommending that investors buy the bond E.T.F.'s instead of index funds like those offered by Vanguard. "There's not a lot of room to price them lower than the Vanguard funds," he said. The new funds will have advantages, he said, but they are not likely to be overwhelming for most of his clients. "It's better than a poke in the eye, but it's not a revolution," he said.

HEADLINE: OFF THE SHELF; 
An Ivory Tower Embrace of Views in the Streets

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL 

 BODY:
FOR several years now, a fractious debate about the role of the big financial institutions in the globalized economy has encircled the world's policy makers, moving from the initial grumblings of the often-unheeded developing world through the street protests of Seattle and elsewhere and on to a much broader agenda.
 With "Globalization and Its Discontents" (W. W. Norton, $24.95), Joseph E. Stiglitz, a Nobel laureate in economic science in 2001, has taken the discussion a step further. He shows just how much the protesters' misgivings about and outright hostility toward some of those institutions have moved from the fringes into influential, mainstream thinking. 
 Professor Stiglitz, a former top economic adviser in the Clinton administration and chief economist at the World Bank, is now an economics professor at Columbia. He has long been associated, of course, with the economics of growth and development in the third world. With this accessible, provocative and highly readable study, he brings an insider's insights into the crises of the 1990's and beyond, from East Asia to Russia and on to Argentina. 
His central thesis is simple -- that the "market fundamentalism" of the International Monetary Fund, with its insistence that markets themselves will achieve a balance between supply and demand, furthering growth and development, is fundamentally flawed. The I.M.F.'s prescriptions in times of economic crisis, he writes, have caused far more human suffering than they have resolved economic problems.
Globalization has been badly managed, he contends, colliding head-on with some of the nostrums of the I.M.F. and what is sometimes called the Washington Consensus. Those include the idea that poverty is eased by the trickle-down effect of prosperity for the elite and that governments should not get in the way of the markets.
He goes further, embracing ideas once thought the exclusive preserve of the street protesters: the I.M.F. and the United States Treasury Department, he contends, pursue the interests of the big investment banks rather than the poor most directly affected by their macroeconomic solutions to crises like those in East Asia and Russia. Indeed, those interests seem intertwined in the very personalities who exerted such enormous influence as globalization emerged as the dominant force of the 1990's.
After all, he says, did not Robert E. Rubin, the former United States Treasury secretary, hail from Goldman, Sachs and move on to Citigroup after his spell in Washington? Did not Stanley Fischer, the former No. 2 executive at the I.M.F., go directly from that job to a well-paid position at Citigroup?
"One could only ask: Was Fischer being richly rewarded for having faithfully executed what he was told to do?" Professor Stiglitz writes.
The World Trade Organization, too, Professor Stiglitz asserts, promotes the interests of the developed world. The developing world, he says, still labors under unfair rules that restrict access to richer nations that preach trade liberalization but keep their own markets closed.
That is a hypocrisy, he says, that extends to the readiness of the global institutions to bail out their "client" states, differentiating between the strategically significant and the rest. "The I.M.F. is a political institution," he writes, saying the fund was ready to ignore runaway corruption in Russia to rescue Boris N. Yeltsin while suspending aid to Kenya on grounds of corruption.
Of course, it would be disingenuous to ignore Professor Stiglitz's own background as chief economist at the World Bank for almost three years, from 1997 to early 2000. In this study, the bank is spared the searing indictment that Professor Stiglitz reserves for the I.M.F. Yet the two are sister organizations, set up together after World War II. And much as he inveighs against what he calls the I.M.F.'s hard-nosed approach to economic crisis, the World Bank itself withholds loans to developing countries that fail to secure the I.M.F.'s imprimatur on their economic performance.
To that extent, the World Bank itself creates part of the pressure, particularly on developing countries, to accept those same I.M.F. prescriptions that Professor Stiglitz finds so distasteful. Often enough, however, officials of the two institutions behave more as rivals than as colleagues.
Not surprisingly, part of the book's purpose seems to be an attempt to ensure that events during his World Bank tenure do not besmirch his own reputation. In the process, one suspects that some score-settling may well be in play.
Significantly, though, Professor Stiglitz dismisses any illusion that the protesters on the streets of Prague, Seattle or Genoa were some kind of lunatic fringe whose arguments will disappear easily. "For decades the cries of the poor in Africa and in developing countries in other parts of the world have been largely unheard in the West," he writes, and it was only the street protesters "who have put the need for reform on the agenda of the developed world."
Once the issue is on the agenda, of course, the discussion moves on to reform issues that have absorbed some strategic thinkers since the late 1990's. Part of his message reflects his argument that the global financial institutions have drifted away from the Keynesian principles on which they were founded. The I.M.F.'s "market fundamentalism" -- placing much faith in freewheeling markets -- has not worked, he contends, as much as the economic policies of nations like Malaysia, where government intervention provided protection from the worst of the East Asia crisis.
The countries that have benefited most from globalization, he writes, "have been those that took charge of their own destiny and recognized the role government can play in development rather than relying on the notion of a self-regulating market that would fix its own problems." Equally, though, he says that far greater openness and democratic responsiveness are long overdue, both in the governments of developing countries and in the secretive global institutions where decisions are routinely made in private.
AS much as anything else, Professor Stiglitz says, all countries should have a clear picture of what development is supposed to achieve. "It is not about bringing in Prada and Benetton, Ralph Lauren or Louis Vuitton for the urban rich, leaving the rural poor in their misery," he says. Development, he says, "is about transforming societies, improving the lives of the poor, enabling everyone to have a chance at success and access to health care and education."
Judged from that viewpoint, the record of globalization has been patchy to date. 
And, Professor Stiglitz says, "if globalization continues to be conducted in the way that it has been in the past, if we continue to fail to learn from our mistakes, globalization will not only not succeed in promoting development but will continue to create poverty and instability."
