HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH: Bernard R. Horn Jr.; 
Polaris Global Value Fund

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
IN some respects, investing overseas was more challenging two decades ago, says Bernard R. Horn Jr., who runs the Polaris Global Value fund.
 "It was difficult to make overseas telephone calls in 1980, and even more difficult to get annual reports, let alone that most of them were written in different languages," Mr. Horn said from his office in downtown Boston. 
 All those tasks have become much easier, he said. But in some of the most important areas of financial accounting, significant disparities remain, and they are big enough to make the difference between a profitable investment and a losing one. These include policies on pension liabilities, depreciation, amortization and other issues that may vary from country to country. 
Such accounting differences, combined with the possibility that earnings have been managed to please investors -- a practice hardly unknown in the United States -- make earnings a very unreliable indicator, Mr. Horn said. A better standard for comparison, he said, is cash flow from operations after interest and taxes. 
The fund returned 8.4 percent a year, on average, for the three years through Thursday, compared with declines of 1.7 percent for all world stock funds and 6.5 percent in the Morgan Stanley Capital International Europe Australasia Far East index, according to Morningstar Inc. The portfolio gained 11.8 percent in the last 12 months, compared with losses of 13.3 percent for its group and 12.7 percent for the index. The fund has $35 million in assets.
Mr. Horn, 47, is president of Polaris Capital Management, the fund's adviser, which also manages about $150 million for institutions and individuals. The Global Value fund, which started as a limited partnership in 1989, was converted to a mutual fund in May 1998.
He chooses the 55 to 75 stocks in the fund among companies of all sizes around the globe, including the United States, with no limit on the amount he can invest in any country. He looks for what he calls the "most undervalued streams of cash flow."
Two computer models whittle down the 20,000 or so companies in his universe to about 500. The first model uses multiples of price to cash flow and price to book, as well as other valuation measures and macroeconomic indicators like interest rates and inflation, to screen 44 countries and 23 industries worldwide.
A second model screens cash flow statements, balance sheets and other financial data, looking for securities that may be mispriced. He aims to buy companies at discounts of at least 25 percent to what he believes they are worth.
Cash flow is important -- particularly free cash flow, the amount remaining after capital expenses are paid. 
He also looks for growth in operating margins and revenue, and he prefers companies that have little debt.
Mr. Horn estimates that he spends about 90 percent of his time poring over financial statements of the companies on his short list, paying special attention to executive stock option plans, convertible bonds and other indicators that shareholder value may be diluted. 
Right now, he sees much value among the United States financial services companies, British home builders and natural resources companies in South Africa. 
Mr. Horn started buying shares of the Astoria Financial Corporation, based in Lake Success, N.Y., just eight days after the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, and has paid an average price of $28. They closed on Friday at $34.75, compared with his two-year price target of $50.
Astoria, which specializes in residential mortgages, has very low default rates, Mr. Horn said, and a loyal base of depositors in the New York metropolitan area. The company's high level of customer service, he said, makes Astoria more attractive to customers as bigger banks consolidate. 
HE recently added to his holdings of Barratt Developments, a home builder in Britain. He starting buying the stock in November 1998 and has paid an average price of 206 pence a share, or $3.33, for the entire position, he said. The shares now trade at 450 pence, or $6.58, compared with his target price of $7.33.
Barratt is benefiting from stable interest rates and a government program encouraging builders to create residential developments.
In South Africa, Mr. Horn likes Sasol Ltd., which converts coal and natural gas into liquid fuels and chemicals. Sasol has little exploration risk, he said; it uses natural gas that would otherwise be discarded by big oil companies, and it can easily mine additional coal. 
He started buying shares last November and has paid an average price of 83 rand, or $9.23; the shares now trade at 113.5 rand or $11.48, compared with his target price of $15.56. 
The American depository receipts of Sasol, which are traded on Nasdaq, closed on Friday at $11.69.

HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.; 
Many Signs of a Recovery, Except Among Investors

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
THE economic outlook is positive, even if it is not as robust as it was a few weeks ago. Some forecasters are talking about a 4.5 percent annual pace of growth in the second quarter and almost 5 percent for the full year.
 But investors are not convinced. 
 The three major stock indexes have fallen for three consecutive weeks and are now at their lows for the year. The Nasdaq composite is down 21.3 percent in 2002, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is off 10.5 percent and the Dow Jones industrials are down 4.3 percent. 
Analysts are still predicting that corporate earnings will turn around soon, ending a five-quarter decline. The current forecast for operating-earnings growth in the second quarter is 3 percent compared with the same period last year, according to Wall Street estimates compiled by Thomson Financial/First Call. 
But that is not enough to offset the damage to investor sentiment as Congress investigates when and what the government knew about terrorist threats ahead of Sept. 11. Investors have also been bothered by repeated warnings of terrorist attacks in the future.
The punters who wager on changes in the Federal Reserve's short-term interest rate target are still counting on a rate increase by September. That means there is confidence in the economic rebound already under way. Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, said last week that the economy is in an upswing.
But even positive statistics are not helping investor confidence. The number of new nonfarm payroll jobs rose by 41,000 in May, the government reported Friday, the biggest gain in 15 months, while the unemployment rate fell unexpectedly to 5.8 percent, from 6.0 percent in April. 
Executives are not helping with their trimming of corporate expectations. Intel has lowered its second-quarter sales forecast to as low as $6.2 billion from $7 billion.
Investor confidence in corporate executives and accounting is also at a low, a point made last week by Henry M. Paulson Jr., the chairman of Goldman, Sachs.
Gold, sometimes a haven for worried investors, is signaling some of these concerns. Its price, at $325.10 an ounce on Friday, is up more than 16 percent for the year.
William E. Rhodes, chief investment strategist at Rhodes Analytics in Boston, detects investor skepticism in the performance of various stock market sectors. He says he is not seeing the rotation from one sector to another that he would expect at this stage of the economic recovery. 
Investors, especially institutions, normally try to get ahead of the market by picking the next winners and getting rid of the next losers. These investors would expect materials and manufacturing stocks to do well as production revived, then a rally in financial stocks as interest rates rose, increasing profits, then gains in consumer cyclical stocks, like automobiles, as consumers spent more.
While the market never moves exactly in this pattern, Mr. Rhodes thinks that the current performance shows that the market "really does not know where it is going."
Financial stocks, for example, are not performing as well as he would have expected, in part because they have been held back by the big diversified banks that have bought investment banks. "The market usually does well when financial stocks do well," he said. "But I have cold feet about finance; I have sweaty palms."
Consumer staples, like food and retail drugs, usually do well when the economy is down, because investors bet that consumers will still be buying these products. But, Mr. Rhodes points out, this sector is also doing well now, sending off a contrarian signal.
He is also concerned about industrials, although many of these companies should benefit from the economic turnaround. And he thinks that health care stocks, which have been an important strong performer in the market, are now near or at their peaks.
"The market is less likely to rally as long as it is locked in this position," Mr. Rhodes said. "You should be in early recovery mode, but the stock market is in an 'I want to roll over and take a nap' mode."

GRAPHIC: Chart: "What Rebound?"All three major stock indexes hit new lows for the year last week. Graph tracks Dow Industrials, S.& P. 500, and Nasdaq Composite from January through June.(Source: Bloomberg Financial Markets)

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT; 
A Bull Is Taking One Step Back

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
WITH the recent sell-off, major stock market averages have fallen below the levels they held before the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.
 Steve Leuthold, president of Leuthold/Weeden Capital Management in Minneapolis, was a longtime bear. But back in February 2001, he became bullish. 
 Mr. Leuthold took some time last week to talk about his current views. Following are excerpts from the conversation.

Q. In the beginning of 2001 you increased your position in stocks, betting on an economic recovery. What is your view now?

A. We are more cautious than we were a month ago, and about 10 days ago we shifted from positive to neutral on the stock market, paring back our equity exposure to 50 percent from 60 percent.

Q. Why the new caution on stocks?

A. Part of the caution is economic. The dollar is weaker, interest rates are on the rise, and inflation seems to have bottomed out. Those are negatives.
Also, while midcap and small-cap stock valuations are pretty much at normal levels, the big cap-weighted indexes like the Standard & Poor's 500 and the Nasdaq composite are still high relative to their historical range. Also, we have been losing quite a bit of ground in the supply-and-demand area. There have been net redemptions from stock mutual funds over the last three weeks. And last week we had about $3 billion to $4 billion in secondary stock offerings, which is a negative when taken against the selling pressure. 

Q. How much would big-cap stocks have to fall to return to their historical norms?

A. To get to median valuation level, big-cap indexes would have to fall about another 20 percent.
If this turns into a secular bear market like 1972-1974, those indexes could go down another 35 percent to 40 percent from here. That is the potential, but I don't look for that to happen. That's why we're still 50 percent invested in stocks. We could go as low as 30 percent.

Q. What would increase your concerns about the market?

A. I am worried about more deterioration in technical indicators like the advance-decline line. If you get much more selling pressure, a lot of those technicals would turn negative. And if you were to see a flood of net redemptions out of mutual funds, that could be quite dangerous. The more you hear about terrorism and see the president on television, the more concerned the public becomes.

Q. Is the unstable international situation more important to the market at this point than recent financial scandals?

A. Questions about financial integrity have been around since the start of the year. But once you call attention to the problem you are on the way to solving it. These issues are about two-thirds of the way behind us.
The real problems are geopolitical, be it Iraq, the Middle East or India and Pakistan. To me, that is the thing that is really disturbing the public even more than the financial integrity issues. And it is the thing that really worries the old-time professionals, people who have been around for 30 years. In my opinion, we haven't seen this unstable an international environment since the Cuban missile crisis. 

Q. Given the problems, why do you still recommend a substantial investment in the market?

A. If you total up the negatives and the positives, you have more of the former.
But the big positive is the recovering economy, which did fine in the first quarter and which I think will expand around 4 percent this quarter. 
Historically, the economy and the stock market move together in the first half of a recovery. Historically, at this point the market should be up 30 to 35 percent off its lows. That isn't happening. We are still 50 percent invested because we think there will be a reconnect between the market and the economy.

Q. What parts of the market do you like?

A. We have been adding to our positions in a number of smaller semiconductor manufacturers, which now represent about 10 percent of the portfolio. They are a leading indicator on the economy, and the signals from that group, Intel notwithstanding, are turning up. We also like specialty retailers, consumer electronics companies and employee services companies.

Q. Are there values to be had in sectors that have been clobbered?

A. I love the drug stocks. If there was a group that I would buy now and hold for the next 10 years, it would be this group.
I also think utilities are probably a bargain, if you can sift through the garbage. Demand for what they provide is not going away. 
And telecom stocks look pretty good for the long term. You are starting to see pricing in this area begin to firm up.

HEADLINE: BULLETIN BOARD; 
For Dad, Some Things That Go Beep

BYLINE:  By MACAULAY CAMPBELL 

 BODY:
An improved economic outlook may mean more gifts for fathers this Father's Day. The National Retail Federation says the average American household is expected to spend $95 on Father's Day gifts, up from $52 last year. 
 Fathers with children in college should not expect the traditional tie as a gift. According to a recent survey by the federation, 18-to 24-year-olds are most likely to give electronics or computer gadgets. Clothing and dinner are most likely to come from women. 
 Adults aged 45 to 54 plan to spend the most on their fathers -- an average of $163. Women plan on spending more than men on gifts, by $107 to $82. MACAULAY CAMPBELL

HEADLINE: DataBank; 
A Third Week of Declines, and Dejection

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The stock market declined for a third consecutive week, bringing the three major indexes to new lows for the year.
 Investors seemed discouraged by the threat of terrorism and by disappointing corporate announce-ments. 
Intel, the computer chip maker, said late Thursday that its sales for the second quarter would be as low as $6.2 billion, down from earlier forecasts of $7 billion. Its stock dropped 20.3 percent for the week. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average, led down by Intel, Alcoa and American Express, was off 3.4 percent for the week, closing at 9,589.67. The Nasdaq composite index was dragged lower by RF Microdevices and Flextronics International. It was down 5.0 percent for the week, closing at 1,535.48. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, paced by declines in Tyco International and the Williams Companies, dropped 3.7 percent for the week, to 1,027.53.
 Bonds moved little until Friday, when the Labor Department said the unemployment rate fell unexpectedly, to 5.8 percent in May from 6.0 percent in April. The yield on the Treasury's 10-year note rose to 5.07 percent, from 4.98 percent on Thursday and 5.04 percent a week ago. JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

HEADLINE: Biting Criticism; 
An Economic Success, But at Whose Expense?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "Passing the Torch" (May 26): Fred Carriere, executive director of the Korea Society, notes that Korean entrepreneurs want their children to go to Harvard. One grocer quoted wants his son and daughter to get "fancy jobs." 
 Koreans follow an American dream to which most immigrants aspire. Korean merchants have created a thriving ethnic niche that New Yorkers appreciate. This would have been impossible without their own hard work and sacrifice. But we should not forget that the immigrant dream should also be accompanied by adopting fair wages and employment practices for workers.
In 2000, the state attorney general's office found that many workers, most of whom are Mexican and Central American, earned as little as $2.60 an hour for 72-hour weeks. That agency is continuing to investigate and work for better conditions in these stores.
Hard work has paid off for some of these entrepreneurs; it would be good if it could pay off for their workers who cannot share these dreams, and who lack the capital to work their way up the economic ladder and take over these businesses as their owners move on to more prosperous endeavors.
As a society, we should make sure that one immigrant group does not prosper at the expense of another.

VICTORIA MALKIN
Brooklyn Heights

HEADLINE: BackTalk; 
Behind the Scenes, the Sexism Is Now Subtler

BYLINE:  By ROBERT LIPSYTE

 BODY:
Back in the good old boy days, female coaches were allowed to use the gym whenever they wanted, so long as it was before breakfast and after midnight. They were welcome to all the boys' old junior varsity uniforms they needed, unlaundered. Their most experienced head coaches were paid less than the men's assistants. 
 After the enactment of Title IX, which is celebrating its 30th birthday, discrimination against female athletes became less obvious. Male coaches and administrators forgot to invite female coaches to university events. If the women showed up, the men would forget to introduce them to visiting politicians or to rich boosters. 
 Such petty incidents of disrespect and inconvenience can cumulatively become soul-killing. Is this what eventually got to Cheryl Burnett, who is still struggling to understand why "my dreams have been squelched by frustrations and discouragements?" She didn't quit over money. Burnett made more than anyone at Southwest Missouri State University, including the president and the football coach. 
She wasn't frustrated by a lack of success. During her 15 years as head women's basketball coach, the Lady Bears won 319 games and lost 136. They went to 10 N.C.A.A. tournaments and reached the Final Four twice, most recently in 2001.
She hadn't lost her popularity in the community. Burnett was a major celebrity in Springfield, Mo., as a jock goddess and as a spokeswoman for United Way and other charities. Women packed her Fast-Break Club fund-raisers, and shook out the pockets of their bosses and their husbands. 
So when Burnett, 43, resigned abruptly seven weeks ago, citing philosophical differences, everyone in the Southwest Missouri State administration expressed shock.
"A total surprise," said Dr. Darlene Bailey, who has been the associate athletic director for the past four years. "Yes, there are always situations between coaches and administrators. She was coaching one sport and we were administering 21. There could be differences in philosophies."
But this is not happening in the philosophy department. Burnett was hired to teach female athletes, to win games and to attract fans. She won more games than any other basketball coach in the university's history. The Lady Bears outdrew the Men Bears. One of her recent players, Jackie Stiles, now with the Portland Fire of the Women's National Basketball Association, set National Collegiate Athletic Association scoring records.
"What happened to Cheryl is puzzling," said Dr. Mary Jo Wynn, who retired four years ago as associate athletic director after 41 years in the department. "I had a wonderful experience with her. I was honored to work with her."
Wynn, then director of women's athletics, promoted Burnett from assistant to head coach in 1987 because she was so impressed by Burnett's enthusiasm, her work ethic, her knowledge of the game and her willingness to pay the personal costs of becoming a champion. Burnett coached the Lady Bears to more Missouri Valley Conference victories, 200, than any other coach. 
Did she just burn out? She sounds ready to coach some more. There are no rumors of scandalous behavior. For years, she has turned down jobs in fancier places. How can the administration keep shrugging in public, while supporters of Burnett express outrage? 
" 'Philosophical differences' sounds like a nice way for Cheryl to say they lied to her," says Joyce Mahoney, a political activist, who was inspired by her Lady Bears fandom to bring a Title IX complaint against the university.
Wynn said: "As long as we were nonentities, the men didn't pay any attention. Then, when we became more than just there, when we won games and got attention and put people in the seats, they started -- well, it's hard to talk about because it was so subtle."
It's clearly hard for Burnett to talk about it. "It became less and less fun to go to work," she said last week in a long and halting telephone interview. 
She was concerned that publicity would make her unemployable. "Little things," she said. "I began to hear myself described as a bad person, the bitchy one, lazy and selfish and ungrateful. Demanding, that's O.K. Maybe if I had been less successful I'd have had less of a problem. Maybe it was an ego thing with the good old boys, but that's your word."
In conversation, Burnett sounds more wounded than angry. Because her friends include Coach Roy Williams of Kansas, Charlie Spoonhour, a former men's S.M.S. coach now at Nevada-Las Vegas, and the present S.M.S. men's coach, Barry Hinson, she is uncomfortable characterizing her problems as gender-related. She is aware that the undramatic little incidents seem individually petty, and open to interpretation. But their corrosive accumulation did her in.
In an exception to university policy, for example, the men's basketball team and many of its supporters received rings from the university for making the Round of 16 in 1999. Meanwhile, the women's team was told it would receive fewer rings of lesser quality for reaching the Final Four in 2001. And they have yet to get them.
Burnett's Final Four incentive bonus, a simple check to cut, was run through the payroll system in such a way that the contracted amount was more than halved. She had to fight for what should have been hers routinely. Money she had raised publicly for a trophy case disappeared into the system and the case was never built. Burnett experienced the incidents as humiliating.
One incident directly affected the team. When she attempted to hire a strength and conditioning coach who had specific expertise with female athletes, she was told there was no money in the budget. Yet after she privately raised $20,000 in two weeks, she said the administration ordered her to use football's weight coach. That never worked out. She said he seemed "totally offended dealing with women coaches," and quit working with the women in midseason.
Bailey and an athletic department spokesman, Mark Stillwell, were generous in their praise for Burnett. After all, they said, her contract kept being renewed and enhanced (her annual "package" was close to $250,000 in salary and the usual TV and radio deals.) But they would not comment on specific matters. Both denied that a negative recommendation that surfaced at Vanderbilt University had come from their department. Burnett was never seriously considered for a job for which she was certainly qualified.
Wynn, who senses something "vile and evil" in Burnett's treatment, had been the coach's most powerful protector at the university. Burnett lost that protection when Wynn retired in 1998.
Along the way, Burnett picked up two powerful fans, the 72-year-old Mahoney, who is a local golf champion, and the 82-year-old Bee Payne-Stewart, mother of the late pro golfer. Both women are political activists, particularly for women's issues. 
"I was inspired by one of Cheryl's fund-raisers, the Free Throw Extravaganza," Mahoney said. "It was such fun. I could imagine myself at the foul line in a real game, in the final moments. I saw the strength that women have now. I was born in 1930 when you were only supposed to be a baby maker."
Mahoney and Payne-Stewart became aware of the disparity in the university's spending on men's and women's sports. After several years of fruitless meetings with university officials, Mahoney filed a Title IX complaint last year charging that the university is nowhere near mandated gender equity. The university, which has a year to show at least an effort toward compliance, claims it was on that track anyway.
The local reaction to Mahoney's complaint was vicious. ("I was compared to Osama," she said.) But with no economic ties to the university and married to "a retired investment guy," she felt the freedom to make the case. As a veteran of various political, health care and arts financing campaigns, she fought right back when a radio personality attacked her. Using the federal protection provisions for whistleblowers, she filed a second complaint; the radio personality worked for the university and thus might be charged with seeking retribution.
Burnett said she had nothing to do with either complaint, although she was blamed for them. She says she is just looking forward to a quiet summer. She would like to sell her home and buy a house on a lake. She wants to coach again but refuses to engage in speculation that if she can sit out a year, a job for her will open at Kansas, her alma mater.
Meanwhile, S.M.S. has hired a new coach and is careful to avoid any disparaging public remarks about Burnett. 
"Once she's out of the news long enough," Mahoney said, "they think they'll just do away with her. But her followers will never forget what she did here. The town came alive when the Lady Bears season started. 
"You know, Title IX is peripheral, it's really about big-time sports corrupting higher education. And it's about all those good old boys thinking, 'What can two old women do?' "

The Series So Far
Previous articles in this series about the role of college sports in American culture have explored race and athletics on campus, gambling, paying the players, a major quarterback at a midmajor college and the debate about Title IX's effect on "minor" men's sports. Robert Lipsyte's e-mail address is thelipsite@aol.com.

LENGTH: 959 words

HEADLINE: Cutting Class on Fridays To Cut School Budgets 

BYLINE:  By JODI WILGOREN 

DATELINE: EDGEMONT, S.D. 

 BODY:
Short $240,000 in a $1.4 million budget, the first thing the leaders of the Edgemont School District did was combine the middle school and high school, eliminating three teachers and a principal.
 Next they dropped the gifted program, chopped the guidance counselor's hours in half, ended full-time kindergarten and recruited volunteers to coach track and wrestling. 
 Now, they are cutting Fridays.
"For us it's a matter of keeping the school open, having a community with a school that's worth going to," said Susan Humiston, a mother of four and president of Edgemont's five-member school board, which also gave up its $50-per-meeting stipend. "I think we have cut as deep as we can cut and still have a school I'll send my kids to." 
In the fall, this tiny district of 200 students here in the Black Hills, along with nearby Hot Springs, will join about 100 rural districts nationwide using a four-day school week, adding minutes to each class to make up some of the time.
With at least 15 states sharply reducing education spending this spring, the radical-sounding four-day week, last tried in the energy crisis in the 1970's, is back. In Colorado, 36 of 180 districts have gone to four days, with 20 of 48 districts in Wyoming, and a smattering in Arizona, Louisiana, Utah and here in South Dakota. About 20 districts in eight states, including some in the Minneapolis suburbs and in Florida, Nebraska and South Carolina, have considered the approach this year. Several legislatures, including those in California, Arizona and Arkansas, have recently passed laws to allow for the shorter week. 
Drawn to the short week for financial reasons, several districts said they stuck with it only after discovering hidden benefits: better attendance and morale; less time lost to extracurricular activities, teacher training and doctor's appointments; and longer class periods. 
But others abandoned the idea because of complaints from working parents, concerns over elementary students' exhaustion and the realization that cost savings were minimal. The short week reduces some transportation costs, but not personnel costs, which make up 80 percent of a typical district's expenses.
The new schedule runs counter to the national trend of trying to improve student achievement by extending the school day, week and year. Already, most schools require far fewer days than their counterparts in Europe and Asia.
"It's backwards," said Ruy Teixeira, who has been studying changes in the school calendar as a senior fellow at the Century Foundation, a liberal-leaning Washington research organization. "It's definitely moving in exactly the wrong direction, so one hopes it won't catch on."
As for the notion that less might be more, Diane Ravitch, a conservative education historian, said the four-day districts were "pretending there's a pedagogical explanation for what is really cost-cutting."
"If you follow that logic, you should only have school one day a week," she said sarcastically. 
Administrators here and in Hot Springs, 24 miles to the east, admit that if they had the money, they would keep school open into the evenings and through the summer, rather than shut down one day a week. But they expressed confidence that the new schedule would make everyone more wary of wasting time. 
Little research has been done, but experts have documented increased attendance, higher morale, and fewer disciplinary problems in four-day schools. From the few papers that have been published, there appears to be no measurable effect on student achievement.
In Custer, a 1,000-student district 40 miles north of here that changed its calendar in 1995, student participation in activities has jumped and standardized test scores have risen slightly, though no one can confirm a correlation. The district saves about $70,000 a year, mostly on busing.
"The students in the hallways are happy," said Tim Creal, Custer's superintendent.
Here in Edgemont, a town of 906 surrounded by bison and buffalo ranches, next year's bells will be at 7:50 a.m. and 3:38 p.m., rather than 8 a.m. and 3 p.m. Lunch shrinks from an hour to 30 minutes. Officials predict elementary students will get up to 80 more hours of instruction, while those in grades 7 through 12 will lose about 10 hours, as the district moves from 172 days to 151.
Edgemont's business manager, Barbara Little, is only counting on a $10,000 savings -- but even that is significant, she said, in such a small district with such a big budget gap. 
Teachers are thrilled to gain minutes in each class period, particularly in hands-on subjects like chemistry and home economics. 
"I'm just really looking forward to being able to get in all the things I want to do every day," said Doreen Schultz, Edgemont's third-grade teacher. "As the kids get tired, there's a lot of activity-based things you can do."
Students are split, eager for an extra day off, but dreading longer classes with more homework.
"It gets tiring going to school five days straight," said Jacob Lively, 18, an Edgemont junior. But Robert Pritchard, 16, a junior in Hot Springs, said that "sitting at your desk for like an hour is going to get kind of tiring."
Perhaps the biggest challenge is what to do with the children on Fridays.
In Hot Springs, where final approval of the plan is expected in June, the district will have 147 days instead of 175, and expects to save $17,000 on busing alone. Deann Arneson, a single mother of six, said she would put her grade-school-age children in day care on Fridays. 
"I think it's a better idea than a lot of other things they tossed around," said Ms. Arneson, an administrator at a Veterans Affairs hospital. "I don't want academics cut. I don't want extracurriculars cut. I don't want busing cut."
Instead, Fridays.

HEADLINE: An Actual Internet Success Story 

BYLINE:  By Richard Rayner; Richard Rayner is the author of "Drake's Fortune: The Fabulous True Story of the World's Greatest Confidence Artist," published last month by Doubleday.

 BODY:
'The Internet has not only turned the used-book business inside out; it has flipped it on its head and spun it around once or twice," says Keith Waters, an instigator of one of the virtual era's more curious and less sung revolutions. Back in the mid-1990's, in the pre-dot-com dark ages, Waters was a computer consultant. One day, his wife, a used-book dealer, complained to him about how difficult it was to find any particular out-of-print book. Basically the only way to go about this was to scuffle through the local used-book stores or to pore through the 30 or so pages of AB Bookman, a weekly magazine that published lists of titles. 
 Waters examined AB Bookman and had his flash of inspiration: why not create an Internet equivalent, a searchable database that would connect thousands of dealers, instead of only a few, and list millions of books, instead of thousands? And so in 1996 he founded Advanced Book Exchange, www.abebooks.com. Abebooks now links some 10,000 used- and rare-book dealers worldwide, each paying a monthly subscription according to how many titles they put online. Abebooks currently lists more than 38 million books, with 50,000 to 100,000 added every day. If you want to search for a newer book, Robert A. Caro's "Master of the Senate," say, or an old paperback of Ray Bradbury's "Fahrenheit 451," you simply go to the Web site, type in the author's name and title and scores of choices pop up. You take your pick, depending on price and condition. In this fashion, the market itself makes the price for a given book, and no book, in or out of print, is hard to find anymore. 
 Waters wasn't the only one who had this idea. Abebooks soon had a competitor, bibliofind.com, which was swallowed by Amazon soon after Abebooks teamed up with Barnes & Noble in 1998. Used books now account for more than 15 percent of Amazon's sales. EBay and its subsidiary half.com sell books; alibris.com, Bookavenue.com and BookFinder.com are other sites that centralize supply. "The increase in the number of used books sold is staggering," Waters says. "It's maybe 100 times what it was in 1995."
A shift is underway in how we buy and think about books. People seek out books on the Net because it is easy and cheap. Often they don't care whether a book is new or used. Someone in Illinois might buy a used copy of a hardback from half.com or a dealer in New York, read it and then sell it to someone in California, having spent, in effect, only a few dollars. 
It seems curious that with the pricking of the dot-com bubble, with the demise of the vast majority of all the weird and wonderful things that were explored in digital commerce, such a seemingly unsexy business as used books should survive and flourish. But this is what the Internet does best: bringing a disparate and disorganized group of people together into a community, and an economic unit. 
In fact, the used-book industry so well illustrates the classic economic model that it could replace widgets in Econ. 101 and no one would know the difference. The demand was always there, but exploiting it was never in the interests of the chains and publishers who dominate the book industry. So the market, such as it was, languished in the hands of tiny, back-street booksellers. With the Net, however, supply was centralized and advertised, prices stabilized and a market was established, or rather, a market that was frozen started to happen.
I am a used-book nut myself, a haunter of library sales and the dusty, chaotic shelves of thrift stores. It was a couple of years back when I noticed that everyone I bumped into in these places was buying more books than usual. When questioned, they tended to be a little sheepish, almost squirrelly about it. They would glance around furtively, as if they were about to confess to a cocaine habit, before saying, "I sell them on the Internet."
Then gradually, as the months went by, I began to see these people develop their own angles or niches. One friend, a teacher, was supplementing his regular income by scouring for science-fiction and fantasy paperbacks. His particular gimmick was to put together entire sets of books by writers that only the comic book geeks knew about. "A rich lawyer in Seattle paid me $250 the other day for an entire set of Tarzan paperbacks by Edgar Rice Burroughs that I'd picked up for 25 cents a pop," he says. "There's a couple in England who pay $8 for any Michael Moorcock paperback. Why do they do this? Because I'm making it easy for them." 
There is an ex-cop who runs an online business in modern first editions, especially mysteries. He orchestrates forays to the yearly BookExpo America to collect boxes of advance readers editions (the advance galleys of books given away by publishers as promotional material that are highly sought after by some collectors). During the recent L.A. Festival of Books, he had a team of helpers and strode about like General Patton with a walkie-talkie, dispatching runners to get books signed by big names like Michael Connelly and T.C. Boyle, thus increasing their value. 
Another guy, who lost his job in the downturn, was helping his wife keep their kids in one of the best private schools on the west side of Los Angeles. He had got hold of a catalog listing books used as college texts and had made a specialty of hunting for those. Some specialize in history or in pre-World War II hardbacks. Others still just grab whatever they can get. 
At the most recent Santa Monica library sale, dealers were lining up at 10 a.m. for an event that wouldn't begin for another nine hours. As the day wore on and people drifted in and out of the line, leaving only their book boxes behind, there were the inevitable squabbles over who had arrived first. "You're waiting for books?" asked a local bum, uncomprehending. "No, we're making a line, and they're giving away free money," one dealer said. "That would make more sense," the bum replied, and the dealer smiled and shook his head. When the door finally opened, and the tally-ho dash into the basement began, the library was, in effect, giving away free money.
One dealer I know used to be a book scout, a guy at the bottom end of the food chain, but someone whose life had a free-and-easy "On the Road" quality to it. He would hunt for books, take them to used-book stores and be rewarded with cash. He happily remembers stumbling into a thrift store, finding a box full of John Steinbeck first editions, taking them to a dealer and the both of them laughing and feeling it was Christmas. 
That doesn't really happen anymore, not since the Internet transformed everyone on the planet into a potential used-book dealer. Yet there are still good things to be found -- you just have to be a lot more organized and purposeful. These days, that same dealer scurries all over West Los Angeles in his beat-up Ford Fairlane, hunting for books he can sell quickly on Amazon or eBay. He got into the business in the first place because he didn't want to think like a businessman. Now he has to think like a businessman. 
His day divides into a rigid schedule: driving, searching, going home and logging books online, packing up the books he has sold and toting them down to the post office. He has only a limited amount of storage space, so he is making constant evaluations: which will sell quicker, this computer paperback, published a year ago, or this handsome copy, a lovely first edition with a dust jacket, of Francis Steegmuller's "Flaubert and Madame Bovary"? The answer is a no-brainer, and not the same one it would have been five years ago. It's the computer book, stupid!
"There used to be a romance to it," he says. "Now you're just a person who schleps. People have the idea that the book trade is a polite business for gentlemen. In fact, it's a lot more like the Mafia." He remembers how one dealer beat another with a tire iron in a dispute over a book and how a dealer was arrested for stealing the contents of an entire store when he realized the store's owner had died. 
This sort of thing has always gone on, because books can be converted readily into cash. But now, with so many more people involved, the scene is wilder. If several dealers happen to be in the same thrift store when boxes of books are brought in, a feeding frenzy may ensue. Thrift-store workers have themselves learned that books can be traded on the Internet. There are fights. To avoid this, smart people try to make deals with thrift-store managers or library-sale organizers so they can take a look at whatever comes in before it's dumped out there for general consumption. 
Such arrangements, leading to further merry-go-rounds of jostling and resentment, tend to be short-lived, but they can be effective while they last. My dealer friend himself had the nifty idea of helping out at a local Salvation Army store, putting the crates of donated books up on the shelf -- meaning, of course, that he was the first to see those books. One afternoon he found a signed first edition of photographs by Ansel Adams. Idly, he picked up another book, the autobiography of the basketball star Kareem Abdul-Jabbar. It, too, turned out to be signed. The book dealer's life has always been given purpose by the possibility of such serendipitous, almost magical, discoveries. It's the thrill of the hunt. My friend paid 50 cents for each of these books and sold them quickly on Amazon. For the Adams he got $600; for the Jabbar, $150. 
The middleman has been eliminated; what used to be the purely regional value of a particular title no longer applies; and the Internet has transformed the world into a huge marketplace for used books. This has happened within a few years, utterly transforming a business that had gone its own way unobserved by almost everybody for centuries. Dan Adams runs Waverly Books out of his home in Santa Monica, with 20,000 titles listed on Abebooks. Most of the books are in the range of $20 to $500, although he has some very expensive ones, including a Knopf first edition, still in its dust jacket, of "The Big Sleep," by Raymond Chandler. The volume once belonged to Tod Browning, the director of "Freaks" and "Dracula," and would make a great addition to the library, should you happen to have around $20,000 to spare. 
Adams's first experience as a bookseller was running an independent new-book store; then he set up a used business, generating his own catalog and traveling around to the various antiquarian book fairs that are held every month or so in the big cities. He saw the writing on the wall pretty early on: he has been doing e-sales for five years, and now his sales are almost exclusively online. "There are times when it seems like I'm selling more to England, Australia and Japan, and it's surprising sometimes what does sell. A woman bought a book from me the other day because her grandfather had signed it. That's a connection, a sale, that would never have happened without the Internet."
Will the increased sale of used books impinge on demand for new ones? It's too early to say. The hope among publishers is that an increased awareness of books will increase the market, just as those authors who mourn the royalty they don't get on sales of used copies can comfort themselves with the thought that at least someone is reading them -- a profile is being raised.
This isn't like Napster putting music up on the Internet so you can download it free, but the market has broadened in a way all but unthinkable seven or eight years ago. Anirvan Chatterjee, who started BookFinder.com, says: "You're almost guaranteed that if there's a copy of a book out there, anywhere, you have access to it." A foreseeable consequence of this, he adds, is that publishers are monitoring what does sell on the Internet, with a view to keeping more and more books in print and in the catalog -- push-button technologies allow them to do this. In other words, the numbers of available new books will continue to grow, and sharply.
The immediate victim of all these changes has been the owner of the traditional neighborhood used-book store. Many have simply been wiped off the map by a combination of the arrival of the Internet and the growth of chain stores, which draw off potential customers with coffee bars, readings and stuffed armchairs. "More than 65 percent of our dealers only have a virtual storefront," Keith Waters at Abebooks says. "And more and more of those who have one are giving it up. Why pay the rent and pay someone to sit in the store all day?"
The storefront businesses, those that have stuck around, have done so because they've moved with the tide. Eddie Sutton, who manages the Internet side at the world's biggest used-book store, the Strand, at the corner of 12th and Broadway in Manhattan, recalls his moment of epiphany: "A couple of years back, a guy came in, a really devoted customer, someone I was accustomed to seeing every day, and said: 'Know what? It's easier for me to buy books on the Net than it is to walk over here from my apartment on Fifth Avenue.' I just went pale. I thought, This could be over for us." 
He went to the Strand's owners, Fred and Nancy Bass, who recognized the problem and invested $250,000. A result was what is currently one of the Web's best book sites, with links to Amazon, Abebooks and all the other virtual outlets. "It turned out to be a natural progression," Nancy Bass says. "We already had a catalog, a shipping room, our reputation as a long-running family business. We haven't changed much. We're not trying to be anything we weren't. We just got bigger." The Strand has yearly revenues in excess of $20 million, and only a year after its inception, strandbooks.com accounts for more than 15 percent. Sales of used books rose more than 15 percent last year; rare books went up 34 percent. "The Internet has been a total boon," she says. Indeed, the store itself is now undergoing a big physical expansion and facelift. The famous red and white sign, "Eight Miles of Books," will soon read, "Sixteen Miles of Books." 
When I ask Bass about the logic of this -- isn't the Strand bucking a trend? -- she seems surprised. "We want to sell more books, to display our inventory better, to have a better store," she says. "Why wouldn't we want to do that?" 
Coincidentally, while I was in the Strand, I spied a copy of my own new book on Eddie Sutton's desk. He had a veritable stack of them, he said, and was going to feature them on the Web site at half the full price -- gratifying, except this was four weeks before the book's publication date, four weeks, therefore, before anyone would have a chance to buy one in Barnes & Noble at full price. Reviewers had brought these into the Strand, and I'll get no royalty on them, a prospect that makes the Authors Guild queasy.
But selling review copies has always been a part of the trade. It's just that until recently only visitors to the store would ever get the chance to buy them. Now everyone can, another instance of how this market has suddenly become more expansive and topsy-turvy. Nothing is more usable than a 'used' book -- especially if it's brand new. While they may not like it, writers are going to have to get used to the idea that small quantities of their books are going to be discounted before they are even published. 
The Strand's particular niche as a business is its fame, its sheer size and its consequent ability to utilize the economies of scale. Other businesses have maintained physical storefronts by specializing ever more closely in a particular sector of the market. For example, each major American city has at least one specialist mystery bookstore, selling both new and used titles. These have not only formed a thriving network but they have also played a crucial factor in the slow-burn and then breakthrough careers of writers like George P. Pelecanos. 
At the very highest end of the rare-book market, customers like to see, touch and smell what they're going to buy. So the Net hasn't revolutionized that aspect of the business. Bauman Rare Books, which already had stores on Park Avenue and in Philadelphia, recently opened a new gallery on Madison Avenue, the first time that a rare-book dealer has opened a physical storefront in Manhattan in some 20 years.
Natalie Bauman, a co-owner, says: "At this end of the market, it's very physical. We're selling extremely rare objects, and the Internet, which has been very useful to us, tells people just how rare they are. But most likely they'll want to handle the books first, to see them, as if they were paintings. It's astonishing how many very successful and famous people will come and spend time and just hang out."
For those of us not in a position to pay nearly $20,000 for a first edition of "The Big Sleep" or $12,500 for Ken Kesey's "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest," perhaps this is the pleasure missed most, a sad trade-off against the benefits of progress, convenience and predictable pricing -- the social and literary ambience of the average workaday used-book stores. Wherever I went in the world, to whichever city, I used to make a ritual of touring them, hunting or killing time, wondering what brightly colored dust jacket my eye might alight on next. What the Internet robs you of is the sensual thrill of the chance find, the discovery of lovely old things, these totems of learning and aspiration, the dotty collector's privilege of holding them, knowing that, in exchange for mere money, in a few moments they can be yours. 
"You had the whole history of books in these places," says Ray Bradbury, who himself does not own a computer and still likes to do things the old way. His favorite used-book store, Acres of Books in Long Beach, Calif., still exists, and he tries to head down there whenever it's raining. All the fiction is in a big room with a tin roof at the back. There's a wonderful smell. I go in, and I just breathe, and I feel refreshed. I walk through the dark corridors, listening to the sound of the rain on the roof. And I pull out my old friends."

The sale was $8,000, not $12,500.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH; 
Far From Wall Street, Intel's Bad News Was No Surprise

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
WHEN Intel dropped the bomb late Thursday, ratcheting down its forecast for both sales and profit margins in the current quarter, Wall Street analysts were caught again like so many deer in the headlights. As Intel's stock plummeted on the news in after-hours trading, Joseph A. Osha, Merrill Lynch's semiconductor analyst, spoke for most of the Street when he said, "Nobody saw this coming."
 In truth, somebody did see it coming -- Fred Hickey, publisher of The High-Tech Strategist in Nashua, N.H., and a card-carrying nonmember of the see-no-evil brokerage firm crowd. In recent months, Mr. Hickey has repeatedly warned his subscribers that shares of Intel, the largest producer of computer chips, were headed for a fall. 
 For instance, back in March, Intel management predicted that gross margins in the second quarter would be 53 percent. But Mr. Hickey speculated that Intel's impressive margins were mostly a result of a buildup in inventory, not sales to end users, and that the margins were therefore unsustainable unless demand picked up. It obviously has not. And so, on June 6, Andy D. Bryant, Intel's chief financial officer, cut the anticipated profit margins to 49 percent in the second quarter, citing weakened demand for chips in Europe. 
Mr. Hickey said Intel "tried to be a hero in the first quarter."
"They continued to produce at high levels, which improved their gross margins, and then talked about efficiencies and productivity when it was only an inventory buildup," he added. "Now they have to pay the piper."
While some Intel watchers may hope that the reduced forecast represents a near-term hiccup, Mr. Hickey has a different view. He thinks the days of mighty Intel's hegemony are over and that it will soon come under severe pressure from competitors -- particularly Advanced Micro Devices. Adding to his gloom is a belief that even if the economy keeps improving, technology companies will not likely participate.
"Intel is in a very difficult position, in the short-term and long term," Mr. Hickey said. "They've got to cut production, which will send costs up. That will put pressure on a stock that is still grossly overvalued even at today's lower price." Down the road, the company faces an Advanced Micro chip -- known in the industry as the Hammer -- that many industry experts consider superior to Intel's Itanium chip.
Advanced Micro plans to start shipping the chip by year-end. Software designers and box manufacturers like the chip's ability to run both high-speed and lower-speed software programs. This so-called backward capability sets it apart, giving Advanced Micro a chance to break Intel's lock on the server market.
"The Hammer is where Advanced Micro breaks into the business-computing market," Mr. Hickey said. "And Intel has had the protection of relatively high gross margins in that area."
If Advanced Micro's new chip is as good in production as it looks in tests, computer manufacturers like Dell and Hewlett-Packard may flock to it. At a minimum, having an alternative to Intel's chip will give the company's customers new leverage when negotiating on price. That would be more bad news for Intel profit margins.
Intel has dominated the semiconductor industry for what seems an eternity. Not long ago, its market value exceeded the combined total of the 16 other chip stocks in the Philadelphia Stock Exchange semiconductor index. For many investors, Intel is not just a stock; it is a religion. Even following the company's reduced sales and profit forecast, Intel carries a $147 billion market capitalization and a price-to-earnings ratio of 42. Quite a price tag, given what Intel is up against.

TITLE: HIGH TECH STRATEGIST NEWSLETTER 

LOAD-DATE: June 9, 2002
